description:
"They have a Beer Bible... what!" I thought that was pretty dope. My boyfriend took me here since he always raves about thee La Trappe. And I must say, he was right once again. 

Everything in the menu sounded scrumptious, it was hard to pass up on several of my options. I went for their Beef Beer Stew with the side of Belgium Fries. The beef was so tender and melted in my mouth. Also, the gravy was so flavorful and rich. The Belgium Fries was amazing, seasoned to perfection - I'm getting hungry just writing this review.  My boyfriend ordered their Konkan and Marinere Mussels - both broths tasted amazing. 

Our waitress was very attentive and sweet, despite of the very loud noise and amount of people dining in since we decided to eat downstairs.

We will differently stop by again, this time for lunch.
author: Johanna M.

description:
The owner Michael was wonderful and he has created a wonderfully hospitable atmosphere with a literal novel of beers to be paired with above average bar food.

Tried the croquettes, mushroom ben, fries, mixed green salad, and brussel sprouts.

Favorites - croquettes, fries, delirium tremes on the beer list. They change the cheese that's stuffed in the croquettes daily, which I though was impressive for a gastrobar. Regardless, can't go wrong with fried cheese.

Brussel sprouts were a tad bit over doused with a mayo, and weren't as crispy as I would have liked, but that's just me being a little picky since everything else was fantastic.

If I lived in this area, it would most certainly be my go-to local bar.
author: Allie L.

description:
I'd love to tell you all about the food. I'd love to, but I can't, because I never got it. 

We arrived around 8:15 PM, and it was immediately clear that the waitstaff wasn't having a good night. I heard a waiter apologize to two different groups about the service before he even took our drink order... which took over 30 minutes to appear and was incorrect when it arrived. As for the food, it looked good on the menu, but we weren't able to try it; at 9:15, almost an hour after we ordered, it still hadn't appeared despite several assurances that it would be right out. We finally gave up and left (politely), since we had a show to see. 

The waiter was apologetic and didn't charge us for our drinks, blaming new staff and no-shows. On the way out, a manager type chased us down to apologize as well, and, strangely, told us that the waiter was lying to us - that the problems were all his fault. I don't know what he hoped to accomplish by telling us that; it certainly did not increase the likelihood that we'd come back.
author: Larry C.

description: If you love Belgian food and amazing beer selections, go to La Trappe.  If the restaurant looks a little bare, don't stress and go straight down the stairs to the bar and beer cellar - you won't regret it.
author: Kat D.

description: The food was 2/5, beer was 4/5 or better, but the service was horrible. We were here almost 3 hours for 2 burgers and a couple beers. They kept seating more people even being understaffed. Can't recommend this restaurant, it was ridiculous. People would come in, wait to be seated, and leave after 30 minutes.
author: Derek A.

description:
We wanted to like it. We really did. We've been twice and both times service was pretty poor. Both times they blamed being short staffed due to a no show. 

The first time we were just dropping in quickly for a round before dinner elsewhere. We got overwhelmed by the menu and ordered a couple of the triples on draft and liked them. Server was a bit flustered for someone having to serve like 3 or 4 parties total, so it took a bit but overall experience was fine.

The next time we were super excited to dive into that beer book and try the mussels. It was pretty full this time, but we found a table, poured over the menu and couldn't wait to order that special bottle. After sitting there 15 minutes the table next to us (who was there first) got their chance to order. The server said he'd be right back for us and about 5 minutes later he was. We ordered, but he said it would take too long to get bottles and could we just order something off the draft list. A little disappointed, we did so. We put in our food order at the same time.

When the food was delivered to the neighboring table they still hadn't gotten their beers. They struggled to flag the server down for quite some time. When they got him he said he didn't know, the bar was really backed up, and ran off again.

Another several minutes went by and they had no drinks, we didn't even have water, and had to leave for a show at Cobbs so we unfortunately had to cancel our order and eat there. 

I'm giving stars for the atmosphere of the downstairs which did remind me of some dark spots where I've drank in Belgium, and for the impressive beer list that I still hope to try. I'll give it another shot some day.
author: New2Northbeach N.

description: Updating my review to 5 solid stars. Never a dull moment here. Dieter aka Zak with a K was awesome once again. he's the man with a master plan.
author: Connie M.

description:
This was a Yelp find! 

We aren't from the area and had no idea where to eat. Wanted something different. More importantly DID NOT want to eat at a tourist trap. We saw the reviews here and headed over.

When we arrived I was nervous. There wasn't anyone there and that can't be a good sign, can it? Then we were taken downstairs. What a cool place! I already had a great vibe. 

Once we were seated we were given the drink bible, I mean menu. It was substantial! I have never seen so many beer selections. Definitely a beer lover's paradise. 

We started off and split the mussels mariniere. We were in mussels heaven. Dipping our bread,  with all the dipping sauces was yummy, but in the mussel broth was just divine. 

My son ordered the steak frittes, my friend the roti de porc, and I the stoofvlees. Everything was perfectly seasoned and cooked to order. The steak was tender and juicy. His fries were perfectly cooked. The pork was seasoned well and the veggies made a nice compliment. My stew was something I had never eaten before and it was very good. 

We all agreed that this was our best meal during our SanFran stay!
author: Jerry D.

description:
It was Friday night after work, and the squad was on a good mood, so we decided to go somewhere with a good selection of beer (I'm fat and I love it!)

As anticipated, they did have a great selection of beer, and they even had Augustiner Braeu on the menu! That was one of my favorites. The only problem is, they didn't have the actual product, and I was bummed. I ended up getting an Aydinger, which was good, but nevertheless I really wished I had the Augustiner.

In terms of food, the mussels were a joy (and they were very fairly priced too - 23 bucks for a huge bucket of mussels and fries). The other dishes were delicious as well.

Really hope that they'll have all the beers on the menu next time, but regardless it was a great place and I'd recommend it!
author: Yuqing N.

description:
For Belgian people in San Francisco who feel homesick : can't get closer to Belgium than in La Trappe: huge variety of the better Belgian beers (draft and bottled), good Belgian style food!
For non-Belgian people who like a good beer: if you're in San Francisco this bar is definitely worth paying a visit, prices are very reasonable, staff's very friendly, great setting!
author: Luc D.

description: Love this place.  Always get the mussels.  Huge beer selection too. Go when ever I have time and am in San Francisco
author: Jon H.

description:
This is one of the best and most unusual restaurants in San Francisco. 
Very authentic Belgian food and it's in a very nice location the people are very friendly atmosphere is roomy and happy service is fantastic.
I would highly recommend the trap again if you're ever interested in Belgian cuisine !!!
author: Jeffrey M.

description: This is the real deal. Seated downstairs reminded me of the many Belgian restaurants I've been to which is half of the fun. Their beer list is outstanding. The mussels are done perfectly and the various sauces were delicious. Great waiter as well to round the experience off. Can't wait to try the cheese and charcuterie plates next time.
author: Steven D.

description: Can I just say how much I love this place? The bartender/server Zack is the best. He has wonderful recommendations for beer and food - he knows his stuff and makes you feel like you just walked into your best friend's basement to hang for a while.  We've been there twice and he absolutely recognized us on our second visit.  The beer selection knocks it out of the park and the food is so delicious.  We had the beef stew and the sausages and both were divine.  The french fries are crisp and lovely with dipping sauces out of this world. And, the best part? The kitchen is open late so even if you show up at 10:30 after a long flight you can still get food with a smile and a great beer to go with it.  Thanks guys for making us feel welcome and filling our bellies with excellent fare.
author: Rosie B.

description:
I'd had La Trappe bookmarked here on Yelp for a while, and one time I walked by only to turn away upon seeing nobody in the airy, high-ceilinged ground floor dining room. Boy, was I wrong. Turns out there's far more space in the basement, which is a reasonably sized yet far more intimate space. And, most importantly, there's a tremendous beer selection, good food offerings, and good service at the bar.

There's a huge variety of beers here, whether domestic, Belgian, or global, many of which pair very well with both savory and spicy dishes on the menu. Some brews I've enjoyed include a Petrus Aged Red, a Verdi Imperial Stout from Birrificio del Ducato, and a Hitachino Nest XH. The servers were very knowledgeable about the beers, and it seemed a lot of the patrons were too. Moreover, there's a good food selection, whether burgers, bistro fare, moules in a variety of styles (mariniere, a la biere, Konkan, you name it), or Belgian specialties like stewed half rabbit, Ghentse chicken waterzooi (traditional Belgian chicken stew), or stoofvlees (traditional Flemish beef beer stew).

So if you love beer like I do, especially in a Belgian pub-inspired setting, La Trappe is a reasonably authentic place to get your booze and grub on.
author: Vincent L.

description: This is my kind of a place. I love a good hole in the wall that you can settle into for a while. There are not enough places like this in SF. We had the croquets (shrimp that night) and really enjoyed them. We also had the large serving of the traditional mussels with fennel and fries. So so good. Great quality mussels with a nicely flavored broth. We even got extra bread to soak it all up. I would recommend the garlic mayo and curry ketchup for your fries. We tried 5/6 beers while we were there and our waitress was very knowledgeable and helpful with the HUGE beer menu. We will definitely be back.
author: Emily S.

description: This place is "closed for vacation" with no notice!  So disappointed, we walked all the way here bc of great review but they are closed with no notice.
author: Amanda E.

description: I wish I could give this restaurant better reviews.  A friend recommended it for being a fun place to eat and great beer.  I liked the location, the atmosphere, and the beer selection was amazing, but the food was not good.  There were seven of us celebrating my son's 25th birthday.  Three of the guys got the hamburger and thought it was extremely bland.  My husband got the stew and thought it was okay.  I shared a pesto pasta and portobello mushroom sandwich with another son and it was okay, but wouldn't order again.  The last person got the vegetable stew and didn't share her opinion.  I also feel I got overcharged for beers.  A few times the server got confused and I feel we were charged for more than we drank. I know it was up to me to question the bill but decided to just settle the bill and depart.  I think it would be fun to go here for a beer after eating somewhere else.
author: Kathy T.

description: Updating to five stars because of how quick the service was. Mussels are amazing (especially the spicy tomato).
author: Rachel K.

description:
This subterranean Belgian brewpub has been around for quite a while, but I always figured it was mostly for people who are really into foreign draft beers. Maybe that's why I haven't been all that motivated to come here until Jamie W. and i strolled by on the way back from the Marina one Saturday. We peeked through the window and didn't see anybody in the dining room. It wasn't until we walked in that we realized all the activity was downstairs in the basement where we saw a lot of chugging and guzzling underway.

We secured a table for two and noticed yes, they serve food, too. We knew we had to have the $8 Belgian Fries since we just assumed it was a house specialty. It came with our choice of two dipping sauces, so we tried the Roasted Garlic Mayo and the Belgian Mayo which had a tangier flavor from the white wine vinegar (photo: http://bit.ly/2fRjNSO). It definitely held us over as we waited for our appetizer. I ordered the $10 Vegetable Tart for us, a nice surprise with slices of zucchini, yellow squash, red onion, and tomato with herbs, lemon and melted goat cheese on a flatbread pastry shell (photo: http://bit.ly/2feJ3yO).

That was a much lighter treat than you would expect from an underground pub. For his entree, Jamie was a bit adventurous and had the $18 Ghentse Chicken Waterzooi, which looked like a creamy soup except it was centered around pieces of chicken, fennel, celery and onion. A Dutch specialty originating in Flanders, it was actually more of a stew with a soup base made of egg yolk, cream and thickened vegetable broth. The fries had yet another place for dipping beyond the double mayos (photo: http://bit.ly/2fvmMfq).

I went all traditional and ordered the classic $16 Mussels Mariniere bathing in white wine and butter filled with thyme, onions, shallots, garlic and parsley (photo: http://bit.ly/2esTmxw). This is indeed where they excelled as the mussels were fresh and succulent, full of the brothy flavor I was expecting. It would have been a shame if we didn't try any of their beers, so Jamie had an 48 pint of a local brew called Defenestration, a nice, golden beer (photo: http://bit.ly/2fpPIXp). Not being a major beer drinker, I just had an $8 bottle of Hank's Gourmet Diet Root Beer to wet my whistle (photo: http://bit.ly/2fpQFyT). 

FOOD - 4 stars...unique Belgian specialties served here and there's the beer, too
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...dark underground spot enlivened by the beer drinkers, a bit loud with the tables a bit too close together
SERVICE - 4 stars...quite attentive and helpful in explaining the dishes
TOTAL - 4 stars...it it's Tuesday, it must be Belgium...or it could be Saturday, too
author: Ed U.

description:
Great space, awesome selection of draft and bottled beer, attentive service. Burger is 8oz grass fed and quite good, but the fries with 2 dips are the standout. Downstairs cellar space is beautiful, bar lovely. Have to pull a star for the music selection, '80s flashback harshed my mellow. Fortunately again, beer selection rocks. 

A repeat trip will be forthcoming, will update my impressions.
author: T J.

description: Walk down to the world of amazing beers and food. They provide you with a very thick book full of all types of beers imaginable. Their food is surprisingly good. The brussel sprouts are the mayonnaise type and not the fried, crispy version. Their fries are quite good. The best is their rabbit stew, which is absolutely divine with a rich clam chowder-esque soup and comes with bread specially ordered from a local store and lightly toasted.
author: Kimberly H.

description: Mussel pot is a really good one. The broth is delicious (I'm wondering what's the recipe?); great selection of beer , beer list. We were here once before. This time our visit was 10pm Saturday and restaurant was empty, server was very attentive. Thank u
author: Svetlana K.

description:
The vibe and ambiance of La Trappe have changed a lot since my first time there in 2012. Sometimes it's a hit, and sometimes it's a total miss. Given how many different experiences we've had here, it's a bit hard to write this review so I'll break it down the best that I can.

*Ambiance: the restaurant itself is pretty unassuming. When you walk by, the top dining area is usually empty, but if you head downstairs, you find yourself in a grotto-like space where the Belgian beer flows and people get rowdy. At some point a few years ago, they started playing house/techno music downstairs and we stopped going. The vibe is definitely less party-party now, but it hasn't really regained the charm that it had back in the day (or maybe my mind is playing tricks on me - I guess we'll never know). 

*Beer: they have a very extensive beer list that comes in the form of a book that is reminiscent of Harry Potter. The beers are categorized really well, and the server is usually really helpful when it comes to choosing what to drink. If you are a beer aficionado or have a very international palette, I highly recommend you come here for a drink. 

*Food: the food here is pretty damn good. Their main dishes are mussel or french fry based (try both if you can). The mussels and fries come in/with an array of sauces or dipping sauces respectively, and they also have a variety of traditional Belgian dishes. My two favorite items on the menu are the Boudin Blanc (white sausage with a creamy mustard sauce) and the Ghentse Chicken Waterzooi (chicken stew). It's a hearty, filling meal no matter what you order. 

*Service: four out of five times, the service is pretty bad. The downstairs area goes from empty to packed really quickly, and they never seem to have enough staff to handle the influx of customers. We've had forgotten orders and item mix-ups more than a few times, and the wait time for your order can be anywhere from 15 to 40 minutes. The servers usually seem frazzled and more often than not, dirty dishes and empty water glasses litter your table until you ask a passing staff member to clear and/or refill. 

La Trappe has become a place that I wouldn't necessarily recommend to people, but would certainly end up at for a casual Friday evening meal. I would love to see this place get a dose of TLC from management in terms of getting consistent service and a warmer ambiance.
author: Regina L.

description:
It is always a pleasure to see a good Belgian restaurant abroad! They have a good selection of beers on draft and a huge choice of beers from the bottle (and they even have the corresponding glasses)!
The restaurant in the basement brings a warm ambiance resembling bars in Brussels. The staff was very nice and helpful.
Food was delicious and authentic, they make homemade sauces that are very tasty, I definitely recommend the stoofvlees and try the Belgian mayo!
Will definitely come back to this place!
author: Nil M.

description: Mike is the owner and knows his beer. Highly recommended coming here for a fun atmosphere and the best beer selection.
author: Kristine T.

description: La Trappe is a Belgium themed restaurant with a great atmosphere, friendly staff, and good service. I heard from my friends told me the beer was good, since I am not legally aloud to drink. My burger was exceptional as well as the fries and sauces. The restaurant nails the European aesthetic it was going for and I quite enjoyed my time there. 4/5, would reccomend
author: Felipe Q.

description: Wow I love this place, a cool restaurant, beer cellar extraordinaire, with a beer book, yes I said book because it is one and a long one at that. The specialize in Belgians, my personal fav and you can find rare aged in cellar bottles, hey if you like beer you'll love this place and then there is the food, it's really great. The service was really great friendly and no attitude at all. I had a La Trappe Quad which I enjoyed very much and  decided to try Ghentse chicken waterzooi OMG it was fantastic, a rich soup kind of stew with tender chicken, baby potatos and carrots, it was fantastic!!!! I want to go back again.
author: Karen R.

description: Food is not good... but the downstairs is a hidden little gem and the bartenders are fantastic. If I were only going to sit at the bar and drink beer... this would be a 5.
author: Doxie M.

description:
La Trappe is a GEM in SF, Belgium influences, literally this place is home of beers. As you walk in, it looks quiet but step into a different part of the world as you walk down the stairs as conversations and music will blow you away. You have over 300 selections of bottle beers, especially vintages, 15 rotating beers. 

Michael A. is a phenomenal person with his immense knowledge where he speaks to you where it's not overwhelming, he explains and walks you through the selections where it's relatable. 

The food is fantastic, the Mussels, smoke trout parfait, get the Roti as your entree, and finally dessert the liege waffle. 

This place is without a doubt, you want to be in but keep in mind Beer is Life and Culture, and as always I've enjoyed La trappe every time and the staff hospitality has always been spot on. 

Thank you Mike for being amazing. I will see you again soon!
author: Jay K.

description: This place is great, yummy (heavy) food, great beer, and really nice staff with great suggestions. The downstairs is a really fun atmosphere!
author: Davita P.

description: Sooooo many beers. Great food. Great service. I enjoyed the croquettes and the steak frites the most. It is pretty dark in the basement area. I had some trouble reading the menu. They could use some sconces or something to brighten the area up a bit. Also, very hot in the basement. Everyone in our party was quite aware of the temperature. I guess there's little to no ventilation down there, but it was surprising that it wasn't cooler since it is underground.
author: Traci R.

description:
Cozy cave-like bar located downtstairs in this small and intimate spot located in the heart of North Beach. A must go-to for Belgian beer lovers.  Once seated you are handed the holy bible of Belgian beer lists to look through (really, this thing is like two inches thick).  A great selection of draft and bottles (sized 330ml - 750 ml).  Some really unique beers you can't find anywhere else in town. 

I didn't have food during my recent visit but the menu has some belgian pub classics like cheese and charcuterie, steak frites, burgers pasta and a handful of different mussels. Happy hour is 5-6 PM with $1 of drafts. Can't wait to come back and try some more beers!
author: Kelsey B.

description:
Belgian in Little Italy!

La Trappe has been around in my neighborhood for a few years now, but for whatever inexplicable reason I had always walked by it, made a mental note to pay a visit, but never had! Come to think of it, the reason may very well be my unreliable mental not retrieval capacity!

Anyhow, the upstairs space is nothing impressive, but the basement where the bar and restaurant is located, is a whole other story! The space is very rustic and European. The bar is laid out nicely and the beer and cocktail menu is impressive.

The service was very good. The young man who served us was on top of his game and managed to pay our table a visit just at the right moments. He got our orders in on time and without a flaw. He made one or two recommendations which I liked.

We ordered their Croquettes to start with and it turned out to be a very good choice. We washed them down with Linden St. Dubbel w/ Coffee beer; tasty!

Then we shared a large Mussels with fries. The two dipping sauces we chose were the Chipotle Mayo and Roasted Red Pepper Mayo. Both were very tasty with the fries.

Good atmospher, good beer, good food, and good service. Give it a try next time you are in my neighborhood :-)
author: Afshin A.

description:
Came for a late dinner since we were in the area. It's interesting that you go downstairs for tables and service. We walked into an empty store and wondered what happened...

This place is great for those who like beer and mussels - seems to be plenty of that here!

We ordered mussels with spicy tomatoes. The mussels were on the small side and were just ok. It came with fries and two dipping sauces (Sriracha and curry). The sauces were a nice change from the ketchup!

We also had the pasta with bolognese sauce. The pasta was fresh and the sauce was delicious. I highly recommend this! 

Maybe it was getting late, but we got an unwelcoming vibe from them. They kept taking our plates full of empty shells, but never came back to give us new plates for empty shells... Was that a sign that they were ready to close shop?
author: Lillian C.

description: I love this place! It has a good selection of beers and great food to match. The lower level space is pretty cool too. Dieter, the guy with the blond long hair, is the best bartender ever, knowledgeable and nice, not many like this guy. Thank you Dieter! I'm a repeat customer.
author: Juan S.

description: A gem in San Fran! From their great food to their amazing beer list! Winner! Service was good and friendly. Mussels and fries is typical for European beer drinking and excellent here!
author: Hector B.

description:
I lived in Belgium for a while so I know what I'm talking about.  The beer selection here is second to none for Belgian and sour beers from outside of the US.  The menu is a little overwhelming at first, it must be close to 100 pages, and has the weight of a text book.  Since many of the beers are uncommon to most they have great description of each beer and a table of contents.  The draft list is maybe 20 or so but all are pretty hard to find and most you just don't see anywhere else.  I could go on about the sours and belgians here but you get the idea.  I'm serious, places that have a selection like this just don't exist.  One of the bartenders told me the owner even cellars his own stuff for years at a time so they have good vintage stuff.  

There is a small seating area at street level.  If it's sunny it's worth it otherwise I prefer the cavern style basement.  The bar is down there too and it just has a cool underground vibe.  When in Belgium you eat Moules-frites (mussels and fries) so I had to get them and I was not disappointed.  They are served in the traditional black pot, and they offer 4 different broths and the mussels were perfectly cooked.  They also have 8 or so handmade dips including the traditional beligie-style mayo.  The Wasabi mayo was my favorite but the others was also very flavorful.

This is the first restaurant that I have been to twice in the same week in many years.
author: Scott M.

description:
We walked in to a completely empty restaurant for the server to tell us the party is downstairs. 

And was it ever. We had a 30 minute wait, which was a lot better than we thought considering the place was packed! 

They have a huge binder of beers to choose from- with glasses specific to that beer! And the food is just as good! 

We ordered burgers and mussels and croquettes (oh my!). 

Service was pretty good too considering how busy it was, and the staff were all really friendly.
author: Mandi W.

description:
The best mussels I have ever had. 

Hands down.

My dad was in town and I knew La Trappe would be a perfect fit for us all to go out - for a casual Friday night.

La Trappe always has a low-key vibe without a wait - so if you want attentive service and to be seated quickly - it's perfect.

We finished off two orders of Konkan Mussels - they were so on point.  Each mussel was huge and brimming with flavor and the service was superb and personable.

For quality, affordable food without pretension - come here. 

Trust.
author: Jessica T.

description: I've been a few times and always go downstairs. Usually sit at the bar and read over the beer menu. They have an extensive list of beers, both on draft and bottles. I tend to choose draft beer. Sometimes I ask for a bartender recommendation and you can try a draft sample first. I like noshing on the fries with their house made dipping sauces.
author: David F.

description:
Title:  beer, and good food (and more beer) 

This is a local bar that serves good food... when I travel, I dont want to eat at chain establishments, so I look for local joints to expand my experiences.  I brought my family to San Francisco for a long weekend, and when we wanted to find a place to have dinner, that was different, this was the place (my wife, two older teenagers).  

First, you go downstairs, and it is cozy, a little dark but that is ok, part of the atmosphere.  Juan was great... he handed me the beer menu and I thought it was the manuscript to a movie, it was pretty thick... After talking with Juan, he made a recommendation of a Belgian Beer which hit the spot.  They have ginger ale or bottled root beer for the kids... the root beer was good, real good.  

We started with a meat plate, and then the entrees. We had a burger, spaghetti, rabbit stew, and Boudin Blanco (white sausage)... all of it was great... Plenty of portions so we had to take some back to the hotel.  

I would recommend this place, since my kids were older, they enjoyed it... I don't recommend younger kids, just not that kind of place... 

If you like beer, and want to try some from the vast selection, I recommend this place...
author: Balinor I.

description:
When you first walk in this place, you'll wonder why no one is there... We thought it was closed or something! Then we realized the real fun is downstairs. Once you walk down the spiral staircase, you are completely transformed to a little pub in Belgium.

We sat down and the waiter handed us a huge book of beer. I've never seen so many beer options! They have old and new, taps and bottles, darks and lights. My boyfriend was having so much fun reading about all the different kinds of beers! And it's awesome how much the wait staff knows about beer!

For food, we started with the charcuterie and croquettes. Charcuterie was nothing special. We were not impressed by it. BUT, the croquettes were amazing! The special of the day was a smoked trout and capers croquette. OMG so delicious. For the entrees, I had the vegetable tart which was decent. And my bf had the Stoofvlees, which was an incredible beef stew type dish. It was so good, I highly recommend getting this.

Awesome experience overall. I love the atmosphere! And the food is great too! Definitely coming back. P.S. this place is good for a date or a big group!
author: Julia M.

description: We had a fabulous family dinner here with three generations and lots of great beers, food and support from the knowledgeable staff in selecting from incredible selection of European beers. Food was delicious, too. Can't wait to return.
author: Kelly B.

description: Amazing selection of beer from all over the world. Cool vibe with games you can play downstairs. The bartenders really seem to know their stuff.
author: Camille R.

description:
One of my favorite SF meals ever. It's cozy, euro, inviting, and everything on the menu is DELICIOUS!!! I was not expecting this from the modest exterior, but OMG come in, especially on a cold, SF day, go down the stairs to the more "taverny" downstairs, and enjoy a true feast!

Service is amazing - the wait staff are beyond friendly and will go way out of their way to make sure you have a good experience.

The beers and wine selection is on point. The waiters all can guide you to the perfect beer/wine if you can describe what you're looking for. I wanted a dry, sour cider, and they got me to the perfect one for my meal. They're also happy to provide samples, so just ask!

And now the food. Oh. My. God. 
-The Frites - you cannot go to a Belgian spot and not try the frites. They invented fries! These are crispy all around but not overcooked like some twice-fried fries can be. There's a plethora of sauces available, my favorites being wasabi mayo, chipotle ketchup, and the traditional belgian ketchup. I'd recommend getting one mayo-based and one ketchup-based sauce to try. For added kicks, mix them for a blush sauce!
-The mussels - we ordered a large order for 6 people to snack and share, in the traditional Mariniere style (The classic preparation with shallots, garlic, celery, onions, wine and witbier). It was so good! The sauce seeped into the mussels and they tenderly burst with flavor. It's a lighter, white sauce and not too thick, perfect for dipping bread or fries into.
-Steak Frittes - steak and fries, a classic. But this was so well done. The steak was cut into strips, making it a very share-able plate. It was tender, juicy, and perfectly cooked. The fries were, as mentioned above, fry-perfection.
-The grand finale, my favorite dish of the day: GHENTSE CHICKEN WATERZOOI, a traditional light Belgian Mary's organic chicken stew with cream, potatoes, carrots, onion, and celery. TRUST ME PLEASE, THIS IS INSANELY GOOD. I did not expect this to blow me away, but it was creamy, just sweet enough from the aromatics, hearty without being heavy, and had such a unique flavor. It was crazy crazy good. I would recommend this dish over and over and over, and will over it over and over and over.
-Dessert was delicious and light. I forget the name (not helpful) but someone from my party said they could now die happy. I'm sure whatever you get here, you won't be disappointed!

Highly recommended for a cool date night, a group outing, guys meet up, or anytime you just want good, homey food and drink!
author: Tiffany D.

description:
When our group of three walked into La Trappe on a Friday evening we were a little bit concerned - where were all the people?? In an overcrowded city like San Francisco it's always a good rule of thumb to "follow the crowds" to good food but in this case I guess La Trappe is still an undiscovered gem!!

We ordered mussels, the steak and fries and the stewed rabbit. The mussels were perfectly cooked, the broth was amazing and I can't stop thinking about the steak! But my favorite part would have to be the fries - perfectly crispy on the outside and soft on the inside. You get to pick a couple sauces out of a wide selection and my favorite was the garlic mayo (you can never go wrong!). Pro tip: The sauce from the rabbit is also an awesome dipping sauce for the fries! They also have a wide selection of beers and are very nice about supplying small tastings before you make your final choice. We ended up with Vapeur En Folie, a Belgian pale ale, and were very happy with it! 

Will be back!!
author: Christina L.

description: I've been to San Francisco several times. This is my favorite restaurant in San Francisco thus far.  If you enjoy Belgian beer, mussels, burgers, and pommes frites with aioli, you'll love this place. The food menu is a little limited for a Belgian restaurant, but the beer menu is robust. Actually, the beer menu is overwhelming (in a good way).  The venue is awesome. The restaurant is downstairs. It's almost like you're in a medieval tavern. It reminds me of Monk's Cafe in Philadelphia. Overall, I was extremely impressed. I will be back.
author: Toby F.

description: celebrated my daughter's 25th birthday downstairs and have a really fun time with amazing pub food done right. Zack was our server and did us good the entire time. Really happy about their wine corkage policy
author: Dawn B.

description: Extensive beer list (mostly bottles) but also several on tap. Food was also good ! Will definitely visit again !
author: M N.

description:
Mussels!  Great beer selection.

My brother and I grabbed a table downstairs.  Dark and small, but comfortable.

The beer menu is awesome...it tells you the history of monastery beers.  I tried some Trappist beers that were pretty good.

Top off the night with a frites and mussels combo.  Delicious!
author: Adam S.

description: Truly a gem. The beer selection is bar none and Michael, the bartender, knows his stuff. He will tell you back story on each brewery and offer recommendations on flavour profiles, and rare to many SF establishments, honestly let the customer know when choices are risky (he isn't going to sell you an aged beer just for the sake of taking your money). The food is really good too! The décor is really mellow and the environment is really inviting to conversation. I felt like I was in Europe for a few hours. This is a special place. Do yourself a favour and sit at the bar and enjoy what La Trappe has to offer.
author: Anthony S.

description: This place is soooo awesome! Came here from out of town on a whim, I wanted a beer! Saw that there was a gastropub nearby on yelp. I love gastropubs. So we walk there. We get to the place and we are worried its closed. I'm from Reno, where there really is no last call unless its empty on a Monday and even then, some bars are always open. When you come to an empty place you get worried! We walk inside and its a small knit beautiful little "cafe" with an open kitchen, kinda neat!! But nobody is there, besides the cooks. I was thinking damn! My chance to get a beer in an awesome city before I had to catch the BART out of town, and I walked to an empty restaurant with no actual bar in sight. Ya know... when you're sitting at a regular table just ordering a restaurant beer? It's just not the bar and beer/gastropub experience I was looking for. But then I notice a sign, it says "join us downstairs." Now, I'm like oh yes! As We walk onto this spiral staircase taking us underground, we are immediately met by someone downstairs, very friendly! He points us towards the bar, and it is moderately busy down here!! People are ordering food! Getting drinks! It was an awesome atmosphere. We sit at the bar, which is just such a cool little bar kept up near the underside of the spiral case, and the bartender was asking us about beers and explaining some other ones to us. Ended up drinking some amazing sours here. Will definitely be back! This bar was out of this world cool for a gastropub! Great selection too!
author: Taylor S.

description: Fantastic neighborhood gem!  This is a cozy spot that's not too busy and not too loud. The service is fast and friendly.  Get the moules frites and one of their many beer selections.
author: Chelsea C.

description: Took a friend here and he could not stop raving about it- all of the mussels are super good, and the beer selection is impressive- it's like reading a novel picking out what you want, but in the best possible way.
author: Rachel F.

description:
Thru a recommendation, we decided to try it out. As a beer lover, please do come here because they have over 200 beer selection. Parking isn't that bad, but try to come early to ensure you get a table since place is small. They have an upstairs and downstairs but almost everyone likes to sit downstairs. Nothing wrong, but downstairs carry a better atmosphere. 

I wasn't as big of a beer lover as my boyfriend, so this was like candy-land for him. They had their own beer menu with a table of contents (it was that intense). It was really hard to choose, so we asked our server to recommend us one. He was super nice and knowledgeable. My first beer was strawberry flavored. It was so good I was hesitant to drink it that fast. I didn't really know want my boyfriend got, but according to him it was very good. 

For food, we started with a dozen oysters, as usual. They were pretty small, but they packed such a taste! It was actually perfect for its size. We were excited for their rabbit stew. Supposedly the meat is very tender and tastes similar to chicken. A whole sectioned rabbit leg was presented along with mashed potatoes and some veggies. Our expectations was slightly skewed, expecting actual "stew." Sadly, rabbit meat tasted like chicken we buy from Asian BBQ places, but just slightly better. Well, at least we can say we tried rabbit!

Round 2 of beer, I ask my server to recommend me another one. Boyfriend orders a Japanese kind. We weren't full so we ordered two more appetizer dishes: curry mussels and croquette with shrimp and cheese. 

Croquette was a let down, too. Barely shrimp and too much cheese. The sriracha avoili was a bomba$$ dipping sauce. Curry mussels was another let down as well. Curry was great, but they added too much ginger which caused it to be pretty spicy. They give a hefty amount of mussels though. 
***Tip: Don't waste the sauce! Use their free bread to dip into it :)

Round 3 of beer. I called it ends. Server surprised my boyfriend with his personal favorite IPA. I think SF may have won his heart over, finally.. 

SHOUTOUT to our server for his great personality, service and friendliness throughout our meal. He definitely made our experience nice. 

Overall, food was normal, didn't struck as anything special. I wouldn't come here for the food, but I would come here for their beer. I found it super cute how each beer had their own glass which sometimes came with cute cartoons. It's too bad their wine selection couldn't be as extensive as their beer though. Their location is nice, too, because just a couple blocks away is the infamous Lombard street.
author: Fiona L.

description:
This is a beer lovers dream location. They have 400 different bottles of beer listed by order and location in a giant encyclopedia style book! If you're a cider fan, you'll have to try something else as they don't have a single cider on tab or in a bottle (hence the minus 1 star). If you like the sweeter side of things try the Wild Strawberry Lambic - it was incredible (hence the 4 starts for this drink alone!). 

We split the steak meal which came with two sides and large enough to share if you have an appetizer or salad as well. We opted for the harvest salad (I think) with the candied nuts. It was good with a light salad dressing and bread with Roquefort cheese spread (too heavy for me).

The ambiance in the basement is cozy with large wooden plank style tables and chess boards. It gets chilly near the corner, so dress warm if you want to hang out for a few hours. A roaring fire would make this place the coziest romantic spot in town for your beer loving significant other.
author: Lisa P.

description: A great restaurant I would highly recomend. The cheese platter is fantastic and so is the service. Worldclass collection of beers and very good moule de frittes
author: Andreas J.

description:
Just. Wow. 

I came by with a close friend on a Friday night, after a full day of marathon boot shopping (for her). 

At 7:00 p.m. on a Friday evening, we were able to be sat immediately. *Cartwheels!  In fact, one of the things I liked the most about LT was that it was not uncomfortably crowded. We were able to enjoy our evening in peace, relatively speaking. 

We sat downstairs, which definitely embraces an old school pub atmosphere. If I could picture what the inside of the shire looks like, this would be it. It's warm, dark, old and wooden. Nothing fancy. 

The beer menu is frakking epic. I normally fear no beer, and certainly no beer menu, to be sure, but I must admit that with 400 imported beers and a beer menu exceeding 35 pages, I was a little flummoxed. But fear not, friends, your server knows what SHE'S doing (*throws another wrench into assumption that beer drinking is a man's sport). If you tell her what you normally like, she can walk you through it and make recommendations based on your tastes.

We started with a traditional lambic, moved on to a red, and finished with a very sweet lambic. We shared bottled import beers, which I strongly recommend because you can try more that way (and you drink less as well). With such an enormous beer list, you're going to want to try a few and figure out what you like (and don't like). Don't forget, practically everything is imported, so even the most seasoned American beer drinker might run into questions. Again, the staff knows what they're doing, so please ask. 

Food wise, we started with the ratatouille, which I was only lukewarm about ordering--but it turned out to be delicious!  It was flavorful, fresh and healthy. Then we shared the Boudin Blanc (3 white sausages in a mustard sauce with scalloped potatoes). The BB was a lot lighter than I expected.  It was so good--my companion was like, "Please, make me stop eating this." So I took my plate and put it on top of the BB, and was about to signal our server to remove the plates when my friend removed my plate and continued eating. Well then! It was that good. 

We were physically unable to do dessert. So full. 

For three bottled import beers, ratatouille and BB, it was about $70, which isn't too bad for dinner in SF. Overall, what a great experience, from start to finish.  

Prost!
author: Sunny S.

description:
More like a 3.5

Great beer selection (for Belgians). They have a whole book of beers organized by country. Tons of bottles to try, though most are pretty large...so coming with a group and then sharing a few is optimal. The last time I was there they were out of a few of the ones I wanted to try though. :( I really like the ambiance downstairs. It's brick and dim lighting and mellow...perfect for a date or catching up with friends. Always a bunch of options on tap (again, focused on Belgians). This is one of the bars in SF I recommend for beer lovers. And Rogue is right down the street if you want to design a crawl. . .
author: Kari E.

description: It was so refreshing to have found this place on my trip to SF. Thoroughly enjoyed the menu of the sours. Will definitely visit again if in town!
author: Ella H.

description: They have so many beer on draft! I loved the pumpkin beer which is better than most pumpkin beers you can find on the market--the aroma and the taste is on point. and they have my favorite sour beer on draft, too!
author: Julia Z.

description: Met a friend for a drink here and really enjoyed it! Felt like I was back in Belgium drinking my favorite St. Bernardus beer. They have a wide selection of beer and the service was nice and attentive. We also had two of the starters - the croquettes and the Belgian fries. Both were good. Looking forward to coming back here!
author: Gloria N.

description: I love this place; so much so that it was literally the only place I wanted to celebrate my 40th birthday this weekend. So it's pretty disappointing that after attempting to reach someone at the restaurant all week, I was summarily told this evening by the owner(?) that because there's been a lot of rain and beer week starts this weekend that they didn't want to deal with hassle of accommodating my large group that was willing to come early and spend lots of money there. Not sure I'll be back after this treatment. Happy Birthday to me!
author: Jessica R.

description:
(Rating: +++ is perfect)
Atmosphere+++:
Rustic

Service+++:
Friendly, They know well about beer.

Value++:
A little bit expensive
_________________
Food

Moules A La Biere +++:
Apparently, it was huge and the taste was wonderful.
Beer and Moules make a good combination. 

Belgian fries +++:
We could choose some in many unique dips.

Chicken Videe +++:
The appearance was beautiful and the taste was rich and creamy. 
I love it a lot.
author: Hiromi S.

description: Food was awesome here and I'm not normally a fan of German/Belgian style food. I had the puréed leek soup and classic salad and it was delish! My friend got the burger and the fries were perfectly crisped. Prices also were reasonable!
author: Stacy A.

description: LOVED the beer selection. Food hit me as just meh, but I'd totally give it another try.
author: Heidi O.

description: Great cozy ambiance. I had the chicken waterzooi which is like a soup. As a belgian I can recommend this place. They should make their drinking menu a bit lighter and clear and more fun to read in the poor lighting.
author: Belgian D.

description:
I wouldn't say I really liked the place, unfortunately. 
We set at a bar; it was very cool, because it was a pleasure to talk to the bartender. 
We ordered croquette plate that comes with olive bread. The bread was freshly baked and delicious. The platter only had three kinds of croquette; personally, I would like to taste more varieties. 
We also had tomato soup. At first, I thought it was made from real tomatoes, but by the time we finished it, I had a taste of canned tomatoes. I wouldn't order again. 
We also ordered rabbit stew, and I was surprised how it tasted. The rabbit was very chewy and dry. Mashed potato, that came with the rabbit stew, was delicious, but I wouldn't order that dish next time. 
I definitely want to go back and try something else. The vibe and atmosphere of this place was cozy and home like.
author: Jenna F.

description: I'm not a beer drinker, but the bartender/owner found me a tasty Belgian beer that I LOVED!! And the food is authentic, local and organic. Recommend
author: N S.

description:
Away from the tourists. This restaurant/bar has tables upstairs and the bar downstairs. Head downstairs if you want to enjoy the place. Numerous Belgium beers to choose from (sorry, no Stella). If you're not familiar with Belgium beers, just let the bartenders be you guide. They do know their craft. I'm not normally a beer drinker (I prefer wine and mixed drinks), but I'd have to say I could make this a regular stop. 
I ordered the Mussels Marinare which had a strong white onion flavor broth.   Comes with fries and two dipping sauces (mostly mayo variations - remember the scene from Pulp Fiction).  This dish is best shared. 
Overall, a real nice local establishment.
author: George S.

description: Five stars except the long-haired deadlock pirate is a prick. Our server was AWESOME. Always great beer.
author: Ben T.

description:
To be honest, We weren't expecting much when we walked in. It is quite unassuming, from the outside. Then they take you downstairs, to your table and it's just great. Dark, almost like a chapel; the benches would fit right in, at a church. We were then given a tome, no other word for it. A tome with descriptions of all kinds of beers and ales, from all over the world. We took 15 minutes to get our beer order in, Pliny for me and Trippel, for my friend. Followed this up with Mussels Mariniere, which was delightful. Both of us got the steak frittes which leads us to our only complaint about the place. The steak was a bit cool for our liking. I thought it was just me, but my friend agreed. This is the only reason for me, not to give this place 5 stars.

Nonetheless, we will be back, because it's the kind of place that deserves it. And I desperately want to update my review, with 5 stars.
author: Vijay K.

description: Great brew selection and attentive staff. Stopped by based on Yelp review and wasn't disappointed.
author: Steve M.

description:
Undoubtedly the best Belgian beer collection in the US! They cover almost all the Trappist beers except for the Westvleteren (which isn't easily available even in Belgium) :)

Enjoy your beer in this cozy hidden gem of a place which has around 300 beers to choose from!
author: Abhijit S.

description:
We could barely read the menu because the place was very dark. I believe that no one wants to have dinner in a dark basement. There are not so many typical Belgian dishes on the menu and we almost tried all of them (except my husband who did a safe bet and ordered a hamburger): the chicken waterzooi was too creamy and very heavy, the carbonnades came with vegetables (zucchini and tomatoes lol) and the mussels were super tiny (the portion was very small too). 
The staff was very friendly but it is not enough to get us back again.
author: Stephanie T.

description: i wanted to give a good review but i cannot. I order a CHIKEN stew as an entree today. I didnt know until I got home and saw the bill, It was actually a RABBIT LEG STEW. I wanna throw up right away. I have a bunny pet, i will never eat bunny. I just feel so upset, but its too late. I tried to called them to confirm what they gave me. I really cannot tell what i ate. but no one answered. I don't know why they accidentally gave me the wrong order. now i accidentally ate rabbit..........crying
author: Felicia C.

description:
This place is amazing!

I had eaten moules frites a ton of times, but had never had the pleasure of experiencing a full Belgian menu before visiting La Trappe. 

Their Nicoise salad was the best I've ever had with perfectly seared rare tuna, delicious veggies and a glorious presentation.

I ate here with a few friends, and though we were all sober, we left feeling euphoric from the great food and magical time we had eating here.

Can't for the life of me remember what the traditional Belgian dish we had was called, but it was fricken amazing! I think we just asked our waiter what his favorite was, and ordered it.

Easily my best restaurant find of the year. If you like French, and you enjoy inventive cuisine, you will absolutely love this place!
author: Lilah L.

description:
Cool looking space but always a weird vibe. Two stars - one for neat basement bar, one for extensive beer list. Almost want to take one away for the prices...

Brief synopsis of last visit:

We roll downstairs to sample their extensive list of beers, grab a seat at the bar and walk into what is apparently a feud between bartenders. Watching this progress, for a while, was strange. Rather than take our order, they squabble, slam menus, and mutter passive aggressive comments to each other. In front of many customers. Feeling very awkward, we left immediately. 

Maybe it's correctable? For now, there are better places to go. Went to Rogue up the street and people were happy. And smiling. That's what we were looking for.
author: Don F.

description:
Amazing Belgian comfort food!
If you are looking for a cozy, casual place to hang out with your friends that has great food and a huge selection of authentic Belgian beers, this is the place.  The upstairs has just a few tables but tends to be much quieter than the cavenous space downstairs.

We ordered a couple different styles of moules and frites (mussels for the non-french speakers).  I tried the typical white wine and garlic sauce and also tried the curry sauce - both were fantastic.  Frites were nice and airy and crispy- just as I would expect.  I enjoyed a framboise lambic beer- was surprised at the selection of lambic- several different peche, framboise, currant, gueze, etc.

My only disappointment was the Belgian waffle.  If you've ever tried an authentic Belgian waffle, you expect it to be very light and airy, with special sugar crystals baked right into the batter that are little bits of gooey sweetness when they're warm. Unfortunately, our "belgian" waffle was heavy, dense, made from whole wheat flour (which could be done successfully), had a slight bitter taste from the type of flour and lacked the sweet sugar crystals.  

So I would love to come back and try other menu items and hope that they can work on getting my beloved Belgian waffle done right!
author: Christine S.

description: One of my favorite bars in the city (But only if you like beer)! This place completely reminds me of a Eurpoean bar. It's downstairs, a little dungeny but lively and well lit. It's like going back in time (or across the globe) to get a feel of a true old-timey bar. They have tons of beers and a great place to try foreign beers that you can't find other places. The food is good and hardy like Belgian food should be! Def a must try!
author: Brittini S.

description:
This place makes me want to go back to San Francisco. 
Cheese plate: bomb.
Mussels: so delicious.
Beer selection: HUGE.
Atmosphere: dark, intimate, European.
author: Kelly F.

description:
I loved EVERYTHING!!!
Mussels! 
Mussels Five Ways! 
Mussels All WAYS! 
Mussels for daysssssss. 

Beers are extensive, lovely and perfectly matched for all the menu items. I especially loved a light strawberry lager and oysters.
author: Mimi S.

description:
Neat spot with an overwhelming but excellent beer selection, & chill atmosphere.

We came at about 8pm and had to wait about 20 minutes for a table so we grabbed some beers. The Bink blond, Ichtegems Grand Cru, & Duvel Strong Pale Ale were all pretty good.

The food, however, is pretty mediocre. 
Steak frites were the highest priced entree on the menu yet the steak was pretty chewy and flavorless. I got the scallops 3 ways which wasn't anything special. 
I tried my sister's little bunny Foo Foo..I mean stewed rabbit :P & it wasn't too bad but she seemed to really enjoy it.

Next time I return, I'll pass on the food & go straight to the beers. They make me pretty full anyway :)
author: Jenny Q.

description:
I was looking for a good introductory restaurant for a 20something family member from out of town. This was perfect including the Russian Hill drive as a SF introduction. Do not be confused by the small upstairs. Go downstairs to the main restaurant. The decor is dark and cosy and the crowd noisy. The place was crowded on a Friday night and they didn't take reservations. We arrived at 8 and didn't need to wait.

The food was epic. We had a beef stew which was like no other I have had. It turned out to have been cooked with gingerbread spread with mustard.  This made a unique and awesome taste. The chicken waterzooi was also quite good. The stew came with fries and a choice of two dipping sauces. We choose the red peppers based sauce which was excellent. I would rave even more but the fries were seasoned so tasty we forgot to dip them half the time. The portions were huge and though quite hungry we had a lunch worth of doggy bag left over.

There is an awe-inspiring list of beers and the waiter was able to match beer preferences with potential choices. I had a most delectable stout with chocolate and cherry undertones. My dinner companion doesn't drink. For her there were interesting imported sodas.

The dessert was good too. I wish I could find you the name of it but the online menu doesn't list desserts.

The service was excellent and attentive.

I am coming back to investigate the rest of the menu.
author: Alyson A.

description:
I really like how they don't play loud music, so you can hear the person across the table from you. Beer selection is great, along with the atmosphere being chill. 

Only thing negative to say is that they put too much dressing on the salads. Next time I'll ask for the dressing on the side.
author: Ashley M.

description: This was my second time here and I would go back all the time if I lived in SF. Came as a tourist, but left as a huge fan of this restaurant. Delicious, unique beers and good service. Fries are the bomb and the steak is two thumbs up. I miss you already, La Trappe!
author: A C.

description: Super good food.  Love the unbelievable amount of choices of beer from Belgium.  The staff was super helpful and accommodating.
author: Kraig T.

description:
4.5 stars for a gastropub. Come here for the crazy encyclopedia of beers from every country - it's literally as extensive as the wine list from a restaurant like French Laundry, except in beer. I have never seen anything like it. They even had champagne beer which I have never heard of. The beer sommelier (is there another name for this?) was super knowledgeable on recommending the best beer to one's taste.

They were running a library fundraising event, so the menu was not as extensive as the dinner one, but both the bratwurst and the baby back rib were fantastic. Great quality sausage, super juicy and tasty (a bit hard to eat though with the sausage keeps on falling out of the bread). The baby back rib was super tender. A bit loud in the basement portion of the pub, but still super fun.
author: Rebecca C.

description:
If you love traveling to Europe and miss it.  La Trappe will fill that void.  As soon as we started descending the spiral staircase, I immediately started thinking about when I went to Paris.  How most of the restaurants are down a level.

La Trappe is very small, since they have like maybe 10 tables that fill up fast, and I noticed they plop "reserved" signs on the larger tables.  Now even more competition for us all.  Good things come to those who wait.

Beer list is more like a bible beer list.  You are handed a book.  Catch is they don't have all the smaller beers, you get talked into the larger beers that are over $20.  My fiance had the white sausage and said it was really good.  I had fries and a waffle.  Fries were good, can't go wrong there.  Waffle, just tasted a little off?  The guy at the food trucks, who makes Belgium waffles taste way better than La Trappe's.  If I ever get the opportunity to go back, I'll try something else.
author: Michelle M.

description: Can not speak much to the food, I only had the fries. They were average (not crispy enough for me),,but the mayo based sauces were unique and tasty. Also, the burgers looked massive. What's more impressive is the exhaustive list of Belgium-style beers from all over the world. A great collection. And if you don't know about beer, it has definitions and descriptions for each to help you. Also this bar has two distinct settings. A bright airy first floor, and a dark old-style pub in the basement.
author: Eric M.

description: Very European experience at La Trappe.  There's something really special about dining on delicious mussels in the dark, intimate brick basement while sipping authentic Belgian beer.  Food and ambiance are incredible! Will definitely be back often.
author: Kim W.

description: The white male bartender is one of the rudest people I've ever met. My girlfriend and I went to dinner here and asked the bartender if they had a dish we found on Yelp. He then started yelling at her saying Yelp wasn't his boss. Needless to say, we immediately left. Probably worst experience I've ever had in terms of customer service, and something the owner should be embarrassed of. I will never come back here and do not recommend it. Also the menu is completely different than on Yelp, don't come here
author: AJ A.

description:
My friend and I were looking to grab something to eat before going out. We parked close to this place and decided to eat here because Belgian food was a mystery to the both of us and we were both curious.

The place looked empty when we walked in but we were lead downstairs to the more crowded pub area. Overall atmosphere was very cute in the old-fashioned pub way it looks. The menu was semi-interesting food-wise. Beer menu was HUGE (a whole ALBUM of different types of beers and descriptions). They had a cheese and wine menu too.

Our server was nice but wasn't that good about checking up on us. Average. Granted, the place was a bit busy. Everyone who was working seemed to be rushing to get things done (whatever they were doing).

I ordered the moules pastis (creamy baked mussels) with an Affligem blonde (Belgium ale) while my friend got the chicken videe (shredded organic chicken with cream in a puff pastry). 

The mussels were delicious. I was very happy with my choice. The fennel sauce really added a nice depth of flavor to the entire dish. Without it, it would have been just okay. I wasn't particularly happy with the slice of bread they gave me since they placed it on my platter to make it look normal...but was burnt on the other side. 

The beer was pretty good. It was exactly what I was expecting based on the description in the beer menu. My friend said her chicken was pretty good too. Nothing too special.

Overall good place. I expect that this place is best for their beer rather than the food but I liked the food too. It might vary depending on what you order.
author: Sofia R.

description:
So. Many. Options. 

Ordering a beer at this place can become a stressful event because there are so many beers! The menu goes on for pages & pages, which is great if you're a beer lover, particularly a Belgian beer lover. They also have a good looking menu, though I didn't try any of the food. But beware, the beer is not cheap! The fact that it's in a nice neighborhood in SF & probably import most of their beer should be a dead giveaway that beers are about $8-9 on average. They have some cheaper local beers & some really rare high end beer, but I'd say that most of their beers fall somewhere in the middle. 

The atmosphere is great & they have a nice seating area downstairs with couches & tables for an intimate gathering. Not recommended for a large party though.
author: Lori N.

description: They have a sign in chalk on the sidewalk advertising the downstairs area so we asked to go downstairs .. 3 servers and almost 30 mins later, they told us to leave ..parties of 12 only the waiter says "I don't even know what you ordered I forgot to put your order in" and he was very obviously drunk. This was our Saturday evening experience. Rudest staff I've ever encountered.
author: Abby B.

description: Loud. Too loud. Reasonable prices for San Francisco. Not a lot of vegetarian options but a couple. Kinda warm inside. I'd try to eat outside.
author: Zene B.

description:
Have the stew!!!  This place is gorgeous to see.  Very old time ambiance.  Kind of reminds me of Great Lakes Brewing in Cleveland,  ohio.  

My husband loved the beer choices.  

I loved the stew and Brussels sprouts. 

Saw many who I think were locals in the restaurant. To me,that is always a great sign for quality and values.
author: Cindy S.

description: Mussels mussels mussels! The rest of the foods are OK, but don't miss out on the mussels. Note you cannot order anything but starters prior to 6pm. Come early though as they don't take reservations.
author: Angela L.

description:
The beer is the star here. Very large selection of some very special beers, mostly Belgian. Had three very delightful bottles a vintage Trappist ale, an ultra bruin, and a Belgian blond ale. I was disappointed that I went 2 for 3 on picking beers that "we just ran out of". The server suggested something "very similar" here I also went 2 for 3 on a up charge from my original choice, however much to their credit they charged me the lower price. 

Started with the onion soup special. Very testy with all the components blending well. Somehow seemed just a touch creamy. Croquet special was  cheese and shrimp stuffed with sriracha aioli. Absolutely wonderful.  Finished with the roast rabbit leg. This was quintessential comfort food. Tender and succulent rabbit leg with "chunky" mashed potatoes (yum) and a rich brown gravy that was NOT over salty. The "fresh vegetables" we're a little pedestrian, yellow squash and carrots, but actually fit with the dish quite well.

Very good, except for the minor inventory issues a top notch place to eat and drink.
author: Mason M.

description: The food: we got a pot of mussels w spicy sauce (Konkan) and they were amazing. Perfectly cooked and I couldn't stop dipping my bread in the rich sauce. The sauces that come w the Belgian fries are awesome too. Get the gribiche or chipotle BBQ garlic mayo. My gf got the STOOFVLEES - CARBONNADE FLAMANDE, a beef stew w excellent meat that melted in my mouth. The giant book of beers let's you pick something special from anywhere in the world. Will come again next time I'm in SF!
author: El C.

description: If you like Belgian beer, this place is unbelievable.  Largest selection I've ever seen.  The have lots of American, German and Italian beer also, Belgian is their specialty.  Met the owner, great guy.  Very knowledgeable.  Can't recommend highly enough.
author: Tim M.

description: Best beer menu and nicest Owner. We truly enjoyed our time which was too short. I would come back anytime.
author: Kurdt L.

description:
Beer Stop 25
---

"Do you have Hoeegaarden on tap?". Ha - so many people ask this question. No HG here, only delicious beer, mainly from Belgium.

This is a Belgium beer lovers palace. La Trappe offers so many abbey beers and other rarities that I have not seen anywhere else. Yes, they are imported from Belgium, so the price may be a tad on the higher side, but so what? You are paying for abbey beer.

The service is great. I have never had a bad experience here. All the servers know beer and seem to enjoy it as well. They can always provide a recommendation for what you like.

I can't get enough of this place. I have been back so many times and every time the tap list changes and I find something new I like.

Props for the Mikkeller beer selection. Walk on Water is a favorite of mine.

Can't wait to go again and again.
author: Justin A.

description:
Love this place. Note, I may be biased because I love Belgian food / mussels / beer. If you like any of that stuff, you'll really enjoy this spot.

I'm surprised that Belgian food is so limited in San Francisco given it's a port city. But if you're craving some Belgian beer and mussels, look no further as it has ~500 Belgian beers on tap as well as some great mussels with fries. And yes they give you mayo dipping sauce :)

We sat in the downstairs area which is very dark and has more of a lounge feel (so don't go if you're looking to be sitting outside / in the sun of San Francisco). But definitely go check it out for dinner or on a foggy day.

Staff is super friendly and loves talking beer. Belgian beers (for those that don't know) are very different than the American hoppy IPAs & MillerCoorsBud grain water. You should go try some of their dubbels and tripels and quadrupels

Price is not cheap but reasonable
author: Peter M.

description:
Used to love this place (with the name i can never remember; keep confusing it with "Affigem" the Belgian beer name on the sign below "La Trappe") - WHEN it was a cafe, not a "gastropub" - when it was filled with locals and the occasional tourist, not the invading techies despoiling our wonderful city by the Bay. 

Now, the energy and atmosphere have changed at our beloved La Trappe. The service is terrible as the servers focus almost exclusively on the affluent, almost-entirely testosterone-laden tables of 12, loud, vulgar, raucous 25-35 year old male techies. 

Local,  tourist and dating couples are shunted off to the corners of the downstairs beer cellar dining room and forced to listen to the techies swear profanities and whoop and yell extremely loud as though they are still in the fraternity house which they were surely never members of because as nerds they not only would not have been accepted into university Greek life, they would have known not to even rush. 

Don't worry. They're making up for lost time all across San Francisco, Emeryville, etc. making going out in public difficult for normal people - whom they disdain.

Back to the service at La Trappe: On the last few visits whether we have dined downstairs or upstairs service has been terrible. Food orders are incorrect. Food arrives slowly as others are served ahead of us. Servers fawn over techies and look at the rest of us as though they wish we weren't here. 

My last server seemed as though he shared in the general mysogyny, ageism (and perhaps even the homophobia/Lesbophobia) of the multiple large- tables of techies that night. 

We (two Lesbian women in a couple who are long-term neighbors and  customers of La Trappe) were there on what was a special occasion for us, a cause to celebrate. La Trappe needs to fire some people or bring in a professional diversity trainer. The dinner was ruined for us by the server and his attitude (he treated us as though we should not even be there)  the unwillingness to control the vulgar, loud, disturbing behavior of techies, the disappointing food. 

We were not the only other couple trying to have a quiet dinner down there that evening. There were at least four other tables like us, romantic or just tete-a-tete discussing life or business QUIETLY. These other restaurant "guests" all had that "never again at this restaurant" look on their faces. 

Did I mention that at a table for two or four downstairs it is nearly impossible to hear your companion(s) once the nightly tech crowd arrives? Its hard to even hear yourself think. The atmosphere which used to be quaintly "Left Bank, beer-cellar continental" is now darkly claustrophobic. I don't care how many beers, ales, etc. you have on your menu as thick as a novel if there's no pleasure in being there to imbibe.

Let's discuss business models: Not a good idea to hitch your star so completely to the rise of the tech boom. San Francisco has seen this before. I predict that when the tech bust comes...and it will, it just may not be as big as the last time... THIS restaurant, so dependent on techies for business, will be OUT OF BUSINESS and FAST!!!
author: Scout F.

description:
How to turn a date night into a nightmare night? That was easy thanks to this tourist Trappe!

1. We were sat downstairs and the ceiling was leaking water on our table
2. A large selection of beers but after ordering ours we were told it was not available anymore
3. The waitress brought us the check right after our appetizers, forgetting we had entrees coming next...
4. One of our entrees came 10min after the other one and totally COLD
5. 10min later the entree can back lukewarm and with no sauce
6. Potatoes in our gratin were raw, the waiter barely apologized and simply disappeared
7. The manager did not even came to the table and took $8 off the check... Nice compensation!

So sad because this place seems to have potential and a huge beers selection however the staff and the kitchen just do not seem to care at all.

Avoid this place, they just do not deserve you!
author: John D.

description: Let me tell you what. This place holds a crown that I bestowed upon it. Being a HUGE fan of everything Belgian, I was incredibly excited to walk past this place. It seemed closed down for good when I passed so I looked it up on Yelp to see if I could expect to come here later for dinner. Sure enough, it's open in the evenings. I've spent about 5 years in Europe when I was younger and spent some of that time in Belgium. So when I walked in, it instantly took me back. The decor, atmosphere and overall feel of the place was exactly how I remembered the restaurants being. The menu was incredible, full of all the normal fare that I remember so vividly. What really kicks you in the face is their extensive beer menu. Seriously. Their beer menu is ENORMOUS, but also priced to be what you expected. The beers are all imports, so that's something that needs to be taken into consideration, but also, Belgian beers take a lot of time to brew, therefore the price you normally see. It took my wife and I an easy 20 minutes to find a beer we could finally settle on. There was nothing that I didn't want. Hands down this is my favorite restaurant in San Francisco and I'll be sure to come in next time I'm in town.
author: Nick B.

description: I was never a beer person :/ but after tasting their beer :D I'm in love with it. I'm not sure what was the beer called, but it was sweet and tasted like an apple. Great place to chill with friends and have some after dinner snacks. Will Definitely revisit to try more beers :)
author: Jenny Y.

description:
SF Weekly had written this place up a while ago and we had passed by it before and it didn't look anything fancy but that was before we knew about the downstairs.  What a great hidden gem.  If you love beer, check this place out because they have a ton of them.  The beer menu is almost as thick as a bible.

Our server was a little salty but in a good way and we enjoyed our experience here.  We shared a lot of little plates including the Belgian fries (really good), Harvest salad with the most amazing toast, hot dog which was no ordinary normal hot dog and the birds nest.  We were definitely full after our meal but we left happy and hope to come back again soon.
author: Blake B.

description:
This is the first place in the U.S. that really reminded me of Cafe Delirium in Brussels.  

The Great:
+  We sat at the bar and the two bartenders knew their beer and made some spot-on recommendations.  I was impressed.
+  Moules Frites were great.  The mussels were plump and sweet and they were served with a mountain of frites with authentic european mayo.  The broth was a tad salty but I loved it nonetheless.
+  Awesome basement area. 
+  Impressive beer list.
+  House wines are a STEAL!

The Average:
o  Prices were a bit high for some of the bottles IMHO, but hey, I'm sure they're not flying off the shelf so I get it.  The draft selection was smaller than expected but they had some gems.

The Poor:
-  A bit of a funny smell down in the basement.  Almost smelled like sewage/gas.  Luckily it only came in a few random wafts but I'd check it out if I were them.
author: Andreas H.

description:
Dined here several times and have never had less than a good experience. After taking a winding staircase down to the lower dining room you will encounter what almost resembles a cellar, with exposed brick walls and thick wood dining tables. It has a fantastic old world vibe that isn't easy to find in the city. 

The stand out attribute of this restaurant is the beer menu. Fifty pages of fantastic Belgium beer. It is laid out more like a beer directory than a menu. I'm not a huge fan of the current IPA craze and the inundation of overly bitter beer that has bred from it, so the amount of flavorful and complex beers of all varieties that this place provides is a refreshment.

The food is also pretty great. Mussels here have always been fantastic. Every sauce is tasty, and frites are crispy and they bring you bread at the end to sop up the remaining sauce. Best of all, the mussels themselves are always tasty. Some places can be a hit or miss with their supply, but I've never had a bad mussel here. The rabbit and chicken waterzooi are also delicious. Portions are fair sized and the prices are reasonable.
author: Michael S.

description:
Went here Saturday night for a friends birthday dinner. 

Pro tip : they take reservations if you are a big party 

When we reached our table wasn't ready but we ordered some beers and waited. Then we were seated after which it took the waitress about 10 minutes to come around for drinks. We ordered some appetizers and beer and got it in maybe 15 minutes. After that we wanted repeat beers and food but waitress insisted on drinks order first and food later. She was then gone again for 15 minutes before we could order food. 

Apps : croquettes yum ! 
Fries - average I would skip then
Mussels - quite smelly and didn't enjoy them

Burgers - average 

Food menu is quite limited and service isn't great. I would recommend coming here for the beer. They have a huge selection and apps are not bad either. Avoid dinner here.
author: Priyanka P.

description: Great beers selection.the best selections I have ever seen.  Bartender is so knowledgeable Adam.
author: Todd A.

description: Visiting San Fran for a wedding and had some down time between wedding and reception. Found this place via Yelp. What a great bar. We had two different types of beer.  A salami platter with bread. I can't remember what it was called, sorry. Overall jUst a great experience. Our server Gabe was friendly and helpful. I highly recommend this place. Stop in and check it out.
author: Nicole V.

description: I had to check out this Belgium tavern again.  Don't let the empty restaurant fool you.  Descend the stairs into this cool underground brick tavern with beers from all over the world, served in their proper glasses, the way beer should be.
