The bartender knows a lot about beer so ask him questions.  The history of the building is also interesting dating back 100 years.  Ask him about that too.  Enjoy.
author: Jessiqa P.

description: Brussel sprouts are phenomenal.  Downstairs is one of the coolest spaces I've seen in a restaurant.  Like other posters said, place looks closed/empty from the street but the basement is where the action is. If you want to get away from the tourist trap joints, venture a few blocks south of fisherman's wharf and you won't be sorry.  Loved this place.
author: Rob T.

description:
Great place for drinks and food. The service was great. We had a terrific taramisu that wasn't up to it's usual par so the waiter gladly took it away and comp our beers as an apology. I ordered the pot of steamed mussels and as a girl, that pot was enough for two full meals. It's also served with a side of fries with two dipping choices!!

This place is awesome. Must must return!!
author: Elaine Y.

description: Food was good here, but I came here for their selection of Belgium beers, of which I am a big fan.  When you first walk in on the upper floor you seem like you are in just another nice bar.  But once you head downstairs it was very cool and cave-like.  The bartender/server knowledge of Belgium beers and his willingness to talk about the large selection was great.  Place had a nice atmosphere and fairly quiet, but I usually visit this place in the afternoon. Anyhow every time I come close to San Francisco I always stop here even if it is out of my way.
author: Erin G.

description: La Trappe, first off, has amazing foreign and domestic brews true to the "No crap on tap" philosophy. The food while not mind blowing does an excellent job of satisfying appetite, and does taste excellent. I had mussles and frits paired with a leipziger gose. (Incredible btw). I also had their blue cheese burger, a little blander than I had hoped but still tasty AF. Where this place really shines is the service. Zack was our waiter twice. I was thoroughly impressed not one time, but both times! Zack, although being the only waiter on staff twice; one of those times being crazy because pliny the younger was on tap, has consistently exceeded his role as a waiter. He consistently goes to extra lengthes to keep me and my people happy. He is always smiling. Even when my friend was having a bad day, and couldn't find a beer to drink, he showed up with a beer in hand ready for my friend to drink we didn't even have to ask him. I can't tell you how amazing it is to have a waiter as perceptive as Zack. If you want outstanding service, incredible craft beer, and great food La Trappe is the place to go. Thank you guys for some fantastic experiences, I'll be back soon and would most definitely recommend to anyone.
author: Daniel-san F.

description:
Love the beer and the Belgian basement decor, but that one long-beard bartender, the guy who looked around me while I was queued to order for 20+ mins, reduced me to an #UglyAmerican with a fanny pack in a Brugges bar.  

Avoid.
author: Nels J.

description:
Service here is brutal. Their incompetent waitress, Cecilia, forgot our order, and we had to wait for over an hour to get two mediocre burgers. We had to go get our own napkins, and we got the silverware halfway through the meal. Getting a beer was also a battle.

You would think that they would comp you something for having messed up so badly, like any service-minded restaurant would, but no. 

Furthermore, they had a bottom of the barrel photographer there from the Chronicle taking pictures the entire time. It was really annoying and invasive. 

They obviously have no concept of anything. They should just close this place down.
author: Tracey W.

description:
La Trappe is quite a little find, well... at least being adjacent to a tourist trap. This is in part due to its newly-refurbished downstairs, which hides the fact that locals actually enjoy their fine food, beer, and even wine selection. In fact, the downstairs is so comfy, so full of tables with chess boards built-in, and so full of old brick and funky wall coverings -- I could spend an entire review just raving about the decor and ambiance. Let's be glad I'm not actually doing that, eh?

While my partner and I are both not exactly beer aficionados, we both had to be impressed at the extensive menu, including some interesting-looking gluten-free Belgian triples and quads. That said, the wine list was up to the task, which is not something you normally get in a place geared towards beer.

We got the fried Brussels Sprouts for an appetizer, which came with a light tangy sauce, and were cooked right to that place in-between crunchy and not-so-much, with a nice crispy outer coating. My partner got the steak con frites, and was very pleased by both the perfect medium-rareness of the meat, as well as the fries and the various dipping sauces that came with them. She's not a big mayo fan, and their dipping sauces are a little mayo-heavy, so there's that as far as complaints go. 

I got the roasted rabbit with perhaps the most amazing mashed potatoes I have EVER had in my life. They were just a hair salty but not too much, creamy, but not overly so, and sat on top of the most basic but incredibly flavorful red wine reduction. I serious started using my fingers to get the last little bits of potato off the plate at the end. My rabbit was well-cooked (not overdone) and came with both half a rack and a full hind leg, which was actually a surprisingly filling portion.

The waitstaff was all incredibly friendly and helpful, and our waiter was very much an easy guy to have a laugh with. And when he made the small mistake of not bringing a steak knife? He immediately corrected the error and apologized within 2 minutes, which is more than enough service for me.

Indeed, it is wabbit season. La Trappe, I'll be back for that triple... although I wish I had asked if you had your own chess pieces.

Our one complaint? What the heck is up with that weird taxadermied cat photo, making the taxadermied cat look like he was kneading out some pizza dough? Seriously -- what the HECK? I'm probably not going to sit where I can see it again... I was freaking out a bit.
author: Amy P.

description: The downstairs bar is very cozy. I came here after going to a comedy show nearby and thought they might have delirium (they don't have it on tap and ran out of the bottles) but ordered some other belgian beer on tap. It was great! The bartender happily poured my date and I some samples before we ordered.
author: Sheena N.

description:
I went to La Trappe a few months ago and had such a horrible experience that I'm still bitter about it. I invited a few friends out to see our favorite comedian and planned to go to La Trappe for dinner prior to the show. We gave ourselves ample time (about an hour and a half) so we could eat, drink, and still have time to find good seats at the show. As much as I want to base my review on the beer and one appetizer, the one star is mostly based on the slow chef in the kitchen and the hostile manager that left such a bitter taste in my mouth.

We sat down to eat, ordered a few beers, a few appetizers, and a few dinner plates to share for the six of us. The beers took 10 minutes to get, which can feel like a long time but it was a bit busy and understaffed... we let that slide. About 40 minutes goes by and one appetizer comes out... ONE. We wait another 10 and the second comes. When I say appetizers, I don't mean something extravagant or hard to prepare - one of our appetizers was a meat and cheese platter; is it that hard to put meat and cheese on a wooden block?? 20 more minutes pass for a total of 1 hour 20 minutes, and our last appetizers come with salads to our main plates. At this point we're running late to our show and we ask the waitress for the check and to cancel the rest of the food. 

What happens at this point, I've never had happen at any other restaurant and is the main reason for my one star. The manager or owner comes up to our table and asks what the problem was, looking very upset. We explain the situation, telling him that we're running late for a show. He gets irritated, clearly holding back his frustration, but puts the blame on us by saying "Why didn't you inform your waitress?" We plainly reply "We didn't think it would take over an hour." He stomps away from our table into the kitchen. Cooking up a dish in a timely manner is one thing, but to lose your composure and blame the customer is UNACCEPTABLE. I do not plan on ever returning. We left the restaurant bewildered that anyone would treat their customers that way.

Breakdown:
Beer is Beer = Great = 4 stars
Service = Poor = 0 stars
Food = Not Applicable
Total = 1 star
author: Jose H.

description:
Don't be fooled... Ate here on a Friday (may 2014) and food was dry and overcooked. Service was totally chaotic like nobody had a clue what was happening. 

$80 for mediocre or worse food=avoid. Not authentic, not worth it.

They call it "the trap" for a reason.
author: Aaron S.

description:
This place is known for it's beer selection... as far as that goes, this place definitely get's five stars.  They always have tons of choices and they always have something new to try.  My friend was very excited to find a beer that he hasn't been able to find since moving away from the east coast.  It is a belgian ale called Bornem Double.  I had it for the first time here and loved it!

The fries here are awesome!  Would you expect anything less from a Belgian place?  They have a ton of dipping sauce choices.

One time, we went here right when the place opened.  We got really great service and the bartenders were all incredibly knowledgable about the beers.  This is definitely a place where you can just describe a style or taste you enjoy in a beer and let the bartender pick something for you.  Another time we were here when they were incredibly busy.  It took awhile to even get seated and our server was clearly very busy, so she wasn't around much.  Since this is a bar, that's not entirely unacceptable.  It's still worth coming here whenever you can make it because the food and drink selection is wonderful, but the best experience will be had during off-peak hours.
author: Chrissy M.

description:
+ Good beer

- Poor service. The bartender here has a serious attitude problem...not just to customers, but to life in general. My friends and I left because he got too difficult to stand.

Also, I've been here another time. They always say they are busy when I call in ahead of time, but whenever I come, it's empty...so...what's up with that?
author: Margaret R.

description:
Love this place for its beer, food and service! 

We were in the area for a show and visited with La Trappe for a quick meal before. Small cosy restaurant indeed but with a giant beer menu! We ended up having their charcuterie and mussels - yummm- still thinking about the bread with these 2 perfect combination dishes! And the beer (try it to believe it!) is OUTSTANDING - luckily I do not live near this cafe, else I'd be too much of a regular here! 

To cap off this nice restaurant - great service with great advice and all at a relatively affordable price too! I would definitely want to return to this cafe when I am in this area!
author: edward C.

description:
It's Saturday night and we know wherever you go there is going to be a wait. Upon arriving we were told a 45 minute wait (but manager says don't quote me on that) and it ended up being a 1.5 hour wait. Bartenders were friendly, chatting about different beer options and quick with service while we waited. Manager checked in with us about three times while we waited which was appreciated.

Ambiance was great on the downstairs floor, brick walls and arches, great lighting and smells of yummy food. By the time we sat down we were starving and after 1.5 hours of waiting, we were ready! Service was not great, they definitely need more staff to ensure decent customer service. Water glasses were set and never filled until we asked about three times. Beer took about 20 minutes to get to table, stalled because one of the beers we ordered was out. So we sat at table with no beverages for 15 minutes. 

Corn and shrimp fritters came piping hot with a great sauce, we inhaled them in about 10 seconds. When entrees came fries were stone cold which is a bummer because I love fries and was excited to try dipping sauces. Sausage came hot but potatoes and kale were cold. It was such a bummer to wait that long and get served cold food!

I would go back on a slow weeknight, but until they get more servers/bussers and fix the issues in the kitchen, I wouldn't go back on a weekend.
author: Megan C.

description:
This place is a hidden gem!!!!!! Love the food and the ambiance! Do not be fooled if you look in the window, the restaurant is downstairs with old world romantic ambiance. Great date restaurant! 
We had the Boudin Blanc (amazing) and Fried Brussel Sprouts with Bearnaise sauce ( to die for). My husband hates Brussel Sprouts and he loved them.
The prices are great too, we had dinner for $20 per person and the portions were so big we should have split one meal. Don't miss this place when in town.
author: Sherri E.

description: Absolutely best mussels ever!  I love this place so much!  What a gem!  I wish there were more stars I could give them!  Stellar Belgian beer selection too!  Love!
author: Leslie B.

description:
Best beer bar in San Francisco. Hands down. The best.

Although expensive, the food is high quality and flavorful, and the beer list is as thick as a novel. Ask the bartender for a beer recommendation, they are all super knowledgeable and helpful.
author: Colton L.

description:
My husband and I visited La Trappe after a fun day touring the north bay. We were able to drop in and get a table without issue at 6pm on a Friday night. The restaurant really didn't start to fill up until a bit later.

The restaurant is split into two stories, with the bar and primary seating downstairs, and the kitchen / secondary seating area upstairs. We headed downstairs.

I ordered the steak + frites. They cooked the steak very rare, just how I like it! The meal was HEARTY and really hit the spot. I liked my beer pretty well (a dubbel, picked out by the server), but I can't remember what it was.

My husband ordered the rabbit and thought it was OK. He really enjoyed his beer, Gulden Draak 9000 quad. Very rich and sweet.

I was still hankering for dessert, but unfortunately there was no chocolate on the menu that night. Ah well, we went elsewhere for an ice cream cone. :)

NOTE: The bathrooms were not the cleanest. The ladies room had a distinct smell to it. :( The previous occupant upon exiting told me that the smell wasn't her fault!
author: Beth G.

description:
Awesome beer, awesome food and super friendly staff. If you have a problem with this place you probably have a problem with yourself.

I've tried most of the food (salads, oysters, appetizers, chicken, steak) and was always pleasantly surprised. Really tasty stuff!!

And Belgium beer..Belgians deserve the beer reputation that Germany has, more than Germany itself. Actually, they deserve even more props. If you don't know much about BelgyBeer try the Delirium Tremens, Rochefort 6 and Duvel.

After 2 years still one of my favorite places in SF
author: Clovis S.

description: Rude rude rude and food ok bartender sucked and a  lot of bottled beers not what we expected so sad
author: Maria A.

description:
La Trappe is a land of wondrous Belgian beers, 99% of which you've never heard of before. If you were Harry Potter in his first year, their beer menu would be like your spell book - together you could be magical, if only you knew how to read the darn thing. How do they expect you to translate 25CL and half L and 33 CL into ounces, especially after a beer or two?! 

Service is horrific. I came in on a Saturday night; the hostess told me to go downstairs. The hostess downstairs told me to go upstairs. During the 30 seconds I spent climbing stairs, the original hostess had completely wiped her memory of my appearance, and redirected me downstairs. 

Food is a-ok. My friend ordered the seared ahi tuna salad, which took about 40 minutes to prepare. Were they waiting for tomatoes to ripen in their kitchen? I mean, that's the only plausible reason I can think of for taking 40 minutes to make a salad when the place isn't packed. All told, it took us about 2 hours to place our orders and get our food. The only thing that arrived promptly was the check.

Between the snail-like service, the fact that I was crowded into a corner seat by the window, and my Groundhog Day-like encounter with the hostess, I couldn't wait to get out of there. Come to La Trappe, feel Le Trapped.
author: Sherry W.

description:
Whenever I mention that there's a beer cave in North Beach, any person I'm near with any amount of testosterone becomes inexplicably hyper aroused and excited. 

The owner is extremely nice and very helpful in navigating their giant selection of beers, and even poured us a few italian beers to try (rare and extremely delicious). 

My beardy beer loving manfriend instantly bonded with him and made many whispered promises to return. I like any place that fosters that type of immediate bro-love. The bar itself is more cozy, less cavey feeling than one would expect.
author: Selina K.

description:
I went here last night with my boyfriend and his parents who were visiting from the midwest.  Realized I had eaten here a couple years ago when my sister and bro-in-law were north beach residents.  We got there around 7 and got a nice table for four downstairs (highly recommend eating downstairs) without a reservation.  The place did get busy in the next hour though as there was also a birthday party there. 

I'm not drinking beer right now but if I was, I def would've enjoyed ordering off the extensive beer menu.  We shared a nice Cabernet which was good.

I had the grass fed steak of the day... a special Japanese cow that received massages though out its life and contains special amino acids that other beef doesn't.  Interesting!  It was delicious.  I tried via my beau and his folks, the white sausage, the pork, and the beef stew and everything was tasty.  The french fries, honestly, were off the chain, and the dipping sauces delicious.  I believe the spicy chipotle was my favorite.  

My only real complaint was it took close to an hour to receive our food once we ordered.  They also seemed short-staffed.... there was one guy handling all the tables downstairs I think so though he was a friendly waiter, we didn't see him quite enough. We were starving by the time our food arrived.  My final request would also be more seasonal veggies on the plate to balance the amount of red meat and potato goin' on.  

I would probably eat here again.. great place to go before your show at Cobb's Comedy Club.  Nice ambiance, good food, great drinks.
author: Leslie J.

description:
very wide selection of beers ;) and also have the specific type of glassware for the beer you order!

LOOOOVE it!!

must come back again when im in town!!!!!!!
author: Eunice K.

description:
I was in heaven the 4 days I was in Brussels. I sampled so many glasses of deliciousness that I actually got locked out of my hotel. I could not cross the border before stocking up at a Belgian supermarket. I sobbed when I left. 

Enter La Trappe. Almost all that I missed about the land of Manikin Piss and Belgian Waffle are found once you make your way down the spiral staircase to the basement of joy... sans Manikin Piss and Belgian waffle. 

Once you're down there you can enjoy a world of Belgian bliss. From the honey-ish Barbar to the tart Cantillion to the quirky Kwak and the golden Afligem, they are among the many pleasures awaiting you downstairs. Ask the folks behind the bar for a recommendation. They know their stuff. 

They tried to pull one on me a while ago when I asked if they had Straffe Hendrik. They told me the monks had stopped making it but "this" is the new stuff. Strange since it was just a month since Brussels. Now they have Straffe Hendrik on tap, albeit on rotation. I hold no grudge. I knew the monks could never fail me and kudos to La Trappe for bringing it in, on tap no less. It's delicious. Go get yourself some Straffe.

The food's okay. It is a fair representation of Belgian food with the expected mussels and pomme frites but have no doubt, the delights here come in glasses.
author: Jon L.

description:
I would like to give this place a 5 but since I have only been once...4 it gets. 

After a day of Macworld, I came here with a few close friends.  Luckily we got here right before the dinner rush so we were able to be seated with no problems. I would say if we got in about 30 min later...we would have had to wait to get seated

The beer menu is like 30+ pages long with at least 5 beers w/ description per page.  The food menu on the other hand is like a page front and back.  

We all tried to order something different... in short it was all yummeriffic!!~ 

Mac n cheese was delish.  
Oysters w/ the sauces were nom.  
Mussels...I dun even know how to describe the awesomness. 
The salad with salmon n goat cheese was full of flavor...just enough dressing too. 
Oh!!~ the fries...the fries were just like any ordinary fry, but the have 11 different dipping sauces...since we couldn't decide we had 1 of each.
author: aja h.

description:
HUGE beer selection and amazing food!

I came here with some friends for a quick dinner before a show. We didn't put too much thought into where we would have dinner and so ended up here. 

I would count the chicken waterzooi as one of the BEST dishes I've ever eaten in my entire life. Seriously. Dip the crusty bread in the sauce and top with the chicken and cabbage and it's like heaven. I haven't been able to stop thinking about it!
There is also a very relaxed atmosphere while maintaining a nice-ish restaurant feel. I will definitely be coming back.
author: Alicia B.

description:
La Trappe is Mecca for Belgian beer addicts.

With a good selection of beers (Belgian and otherwise) on tap and a overwhelming number by the bottle, La Trappe rocks.  The knowledgeable bar tenders can not only suggest a beer that will match each individual's taste preferences, but also adeptly pair beer with different foods.

While beer is the star at La Trappe, the food is no slouch either.  Slightly spicy, the Thai mussels were delicious.  Crispy on the outside and soft and creamy in the center, the fries were perfectly cooked.  Also there is a plethora of dipping sauces--from roasted garlic mayo and Dijon mustard to spicy ketchup.

Service was pleasant, if a little slow.  Be sure to arrive early, as the place fills up by 7:00. 

So many beers; so little time ...
author: CJ G.

description:
I'm so sad to have to write this update. I think La Trappe must be under new management and it pains me to write this review. 

First off, new management doesn't let you taste any of the beers that are on draft. They used to let you do that to make sure you were going to enjoy your $8+ beer. 
Second, the food was not as good. I used to love the chipotle mayo and fries (not that complicated, right?) and I would not order them again. 

The mussels were fishy, used to love them...

Finally, WORST of all. We were there for my husband's birthday and they called last call. He ordered a beer and within 5 minutes, some rude man came around grabbing all our beers. He took both of my friend's beers and my own without even letting us take a last sip. THEN, he took my husband's HALF FULL beer out of his hand WHILE HE WAS DRINKING it. Don't call last call or let people order beer if you're just going to take it away 5 minutes later. PLUS, their beers are expensive. I don't know if I can go back. The only way I would is if I heard they changed management again. 

Sadly disappointed....this was our favorite Belgian beer house. This is where I became exposed to all the delicious Belgian brews and now I don't want to go back. :(
author: Anne D.

description:
5 stars for La Trappe just based on the ambiance and beer list. What a great, cozy place to go during the winter to enjoy one of the best beer lists around. So many great choices it is a bit overwhelming, but all of our waiters were engaging and willing to help out. I could go on and on about the great ambiance and decor but let's just say it makes the place.

We also ate dinner and the food was a solid 3 stars. We started with a large pot of mussels with a great tomato sauce, everything was good but we were woefully short of the tasty sauce, which kills a mussels dish. We also shared a burger and two pork chops with other people in our group. They both were decent, nothing terrible, nothing outstanding, pretty average. I feel like there is a lot of competition for pork chops in SF and this one didn't stand up. 

Definitely come here for the bar and ambiance downstairs, it's a fantastic beer bar. There are literally hundreds on their list. I'd say stick to bar food if you're going to order food, or just skip it and order yourself another beer or two....
author: Kate N.

description: We were recommended this place. It was a rainy late Thursday night, and the only thing I wanted was something homey and relaxed (I was afraid this will be too posh). This place was just what I needed, the basement had a lovely and comforting feel, and it also delivered with food and drinks. I had the best veggie portobello burger I have ever had, the pesto complimented the whole dish beautifully, and the fries were to die for! I only want double cooked, Belgian fries from now on!! I'm not a big fan of beer, but whatever Clayton recommended to me (I don't remember at all) was a big hit, and I ordered another round. Overall, a very lovely place with great beer and food selection, and with an amazing staff. I highly recommend!
author: Nat C.

description:
My friends and I came here for my birthday dinner and we all loved it.  True to form all the girls showed up about an hour late, so the guys waited patiently drinking beers at the bar until we arrived.

The whole establishment is small and cozy.  Everyone that worked there was very friendly and when we finally showed up our waiter helped us pick out beers that would suit our likings.  We shared the french fry appetizers. Lots and lots of homemade sauces to chose from.  We had everything from soup, to mussels, to mac n cheese, to burgers (portobello and 100% grass fed organic).  Everything we ordered was delicious.  

I just love this place. Love love love. Great place for an intimate dinner or just to grab some appetizers and drinks with friends after work.
author: Jessica F.

description:
This place is amazing. As a beer lover from Belgium visiting San Francisco I was amazed by their selection of Belgian beers and authentic Belgian food. The place looks the part too and the owner is super cool too.

This place is the real deal, take my word for it.
author: Yoni D.

description: I've been to my share of Belgian beer bars in Los Angeles, and this one blows them all away. The key here is not so much the selection, which is still very good, but the food. It's rare to find a bar that does steak and fries the right way, and the Boudin Blanc is done to equal perfection. Don't pass up this bar, it's one of a kind.
author: Brett D.

description: Delicious muscles and steak frites, but it's all about the beer selection
author: Cass G.

description:
We went here because my boyfriend wanted to get some belgian beers. They do have a large selection, but it's not worth a large selection to spend time and money here. Here's why:

1. Cleanliness: The napkins all had little dust bits of fabric in them... when opened, all of these dust fabric bits flew all over ourselves and the table. These little fabric bits I speak of were also in our water glasses. Deal breaker: my boyfriend's cutlery had dried mustard on it.

2. Poor service: It took over 5 minutes for us to get our beers and we were one of the only tables in the restaurant (this should have tipped us off not to come here... it was 8 pm on a Saturday). The waitress sneakily upsold my friend on the cheeseburger ("eg. what type of cheese would you like with that?" when cheese was an extra $1.)... not that $1 is an incredible amount or that he wouldn't have ordered cheese anyway, but I didn't appreciate this sneaky upsell. 

3. Bad food:  My boyfriend and friend got burgers (not done to temperature requested) and I got the hot dog. Burgers were bland, fries were limp and likely out of some Ore-Ida bag. Sausage was a sausage with some mustard at $10. I asked if they could make me the portobello sandwich, but not fry it. She said it's all "preprepared" so she couldn't swing it. This indicates to me that much of the food they serve here is frozen and going straight into a microwave or deep fryer. 

4. Horrific value: Bad burgers for $15, bland sausage for $10 (beers were also $10, but I think that's pretty standard for the beer we ordered). 

Bottom line: Poor service, bland food, inflated prices. DO NOT EAT HERE.
author: Kate B.

description:
Saturday night before 7pm no trouble getting a table down stairs in the cellar after a warm welcome at street level in the bar. 

The underground windowless dining area is actually pretty cool and cosy.  The never ending beer list all cross referenced and educational - kind of got my head spinning and to be honest I don't remember which beer I downed two glasses of. It was German - I remember that and quite good if a little small. 

We ordered croquettes which were nice if a little underwhelming and dull. 

Mussels two different ways for main -- with Belgian fries and dipping mayo both were well prepared and presented and great service throughout. Holding off on the bread until we were both down to the mussel free broth was a nice touch, if that is in fact why the bread came then ...?

I would have given three stars were it not for the service, good mussels and interesting setting. 

Go here.
author: Mel R.

description:
This is a really awesome bar. The upstairs restaurant was deserted and looked closed on a Friday night, but my friend led me in and down the curved staircase in the center of the room, and suddenly I was in a super friendly local scene filled with great Belgian beer and food. 
I don't even know what I drank because the bartender kept making amazing recommendations. I liked everything.
My favorite food thing was by far the polenta with mushrooms. Noms.
author: Tasha D.

description:
I'm not a Belgian beer expert, but I'm starting to really enjoy drinking and finding places that specializes in Belgian beers. I'm not local, so a friend, who has been in SF for a couple years, told me this was one of the first places he found. This was my last night in SF, and I got to say, great place to finish the trip.

So when you walk in it looks like your normal cafe/sit down place. However, there's a spiral staircase that leads to where the good stuff is. It's a little dark down there, but your eyes will adjust. Tables, booths, old wood, a bar and zero flat screen tvs reside downstairs.

Looking at their beer menu, it's massive. Asian karaoke song book massive. I recall trying to pronounce the names because the bartender jokingly said you can't point at the beer you want, you have to attempt to say the name. My first beer was a quadruple (unfortunately I can't recall the name because it was 6 words long), so it was a little sweet & raisiny tasting. I actually really enjoyed that one. My second beer was a St. Bernadus Abt 12. I remember this one because the monk on the label looked like he was really enjoying his beer (as was I).

I really wanted to sneak one of the Belgian beer specific chalices out. It just a different feeling when you drink out of a Belgian beer glass. I would have drank my OJ out of it.

The only issue I had really was that it got pretty warm down in the basement. I know San Franciscans are sensitive to cold air, but a little AC would be great (how about an oscillating fan or two).
author: George Y.

description:
3.5/5

Great selection of beers, lots of seating, and well decorated.

The food was OK, but not great. And the service was mediocre.

I've been here twice; on a Tuesday and a Thursday. I've never experienced such slow service before. Waited 15mins+ to serve a beer. Orders were wrong. Food took almost an hour. I don't understand how such simple food could take that long, and on a Tuesday.
author: Andrew D.

description:
When you come somewhere like this, with a beer list like this, you want a bartender like Jeremy.
Quick to judge you based on your initial request, if he likes what he hears, he'll be your best friend; if he doesn't - he'll probably introduce you to a great new beer that you never would've considered (or he might glower and scoff - it's hard to tell for sure).
Out of the kriek I initially wanted, he recommended a back up that I actually liked BETTER than the beer I had requested.  He was chatty, very knowledgeable, and had good taste in music.  You may not always be able to take advantage of these things when it's packed, and for that, I suggest going early.  You're going to need time with that beer list anyway.
author: Jennifer D.

description: As expected from a place called 'La Trappe', they have a great selection of Belgian ales, and the food to match.  Service was decent if not noteworthy, nice, quiet ambience in the downstairs room.  I had mussels & frites, which were delicious as you expect seafood in San Francisco to be.
author: Spencer S.

description: Great beer list. Cool downstairs cavern. Order the mussels and fries with dipping sauces then walk it off over at Washington square park up the street
author: Martin R.

description: Steak Frite and a St. Bernardus Prior 8. Awesome. Service...Awesome. Great ambiance. Highly recommended, especially if you dig the Belgian.
author: Jerry K.

description: Went back a few weeks ago, enjoyed the food and service.
author: Andrew B.

description:
So I started out the day thinking this was going to be a fun bar. I came here with a group of about 20 of us. We ordered drinks and tipped very well. Then someone near us spilled a drink and they blamed our group. I was right there and you can trust me our group had nothing to do with it. But, me being the nice guy I am I paid for the guys drink. He immediately became a friend of ours and it was all good. A few minutes later we are all talking and owner comes down stairs yelling at us for no reason. He himself knocks a few drinks over and blames us and then kicks us out. No wonder we weren't happy. Anyway, this is the last time I will be letting any of my friends come here. Please take my word for it, go pretty much anywhere else but here and you will have a more affordable and better time!

Also keep an eye out for the owner. He is a semi scrawny rude guy who is always looking out to get the extra buck or two. Do not trust anyone in there. I am a local and I am telling you stay away from this place!
author: Jason M.

description:
Came here last Friday before seeing Chappell at Cobb's. I had the mussels Mariniere (white wine and  white beer sauce reduction with lemon, shallots, and fresh herbs) and the boy a burger. 

First of all, i was a bit taken aback by the ginormous cauldron that contained the mussels when it arrived. These people meant business when it comes to seafood. Since the dish came with fries, I get my pick of two condiments. I decided on the peanut sauce and wasabi mayo. I also tried Orin's roasted red bell pepper mayo; think that was my favorite. The fries had a lovely crispiness and mushy on the inside, just the way I like it. The mussels were plump although I think the French do it much better. 

We had a rather rushed dinner, but the place looks great for groups. Will definitely come back with more people next time and try out more things on the menu.
author: Alice W.

description:
Humongous beer menu and moules frites. What else do you need? This felts like like a legit Belgian pub. I've always really liked the food here and trying all the different types of beers. 

The service was a little meh. We talked to a guy at the front who didn't know anything but continued to talk to us. The bartenders were great but it took us a while to get seated since there were 8 of us. Then once we got seated, the service was pretty slow. I guess that's what you get for going out on a crazy Tuesday night?
author: Kara Y.

description: I love this place! Great food & beer selection, love the ambiance, and wonderful servers. I've been here with both large and small groups and we were really well cared for on each occasion. I recommend this place to all my beer-snob friends.
author: J. W.

description:
What happened?! After only hearing positive things, I was super excited to go all in at La Trappe. 

Here's what I loved: the downstairs space and gargantuan beer list, super friendly waiter.

Here's what I didn't love: 

- We were told to sit anywhere downstairs since it was empty, and 5 minutes later asked to move because a big party was coming in and had the space reserved. No biggie...but an hour later....no one was occupying the space.
- Bartender on duty didn't know anything about the beers (what?!) not acceptable at this type of joint.
- I opted for wine (I know, weird), and when presented with the list, said bartender mentioned those weren't actually the wines available...again...what?!
- Food came out ambient temperature. We tried the croquettes, brussels, and beef stew which all had good flavor, but were cold. I nicely asked the waiter if he wouldn't mind having it heated, which he was happy to do, but offered up the "fact" that Belgian food is typically served luke warm. Am I totally out of the loop with this? I'll give him the benefit of the doubt...sine I'm far from being Belgian...but really, I just wanted piping hot beef stew.
 
Sadly, probably won't be back...
author: Brianna M.

description:
In my desperate attempt to love La Trappe again, I went back last night for drinks and dinner -- and left 30 minutes later fully deflated and disappointed. La Trappe is where you go to be ignored and mistreated by the staff -- the group of 8 who walked out in front of us are a testament to this.

Pull it together or lose all of your local customers.
author: Andy S.

description:
Come here for the beer.  If you love beer - especially Belgium beer - look no further.  The bartenders have real experience - we're talking they GO to a trip to Belgium every year to TASTE test beer. 

You know a place is legit when not only do they pour your beer right, they know how to pronounce it and describe it's flavor and body in great detail.

The place is also unique - the downstairs looks like a cross between a European dungeon and a brick mill house.  That doesn't sound appealing - but it is :)
author: Lauren B.

description:
One of our favorite stops in San Fran.

Jeremy the bartender is as good as it gets.  He LISTENED to our tastes and had the know-how to find the right match every.single.time.  

The beer selection here is just fantastic.  But don't bother reading the Beer Bible.  Just drink what Jeremy says to drink and you will be happy.

The scene is a little dark, a little divey, a little loungy.  We loved it :)
author: Lucy L.

description: Really impressive beer list! Mike is a beer authority. He really knows his stuff, and is a fantastic host! We wished we had two stomachs so we could've tried his Flemish Beef Stew and Waterzooi. Judging by the frites and croquettes, they are most likely authentic and delicious. This place is so great, it can even make two curmudgeons from Philly happy! ;)
author: J C.

description: I started to give this place a 4 star rating. The 5th star was added for Gabe who totally added to the meal on a lot of levels.  Worth a visit and  wait if needed. The oysters could have had a little more oomph, but I still stick with my rating.
author: Ifti K.

description: Used to love this place until I ran into the friday afternoon bartender Adam! What a clown, he claimed to be the manager, poured a glass of foam and tried to peddal it off as a specialty pour.  When we called his bluff he said that was the way he pulled beer and if we didn't like it we could leave!  I think someone forgot to tell this joker there are about half a million bars in San Francisco ;). I suspect the owner doesn't feel the same way he does about beer loving customers.
author: william b.

description:
The beer here is legit. If you love crafty beers on draft, this place will be pure heaven. I had the Peche Mel and the Duchess here. Both were delicious. If you like strong fruit flavored beers, the peche mel is the way to go. Please stop and smell it before your first sip. Its fragrance is absolutely delightful and totally fruity without being overly powerful. The duchess is a sour beer that pretty much tastes like black cherry champagne. I'm HOOKED. A glass of the beers will cost you $8.50-$9.50 on average. There are more expensive bottled beers available if you want to go all out. As an amateur of craft beers however, I'm well satisfied with the $8-$9 selections.

The ambiance is warm, cozy, and underground. One star off for being sat next to a huge portrait of Edith Piaf's stuffed dead cat. Its face is literally grotesque. It looked like it was rotting and molting all at once. Not exactly the most appetizing view, which is a shame because the food is so very appetizing.

For example, take the Belgian fries. You can choose from a variety of  dipping to accompany them. From roasted garlic mayo to dijon mustard or spicy ketchup, these fries are sure to delight the palette. I also had the Chicken Videe which was shredded chicken cooked in yummy cream sauce and baked in a flaky, puffed pastry. I was afraid it would taste like chicken pot pie (which I do not enjoy), but to my surprise it was really great! Not too salty and not too heavy (which summarizes how I feel about chicken pot pie). The Chicken Videe is served over a bed of greens, which creates a really nice balance.

I will definitely come back to this place to try more beers and eat more delicious food!
author: Evonne L.

description:
A Gem!

You know the drill, great food and astounding beer selection.  A beer selection primarily geared towards pleasing the Belgian enthusiast (because lets face it, the Monks knew what they were doing).  If you are like me, this place is your personal treasure trove!

Plus, the downstairs bar is in cahoots with ambiance!  Straight outta Inglorious Bastards, spiral staircase shootout and all.  Minus however, the East German accents and all the drinking beer out of boots.
author: Aaron A.

description:
Great place for Belgian food and beer.

The main restaurant/bar area is downstairs from the street level entrance. It's quite dark, but very cosy. You might need a keychain light or your cell phone light app to read the menus.

Keyte Dobbel Tripel - A strong, dark, ale with great flavor and extremely smooth

Fleur de Houblon - A refreshing and light summer ale

Belgian fries - A must. All the dipping sauces are pretty good. I like the chipotle bbq mayo.

Chicken Waterzooi - A hearty stew with chicken, potatoes, leeks, and onions. The cream sauce was delicious.

Come early, it gets packed. We were the first to sit downstairs as the kitchen had not opened yet. 

They have an extensive book of beers by the bottle and also more details for some of the current drafts. Service was great.
author: Kenny J.

description: Stopped by here at 8 on a Wednesday and it was closed. We were really looking forward to the food, sad that yelp said it was open and the entire place was dark with no sign.
author: Heather L.

description:
Brought a group of 13 here for my boyfriend's birthday. Unfortunately, when I called and they said they didn't take reservations, they failed to mention that they couldn't accommodate a table for 13, period. So, when we got there, there was som confusion. They did end up moving a table so that they could break us up in to three tables and sit us promptly. 100% made up and very appreciated. 

The food as usual was good, the beer and wine, great. The server was very sweet and while she was SUPER busy, she was still able to be pretty attentive to us; although, we found it far easier and faster to order our drinks at the bar instead of at our table. We felt a little guilty for this, but she was extremely busy. We still tipped her well. 

All in all, this place is always a good time. I wouldn't recommend coming here if you're larger than a group of 6, but that's about it. 

Thanks for making my boyfriend's birthday a success!
author: Noneya B.

description:
La Trappe caught me on a downward spiral...

On the tail end of a hellaciously fast-paced week, eyeing a red-eye flight to Detroit (of all places), already jet lagged and feigning time zone stability...I had one last meal to enjoy in beautiful San Francisco. 

And by a stroke of fate and a drop of excellent beer...La Trappe was the destination, by no fault or choice of my own. Chalk it up to swell colleagues originating from 3 different countries. International flava' dinner, indeed. Not too crowded despite the hour on a Friday evening, and even kind enough to stow my suitcase while I imbibed. 

As many reviews have already stated...downstairs is where its at. Something with the lighting and the formica in the upstairs lends itself to a bit more "geriatric" and a bit less "beer sexy." The lower level is dimly lit, heartily furnished, buzzing at a key level and feels a bit more...well, underground. 

An Affligem Blond met me at my table...and was quickly followed by an organic heirloom cider. Both prepped me ostensibly for the fuckofaflight I was about to embark on. Kudos, fine Belgian brewers and organic cider makers. I'd reorder either of these beverages in a quick second. 

As for the food? Well, not a miss in the bunch. The asparagus was delightful, my nicoise salad was quite perfect, lush and well-portioned...especially for a spot known more for schnitzel and frites. Oh, and I may have snuck a few frites with aioli for good measure, what would a beer be without them? Full of carbs. Well, stick a fork in me...I'm done.

The service was impeccable, and though it began to hop as the drinking hour approached...never did we feel rushed out of our cozy, comfy booth for 4. Not a once...so as I retrieved my suitcase to head to SFO, I swigged the last drops, bid La Trappe farewell, and thanked it for a string of legitimately enjoyable moments filled with coworkers-cum-comrades, Belgian ale and the kind of smiles only born by way of genuine surprise and elation. And bad date stories.
author: Colleen C.

description:
Really wanted to love this place. We live in the neighborhood and immediately found the downstairs vibe so fun. We came one time before, and waited about 45 min for our food, but wanted to give it another chance because the atmosphere was cool and it seemed like the perfect place to have a late dinner and some drinks. 

Unfortunately, our second time even worse than our first. They were out of the first beer my boyfriend tried to order and out of the first 2 glasses of wine I tried to order, so it literally took 35 min to get our first drink. 

Two bread baskets later, we are still waiting for our food. We were told there was a large party that "was taking up all the burners." The large party was about 10 people, and the restaurant did not seem that busy. Fast forward to an hour and 15 minutes later, we were laughing with the table next to us about how starving we were, and how hard it was to track down a waiter. 

The wait staff seemed to express their condolences, but when the bill came, nothing (not even the glass of wine I waited 35 min for) was comped. I, personally, am usually happy with mediocre service - I just want to order some drinks and not wait over an hour for food. This experience really was terrible, not one good thing to say about it, and I hope the management takes this experience into consideration so this place can live up to its potential.
author: Maddy D.

description: We stopped by last night for a beer or more. My beer was empty for at least 10 minutes before the bartender acknowledged my empty glass. By that time my husband's glass was empty and we had decided to leave. I love Belgian beers so I wanted to stay longer but the bartender ruined the experience. I'm sure we'll try again and hopefully the bartender will be better.
author: Danielle C.

description:
This is one of my favorite places in San Fran.  It is only open certain nights so check before you go.

From the street it looks really quiet and that's because all of the action is downstairs.  The upstairs tables are frequently empty meanwhile it is heaving downstairs.  The beer is amazing - huge number of incredible Belgian drafts.  

The food is typical Belgian fare with Mussels and Waterzooi.  Also be sure to try the assorted selections of mayonnaise with your frites. Yum.
author: Michael C.

description: Lackluster service. My friends and I came here on a Friday night and patiently waited over a hour on a waitlist for a booth to open up to seat 6+. After a hour wait we were excited when a table opened and we took our righteous spot as #1 on the wait list. We were then kicked out and our table given to a group of 4 as "they requested a booth" but weren't on a list. On a busy Friday night they don't much care for locals and their customer service. In a city full of places trying to gain customers, never going here again due to the bad service. The long list of beers don't justify the terrible service.
author: Tiffany K.

description:
Mikey likey

We arrived to the restaurant and it was totally empty! Sounds crazy right, well it was cause I noticed there is a downstairs and that's the place to be so when you arrived head to the cellar. I loved the atmosphere. The food was good, we had a small green salad and a couple different types of mussles. The service was attentive, knowledgeable and friendly. I had 2 beers I'd never had before let alone heard of and both were great. I like this spot a lot and will return again
author: Michael B.

description:
A really kick ass feel to this place stepping down to the dungeon like bar w/mini waterfall backdrop

An awesome burger and the best Belgian beers you can't pronounce live here
author: Clark G.

description:
Love the selection of Belgian brews in this place. I would stick to what is on tap for that day. They have the big ol' binder of beers from everywhere, but those command a premium. Better yet, they have delicious fries (with a dizzying array of sauces if you pay another $1.50) and steamed mussels. The staff are nice, if a little curt.

Another way to think about it if you aren't generally a fan of paying a larger premium for Belgians. If you consider the cost of the stuff on tap in $/ML of pure alcohol, I would say that the beers here are a bargain compared to your neighborhood local, since you can get a 10-11% beer for $9. ;)
author: Josh K.

description:
I was pretty much in love at first sip. But it wasn't just their drafts that were delicious.... the bartender was able to help me select from their enormous menu a Belgian that fit my taste.

And when I thought it couldn't get better, I had the mussels for dinner. So. Amazing. I can't wait to come back!
author: Jess C.

description: Don't tell anyone! Once you go, you'll want to keep it all to yourself. 300 or 400 different beers, great mussels and fries.
author: Joshua G.

description:
Been here twice now and plan to make a lot more trips when I have the time between school and work. I love that this place has opened my eyes to beer. As a person who grew up with hicks drinking Coors and Bud, I couldn't stand beer. La Trappes staff and the help of my Brother In Law have made me a Belgian and IPA fan! 

If you like beer or don't know anything about beer, GO HERE! You will be handed a giant book of brews and their info. The bar tender/waiter will help you choose something or recommend some awesome stuff based on your tastes. In the mean time order some REDONKULOUS tasty frites and enjoy! 

Just expect to spend a pretty penny on beer. GOOD beer is not cheap. Shitty beer and other alcohol is. If you are looking to just get wasted this probably isn't the place for you. :/
author: Brie S.

description:
Oh god, I have a serious problem with this place. I love Belgian food. I love Belgian beer. I have acid reflux. This is not a great combination.

For a while, I was taking people here every two weeks. Someone would visit, and I would insist that they come to La Trappe. It's actually one of my favorite bars in San Francisco. I came here during SF Beer week and sampled cheeses with beer pairings (oh man, I feel so refined). If you are intimidated by their album of a menu, stick to the first page. Their draft beers have never steered me wrong (Except for that one time a friend of mine ordered a beer that was very reminiscent of soy sauce. But 1/25 beers I've tasted here is not a terrible ratio). 

The food here is also delicious, but avoid the burgers because I feel they're not up to the same standard as the rest of their food. Mussels + fries are delicious. The fries come with two dipping sauces, so choose wisely! I like wasabi mayo and curry ketchup, but to be honest, I haven't tried every sauce yet. The boudin blanc is also amazing. If you don't know what it is, look it up, because it's so suggestive sounding that I really shouldn't describe it in a review...Their fish is also pretty good.

Basically, it's difficult to go wrong here. Give it a shot! You'll probably be hooked :)
author: Angeline P.

description:
As if you haven't heard it before, the beer list here is simply majestic.  Was in SF on business and we made a pact to hit a different Brewpub each night.  Well this place isn't actually a brew pub, but after reading the numerous awesome reviews on Yelp, we moved this up on our to-do list.  

Went with the Steak and Fries for the dinner.  Steak was good, a little fatty, the fries were excellent as was the peanut sauce that I had to dip them in.  

The atmosphere in this place is awesome, dark dungeoness but still inviting.  The beer list was why we came so we didn't let the food disappoint.  Not that the food was bad, I've just had better elsewhere.  Now the beer list is why I would give this place 6 stars if I could.  My friend and I did our best to work our way through as much of the beer book as we could :-)  I soooo   wish we had something like this back in NY.  

Our waitress, I think her name was Theresa was very helpful with suggestions based on the style that we wanted to drink.  Being a self confessed Bud-Light drinker prior to working at La Trappe her selections were spot on.

I would definitely hit this place up again if I ever find myself in San Francisco in the future...   

Maybe my only complaint is that last call was a little early.  It was a Wed. night and we'd
author: Timothy W.

description: Mariniere mussels were yummy and well-priced. Bartender also brought us 2 half glasses of Gouden Carolus Cuvee van de Keizer Blauw on the house. Friendly service. Will come back.
author: Emily W.

description: 400 bottles of Belgian beer and then some on tap?  Yes please.  Three of us came here last Saturday at 5pm.  I had the best Belgian IPA I've ever had, the Hop Verdomme.  It was lighter and more crisp than a regular IPA, and didn't leave your mouth dry afterward.  We shared a large cheese plate with four different types of cheese, figs, gherkins, olives, grapes, honey, and olive bread.  Thank goodness there were some snacks because I was pretty tipsy after drinking just one, which contained nearly 8% alcohol! Great service from the bartender downstairs.
author: Elise G.

description:
I love this place, but I have a weakness for authentic belgian beer, mussels and frites, and it's really hard to find an authentic Belgian restaurant in the city.

Be sure to head downstairs where they have the bar seating and better atmosphere.
author: Jeff A.

description:
La Trappe is conveniently located in our neighborhood, and Mr. Brooklyn and I have enjoyed their massive selection of beers and tasty food. We were looking forward to dinner there this evening. When we arrived, a hostess told us that there would be a 20-minute wait for a table, and she took down my name and physical description (I was the only redhead in a black jacket at the bar, and probably the entire restaurant). 45 minutes later, we saw that we were finally next on the waiting list. Elation turned to frustration turned into pissed-off redhead when we saw that a couple who arrived after us was seated. When we confronted the waitress, she said that she didn't see anyone fitting my description (and I guess she didn't feel the need to, you know, take the arduous step of calling out my name to verify whether I was still there).

La Trappe wasted my time once, and they won't get the chance again. We'll be getting our frites and beer fix elsewhere.
author: Brooklyn R.

description: I came in early on a Saturday evening (around 6: 45) with three other people and had a beer at the bar after defaulting to a draft beer that sounded good in the very large beer book.  It was a blonde ale that was delicious! We were seated quickly as the tables were still mostly empty and I ordered the spicy tomato mussels which were sooooo delicious!  Great place to hang out and catch up with friends if you get there early enough.  By the time we left there was quite the wait, so we made the right move in getting there a bit early.  I would love to go back and sample more of their beers/sit at the bar where the customers seemed to be getting some advice from the bartenders.  It's a little overwhelming in terms of beer selection otherwise!
author: Raina D.

description: It is always a pleasure to be at La Trappe. I enjoy the variety of beer , albeit mainly Belgian beer . The bar tender is a encyclopedia of beer knowledge. I love to learn something and get drunk !
author: Aditya V.

description:
I met a friend here for dinner and I was apprehensive at first because the place looked completely empty. When I realized there was seating downstairs as well I ventured down the spiral staircase and was delighted to find the underground is a lively yet cozy pub with a distinctly European vibe. 

We ordered the mussels which I enjoyed. The fries are a must.The choices in dipping sauces and the choice in beer (200+) can be overwhelming for an indecisive person like myself but luckily I had a more decisive friend with me. 

Great ambiance, great drinks, good food.
author: Kathryn V.

description: I love this place! A friend lives around the corner and it's our go-to spot. We are never disappointed - always get great service and enjoy the wonderful, interesting selection of beer, and food that's a welcome change from the usual run-of-the-mill SF offerings. Our dinner a couple of weeks ago was especially memorable - great service from Gabe, the long time waiter who's there for everything you need but not intrusive, and we were blown away by the new busboy, Jason, who was absolutely fantastic. Since we were there early, the owner's wife and baby stopped by for a quick visit. This is exactly the kind of business I hope is around for a very long time!
author: Mel R.

description:
5 Stars for the bar area!! I did not have food there so can't comment on that. This is a hidden gem in SF.. Reminded me of a few bars i visited in London..

Will definitely go back!!
author: Harita S.

description:
....North Beach.  I would imagine that we would eat at an Italian place, but he had other plans...

The downstairs was PACKED.  I mean packed. The bar top was filled and the booths and tables were filled with beer drinkers.  We somehow got the attention of a busser who put us on the wait list and also recommended beers for us.  We couldn't pronounce it for the life of us so he wrote them down for us to show the bartender.  Bartender wasn't too friendly, but I suspect it's because his bar was crowded and getting a bit out of control.  We got our drinks and sipped them and people-watched while we waited for a table to open up.  No more than 10 minutes is what it felt like when the Asian busser came to us and asked us if we wanted to sit upstairs.  

HELL YEAH!

We sat upstairs literally, next to the door, so cold air came around us everytime the door opened.  Pretty wack, BUT we wanted to sit and it's not their fault it's cold, right?  Later on through the meal, the table next to us left and our kind server let us scoot over so we weren't' next to the door.  

We ordered a few small plates.  the mussels and frites with the garlic white-wine, sardines and a smoked salmon salad. 

The mussels were the highlight of our dinner.  We just kept dipping our bread and fries into that gorgeous broth.  The mussels were ridiculously good-  and it didn't cost an arm and leg.  The sardines were on point too, grilled, served with lemon, fennel and a duo of herb sauces.  The smoked salmon arugula was great too-  served with a lemon vinaigrette, cherry tomatoes red onions and goat cheese. We also dipped our frites with the sauces they recommended.  Garlic mayo and spicy ketchup were good (We killed the garlic mayo first.  Duh)  I wanted to bring the mussels home, but for some odd reason, La Trappe doesn't allow guests to take home food?  Their excuse is because mussels go  bad.  Listen, I eat Chinese seafood all damn day, and I take that shiz home too.  It ain't bad, It's wasting!

I think the best part of our meal, aside from the mussels, was the service.  Not the bartender, really but more so our server and busser.  Our server was gracious, on-point and always around to help us.  The dining room was small and he somehow managed to practically dance the ballet weaving in and out of the limited space he had to drop off food.  I always appreciate good service, as I once did a heavy amount of time at the restaurant.  

He told us he had to work St Patty's day, so we hooked him up extra, cause nothing's worse than working on a night where you should be enjoying beer and festivities, NOT serving obnoxious, singing drunkards.  We'll be back!
author: Cat A.

description:
Plain and simple, you cannot beat La Trappe's beer selection and when you don't know what to pick, Mike the owner helps you pick the right beer like a Level 5 Sommelier helps you pick a fine wine! 

Don't bother coming here if you are planning to order a Coors Light or a Budweiser as you might not make it out alive.  This place has serious beer for serious beer drinkers!  Good news too... if you are bringing a date and they don't like beer, worry not.  Order them a Fruity Lambic or something along those lines.  The "Beer Bible" has a verse that will touch any person's heart.

I gave it 4 stars out of 5 because the dinner doesn't always wow me.  The fish of the day has been bland in the past and I give the burger a strong "B" grade.  Food highlights include oysters (always fresh), mussels, and Bugs Bunny Stew.  Desserts are worth a look too... we really liked the Ginger Snap Ice Cream Thing.
author: Ryan S.

description:
Wonderful decor, atmosphere, food and beer selection! I went here for a casual,fun work dinner and it couldn't be more perfect.  

The downstairs decorations and aesthetics made me feel like I was back in Belgium.  I love beer and I couldn't be happier with their huge beer selection! This place is definitely a must visit.  I recommend the pork loin special or the steak and fries; although really everything on the menu was great.
author: Svetlana F.

description:
Last stop on a pub crawl!  Dark - den dark - I liked it.  Squid Ink - black IPA- yummy!

TIP: Watch how much you drink down there, because going down the stairs is much easier than coming back up.  I'm just say'n.  

Also, if you like funky mayos and ketchups for your fries, this is your spot.  I always feel vanilla wanting the regular ketchup but the wasabi stuff is kinda good.  Don't judge me.
author: Rayna A.

description:
We came here to drink beer.  Down the stairs we went to the dungeon.  I almost expected to see people shackled to the walls.  Instead it was a dreary little wine cellar.  I had to stand under a light at the bar to read the beer list.  The more I read, the more confused I got.  Finally I asked one of my friends what they were drinking and ordered one of "those".  Next, the bartender offered me a sample of another beer and it was so damn good that I had to have one of "those" too.

The longer I sat at a table and drank my beer, the more the place grew on me.  It seemed to transform from a dark hole into an enchanting little pub.  I definitely have this place on my list of places to come back to.

If at first, the bartenders seem a little cold, give them some time and they will warm up to you.

The Wizard says; check it out.
author: Joe K.

description: I came here with my wife and another couple and we made our way downstairs to a comfortable and dark, but not particularly well decorated, bar area. I think I may have been drunk before coming in because all I remember afterwards is that I had a few tasty beers out of huge steins. I may have also had some food. I'm giving the place 4 stars because, for some inexplicable reason, it's found a warm and cozy corner of my subconscious.
author: Bobby N.

description:
+ Food is okay. I have to say it is true -  the mussels are great. But the fries and mac n cheese is nothing to write home about. 

- Service is lousy. 

+ Love the vibe and neighborhood. 

- WAY too expensive. Beer prices are ridiculous. 

I will most likely never return.
author: Carrie A.

description: Came here for NYE dinner and I was so impressed! We were immediately seated downstairs, by the bar at a table with a built in chessboard. When we asked our waitress if they had chess pieces, she was ecstatic - really happy to see people interested in playing and brought out a box of pieces. While we were playing, our food was brought out and the server made it a point to arrange our food without interrupting our game. The food itself was fantastic - I had the portobello mushroom burger AND IT WAS SO GOOD. Mouthwatering fried mushroom topped with goat cheese. We also split the belgium fries which were huge portion wise, and came with our choice 2 dipping sauces. We had the garlic mayo and the curry. I preferred the curry which had a spicy kick to it, but the garlic was good too even though I'm not a mayo fan. All in all, the service was exceptional and though the food may seem slightly on the pricy side, La Trappe is worth every penny.
author: Umeet S.

description:
Disclaimer, I had one beer here.  So I can't really say a whole lot in terms of the actual place...but i'm trying to reach 200 reviews, so I'm gonna do it.  

We left church key, which was awesome, but I had my heart set on a sour beer they had just recently sold out of...so it was on to la trappe.  It was late on a friday, and it was kind of dead.  My friend assured me the sneaky secretive downstairs bar (by secretive I just mean I didn't see it through the window outside) would be where it was at!   There were at least 10 people down there! 

They had sour beers, actually a bunch.  A great beer menu for sure.  Good service and lovely little booths to relax and chat in....I am a fan.  And I am coming back for sure to try les moules...
author: Kierstan G.

description: Endless options of beers and good snacks. The downstair place is great.
author: Truc N.

description:
Let's be clear...if you are going for a beer, this is a great place to go...that' is where both stars come in. 

For food, this is not where you want to be. and it would be three stars, but My GF got food poisoning from the mussels and the prices are way to high, I order the Beef Stew, it was $21 and was some beef in a water broth. It felt like they boiled beef in water and then served it...no veggies, and hardly any flavor. 

An amazing beer menu and friendly staff (One star for each).  Other than that, it's over priced and the seafood was not to be trusted.
author: Daniel D.

description:
The beer is great! Environment phenomenal! Service is very poor, to the point where you're frustrated that such a cool place has such awful service.  

Appetizers take 45 mins to an hour. It takes 2 hours to get seated. They don't do a good job at managing expectations. This place would have happier customers if they hired a few more servers. 

Figure this out and get 5 stars and more business.
author: Collin H.

description: The place to go if you want Belgian beer. Their selection was incredible. Had to be 500 bottles, and the owner said he has another 200 that aren't on the menu
author: Brett N.

description: Stopped by before a show at Cobbs. Let me just say; mussels, mussels, mussels!!! They have 4 different sauces of choice. One down, three to go.
author: Delois D.

description:
What a cool place!  Good ambiance, great food, yummy beer.  How could you go wrong?

It's definitely got a SF feel, a little on the expensive side, but definitely worth a visit.  The fries are really good; I highly recommend the roasted garlic mayo dipping sauce!  The Carbonnade a la Flammande, a delicious beef stew, was quite excellent and hearty.  The muscles were good, but not great.  I've had better...

I really like the layout of the place, but it gets really loud and overbearing with noise.  All that brick is nice, but doesn't do much to absorb the sound.  Easy on the eyes, not on the ears!

I'd head back for some beer and fries, but skip the main meal.  But I've heard during the weekdays it's not as busy, so I might try that too.
author: Greg S.

description:
The beer and meal was good, but a couple critiques. 

I could barely read the menu it was so dimly lit and I have 20/20 vision. 

The beer list is like an encyclopedia. I appreciate the in-depth descriptions of the beer I'm about to pay 10$ for! However- the description of my beer pointed out the "American hops flavor shines through" and that this beer was some of the best of "American craft brewing." When I got the beer and read the bottle, it proudly said 100% British hops and was a British brewery. Not a big deal because the beer was good, but a little odd to so completely describe the beer in print and have it be incorrect. 

Also, every time a table left a bus boy came to clean it and would spray the table and wipe it down. Great- except three times during our meal I unexpected inhaled a mouthful of Windex, which was rather off-putting. Good to know the tables are sanitized- however, a spritz of windex was not a good compliment to my trout.
author: Lindsay K.

description:
I'll keep this short and sweet:

I did not come her for the food since we just ate at Swan Oyster Depot less than an hour before. We walked in about 530 and it looked like there was nobody in the place but then we discovered the basement. If you just want to drink they said you can sit at the bar or the lounge, always looks good to have a pregnant girl at the bar I think so I suggested to my wife we go to the lounge. We got luck because there were no tables taken when we arrived in the lounge but in about 10 minutes the entire lounge which holds about 12 was filled. 

I tried these two beers and was happy with both. 

Allagash Black and Silly Scotch Ale, "scotch de silly".

Allagash Black was not very heavy IMHO and it was a little dry on the finish for my taste but I'd take it over many others I've tried. 

Silly Scotch Ale was nice and sweet without the strong taste of a strong ale although it still packed a punch of 9%. 

Another notable find on the bottle list was the Santa's Little Helper aged in Boubon Barrels which I've had before and love but did not want to spend $32 on the bottle. 

Over all cute, cozy, calm environment (at 6pm that is since I can see this place filling up quickly) to chill and taste a beer. I'd go back for sure if I lived there.
author: Kevin C.

description:
I've now been to La Trappe 5 times, and as much as I love some things about it (some tasty food, great beer menu, and cool atmosphere), I have to say that if they don't change something up with their "system" and general attitude of how to do business, they are probably going to crash and burn, because repeat customers like myself are no longer going to return.

I started off with a 4-star rating after the first visit (docked a star because they are closed on Sundays, which doesn't make sense to me... not very "European" either, to be honest), but I am going to start subtracting a star each time we visit and have a problem.  In fact, I'll probably give this place one more try, and if the experience is as flawed as the last few visits, I'll just stop coming here:

1) On THREE out of my 5 visits, the servers have been somewhat inept. This could be because they always seem new (management can't retain their employees?), and having an extensive beer menu and foreign names doesn't help anything, I'm sure.  That could explain why I was given an incorrect beer (which I didn't realize until tasting it)... but it DOESN'T account for the fact that two different waiters have spilled beer on us: the first time, they knocked a beer over on a nearby table, splashing everybody in the vicinity; the second time, they didn't seem to know how to pour the beer, and poured it way too steeply/directly, foaming up and overflowing the glass.

2) Last time we were there, we had a show to hit (Beach Blanket Babylon) 2 hours later, so we were on a time crunch, but that should have been plenty of time. We arrived early, and the place was pretty empty, so we were promptly seated and served. We made sure to order our food first (mussels, rabbit, and "Wallonian hot dog") to make sure it got started while we perused the beer menu.
Then our beers arrived, but it seemed to be taking a heck of a long time for the food... then I started looking around, and noticed: about 10 PEOPLE that had come in AFTER us were being served their meals (they weren't even in the restaurant when we arrived.)  We had difficulty flagging down the waiter, but when we did, we pointed out that we had ordered food 40 minutes earlier, and he said he would check on it... he brought 2 of the dishes but said "Sorry, the mussels are going to be a few minutes more... there was a bit of a backup."  If there was a backup, shouldn't our order have been AHEAD of the 6 people next to us who weren't even there when we placed our order? And it can't be what I ordered... 3 of them got their orders of mussels, while I had to wait for mine.  Basically, this place seems like they simply do not have a good system.  It's like our order was somehow lost or forgotten entirely...

3) On a previous visit, I was overcharged for a beer, and the manager wasn't exactly friendly about it. I was charged $2 more than the price listed on the menu, and when I brought this up with the waitress, she got someone (manager? owner? It was a guy with a dark beard) to come talk to us... he seemed very agitated and said "The price printed on the menu is wrong, but since that is what is on there, we will adjust the price for you this time." 

Look, it's not my fault you don't update your menus, or print the wrong price on it, or whatever happened (or maybe try to fleece people when they are inebriated and hope they don't catch it??)  There's nothing unreasonable about me expecting to pay the price that is right there in black-and-white... in fact, if it had been more expensive, I wouldn't have ordered it!


Other than the service, the place is pretty cool -- I like the atmosphere, the beers are good (but sometimes overpriced), some of the dishes are excellent -- particularly the mussels and the rabbit dish (the french fries aren't anything special and are way too expensive for what they are, which is a shame.) 

But the total lack of friendliness and professionalism is starting to leave a sour taste in my mouth (and it isn't the gueuze)...
author: Matthew G.

description: Great little place to grab a beer.  Waitress was very knowledgeable and made some excellent suggestions.  Had no cell reception on bottom level so keep this in mind if you are meeting up with a large party.  Overall, can't wait to go back and try more!
author: Josie M.

description:
Got dragged here by friends the other night.
Still sucky, pretentious, and fem beard beer boy still there. 
Fries were good though!
SKIP
author: Kyle K.

description: We found La Trappe while looking for a place to eat before going to Cobb's. Definitely go downstairs, the place has a very European vibe. The restaurant lost a star because it was hard to read the menus. yes, menus: one for beer, one for wine, another for the cheeseboard, a dessert menu and finally the dinner menu. The attentive waiter recommended my beer and we each ordered burgers which we gobbled up quickly. My burger was cooked to order, MR, and delish with some chipotle mayo in it. Definitely will return.
author: Shirley F.

description:
Food was, for the most part, spot on. We started with mussels and frites, which were great. Bread was flaky and great for dipping in the different, great sauces. Hamburger was awesome, but the scallops and spaghetti were not good. 

However, service was the big letdown. We entered the establishment, which has no host station, where the first 3 employees we encountered (2 waiters and a bartender) showed little interest in explaining how to get on the waitlist for a table. Not just unhelpful, but unfriendly. By unfriendly I mean we were getting looks from all staff that basically scrutinized us while we waited patiently to spend money on the food and beverages that La Trappe was, by our understanding, intended to purvey. 

We finally found the person we needed to talk to and sat down. We asked for pepper and hot sauce and got it about 10 minutes after we finished eating all of our food. The wait staff was confrontational, asking why we didn't want something when a person cancelled their order after falling ill. Finally as we were leaving, the gruff bartender and his cronies were silent and cold, looking at us with a glance that asked why we were still there. I guess they must have been really busy and forgot that there were customers eating food and drinking beer there. 

I'll probably go back, but I'll probably keep to myself and just eat the frites.
author: Matt V.

description:
Met some friends who highly recommended the place. My boyfriend loved the beer (pages upon pages of selections). I ordered the rabbit, which had been freshly marinated and prepared the evening prior, and the meat was succulent, tender and the flavor just hit the spot. My bf ordered the fresh salmon which was cooked nicely and with tasty sides, but didn't taste particularly special.

I preferred the rabbit by a long-shot and will return for the beer because I was unable to drink this particular evening.

We followed up with tiramisu - delicious with a very fresh strawberry in the side. Unfortunately, they were out of the panna cotta.

What impressed me most was our server's knowledge of the beer. The service was top-notch with an average wait for the mains.
author: Michelle D.

description: Great service, great food, great beer.. The only thing that could be commented on, was the noise level which were quite high, however we were sitting downstairs where the bar is located, the upstairs level seemed more quiet ..
