author: Mette B.

description: Very Belgium.   Loved the vibe, Jeremy the bartender is great, picked beers based on my taste. Don't go expecting an easy tourist experience.
author: Trey R.

description:
I heard about this place from some coworkers as I wanted to grab a drink after going to Cobb's Comedy Club down the street.  The restaurant is upstairs and the bar is downstairs.  

They have a GREAT selection of beers. Would definitely recommend this place for someone looking for a yummy beer.  I tried a whiskey aged beer that was rich and tasty.  I also had a glass of Port.  The bartender was very helpful and provided quick service to our group of 6. 


I look forward to going again and trying different beers!
author: Michelle W.

description:
Great atmosphere. Overwhelming beer selection. Friendly staff, who will take their time to explain what each dish/beer is and willing to give their own input on favorites.

Their beer selection is absolutely overwhelming (and expensive). I've never seen so many beers where I have literally zero knowledge about the kind of beer. That being said, you're always in for a new beer adventure every time you step in to La Trappe.

The food is excellent. Homemade favorites, such as mac and cheese and spaghetti are done exceptionally well. I had the Fish Gratin, which was an explosion of flavor. You can tell this is a popular dish because when we arrived, there was only 1 left for the night. Of course this review is not complete without some say about the fries. The fries are good, double fried and served with an assortment of sauces (you choose 2). Fries are good to share amongst 4 people. 

La Trappe is great either as a casual place to have some beer and fries or a whole complete meal. The downstairs area is so unique and surreal with a dark dungeon feeling. Be prepared to spend at least $40 for yourself for beer, fries, and an entree.I'd come back (especially for the mussels touted in the reviews), but I wish the prices weren't' so steep.
author: Brian L.

description:
Just because the upstairs dining room seems empty, don't think the place has no business.  The hot spot is downstairs where the bar is located.  The downstairs is like a cave - very dark but great ambiance.

Their beer list is like a five star restaurant's wine list.  A thick book that gives you history and information on the beers they carry.  Every beer has a brief description.  If you are stuck, the waiter can definitely help with the selection.  Like wine, different beer is served in different glassware.

What we enjoy most are their mussels and fries with their flavored dipping sauce, our favorites are wasabi mayo and curry ketchup.
author: Gloria H.

description:
So apparently this place is famous? I had no clue. I don't usually make it out this far, but ironically I think I might have spent my first few days in the Bay Area here, then wasn't able to find it and then finally came back 5 years later. Even then I thought it was a burrito place by looking through the window. Then I went to the downstairs where it's a beer drinking palace :) It's pricey for some of the selection (even for a bar) and the service is sort of hit or miss ... usually on the miss for me (and I'm nice).
The setup is like a lounge area that you can sit and enjoy a few beers with your friends.  I have never been here for food so I can't speak to that, but their Belgian selection is pretty large. Not sure who's selection is larger Monks or La Trappe. Anyways in the end, it's worth the trip.
author: Greg G.

description:
I have only been here once about a year ago, and dream about the mussels on a nightly basis. Oh, and yeah, the beer I dream about on an hourly basis. 

There were like 6 or 7 of us, and we didn't have a reservation. We sat in the downstairs area in the dark lounge area while we waited for a table. It was so cozy, big welcoming couches, lantern/candles type lighting, very cozy. I seriously did not feel like I was in America, felt so European and historic downstairs. Sipped on some very enjoyable Belgian beers and finally were seated. 

Just had appetizers, and the best to note were the mussels cooked in a beer sauce. Oh I just love anything phallic and Georgia O'Keefe, smothered in a hot beer sauce. Okay so you just learned a little too much about me.

Anyways, my 60 year old dad got tossed here and he loved it, so I am officially a huge fan!
author: Summer C.

description:
How do I even begin to explain my love for this place? Continuing with our beer tour, La Treppe was the last on our list for the day. It was the perfect ending to our day. 

Now, I am pretty awful with my belgium beers. I know NOTHING. I prefer IPAs or stouts so I was a bit thrown off with the overwhelming list, aka Beer Bible. I left our bartender take the lead which he was more than happy to. If you need help, ask! 

I let him know what I usually drink and he started me with the perfect first drink, then a second, third...maybe a fourth? I was feeling pretty tipsy at that point ;) 

After many drinks we ordered some food. No complaints there either. Mac and cheese was delicious and the hubby ordered a salmon app. 

PROS: Awesome service, sitting at the bar made the experience for us! Good food, prices were good, got served quick. knowledgeable staff. Awesome, cozy bar. 

CONS: I was too full for more!! Oh, and it gets busy pretty quick- and full of people who have no clue this isn't a budlight bar.
author: LeeAnn N.

description:
Does anyone know how many letters are in the word bacon? Because I would imagine if a restaurant owner would like to protect himself from the wrath of people who don't consume bacon, he'd include those 5 letters on his menu. 

A bit of backstory. We decide on La Trappe for a lovely meal, pre Cobbs Comedy Club. We've done it before and had a great experience. We're feeling a bit adventurous so we order a rabbit. Out it comes smelling great and looking delicious. I take a bite and it oozes flavor. Seriously it melted in my mouth. I exclaimed, which I never do out loud, "The onions are so goood". I take a few more bites of the rabbit, sauce, potatoes and green beans. My friend then discovers why the onions were so good, huge pieces of bacon! But I don't taste any bacon! That's because I've never had it! 

Fast forward 7 minutes. We ask our lovely waitress if there's bacon in our rabbit and she says no. She asks the manager, who we'll call A$$hole, in front of us and he says "yes! Prunes and bacon". They both take off to go check out the menu. He didn't even know his own menu and didn't bother to return. Oh and A$$hole wasn't busy at all except at being the resident a$$hole.

Fast forward 3 more minutes after a nice apology from our waitress and after we pay full price for a half consumed bacon rabbit, we walk upstairs and my friend seeks out A$$hole. She politely as all hell mentions that maybe they should say bacon in the menu. A$$hole doesn't say a word and looks at her as creepily as possible and keeps nodding condescendingly and then says "I can change the menus". Nothing else. No apology and no offer to comp our bacon infused rabbit. A$$hole's obviously not given a sh!t about his customers before us. Dude was an expert in making us feel like idiots for politely mentioning bacon should be included in the description of a dish. A simple sorry would've resulted in a Yelp positive review. He has no intentions in changing those menus.

Cliff notes. We order rabbit. We get bacon rabbit. We stop eating bacon rabbit. We mention they should describe it as a bacon rabbit and not just rabbit. We get the death stare of all time for attempting to help future customers. 

Cliff cliff notes. Avoid A$$hole if possible. Everything else about La Trappe is great.
author: Sameem S.

description:
Three of us went to dinner here on a Saturday night.

We got
- beer battered mussels
- belgian fries
- a burger
- white sausage entree
- chicken in a creamy broth

Everything was incredibly oversalted. Imagine a cup of store bought chicken noodle soup, then add more salt.  The beer battered mussels were particularly forgettable, which was surprising for a restaurant that supposedly specializes in mussels.  The burger was ordered medium but came out well done with virtually no juice left.

Lastly, the service was out-right lousy.  It took us forever to get initially served and then about 15 minutes to get our drinks.  We did mussels to share, then ordered the entrees.  Two of the three entrees came out 10 minutes before the third.

I won't go back and I live half a block away.
author: Todd A.

description:
I was brought to this fine restaraunt by a friend who was touting their beer selection.  I found that not only was he right about that, but their food was excellent as well.  I had the Flemish stew and we split orders of Brussels sprouts and fries.  

Everything was exceptionally delicious.  I was blown away by the Brussels sprouts.  I'd never had them so tasty.  My Flemish stew was a unique dish I've not seen anywhere else.  Although the consistency was a little different than some stews I've had, the flavor was intense and memorable.    

I will definitely revisit this location the next time I'm in San Francisco.
author: Bryan N.

description: Mind-boggling selection of beers. Asked the server for a recommendation and it was excellent. Definitely check the place out
author: Anuj V.

description:
If you are a fan of mussels and seafood, this is the place for you.

Recommendations: Seafood waterzooi, Coconut Curry Mussels
Best part: the portions are quite generous!

Cons: Service is a bit slow. They also ran out of a few dishes by 7:30 PM (which was quite weird / annoying), so my friend who liked chicken was annoyed!

Overall Experience: A definitely place for a seafood lover!
author: Mil K.

description:
Wow.  Wow.  Um - wow.  If you are drinking a lot, the price goes up quite a bit.  But it is totally worth it.

So I got there early.  The restaurant has 2 floors.  The 1st floor (where you enter is not a good indication of the restaurant) and the basement (this is where you want to be) I sat at the bar in the basement.  Let me say, the bartender was fantastic and really helped me get the best experience.

The beer menu is 51 pages.  I thought it would take too long to read so I had beer that was recommended by the bartender (Chimay special that I had never seen).  They had some other interesting beers that I had too (I don't remember them).  To be honest, it is worth going there if you enjoy beer and don't plan on eating.

I was hungry though.  There were some great looking things on the menu, but I went with the mussels.  They were awesome.  It was a huge pot of them. I had some fries with them and they also brought bread.  I never thought it was possible to fill up on mussels, but I did it.

I walked out of there very happy.  I highly recommend this restaurant if you are in the area.
author: Ted H.

description:
*good mussels not great but solid curry coconut ginger
*weird vibe from the female bartender, helpful, ignoring, uninformed on the oysters but knew the beers
*dipping sauces rocked, get the peanut one
author: Dan S.

description:
I've been to Le Trappe a handful of times over the past year since I live in the neighborhood.  I've never been overly impressed or disappointed so never wrote a review.  (In fact I haven't wrote a review on here in a long time apparently) But I witnessed something at La Trappe the other night that was downright disturbing, so here I am.

A customer seated near me at the bar ordered something and was asked his name on the tab.  Apparently the customer was annoyed having to give his name each time he ordered (he said 5 times that night)  I can see this being kind of annoying since the bar only seats about 8-10 people and he's seated right at the bar and it was loud in there.  Having to shout out your last name every time you order a beer could get old.  I mean, even at chain places they put your tab in front of you at the bar in a cup.  Anyway,  the customer gave his name again, and said,  "you guys need a better system".  A pretty fair statement perhaps.  Well, NOT TO THIS BARTENDER!  You would have thought this customer just insulted this bartender's mom with the insanely crazy way he reacted.

The bartender jumped down the guy's throat, (forgot what he said exactly but it was nasty) and refused to serve him something his wife ordered.  When the customer asked to speak to the owner this guy said, I AM THE OWNER!!  Honestly the way he was acting in a rage I think he was on major drugs....or, he has serious anger issues.  The 'owner' started screaming out his name and how his family has been in the neighborhood forever and other nonsense.  The customer must have felt threatened.  Hell, I felt threatened.   It ended with the 'owner' threatening to find the customer in the neighborhood and that the customer should watch his back because he knows everyone in town!   ARE YOUR SERIOUS?  This owner was going to hunt down the customer for expressing his opinion.  Class act.  

That would have been enough entertainment for my night but then it got better.   As the customer was leaving he shouted;  "Oh you look like one of those "yelpers"....and made a sour faced gesture of a geek  typing at a keyboard. (no exaggeration)  He said "what are you gonna  do, go write a bad review?" then he laughed.  He said this so condescendingly, so rudely, so arrogantly, in front of so many people, I have no idea if this guy has any brain in his head? 

I mean isn't Le Trappe the beneficiary of a 4 stars review on yelp?  How much of his business is coming from "yelpers", the same "yelpers" he seems to despise so much? My guess would be A LOT! 

Now, I know this owner doesn't take advice well but I have some for you:  Don't bite the hand that's feeding you buddy.  The "Yelpers"  are clearly helping put food on your table.  Give props where it's due!

I don't know what was wrong with this young owner.  Maybe he was just having a bad night.  And a negative comment of his perfect little business just wouldn't be tolerated...I'm not sure.  If I had to guess it's probably more a case of nepotism: mommy and daddy handing the keys to the restaurant to the bratty underachieving son with anger issues.  A great recipe for sure.

Look, we've all run across jerky bartenders with attitude.  Le Trappe certainly has them and we learn to live with these types, but I've never seen a proprietor act so shamelessly.  I could never imagine in a thousand years that a  business owner would ever do such a thing to a customer for such an innocuous comment.  Because of the outright thuggery displayed at this place, I won't be back.  I felt dirty just sitting there.

I'd suggest CHURCH KEY on Grant / near Vallejo for some great beers and great atmosphere without the attitude, and definitely without the hostility.  I'm also sure that they would appreciate your Yelps, unlike ahem.......Mr Whatshisface.

3-Stars for beer and food. (decent but bland and overpriced)
0-Stars for staff & service.  (and not just because of this night)
author: NB B.

description: IT'S A TRAP!!!! 2 stars for a great beer list only. Bad, frozen food.
author: Michael B.

description:
Not too unreasonable for beers (they are all high quality by the way), but sometimes you gotta say F it and go for it.  I love these types of places that cater to those who want real craft beer and want to learn as they try new things.  Unfortunately, my decisions ended up sucking, but I was with two others and we made sure we tried each others.

The service was awesome and the bartenders were willing to talk to my indecisive ass about every damn beer on the menu with surprising patience.  

The food wasn't spectacular, but I didn't expect to be wowed by the food.  This was more for drinks.  I did get the Portabello burger and that wasn't too bad.  The consistency of the patty was a little odd, but seeing as I had been drinking nothing but heavy and strong Belgian beers, I wolfed the thing down in no time.  

Right down the street from where I was staying and I'd come back to try some more dank brew.
author: Dan B.

description:
I love this spot! I stumbled upon it right before attending Cobb's Comedy. We were looking for a new restaurant to try out and just happened to be in the mood for Belgian. 

Although I'm not much of a beer drinker, the Timmermans Framboise Lambic was stellar! In fact, I also tried the cherry lambic blend, which was my favorite by far. We ordered a bunch of small plates, e.g. sliders, mussels in a dark beer sauce, Portobello mushrooms, ratatouille, mac n' cheese, and of course a side of Belgian fries! 

I highly recommend it as the perfect date spot! The atmosphere is cool and mellow, not at all pretentious. It's underground too, so feels like a hidden gem. 

Lastly, the service is fantastic! The staff is accommodating and very helpful!
author: Kim H.

description:
La Trappe seems like it would be a beer connoisseur's paradise; for a run-of-the-mill beer lover like me, however, it was a bit much. I admire people who approach a glass of beer the way an eonophile would a glass of wine, but I'm more of a "give me a pint of Bass, please" kind of girl.

But if you are someone who takes beer seriously, you will most likely love exploring La Trappe's selection.

The bar atmosphere is quite nice...a dark, cozy spot hidden under the restaurant space. At times I was a bit irked by the service, though. I can't quite put my finger on it, but I think it has more to do with systems and procedures than the actual servers.

For example, unless you're going to order full-on dinner, you cannot occupy a table. Really? There are 4 of us who are about to drop $8 apiece on a HALF-PINT, TIMES THREE OR FOUR, plus possible appetizers, but we don't merit a table for 2 1/2 hours while the tables upstairs sit empty and the bar is standing-room-only with the nice, big tables being occupied by sometimes only 2 diners each?

And for a place of this caliber and price point, why isn't there table service in the lounge area?

All in all, I can definitely see the appeal of La Trappe, but I'll file it away as a potential "date" spot and keep going to my beloved dives.
author: Valeria R.

description: once you head downstairs to the beer cave, take a look at the beer menu. it's pretty extensive. service was ok, ordered some small appetizers and they came out to our table in what seemed like hours.
author: John N.

description: Came here a few years ago, reluctantly came back - so glad we did! The bartender was so helpful and did a fantastic job helping us pick and choose and I so thoroughly appreciated his willingness to discuss assorted flavors etc.
author: Marissa C.

description:
Fantastic, quaint little spot in the ever-so-busy and so-many-places-to-eat North Beach. Walk in and head downstairs and you almost won't believe your eyes. One of the coziest "downstairs" seating I've experienced in the U.S. (In Europe, it's a dime a dozen). 

Service was lovely. Food was good (the bonus is all the condiment choices you get to pick for your meat and frites) but not great. Average burger, average steak frites, average frisee salad but not average minestrone soup: that needs major work. Ambiance perfection.

I would 4 star it if I were a beer drinker but unfortunately I'm not. They basically have a beer bible you can thumb through to find the perfect ale to fit your mood. I was impressed but can't speak for the selection.

If you ever find yourself out in the cold in North Beach on a rainy night... enter La Trappe.
author: Meredith R.

description:
Such an awesome place to sample exotic beers and delicious menu items!  My BF and I went here on a whim and it was fantastic.  When we arrived it was completely empty upstairs, but we've heard about their downstairs seating and was curious to check it out.  The bar downstairs is dark, lively and fun!  We tried the cheese plate and shared the moules frittes.  Both plates were great!  The Chimay cheese is quite delicious and the mussels were cooked perfectly.  

The beers are amazing and was really up our alley.  We spent more on booze than food, but it was worth every penny.  The service here is relaxing and inviting.  I really can't wait to go back!

P.S. This place won't take any reservations unless you have a party of 20+...I asked simply because it's a spot I've love to bring more friends to.
author: Lisa R.

description:
Friday at 6p - 9p.

One server, One barkeep, One reservations taker guy, two backwaiters. I am sure there were more... but seriously?  If there were two barkeeps (handling a 25 foot long bar and table service orders in a beer & wine only pub?), why did it take 25 minutes to order 4 beers?  We desperately wanted to give you money. DESPERATELY. Take my money for your services.... I almost walked out. I should have.  This was all waiting for a table at my friend's behest.  Hour and a half later, we sit down.  The menu is okay, the food is drowned whenever possible.  I enjoyed my onion soup puree (a take on the more traditional french onion soup) and oysters... and I enjoyed those immensely with a mignonette and a hot sauce they bring along with cocktail sauce. Yum.

But the design looks as if they made a big booth for large parties, and realized you never get large parties of 12, ripped out the table, and now have two 5 tops oriented so you are staring DIRECTLY AT THE OTHER PARTY ACROSS FROM YOU... a loud mouth PI, his drunk ass wife who kept puking and coming back to the table, and they terrified, captive dinner dates who just sat and silently listened to him drone on.  So did we, it was nearly impossible to talk over these people.  We are staring directly at them, like opposing teams across a playing field that is no more than a foot wide.  It was miserable.

The server was badass.... she was on it, and multi-tasking, and dealing with my asshat friend who showed up 3.5 hours late for a place he recommended we go.  I have known him for 15 years, and should know to ignore everything he ever recommends, EVER. This is the final nail in that coffin, by golly.

The margins on this place must suck. Get some liquor, speed up service, make people happier. Staff properly. Also.. don't let a poor barkeep get so buried for so long without any help that he adds up a $9 beer, a $10 beer, a $15 beer, and a $9 beer to be $28.  He couldn't even listen to us to tell him he was wrong.  How often does that happen?  We were trying to give you even *more* money, but how long do we have to try to point out your mistake before it's furrowed glances and shrugged shoulders?
author: Uncle Fishbits Aeneas X.

description:
During a recent trip to SF to visit my brother we went to La Trappe after dinner and I don't think I'll ever be the same. If Alagash Interlude is the Lost Ark then call me Indiana Jones because I will not stop till I find it on the East Coast (or does that make me the Nazis?) 

The bartenders were awesome, and extremely knowledgeable. They gave us a full spectrum of sour beers but due to the potency of the Interlude I can't remember what they were.

Is La Trappe franchising in Philadelphia any time soon??
author: Noah G.

description:
I went to La Trappe on a Friday night with a party of 10 for my birthday. They don't seat your party until everyone is present. All ten of us arrive fashionably late. Typical.

Three of us had the moules frites and shared, and everyone else had a different assortment of foods: burgers, pastas, what have you. Needless to say, everything was delicious. But who cares, right. I think we all come to La Trappe for the hundreds of different kinds of beer that they serve.

There's also a bar downstairs, so while you dine you'll get used to a steady stream of buzzed people coming up the stairs. Overall, great food and an awesome atmosphere for the start to a fun Friday night. I'd definitely come back.
author: Patricia Q.

description:
The mussels in spicy tomato sauce is very good. Please order yourself a Chimay Blue.

The overall atmosphere is wicked good. One of my favorite restaurants/bars/hang out spots in SF.
author: Abhi M.

description:
Awesome selection of beers and great food. :) 
Grilled sardines were surprisingly great. We had to wait to be seated, it was a busy evening for them. However, they have benches inside of the restaurant and we ordered beer during our wait, so it wasn't a big deal. (vs restaurants where you wait outside)
author: Galina F.

description:
We stopped in here for dinner saturday night around 8pm.  There was some space open upstairs but the downstairs was packed.  Being our first time there we walked downstairs to check it out.  I liked it a lot, especially the slanted rock wall.  Totally different vibe than upstairs.

The wait downstairs was 45min or more so we took the open table upstairs (near the door which made it cold but we were hungry).  Our waiter was serving everyone on that level (plus a food runner or tw) and did a good job for being so busy.

We ate:
Salmon toast: Toast with smoked salmon/fromage blanc spread, radishes.  It was ok but a bit more bland than I would have throught.  The smoked salmon didn't add enough saltiness so a little sprinkle of salt over the radishes really helped.

Mussels: we had the traditional white wine version.  It was good and very similar to the ones we ate in Brussels this summer.   Good firites too.  The garlic aoli was good (salty) and the curry ketchup was tasty too. 

Rabbit stew: Also quite good.  Tender rabbit and a nice sized serving.  The mashed potatoes were good too.

We drank: 1 La Chouf and 1 Rochefort 8.  Delicious of course.

Overall we liked it.  The service was fast and friendly and the beer list was impressive.  I'd go back and hopefully get a seat downstairs.
author: J. B.

description:
This is a cramped, hectic, loud, underground (literally), dark, cozy, rich, beer drinking place. Long wait if you are eating. So if you are picky and need everything perfect avoid this place. If paying an extra $3 for beer makes you panic, then avoid this place. I think this is an okay place for  kids, but the food is more adult oriented.

I'd say this place is $$$, not $$ like yelp says. But I guess it depends on what you order. Last time I went we spent like $65 a person on just entrees and drinks. I wish I could provide insight on the beer, but my friend is the connoisseur. I will just say the beer is very impressive and the food is fine.
author: Walter M.

description:
yummmm MUSSELS!!! You can resist the mouth-watering, tasty little things boiled in fennel and delicious broth you just want to drink up but slowly with mussel shells. This was just a starter and it comes with fries plus sauces you can pick. I got the scallops which was a special. The seared scallops were definitely raw enough inside to keep it soft and the sauce was so great. I couldn't even tell what was in it, but I loved it. I wish I could have more of it.

I can eat dozens of mussels myself. I wish it could be AYCE.
author: Stephanie Y.

description:
EAT BEFOREHAND! EAT BEFOREHAND! EAT BEFOREHAND!!!

Yes, La Trappe is great for beers... all the reviews say so and I agree. But whatever you do-- EAT BEFOREHAND (yes, I'm that serious- I'll yell it as loud as you need me too).  We waited two hours for a table and once we were seated waited another 20 mins for the server and then another hour for our food.  

I was there will my favorite homies...all of us pretty jovial in nature... so we were low on the scale for complaining (yet high on the beer consuming)-- we did a good job trying to make the best of it. 

But guess what... when we did receive our food... it was horrible. HORRIBLE. (again-- EAT BEFOREHAND!) I won't bore you with the details but it consisted of cheese on vegan orders, unopened muscles, and a sandwich consisting of lettuce, on hamburger bun and a small piece of melted cheese. (wtf?!)

Two friends joined the table later in the evening and when we asked (Mark? Michael? the asian server...name started with an M) if he could start them on another check (ours was running at $300 and theirs at $20) we got attitude. A lot of it. 

Part of me thinks that maybe Chef Ramsey needs to get up on in there and check that place out! Our whole experience reminded me of the show Kitchen Nightmares! 

La Trappe might be great for a beer or two, but do not eat there.
author: Homechicken P.

description:
The food is pretty awful for a place that class themselves Belgian. The mussels were rubbery and pretty tasteless. I had the waterzooi which featured very over-cooked shrimp and chalky tasting white fish. Went with my wife and we both sent our plates back to the kitchen. The fritjes were totally un-Belgian, they were just regular fries like the kind you get frozen at Vostok and heat up in the oven. If you want to get an idea of what Belgian fries taste like you should go to Frijts on Valencia. Still not quite Belgian, but way closer than this place

The service was so bad that even the Maitre D' noticed and came over to apologize. Three times. Prices are astronomical, but whatever.

These guys get two stars for having a decent beer selection. Honestly, the relentless IPA assault in San Francisco wears me out. So finding a bar in town that has good brand-name Belgians on tap is great. And they serve the beer in real beer glasses, not the Big Gulp glasses you find all over. The bar tender should go to Belgium and learn how to pour, though.

I will not bring my Belgian friends here, to save everyone a lot of embarrassment. But the beer was pretty good if you're looking for an escape from the punch-in-the-head IPAs.

Follow-up, reduce to one star.  I just looked at my bank statement and there is an additional charge there for about $27.00.  Not sure what that's for - the bill I brought home was for about $80.00, which also appears on my bank statement.  I suspect that they forgot to include my bar tab in the whole bill, so surprise!  I'm really not going here again.
author: Dave S.

description: The variety of available beer really is remarkable here. The bartender was a smart ass but in a cute way that didn't put me off. There is plenty of seating downstairs and I liked that there's a lounge area too if you have a big group that cannot seem to sit still. The first thing I heard about this place was that they have some really special fries. When I got here everyone was talking about them too. Of course I got us a few orders of fries to check them out. You would think at seven bucks a pop they'd be some damn good fries but I think the hype is also in the sauces that come with them. If I were rating just the fries id say three stars but the massive beer menu takes it up a big notch! On a side note the restroom was nice and clean too.
author: Yolanda Y.

description:
Since this was my first visit to San Fransisco, I had to ride on the outside of the Trolly. During the trolly ride, my fiancé noticed a glowing sign that advertised Affligem. We've had a very hard time finding Affligem where we live so we had to jump off and check this place out. The lady working there directed us down stairs & were we surprised at what we saw. An amazing basement type beer bar with a beer list ranging into the hundreds! We promptly ordered our Affligems. The bar tender was very nice and knowledgable. We left but came back later the same night for some grub. I ordered the pasta bolognese and my fiancé got the sliders. I have to say, that was the best pasta bolognese I've ever had! It was flavorful and light at the same time. I could also tell that the pasta was fresh and not from a box. Our server was very friendly and energetic. Perhaps too energetic.
I've read some bad reviews on this place and I noticed that the manager did too and fixed whatever mistakes were made. During last call, the servers did not rush us at all. He actually encouraged us to relax and take our time. He made sure to let us know last call was coming up so we could order last minute beers if we wanted. I can't tell you how much I enjoyed La Trappe. Such a great locals place that's not overrun by tourists. If you're a beer lover, especially Belgians, then La Trappe is NOT to be missed. You won't regret it.
author: Katie W.

description: This place has a great selection of beer and a number of other pluses.  It does remind me of a typical bar in Belgium.  Beer is served at the right temperature and service was really good as well.  Wish we could have stayed for food, but the night was already booked.  I have put this high on my list for next time I am in the area.
author: Mark B.

description:
You really have to appreciate a waiter who doesn't give up in disgust  when faced with a person who doesn't like beer (in a bar that serves only beer, no less).  Instead, our waiter rubbed his hands with relish and worked until he had found a delicious raspberry lambic that I proceeded to drink three glasses of, and happily.  We later got another waiter who figured out in moments the perfect beer for my husband (one he absolutely loved).  Additionally, the mussels and frites were delicious and they were happy to refill our bread basket three times so that we could mop up all the sauce.

In short, yum.
author: Libby V.

description: We found La Trappe as we were walking back from dinner and decided to have a drink. We went downstairs and James Knox was probably the best bartender/beer know-it-all we have ever met. He was friendly, knowledgeable and funny and the beer he suggested was a perfect match for my husband and I. We will most definitely come back to La Trappe next time we are in The City!
author: Jen B.

description:
*update 3/6/2008*
Norm has Cheers.  Sav has Jade.  Phil H. has La Trappe.  I hope they aren't sick of me yet (so far no restraining order - yeah me!) because I have no plans on leaving.

*update 2/21/2008*
Last night was my fourth visit to La Trappe, this time to celebrate my birthday. I couldn't be more pleased with the way the evening went - from the beer to the food to the service everything was top notch. Thank you to Michael and staff for taking care of us and for helping me celebrate my big day!

*original review*
Here's what the Belgians do right - fries, mussels, chocolates and beer. Ok, there might be more but those are the only things I care about. 

Friday night I met up with some friends at La Trappe for a couple of beers and we were all impressed (so much so that one of my friends brought a group back on Saturday night) We tasted some fantastic beers and had a great conversation with one of the owners who filled us in on some of the history of the place. There are a few bistro tables  and an open kitchen upstairs but the highlight of the space is the basement dining room/bar. We nibbled on some tasty fries and were all salivating at the dishes coming out of the kitchen - this is the type of place where I could roll in solo and grab a burger and a couple of beers at the bar without feeling like a total loser. Well, at least for dining alone.

Five enthusiastic stars. Now this is a neighborhood spot where I can see myself becoming a regular.
author: phil h.

description:
I went to La Trappe last night with a friend to liquor myself up a little bit. Not like I needed to, but I hadn't ever been here before and lots of my friends have, so why not? 

We walked in and sure enough, the top part was empty. Well, what's this? Stairs? Going down? I wonder what's down there...oh! It's the rest of the bar, and OoOoO look at all the pretty colors on the taps, and the bar is so smooth and look at the nice couches with it's pretty pillows and...well, you get the picture that I was about excited about the place as a 5 year old in a candy shop that was just handed 100 bucks.

So I'm sitting there, looking at the menu, and suddenly Keane's story pops into my head (http://www.yelp.com/biz/la-trappe-san-francisco#hrid:P3hGSmY02YhIs-bt1hB-Sg). Plus, since I'm obviously in no condition to be opening my mouth and talk around normal human beings, I decide that it's a good idea to tell this story. Do you have any idea how difficult it is to take the awesomeness of this story, and try to explain it to someone else? It's hard. So hard, that I'm the only one laughing by the time I'm finished. 

Bad story telling aside, the beers here are actually really awesome. The white beer, so light and flavourful, was awesome. The other two beers I tried were robust and full-bodied, and the bartender was extremely knowledgable about them and even offered me a taste. 

At the end of the night, my friend said, "You know...I would have thought it was 4 bucks too." Score! Keane, you aren't stupid!

Or maybe my friend is too. 

...

I'll go with "Keane is not stupid, but my friend kinda is" KAY :D
author: Jaime L.

description:
Was just here on Friday night for beer and a late dinner. The ambiance downstairs is like a loud dark cave in the best way possible because that cave has hundreds of kinds of yummy Belgian strong ale. We waited like 45 mins. for our table which was fine because it was the end of a long work week and we got to just relax at the bar and try lots of strong, yummy libations.

 My suggestion would be to skip the drink menu which is a little overwhelming and intimidating, and just talk to the bartender. They're super helpful about finding a beer that suits your taste buds.(I like bitter and not at all sweet- we got it right by beer #2). It gets really noisy downstairs so I wouldn't recommend for people wanting a quiet evening out. I like dark, loud, late dinners so I really enjoyed the scene. 

The mussels were awesome! I wanted to drink the broth right out of the bowl. And our server, Matt, was a friggin gem. I'll be here again and again for sure.
author: JoAnn P.

description:
This is one of my favorite places in the world. The minute I step down those stairs I feel like I've been transported back to Europe. 

If you like beer, I can't think of a better place to go. Having just gone to Belgium, the only bit that's not authentic could be the food.... The food at La Trappe is much better than most places in Belgium. Mussels and fries are a must, and the curry ketchup is terrific. The rabbit stew is also top notch. 

But the beer! The beer list is an inch thick binder which will not disappoint. And of course, each beer is properly served in the correct glass. If you want to go exploring, tell the bartender what characteristics you are looking for and they will lead you towards beer nirvana.
author: Bill W.

description:
Great for groups. We came here with about 16 people and had a blast. we didn't have a reservation but we came early to get a couple of tables upstairs. 

The fries and the sauces are pretty awesome (esp the wasabi aioli) I got the portobello mushroom burger and it was great! The rabbit and steak and mussels were all tasty but not spectacular. 

We asked for recommendation for beers and they were all pretty good. We just ordered a bunch of bottles and we all shared

Overall great experience!
author: Emily T.

description: What a great find near where we stayed on vacation!  Who knew Belgian food was do great?!  Fabulous beer selection, too.
author: Molly I.

description:
Great Belgian beer selection & tasty frites!  

Being a beer snob, I recommend that you ask to pour your own bottle (unless you don't mind yeasty sediment.)

FYI - Don't be fooled by the empty restaurant upstairs.  They bar area is in the basement.  IMHO - I think they should switch-up the two usages so that potential customers on Columbus Ave can see happy patrons enjoying great beer (but then again... I'm not responsible for the remodel cost.)
author: Tony S.

description:
Oh Witkap Pater....I love you. Delicious, fruity and light taste. Now that Bar Crudo hasn't been selling it anymore, it's harder to find. But not at La Trappe...where you're literally up against a BINDER full of beer selections.

I don't even want to guess how many options you have, but wow it would take me maybe 50+ visits to try them all. I was able to try the Affligem Blonde, along with the Witkap. Similar but both distinctive in terms of fruity hints and alcohol by volume.

The actual bar is awesome. You can sit down for food and drinks at one of the tables (your name goes down on a list...no reservations), or you can chill in the lounge area, that looks more like a pirate's den. The exposed brick on the back slanted wall is amazing, give the place a very warm, homey feel.

I want to have beer here every night for the rest of my drinking life!
author: Alyssa G.

description:
My son and his girlfriend took us here after a walking tour of the city. It was a fantastic choice. No better beer selection--I think they said 419 different ones. Beer menu is well-organized and helps you find what you like even if you are unfamiliar with the vocabulary.

After a few, we decided to eat--very good decision. The chicken in the chicken waterzooie (sp?) was so flavorful. It doesn't "taste like chicken"; it's better. All of the food was so good, I'm just a little fuzzy on what we had after all of the beer (don't worry, we cabbed).

Definitely recommend this; will be back.
author: Bob H.

description:
Vegetarians, beware. You pretty much will have to concoct your dinner out of a mixture of side dishes.

If you're a meat lover, this place is aight. Nothing particularly spectacular. But decent food and a great beer selection. The salade nicoise was pretty good - love that they actually do put in anchovies. Although it was so dark I ended up eating a whole one at once. Luckily, I had a delicious belgian to wash down all the salty goodness.

There's often a huuuuuge wait for big parties. I think we waited over an hour and a half. At least they kept us hydrated with tasty beers while we waited.
author: Monica C.

description:
This place has a beer binder. A WHOLE DAMN BINDER. How does it get better than that?

Oh, with the freshest mussels you've ever tasted, that's how, paired with awesome belgian fries. One great thing about this place is the level of customization you get - you can choose among 3 broths for the mussels, and you get to pick 2 dipping sauces (out of 10+ options). 

There's definitely plenty of beer here that you won't be able to find anywhere else, and our waitress was so helpful in helping us decide. Two beers and the moules frites entree (mussels + fries) was just enough food to split for two people.
author: Lisa W.

description:
This place is a cozy romantic candlelit subterranean dungeon monastery, if you can even imagine that. K, come on now and get your head out of the gutter!

All I have to say is beer, beer, beer. I was blown away with the selection and the knowledge of the staff. As impressive were the complementary tastings for indecisive (or just down-right confused and clueless) beer drinkers like me. I'm sad they no longer carry Kwak, but on my most recent visit I got a Tripel Karmeliet (trust, I only SOUND like I know what I'm talking about) which was delicious and is still is served to you in a neat (but different) glass.

The menu is distinctively Belgian; you have to at least try the moules and frites. In fact, there are other subtle touches of Belgium in several dishes you might not notice like salads with Belgium endives (salad with the apples is refreshingly crisp and good), the pork loin with Brussels sprouts and the Belgian waffle dessert with a caramel and Belgian beer syrup (a must-get dessert).

LOVED IT. Can't wait to come back and try more beer.
author: Chelsea P.

description:
This review is for their gluten free-ness...

I went to La Trappe as I had heard that they have the largest selection of gluten free beers in SF. Of course I had to check it out in the name of science, right?

So I get my first g-free beer and it's pretty yummy... as is the second. A bit pricey but they are (as I call them) "big girl" sized bottles. So about halfway thru the second bottle we decide to get a nibble too as it smells amazing. After a rather long wait (uh oh, there went 2 stars for an hour wait and parties after us being seated first) we're seated at a table away from a rowdy drunk party.

The guy seating us (not our waiter) then proceeded to go over the gluten free items on the menu with us. Then our waitress comes and, having noticed our gluten free beers, goes over the menu in great detail about trace gluten and which grills have meat also on them! (back a star)

The food was wonderful but as a gluten free diner, this is the first place ever to go into such detail and care with me. 4+ stars indeed!!!
author: Missy D.

description:
It's all about the beer here.  It's extraordinarily expensive to carry these amazing Belgians on tap and the price is carried through to what you pay but oh, is it worth it.

Also, the digs are comfy downstairs.

Every time I walk toward La Trappe and see that hanging Chimay sign my eyes light up.
author: Jared W.

description:
Solid recommendation from a SF native (kudos James!). An incredible amount of beer selection. Ultra good and ultra strong. Fair warning...

The lounge area downstairs is a good compliment to the dining area. We wanted very badly to get some frites with customary mayo in true Belgian form, but didn't want to ruin our appetite for west coast sushi. 

Not cheap...one of the more expensive stops during our trip, but totally worth it.
author: Joseph H.

description:
I am Belgian and I definitely won't recommend this place.

First: overprice and cheap (they even count the extra and fake ketchup $1 each!!)
Two: extra small portions. Don't take the charcuterie (sausages, pate, ...) plate as appetizer it is ridiculously small and therefore over expensive!
Three: Not real Belgian cuisine - they mispelled the vol-au-vent in the menu and indeed it was not a vol-au-vent at all although the description looked like it!!
Four: Poor service
Five: They charged us 2big beers instead of 2small one (quite a difference if you look at the menu!! chimay blue to be precise) and it took forever to change it, with additional "mistakes" in the process of having the right bill

EEK!
author: Daphne D.

description:
After drinking a bunch at Rogues Ale House down the street we went here. When you first walk in you'll wonder where the bar is since it looks like a restaurant when you first go in. Downstairs, sucka.

They've got a very interesting selection of beers on draft and in the bottle. Mainly german and belgian, but they're all good depending on what you like. More expensive than I would like, but the rarity of some of the beers, and the fact you're in SF, means it's worth it on occasion.

We didn't try any food, and the bartender was alright, but the underground feeling of being in a monk's underground lair was worth checking out.

Don't get the Rodenbach Grand Cru. It looks like carbonated goats blood and tastes like rotten, fermented strawberries mixed with lemon juice and a throat punch.
author: Taylor A.

description:
For beer 4*
For food 2*
Average 3*

The beer menu is intense, it is an entire binder of beers, plan on spending sometime selecting a beer, it will take a minute. I think close to 20 tap beers and who knows how many bottles, the choice is endless.

The food I was not so impressed with, limited menu choice and just ok food, for the price eat elsewhere and come for beers after.

The servers were very helpful and knowledgeable on the available beers suggesting beers based on your preferences.

Prices are a little more expensive but they are quality imported beers so this is to be expected. It is a pretty quiet atmosphere, good place to hold a conversation over a beer or dinner.

The location is cool, in the heart of North Beach, so easy to combine with other NB spots.

I will be back for beer! Probably not for food
author: Chris M.

description:
On my last night in SF I was in need of a low key spot to get a few brews in to aid me in sleeping on my red-eye flight back to the A. La Trappe fit the bill pretty perfectly.

Definitely head downstairs. The upstairs decor is pretty non-descript but downstairs is sexy, cozy, and worth a stop in and of itself. There weren't any small tables available so we took over a large booth and due to the early hour our waiter was nice enough to let it slide. Obviously, the beer menu was pretty stellar, with tons of Belgian options I had never heard of: an impressive feat. They describe most of the options which is a major bonus, as well. 

I was super excited about the moules frites, as there really is nothing better with a great Belgian beer. Unfortunately, when my friend's burger arrived, they informed me that their most recent order of mussels was below-par and didn't feel comfortable serving them, so would I like something else. While I appreciate their attention in the matter, I was a little miffed they couldn't have told me this when they actually found the problem, not when my dining partner's food had arrived. Alas, I ordered up the burger as well and it was pretty good: the brioche bun was too soft but the actual taste of the burger was pretty solid. The fries were a bit lackluster as well with very little flavor: I've come to expect a good bit more from a quality Belgian spot.

The atmosphere and beer list is what makes this place really shine, and our server was quite happy letting us chat the night away before we had to say our goodbyes.
author: Kathleen M.

description:
Had a burger here last night, and it was lacking. There was nothing bad about it, it just want's great.   The fries were soggy, and definitely not up to par. 

The beer list is impressive- longer than most venue's wine lists. I think it's something like 40 pages, and the beers are good. Like really good. 

Bottom line: great place for great beer, not a great place for food. I guess you can't have it all.
author: Jennifer K.

description:
A fine, rotating selection of beers on tap.
There are also beers-in-bottles, but that's not as much fun.
A nice seating area downstairs.
Mediocre food; but if you pretend it's a bar, and not an eatery, it's easier to not mind. After all, most bars have no food at all, not even the mediocre kind.
author: Max R.

description:
***Good***
Food = ??? 
Beer Selection = Unmatched anywhere in the city.

***Bad***
Nothing.

***Recommendation***
Browse the beer menu. It will overwhelm you in a good way. It is awesome. This place is amazing.
author: Nick K.

description:
Probably the best beer bar in the city. It is a Belgian beer bar, so don't expect to watch the big game here. The best thing to do is to go in when it's slowish, sit at the bar and talk beer with the owner and bartender. Most know a lot about beer and you can sample the drafts (of which they have a ton) before buying.

It's a bit pricey as all Belgian bars are and they will not let you take beer out of the bar which is bs.

The menu is small, but good. I don't know if all Belgian food is like this but it is RICH.
author: Will D.

description:
Recommended by a friend, whom I personally believe has a secret file on every Belgian restaurant in the continental U.S.  So when he recommends a place, you probably should go.  He's like the Julius Rosenberg of Belgian restaurants, except, you know, not a traitor.

Had the Belgian fries - this should be mandatory - with wasabi mayo and roasted red pepper mayo.  I wish I could say I was ashamed to have eaten two ramekins worth of mayonnaise,  but if you haven't figured it out by now, I have no shame.

Also had this chicken puff pastry appetizer thing with fancy French cooking terms.  You'll know it when you see it.  Perfectly sized for one, super good, and my waiter was nice enough to time it well with my fries.  Oh, it was his first night, and he was GREAT.

Beer selection is of course fantastic.  19 taps with a wide selection of different styles.  The usual suspects were there, but also some stuff I never heard of before, and any time that happens it makes me happy.

I love North Beach, I love fries with mayo, I love trappist ales, and I love this joint.  Will be dreaming of you until we meet again, San Francisco.
author: Katie S.

description:
First off the beer menu in here is awesome - they have a great selection of beers. Some of the Belgian ones are definitely expensive but thats the price you pay for really good imported beers.

The food here though leaves a lot to be desired. My wife had the mussels which were OK. I had the steak which was pretty terrible, probably the worst steak I have had since arriving in San Francisco in July 2010. Maybe it was just a bad night for steak though.

Staff were friendly and helpful. Ambiance was good - we sat downstairs which I think is definitely better. I would go back to La Trappe for the beer alone if I was looking for Belgian beers. If I ate there again though I definitely order the mussels and not the steak!
author: Michael R.

description:
Great restaurant. Huge beer selection, and everything I tasted was really, really good.

The thai-style mussels were simply incredible, and huge. Loved it.
author: Andrew L.

description: My favorite restaurant in North Beach. We had the rabbit and a boar special, both were flavorful and perfectly cooked. Can't go wrong with Belgian beers either. We happened to be there on a day where they were having the world's smallest toast of La Petite Chouffe and the waiter came and gave us little tiny beer glasses and had the worlds smallest toast with us. A wonderful experience, unique food and Belgian beer makes for a good time!
author: Beini Q.

description:
Saturday in the city with my oldest friend and since we rarely get to spend time together, the locale needed to be perfect.  You see, my friend lives, breathes, and makes wine for a living and knowing her, the last thing she'd want on her free day out would be more wine.   

The antithesis of a wine bar?  La Trappe, with 120+ Belgian beers on the menu.  Guess what-- she loved it!  Score one for me.  And I loved it too.

We were both wary upon entering the quiet restaurant, and then we were directed downstairs.  Sigh of relief...and of surprise at the large downstairs area, with tables, loungy areas, and bar.  Totally my type of place- not too crowded, not too loud, chill atmosphere, good food, great drinks.

We took up two stools at the bar and were immediately handed over multiple beer tastings to help us decide on what we liked.  She got the Wittekerke and I had the cherry lambic, though I think I preferred my sample shot of raspberry lambic. 

The sliders on brioche (2 for $9.50) were huge, or maybe I was just expecting them to be mini.  Highly recommended, as these were really tasty.  The twice cooked Belgian fries with two dipping sauces- needed more salt.  Good, but I still prefer the ones at Frijtz.  

Great service, bartenders who know their stuff, and fabulous company.  I'll be back soon enough.
author: Joanne G.

description:
Beer selection alone gets five stars,but the overall food quality and service gets 3  stars.  For 5 stars on the beer, the menu was over 30 pages and 200 beers not on the menu.  I would like to see their cellar.  Be warned, if you want to get adventuresome with the beer, be prepared for 30, 40, and 50 dollars per bottle.  Others can be had for 10 bucks or less.  Remember, this is fine, high end pivo.  For the price, it will probably be the best beer you have ever had.  From fruit beers that are perfectly tart and not too sweet, to some great white lambics. 

I would like to come back to give the food and service another try.  Got the mussels...for every 3 great ones, there was one that tasted like it lived in some murky swamp.  Curry ketchup was way too strong, almost an earthy bitter flavor.  The service was puzzling, with some areas receiving wait service and some areas you had to go to the bar and get your own beer.   If you like beer, I don't know what you are not already on your way.
author: Matt M.

description: La Trappe had an awesome beer selection, a varied and interesting menu, nice, attentive servers, and a kick-ass beer cellar! We'll be back!!!
author: Mindy S.

description:
Stopped by a month before heading to Belgium. Writing this review after returning from my Belgian trip. Michael? and Eric were very helpful at the restaurant and encouraged my friends and I to try new beers and foods. The advice on where to go and what to see in Belgium was also spot on. If you are a fan of Belgian ales and food or just curious, La Trappe is a must. Go early and sit at the bar!

I read the reviews before coming. If you are expecting a Budweiser, don't waste your time. La Trappe is about a true Belgian experience and compares favorably to what you will find in Belgium as well as other parts of the U.S.
author: W. B. M.

description:
One of the BEST mussels and Belgian fries I've had in my LIFE.  No joke.

I am not at all a beer drinker, so I was a bit worried how my night was going to turn out to be when my husband's friends were gathering here for one of the guys' bday... but when I saw their menu out front and saw their steamed mussels, 3 styles, I was totally sold.  And I was not at all disappointed!

Sorry I can't comment much on their beers but here's my big fat 5 stars on their food.

I had their roasted fig salad and their mussels and Belgian fries combo.  They had the 3 options for broth, but I went with spicy tomato broth... and boy o boy were they good?!  

The fig salad was a good portion of leafy, dark greens with sweet, intense roasted figs.  The flavor was complex and beautiful.

The mussels came in a HUGE pot piled all the way up with tons of fresh mussels soaking in excellent spicy tomato broth, and a big cone filled with fries and mayo on the side.  I devoured the mussels.  Literally.  sat there and ignored the party and totally devoured them.  Then I went on to taking one of the shells as spoon and drank up half the broth.  I ate about half of the fries which were also excellent but by the time I got to it I was getting pretty full : )

My husband ordered their burger which looked HUGE and extremely juicy too.  

I told him and his friends that I am down to coming here every Friday after my ballet class if I can get my hands on those mussels and they can get their beers and do whatever the heck they want, I'd be happy lol.

Seriously, that good.  And I really hope it wasn't a one-time streak of luck because I am going to come back here for sure and they better be as good the next time too!
author: Sascha O.

description:
3 1/2 stars, really. This review only covers drinks downstairs... 

The good: 
- they had the usual suspects on tap (but nothing more)
- they had a number of unusual suspects in bottles
- the owner was eager to share his favorites
- We sampled 6 different brews in the evening; only 3 were really new
- Owner replaced a brew that he suggested that we hadn't t liked

The bad:
- truly bizarre vibe downstairs, like an awful European discoteque
- close to empty at midnight, but music is blasting uncomfortably
- 4 people on an otherwise empty dance-floor and bar
- did I mention the weird, loud European discoteque vibe?

Can't say that I'm excited to go back... and this from a huge Belgian beer fan.  But where else to go?!?
author: Laurence W.

description:
La Trappe was the highlight of my dining experience during my recent trip to San Francisco.

We hit up La Trappe after receiving recommendations from both Yelp and Draft magazine (listing it as one of the country's best bars for beer), and it is a can't miss for any time I am in SF.  Making it especially good is that we arrived shortly after 8pm and the only thing I had really eaten that day was a hot dog on the ferry to Alcatraz.

I had several beers, wit, trippel, sour, etc.  Each were some of the best tasting beers I've had.  The special Lady friend scored some fruit beer that tasted like kool-aid and she put down quite a few of those.  Good times.

The food was very rich and tasty.  I got some chicken sausage and sauce... with fries.  Oh man, the dipping sauces with the fries are great.  My lady had a burger, which was was decent, but this place isn't known for their burgers.

We had to wait a LONG time for a table, but it was 8pm on a Friday night.  I didn't really mind, aside from the fact that I just came from Alcatraz and I was tired of being on my feet.  In all fairness the place is pretty small and we were downstairs and it is more of a bar, and not the type of place where people are leaving at regular dining intervals.  It's really not such a bad thing, I wasn't in a hurry, and it gave me plenty of time to try various beers.

This place rocks, I've already began informing people they know to go to SF and have a few drinks here.

Cheers,
author: Jeff C.

description:
I had been looking for a good Belgian beer bar and heard about La Trappe through some friends.

I'm a sucker for a beautiful curved staircase.  This is what leads you to the downstairs bar.  I enjoyed drinking delicious beer in what feels like a cave.  It's cozy and comfortable.  They have a number of different seating areas, many which would work for large groups. 

They have an amazing beer selection.  If you are not sure what you may like, talk to a bartender, they will help you.

After enjoying our beer we placed an order for frittes (Belgian fries).  For four of us, we got two orders and six sauces so we could try them all.  The ginger mayo was my favorite, followed closely by one that tasted like bacon (chipotle?).  The fries were prepared well but were inconsistent in size which made dipping (and not also dipping your fingers) a bit difficult.  

I look forward to returning to La Trappe soon.  It will take a while to try all 30 something pages of beer but I'm planning to try.
author: Emily J.

description:
One of my favorite restaurant/bars in North Beach!

Great Basement Bar with a wide variety of Beers and a nice ambiance.

Highly recommend for a beer connoisseur. 

They also serve really good Belgium style french fries with a variety of dipping sauces.
author: Ayall S.

description:
I absolutely adored my experience at La Trappe when visiting San Francisco this past week. La Trappe was just a short walk down the hill from our hotel, which was incredibly convenient.

Upon arriving you walk right into the kitchen/small restaurant area where the host told us to head downstairs for drinks and dinner. The downstairs area has no windows, but is dark and cozy, making for a great dinner and/or date spot. We were promptly greeted by our waiter who gave us the impressively long beer list and let us browse through it for a solid 10-15 minutes before checking back on us. It was hard to narrow down our selections, but my boyfriend and I went with a draft tripel and a saison, both of which we were happy with. 

As we were sipping on our beers, we put in an order for the charcuterie plate. While this was being prepared the waiter brought us over some freshly made bread with butter. The bread was absolutely delicious--very soft and flavorful on the inside with a nice contrasting crunch of the crust. The charcuterie plate arrived a short time thereafter, which I was thankful for as we had done quite a number on the bread basket.  The charcuterie plate provided a great variety of delicious items, including cured duck sausage, garlic salami and pork rillette with a side of pickled onion and bell peppers. My favorites were the duck sausage and the salami, and the vegetables were slightly pickled which gave a nice contrast between the freshness of the vegetables and the vinegar flavor. I'd highly recommend getting this as a starter as it went wonderfully with our Belgian brews.

For the main plates, we decided to split two items, the first being the Birds Nest which was a trio of organic beef meatballs, breaded and deep fried with hard boiled quail egg in center and topped with a tomato based sauce. These were fantastic as all of the flavors complimented one another while standing out individually. The beef was flavorful and well seasoned and the richness of the quail egg was outstanding. They weren't overly breaded as many places tend to do and the frying process didn't rob the meatball of its unique flavor. As for our second dish, we went with the Mussels Mariniere which was cooked with shallots and onion that were sauteed in white wine, witbier, butter, creme fraiche and parsley served with fries and two dipping sauces of our choice. I absolutely adored this dish. The mussels were tender and soaked up all the flavors of the wine and witbier, and a silence descended upon our table as we enjoyed these. The frites were perfectly crispy and dipping sauces (Chipotle BBQ Mayo and Roasted Red Pepper) were great additions to the dish. I have no complaints whatsoever about the meal!

We finished our dining experience with another saison and the tiramisu. The tiramisu was probably my least favorite dish of the evening. It wasn't bad, but it fell short when compared to other tiramisus that I've had in the past. The dessert was a bit dry and lacked the almost overpoweringly strong coffee/espresso flavors.

The service was friendly and attentive, and food came out promptly, so I have no complaints there.

La Trappe is definitely worth the visit, so if you're in the mood for frites, Belgian Beers, and mussels, definitely check this place out.
author: Megan K.

description: This is the place my husband chose for his birthday dinner and we were not disappointed.  Had not been there for almost a year, and I don't know why! We will definitely be back soon for the mussels and fries! I do wish they served Guinness Stout, or draught from the bar.  (I do not like Guinness draught in the cans. Not the same.)
author: Emily M.

description:
Hello beer drinkers. Look at your beer, now back to mine. Back at your beer, now back to mine! Sadly, your beer isn't mine, but if you want delicious beer from a cool place, then you'd be at La Trappe. 

Look down, now up, where are you? You're in an underground bar with the beer your beer could taste like! What's in your hand, back at me. I have it, it's a Chimay glass filled with the beer you love. Look again! The beer is now delicious fries with an assortment of dipping sauces. 

Anything is possible when your beer comes from La Trappe. I'm on a stool.
author: Jeff O.

description:
Went here a while ago. Had such a great time and was poring over the many photos I took of the food and the place while I was there this winter.

I miss this place, and would consider moving to SF just so I could come here and to the multitude of amazing coffee shops around here more often.

I want to live in their basement.
Please?

The rabbit and frites-sauces were awesome.
It got me in the mood for some epic cyclocross racing.
I WILL BE BACK.
author: Milhouse B.

description:
I want to come back here!
I ate delicious food
(burger & fries!)

and had beer done right, the strong and flavorful Belgian way.
Next time I'm getting waffles.
author: Van W.

description:
Someone say beer?

CLEANLINESS: 5/5 (Although it was really dark)
SERVICE: 3/5
FOOD: 4/5
- Beer, beer, and more beer.

From the exterior, no one would have guessed what's hidden underneath this restaurant. They have an underground seating area that includes a bar and multiple tables for dining. The ambiance is dark and cave-like. It's actually really cool. Upstairs, they have the kitchen and several tables here and there.

As for the beer, they have a wide selection... it's almost overwhelming. If you're a beer fanatic, this is the place to go. The prices are a little expensive for what you get, but it's pretty good beer. It's a nice place to hangout after a long day of work, that's for sure.

If you're ever just hitting up bars, check this place out!
author: Desmond C.

description:
Expensive yet not overpriced.  The hours great for a restaurant, but not phenomenal for a bar, so check this out: 

1. Hands down the best beer selection in the bay. Toronado and Church Key are the only other places of its class (although they are not full restaurants) 

2. Underground. Enough said. 

3. Excellent food. Rabbit stew, Moules a la Biere, and a very decent NY Strip.  Well beyond acceptable. I'd be happy with just their incredible drink selection. 

4. Staff: Completely knowledgeable, reasonably speedy, professional and friendly. 


A total hidden gem.
author: David D.

description:
I cannot give them enough stars!

I LOVE La Trappe for many reasons. The 2 main reasons are:

1. Their beer selection.   I LOVE the Grand Cru on the tap!  They serve all of their beer in the "correct" glass wear.
2. They serve Marin Sun Farm beef!!!!!! My favorite farm for free range grass fed beef and fresh eggs with orange yolks.   http://www.yelp.com/biz/marin-sun-farms-point-reyes-station#hrid:qgwE0XtNoSgFHkamBGZfvQ They used Marin Sun Farm beef for their stakes, burgers and sliders (mini-burgers).  They were perfectly cooked and tasty!  On top of that, they are reasonably priced... Almost cheaper than buying meat at the Marin Sun Farm's butcher 1 1/2 hours drive up north.  

I LOVE La Trappe!
author: Chie J.

description:
I REALLY enjoyed this place... excellent beer selections, dim lighting, comfy back area, a chill environment to hang out with friends and enjoy high alcohol content beer. 

I don't even care for beer THAT much nor the city - the fact that I'd go to the city again JUSt to come here say a lot.
author: Michelle C.

description: Cute place but bad service. Beers were short poured which is frustrating based on the price. Bolognese pasta dish was good. Burger was just ok.
author: Maria C.

description:
The beer menu looks like a bible and if you just tell them to make a recommendation, it's usually pretty spot-on. The food is darn tasty (note: pomme frites/french fries, whatever you call them with the various dipping sauces are awesome (recommendation: crushed red pepper aioli & curry ketchup)).

Plus, even when the place is a madhouse, the people who work there are friendly and down for a few jokes.
author: Leslie T.

description:
Utterly disappointed. I had high hopes for this place given the recommendations from several friends. The service is slow, the bartenders inattentive, and the food is mediocre. 

The owners should note on the menu that the pork item is a sausage. I expected a piece of pork, like a chop, but instead I got ground pork in the form of a round log. This dish is also overly salted and way too creamy. 

The fries are good, but that's about it. Even the burger, which my friend had, was quite dry. 

Come here for beer and fries, but I wouldn't recommend anything else.
author: Jun W.

description: My favorite restaurant in North Beach. I love the atmosphere downstairs, a great place to enjoy dinner or just beer. I always order the spicy tomato mussels, I can't get enough of them. I also love their fries and choices of dipping sauces. By the way this dish is gluten free and goes impeccably well with the greens gluten free beer.
author: Ali A.

description:
My husband and I went to La Trappe last night and it gets 5 stars for a few reasons.

1. My husband has been to all the 7 Trappist monasteries. He did a beer trip to Belgium two years ago. He is a bit of a fanatic when it comes to beer...so if I can take him to a place where he can order some of his favorite beers (some on tap) and they come in the beers own special glass-five stars for making him smile. 

2. Service. We arrived at 6pm on a Friday night and went straight downstairs. We picked a small table for the two of us. Our server, at tall beautiful gal, explained a couple of changes on the menu to us. She was very attentive and kind. Towards the end of our meal the place was packed and I was worried that the service was going to go south but I started to realize that other people were helping her. Moving plates on and off the table, refilling waters etc. All the staff worked as a team to keep everyone happy and that really impressed me-5 stars.

3. Food...We had a cheese plate. 2 cheeses were $12 dollars. Typically when we order cheese you get such a small amount. NOT HERE. Holy Queso my friends! There was so much cheese as well as grapes, honey, dates, olives, gherkins and this delicious dark nutty bread. My husband had the lasagna which was moist and very tasty. It wasn't an Italian lasagna but was very flavorful and a welcome surprise. I order The Boudin Blanc. Dear god. There are no words. The sausage was amazing, the gratin was cheesy and flavorful...bring it all together with the sauce and it's like an orgasm in your mouth! 5 stars!

4. They have Duchesse Du Bourgogne on tap. This alone gets the place 5 stars. Not many people are into Flemish Sour Ales but I am. I didn't see anyone else order one that night. I have a feeling that if all those women that ordered wine would have been a little adventurous they could have enjoyed something so amazing and not a glass of wine made 20 miles away. This is a BEER place people. Not a wine bar...suck it up and try something new!
author: Amanda M.

description:
Some friends and I went on a beer crawl yesterday, and this was definitely my favorite place we attended. 

I love spiral staircases. They make me feel fancy. 

Once we made it to the bottom of the stairs I felt as though we had been somehow transported to another place in time. Or the same time, different country. I definitely did not feel like we were in an everyday bar in California..or the US for that matter. 

With dim lights, a complex ceiling, encyclopedia of beers,  and just enough bench space to play legseys with the cutie next to me (either Chewbacca or baby face, either will suffice) I was pleasantly pleased. 

After being overwhelmed with the different choices I headed over to the bar and and let the bartender pick out my beer. I told him what I liked, and within seconds a beer that was to taste like apple pie appeared before me. And taste like apple pie it did. Unfortunately there was no a la mode option. 

I think it was a cool experience for each of us, and hopefully I will be back sometime soon. Maybe I will bring my own ice cream. Apple pie beer float anyone?
author: Whitney B.

description: This place really has an geographical identity crisis----the bartender (downstairs) was rude---and sneered at me when i asked for a chilled glass. EXCUSE ME. What---is it , some beer thing that it must be served in warm glasses? Most places accommodate my request for a chilled glass, albeit with a tude, but come on !! Sad thing----bar downstairs is super cool----I mean great brick facade---cool vibe---I assume the food was good by the crowd. Look---its is a nice place---but give the customer what they want---and if you insist on holding to some European standard of how to serve beer---go back to Europe....
author: Chris O.

description:
YES!!  

This place has like 1,000 beers plus really amazing food, not the least of which are their Belgian fries with dipping sauces.  They do get busy, but it's well worth a visit.
author: Ash T.

description:
If you like beer and you love a good time drinking it, this is the place for you! Been here a few times now and always always have such a great time. They have an EXTENSIVE selection of Belgian beers and many of them are just fantastic!! 

We have also had desserts here before (if you are lucky enough to get a table)... I think they close early though and that's kind of a bummer...
 
Check it out if you love beer (is there anyone who doesn't??)
author: Sapna E.

description:
+1 star: great food
+1 star: great selection of Trappist ales 
+1 star: basement seating is super romantic
-1 star: hard to hear anyone
-1 star: small, long wait to be seated unless you come early
author: Jenni C.

description:
It's nice to visit places where your friends live, because then they can take you to establishments you'd never know about as a tourist, like La Trappe.  Definitely not a tourist trappe.  Oh, ha. Ha. Ha.  The nice thing about La Trappe, tho, is that you can indulge that dorky tourist side of you that wants to experience "real" San Francisco by riding the cable car right to the front door -- the Mason Street line stops practically smack in front of this homey little place.

Love the rustic brick atmosphere of the downstairs dining room with its long wooden benches and low, sleek bar.  The Belgian beer list is extensive, and I do so love Belgian beer.  Portabello burger gets a new twist by being stuffed with goat cheese and fried.  Good stuff.  Moules frites are delish, too, plump, nicely cooked, very fresh tasting, and come in your choice of beautiful sauce.  Husband and I enjoyed the mariniere, a beer and lemon broth.  Prices are *really* affordable, considering this is high quality food AND San Francisco.  I was pleased to get out of La Trappe for relatively cheap, all things considered.

This was a great place to meet up with an old friend, drink some wonderful brew, and eat some tasty food.  I will definitely go back on my next visit to SF!
author: Mac O.

description:
What a wonderful find! This bar very fondly reminds me of my favorite bar back at home (in Cleveland) and is a total gem! When you walk in, don't be fooled by the ordinary first floor and make sure to find the stairs and walk down them. You'll be greeted by a cozy, lively basement full of many delicious treats! 

Although I wasn't in the mood for drinks, I took a look at the extensive menu and immediately knew I'd be back for more. What a selection! 

I ordered the 100% grass fed burger with the gouda cheese and is served with tasty, melty fries & two dipping sauces. I chose honey dijon and roasted red pepper mayo. I'd take the dijon again and try another mayo next time. The burger was very very tasty! My friend bought the pudding dessert and I had a sample: it was perfectly delightful. Yum, yum, yum!

Needless to say, I have scheduled tomorrow's happy hour with my out of town visitor here! I can't wait to come back, a second day in a row, and enjoy many more of the beers. A great crowd :)
author: Magda M.

description:
La Trappe Cafe could quite possibly be one of the fondest destinations to add to any pub crawl. The downstairs bar, lounge, and dining area is a world of it's own. They offer a modest western European and California wine list, but boast an incredible selection of Belgian beers truly worthy of the Trappist seal.

     A very modest Belgian Bistro stands on the corner of Greenwich St and Columbus St, south of Fisherman's Wharf. The Bistro itself is a bright, small, and simple cafe like setting that leads to an elegant spiral staircase. The iron decorative railing with an organic design guides you down a cedar/redwood like staircase into dark but very welcoming cavern like basement. 
     The vibrant red, earth, and amber like shades fill the lounge, bar, and dining areas. The dim lighting and the trickling sounds from the waterfall like fountain truly amplify that secluded, but cozy cavern like feeling... completely extenuating the fact that your in the middle of a crowded city.  

     The selection of beers is overwhelming. The variety in itself is impressive, but the rare finds and large array of flavors simply makes the lists of Belgian ambrosia's remarkable. It doesn't matter if your like my friend Eduarado, and you like your beer as bitter as your women, or sweet and mouthwatering like their Floris Apple. The selection is sure to please the palate of even the most demanding of critics.

     I lack the complexity to truly describe the wonders La Trappe can offer, but even a blind, drunk, and inappropriate fool such as myself can appreciate what it offers.
author: Yves J S.

description:
