La Trappe used to be great - but now service has turned to La Crap.

Sure they were busy, but business must be managed.  We won't return because of the poor service.

Unless we are very drunk and obnoxious ... then we might fit in.
author: jack l.

description:
Love this place. I went with a group of friends for a few drinks on a Thursday night. We arrived early enough to take over the downstairs lounge area complete with comfortable couches. The atmosphere is very welcoming - gently lit with candles, and offering great acoustics that allow you to carry on a conversation with your friends without yelling like a lot of other bars. 

And the beer selection. Wow. Amazing. The bartenders are very helpful at explaining the plethora of varieties, and will let you sample a few if you can't decide. I went with a few beer-coinsures who ordered some tasty brews, so I got to try a bunch of new flavors. 

I hear the food is great too, though the only thing we tried was the fries (yum).
author: Kori M.

description:
BEST selection of brew in the Bay, in my opinion.  They even had Straffe Hendrick Quad on tap...I haven't seen that anywhere (and I have looked long and hard believe me) outside of the actual brewery that we had the fortune of visiting in Belgium.  Additionally, the Moules Frites is the best that I have had outside of Brussels...far too many places in the US murder mussels, but La Trappe definitely gets it right.  

The staff is friendly and attentive and the ambience in the downstairs portion of the bar/restuarant is lovely.  It's totally worth the BART ride to get there!
author: Jen P.

description:
Brilliant Belgian beer brothel --I mean, bar.

For groups, fries with dipping sauce are terrific. Belgian waffles with cream and berries are delicious. The beer, say no more. 

The downstairs lounge is a great space to hang out in, too. Love the slanted walls, corrogulated ceilings, and dim lighting.
author: Angie C.

description:
La Trappe is a great, great drinking, hangout spot at the start (North side) of North Beach. They have an excellent, albeit overwhelming list of mostly Belgian or Belgian style beers. The staff knowledge is impressive and the service is grounded and friendly - a nice change from some stuff craft beer or beer-centric bars sprouting up around California these days.

Only had a quick dabble in the food - all was average (muscles, fries, salad). Your best bet is to use this as a starting or ending off point for your night out.

It fills up quickly once the end of the day comes, so showing up for an afternoon drink is probably your best bet if you want one of their nice tables.

Bonus points for the great below-the-main-room bar space - welcoming vibe - the type of place you want to stay and drink for awhile.
author: Joel M.

description:
La Trappe is so hit or miss for me. I love coming in on off nights for some beers, but making a dinner reservation is such a disappointment. The wait staff is super frazzled and constantly mess up orders; last time I was there, my waiter didn't bring a couple items and we were still charged. The food isn't that good either.

I've had such good experiences on weeknights when I wasn't eating dinner, so I'll come back and stick with the 18lb book of beer choices. I'll probably bump up my review when the bad taste from dinner has left my mouth.
author: Rebecca P.

description: I love this basement, Belgian establishment. Cozy and unique with a huge beer selection of over 400 different types of beer.
author: Carson K.

description:
Amazing all around. 

My first experience with mussels and I am not a seafood fan usually and bivalves freak me out, but I was won over with what I experienced here. The beer selection is on target with being large and fantastic and the service was friendly, present but not in your face. 

Plus they have what appears to be homemade curry ketchup for the fries. Another score.

I want to dismantle this place brick by brick and take it back to Chicago with me.

But it would be taken over by hipsters in about three weeks.
author: Jason G.

description:
What happened La Trappe? You seemed so cool, so relaxed. The crowd was awesome, not pretentious. It seemed like people were having a good time. 

Until we sat down at a table. We were about to order a ridiculous amount of appetizers and beer until we got shooed away by bearded glasses man with 90 degree hat tilt (we'll call him BGH). BGH assumed we were just going to order the cheapest appetizers, just to have seats. BGH kept coming over to tell us to leave for possible dinner guests. Dude, it was 10pm at night, there were at least 4 empty tables and it wasn't even crowded. After we all had gotten up, he told us 20 minutes that we can sit down 15 minutes later and have the table. A bit late on that. Our group wasn't happy and  I'm thinking, this ain't no fucking musical chair shit.

Totally did not look good on the establishment. Here's how I'd handle it. Apologize to us that we have to get up for dinner guests and that maybe in 15 minutes, we can have it back. Done. Cool. You get an an awesome tip from us.

Instead, BGH decided to piss off a bunch of people. 

Anyways, the beers are tasty, but man, the waitstaff are just not happy. At all. And it shows.
author: Roth E.

description: If you are a beer fan, this place is Mecca. There is no bar with a better selection of Belgian beer in San Francisco. The atmosphere is terrific, and the food is fantastic. I recommend the cheese plate and the sliders.
author: Sunil R.

description: Went on a Thursday night and enjoyed a couple of tasty Belgian beers.  They have a massive selection and service was fast and friendly.  Sitting at the bar I was able to order from the full menu and opted for a $15 1/3lb.burger.  Given the price and that the bartender asked how I'd like it cooked (medium-rare) I expected a damn good burger.  Unfortunately what I received was cooked to medium-well and so was pretty dry.  The garlic mayo I was served with my fries was tasty.  I plan to go back for beer but will be cautious about ordering food.
author: James B.

description:
A go-to establishment for these reasons:
1. Moules Frites. I love the coconut curry & spicy tomato sauces.
2. Every beer in the world (not literally but probably close)
3. Great atmosphere, European feeling.
author: Sara P.

description: Top 10 beer bar in the US!  The selection is more unique than I have ever seen. The bar is downstairs so don't let the empty restaurant fool you. The owner Mike is a great guy and takes pride in delivering an experience. The only caution is that those unique beers can cost $14/glass. Highly recommend.
author: Nicholas P.

description:
At the suggestion of some friends, we visited La Trappe while in San Francisco. We were lucky enough to be there at the beginning of beer week AND the brewer of 9 of the Belgium beers was visiting. Although much of the cafe was reserved for his dinner party, the put us at the bar with the "beer book", until our table was available (about 20 minutes).  The beer was great and the dipping sauces were amazing! 
If you like beer, a quaint atmosphere, and good food go here!
author: Caron L.

description: Poor customer service.  Put my party's name of six on the list and the staff completely by passed us and gave the table away even after calling their mistake out. Get a drink somewhere
author: Kurt K.

description:
Exceptional Belgian gastropub.

Plethora of Belgian ales as well as several other specialty craft brews.

Exquisite cuisine a la biere.

Enter the building, walk downstairs to the dining/bar area. Dimly lit, brick walls, slightly crowded, yet intimate - pleasantly reminiscent of Old Europe.

Carbonnade a la Flamande was one of the finest dishes I have had the pleasure of enjoying. The beef braised in Belgian ale was divine.

The above traditional Belgian dish is served at only a handful of select establishments throughout the US; I was extremely pleased La Trappe offered it.

Waiter advised their Carbonnade a la Flamande was braised in Delirium as well as another Belgian beer, which I am unable to recall. Although this recipe is somewhat divergent from the traditionally used Oud Bruin ale style due to its slightly lactic character, this dish was phenomenal nonetheless. 

Moules frites were amazing as well.

We complimented our cuisine a la biere with N'ice Chouffe (from the brewers of La Chouffe), Duvel, as well as a few others. All were delightful.

Even though the waitress accidentally spilled an entire plate of frites on my lap, La Trappe is an amazing gastropub.
author: Anton T.

description: Great selection of delicious beers!  Though the bottles get pricey, the ones on tap are quite reasonable.  Dark, intimate cellar-like walls and painted ceiling complete the Belgian bar atmosphere.  A fun game is to try and guess what each person is drinking based on the shape of the glass!
author: Ling W.

description:
I was recently in San Francsico for a short vacation, and I visited La Trappe on a weekend night. It was around 9pm, and surprisingly, the downstairs bar was not terribly crowded. Prices were fair, and it was easy to get the beer that I wanted. The selection was heavy on certain types, light on some others. I don't know if they were going for a certain theme, but being in SF, I was on a hop kick, and there wasn't anything that was exciting me. We had just missed PTY, so that wasn't happening. I split after one beer, mostly because I was tired.

Coming from Philadelphia, which is a bit of a beer mecca (Monk's and Eulogy to name a few places), I wasn't terribly impressed. They hit all the bases, but I think this place would be more fun if we had friends to hang out with there, but I would go back another time to see what's changed on their taps.
author: Christopher W.

description: I came here in 2011 with some friends and colleagues of mine. We had some great beer, and potato and dip for snack. Loved the atmosphere, the dim light and the beer casks which wrapped it all together so nicely.
author: Stian E.

description:
First time I came here, it was for my friend's birthday party. There was many of us and we experienced such slow and poor service, I did not have a great experience. 
This past weekend though, i met three of my friends here. the service was slow but it was more friendly. WE ordered on the tap beer, everything we tried (we tried 2 different beers each) and it was so good! Seriously, I have to say that the food isn't good. I had the mussels and Belgian fries and the fries came out with what looked like left over ends of the fries and the mussels? they give you SOOO much that i thought i was going to be sick before i finish it. food... seriously isn't that great. 
I would suggest on coming here after dinner, ordering appetizer and beers, because beer itself is worth coming here.
author: Katelyn M.

description: On my list of top 5 beer bars in San Francisco. The first time I came in here and found the spiral staircase that took me to an underground brick tavern, I immediately thought 1) am I in Europe? and 2) what on earth would happen if I was down here in an earthquake? The giant beer book immediately set me at ease, and it took me half an hour to comb through their extensive bottle list (200+ they say) of Belgian beers. The atmosphere here is relaxed and European, and the staff has just the right amount of attitude and snobbery for a intellectual beer bar.
author: Caitlyn G.

description:
Our family eats here often as we live about a block and a half away.  First, if you like french fries, then this place is for you.  Their french fries are twice-fried, making them super light and crispy.  They give you a range of dipping sauces (wasabi, mayo, etc).  Our family usually goes through 2 orders ;)

If you like beer, this place is for you.  My husband probably orders a different beer every time we go - and they've all been delicious.

If you like a relaxing, non-touristy restaurant, they have a hopping bar scene downstairs or you can watch North Beach pass you by in the small dining area upstairs.

Finally, the owners are wonderful, upstanding citizens who support local causes such as the neighborhood elementary school.
author: Serena S.

description:
Although I have lived in North Beach for 18 months, it was my first time at La Trappe. Glad the date picked up that place! A gem hiding in the middle of my neighborhood.

It's definitely a locals'  place. From the outside it looks like an empty restaurant, but they have an open place downstairs where everyone is hanging out. It's cozy, nice lighting, casual, reasonable food. I am not a beer fan, but they had a good wine selection (the Malbec was good!). The menu was typical SF - a little bit of everything, not necessarily Belgian per se, but good variety for a bar, including the desserts. We had the mussels with fries - creamy sauce and Belgian mayo dipping - and it was really good, not to mention a good topic for conversation on a first date. 

I will definitely come back for a casual drink and appetizers with friends when I don't feel like facing the tourists nor walking too much.
author: Simone W.

description:
2 level Belgian bar/restaurant with the lower level being the "cool" basement vibe and the top (day and night to the bottom floor) is more casual and quiet, maybe more for dining.  Had a few drinks downstairs and was ready for food and found out that it was a 45 min. wait for a table downstairs, so upstairs we went for grub and immediate service.

Tried the Mussels with Fries (and don't say "french" fry) and it was nice that you picked the style of broth (i picked fennel, shallot, tomato and white wine aka pastis) and a couple of flavors for your mayo cuz that's what they dip their fries into over across the Atlantic.  The dish was good with the mussels being plentiful but small, but the broth smelled better than it tasted, maybe under-seasoned.  I expected the "belgian" fries to be better but it wasn't any different than say a frozen fry at a greasy spoon.  The mayo for dipping was homemade and spot on.

Other members of our table ordered their Braised Rabbit ($24), which was heavily sauced with a tomato and bacon reduction with the end product being real close to store bought bbq sauce.  Not bad tasting, (actually the dish tasted like bbq chicken, if you would've been blindfolded) but maybe was just expecting something more/better.

Where this place excels however is in the beer menu.  Their menu resembles a fine dining restaurants wine "book", yes book, not list, and reading it is like browsing through a Western Civilization history book, with stories of Abbeys and monasteries with long histories of brewing.  

I tried a very tart Flemish Red which was unique, but the star was this Duchese de Bourgogne, a brownish redish beer with a very complex flavor and the most perfect balance of tart and sweet.  It was cherry, raspberry and caramel notes on every sip and it lingered.  I've had many beers over the years but this stamped an impression on my palatte front and center.  So good I can't wait for my next sip.
author: D.wight L.

description: Came downstairs to the bar, I was too late to try the food, however this place is just awesome. The bartender claimed they have the world's biggest Belgian beer selection , I believe it.. The logic being that in Belgian many bars are sponsored by particular brands and don't carry so many competing brews as this place does. The downstairs bar is beautiful, the ambience feels very Belgian.. Our bartenders was actually quite friendly and helpful.  Location (near streetcar line and bus line in North Beach) is very convenient.. The hours of the restaurant seem to be kinda strange, I actually tried to come here twice before and was not able to because it was closed when it seemed like it should be open. I guess confirm hours before coming down, although the general area has so many cool places this can be just one stop in an evening of exploring this wonderful neighborhood.
author: Mark N.

description: The staff is slow and pretentious. The service is seriously lacking. With all the beers on tap, we requested a taste to determine what to order. The bartender refused to pour a sample and suggested we buy a pint. "And if we don't like it, but a different pint." With all the competition in North Beach, I can't believe this place is still in business. I won't be going back again.
author: Giselle B.

description:
I've lived a block from here for quite a while now.  Its a good thing I've stayed away this long or else they're going to have to build a gym next door.

The beer selection is amazing a definite rival of church key.  Try the Cherry Beer on tap.  Its like drinking a melted popcicle, but with alcohol.  

The appetizer menu is great, try the fritters.  The fries are great too, they have a lot of dipping sauces to choose from.

I'm pretty sure I'll end up there again for a full on meal.
author: jessica b.

description:
I always walked past this place and thought... what a quaint little spot. From the outside it looks small and cozy and never super busy. Friday night rolled around and we decided mussels and fries sounded pretty Belgian and tasty so we pulled on our boots, grabbed our coats, and marched our way down the hill to what was supposed to be a cozy little eatery. 

We walk in to what I later found out was just the top floor and were promptly ignored by the two waitresses walking by. It was obvious we had NO idea that we needed to go down stairs to put our names in. After standing there for five minutes we finally asked only to be told to put our names in at the bar. So, we headed down stairs only to find a medium sized room PACKED with people. After finally making our way to the bar we put our name in and waited. Upon looking around and checking out the different crowds of people that were there I had to note that the beer must be STRONG if there was a table of four tourists where one was passed out at the table and another kept knocking over her chair. hmmm.. note to self... take it easy on the beer. 

40 minutes later we had already finished one beer and were finally seated at a small table. We ordered Fries and mussels to start along with a seafood palooza plate for him and a fried portabella mushroom burger stuffed with goats cheese for me. And don't forget the 2nd and third rounds of beers as well. The food arrived about another 40 minutes later and even though I was a little perturbed that it took so long the atmosphere and energy were positive and the food was worth waiting for. 

OMG, the fries with the spicy ketchup, red pepper aioli, and wasabi mayo sauce was finger licking good. The mussels were perfect and the sauce they came in ... OMG. The main course is kind of a blur due to the food coma and amount of beer I had already consumed but I know it was delectable. 

Overall, I had alot of fun at this place and would totally go back with a group of people or even with just my man again. Just be aware that you need to go downstairs to put your name in and you will definitely want to either walk or cab it because no one can leave this place sober. Or hungry for that matter. 

ENJOY!!!
author: Kylie L.

description:
Me and a few friends stumbled into this place around 10? 11? I have no idea. I live right by here and had no idea there was a downstairs that was packed. I would always walk by at street level and feel bad for the place. 

Downstairs was crowded, but we were immediately seated and ordered beer, fries and sliders. Really great waitress and really good fries and beer. We were right by the water fall thing so it smelled a little antiseptic but I am still def coming back.
author: Karen S.

description: I almost prefer to wait 1+ hours to be seated for dinner here, as it gives me ample time to peruse their beer selection and try as many delicious Belgian beers before filling up on mussels and fries.
author: Anna H.

description:
I was visiting from out of town and we passed by this place on the cable car. I looked it up the next day and based on the yelp reviews I knew we had to stop by. Being beers lovers, it was a great find. We already had dinner plans for the evening, so this review is based only on the beer selection.

We arrived approx. 15 minutes after they opened. We sat at the bar and were joined by quite a few more folks. There was a homebrew meeting going on in the back room.

Amazing beer selection and a great staff. The owner was very friendly and was wonderful to talk to. Both the owner and the other bartenders were very knowledgable about the beer selection and were quick to offer up free tates.

My wife really enjoyed the Rodenback on tap. 

Excellent selection, atmoshpere, and friendly staff. 

(The don't start serving food until 6:00)
author: Matthew B.

description:
[Before La Trappe] 
"Sure, I've had Belgian beer before"

[After ONLY 3 glasses of Belgian Beer w/ freakin 12% of alcohol in each glass at La Trappe]

"Hey! Who punched me in the face?!?!?!"

Mussels & Belgian Fries in face NOW. PLZ.
author: Geezy B.

description: French Fries w/ various dipping sauces are a MUST! Staff is absurdly knowledgable about the beer list, which I appreciate given how long it is! Great little place, but the service can be a little...snotty...
author: Amber M.

description: The beer here is top-notch. Pretty much anything you want is here. Don't be intimidated by the beer menu. Just tell the bartender what you like and he'll hook you up. The service is extremely friendly and helpful. Highly recommended.
author: Michael S.

description:
Great place to go get a beer with some friends.  Make sure you try their mussels though, they're delicious.  So many beers, so little time..
The only bad things are:
1. They close too early
2. They close too early
3. You have to order one food plate per person as a minimum if you want a table.  Dumb.
author: Tony N.

description:
Incredible selection of Belgian beer - almost intimidating, actually - but the staff has been friendly and helpful both times we've been. 

It's unusual to find good beer & cheese pairings, but La Trappe does it well. Also, fries. Also, dipping sauces for the fries. Mmmm.
author: Nicole R.

description: An impressive selection of dipping sauces for the fries, outdone only by the extensive beer list.
author: Amit V.

description:
This place is getting 5 stars for service. I took boyfriend here for his birthday and it happened to be during SF Beer Week. That night La Trappe was having an event, but we showed up early and still managed to get a table in a decent amount of time. 

When we were talking about where to go he brought up La Trappe specifically for the mussels and fries so that's really all we were interested in trying. We figured we'd get two different flavors of mussels and split it. When the waitress came over she explained that because of Beer Week they were only serving one style of mussels. She saw our faces fall and how disappointed we were and immediately offered to ask the chef if he'd mind making us another flavor. And we didn't even tell her it was his birthday!

Turns out they did make the special order for us (shh...I promised not to tell but I figure by now it's ok...) and the food was delicious. A little expensive to eat on the regular but that's the only reason I wouldn't go here alllll the time.

And it goes without saying the beer selection is phenomenal. I'm still learning about beer (versus wine which I'm much more comfortable with) so it was fun to try new things.
author: Katie V.

description:
Maybe because it's a Tuesday evening or because the economy is down. Either way, it seemed a little slowe at la trappe and our experimece was all the better for it. La trappe is the bar that intoducrd me to the duchess de Bourgogne and many other Belgium beers.

Today we went through most of their sour beer  list: monk's cafe, rodenbach, la roja, gueze, iffigem. For food, the boys had burgers and I had the special: a white sausage on baguette with onions and leeks. the Belgium fries were not as narrow nor as fried as I remember.

we sat at the table for 4 at the base of the stairs. those chairs are not the most comfortable...make sure you get a bench-table instead.
author: Mel L.

description:
Very cozy atmosphere in the main room downstairs, with a nice bar, sloping brick walls, warm lighting, and comfortable tables nestled into interesting nooks and crannies.

Extensive and interesting beer selection, each variety served in its own special glass.  Equally interesting wine selection; I tried the Albarino which was very good.

The food was good not great.  In our party , we enjoyed the fig salad, the fries, the steak, and the Boudin Blanc Sausage.

The greens and tuna in the Nicoise salad were very nice. Unfortunately the anchovies were overly fishy and this flavor polluted the potatoes and eggs.

Service was mostly decent, although I wish the waitress hadn't left my second glass of wine sitting at the bar for so long, finally bringing it to the table after I had finished my meal.
author: Martha M.

description:
I just can't shut my La Trappe about this place! but seriously folks... A great place for drinks and conversation. Walking into this place can be deceiving at first because the upstairs area looks like your average small cafe. Then you walk down the spiral staircase to this cavern underground. This really has a europian pub vibe and the beers and rabbit stew to prove it. 

My friend had said stew and I managed to snag a delicious bite. I would order it myself next time. 

I had the burger with blue cheese. For my dipping sauces, I chose the Thai peanut and wasabi aoli. I was quite happy with the belgian fries which were nice and crispy. As for the hamburger itself, I ordered a medium and I got a medium (not as easy as it sounds at some places). The meat was great quality and very tender. The bun was brioche and that aint bad neither.
author: Eric G.

description:
This bar/restaurant made me like mussels. As a lifelong non-eater of seafood, this is a huge coup. Well done! 

Aside from that life-altering experience, I had a great time here. It's a somewhat hidden downstairs place that you enter after walking down a winding stairwell with a beautiful wrought iron handrail. The walls are exposed brick and has a slight dungeon-y feel, but not in a creepy way. More like an awesome beer cellar-y way. 

The beer list is almost exclusively Belgian, and that's fine with me! I ended up with the Affligem Blonde and later on, a Blue Reserve Chimay. Both were excellent. 

In short, I will definitely be back!
author: Jenna H.

description:
Lovely place, lovely food, lovely beers.  A very happy crowd & extremely pleasant staff: This is a beerfest every day.  Minus one star for the astonishing markup on the beer.  Strangely, the food is relatively inexpensive despite being very, very good.

One of the only places you will be equally happy with your food and your beer and your beer will be exponentially more expensive than your food.
author: Michael H.

description:
wonderful atmosphere.
wonderful patronage.
wonderful and helpful bartenders/service.
wonderful amazing mussels/pomme frites.
wondrous inexplicable list of belgian beers.

i could come here everyday all day. WINKYFACE.
author: Ki W.

description:
This was my 3rd time there, and unfortunately, my least memorable experience. As usual, the service, beer and ambiance were top notch. I love the decor, and I've only eaten in the downstairs restaurant section, where it slanted exposed brick walls, a classic bar and long wooden tables.

I've only ordered the mussels here, and unfortunately, they were extremely small....I guess they might be out of season, but that's unfortunate when they are the house specialty. I could have easily sucked down two orders last night. Several people at my table ordered the chicken, and were pretty surprised at the style, it was basically not what they were expecting, but that is not the restaurant's fault...was is their fault was that it was a pretty bland and boring boiled chicken dish.

Finally, the waitress, despite asking me which type of mussels I ordered, served me the wrong ones, and it took a few minutes to realize my friend had my order, and she mine.  Having learned to cook mussels myself and realizing how incredibly easy and quick it is, I am less impressed than I was the previous too times, though I do like that they serve them in the same cast iron pot they're cooked in.

The dessert, Belgium waffles, was first rate, and the coffee was pleasantly strong. As always, the beer was excellent, and they have hundreds on their menu.
author: Jordan C.

description: I love this place so much. Their beer bible is ridiculous--I don't know how I was even able to choose what to drink. I stuck with the trappist ales. I cannot wait to come back and try more and more!!
author: Anna V.

description: Their beer selection is fantastic! The burger, fries, and dipping sauces are just out of this world! Definitely recommend this place. The waitress was super nice and very helpful as well. You have to stop by this place even if it's just to look at the book with the list of the amazing beers they have. You won't walk out without trying at least one.
author: Food L.

description:
Do not be put off when you first enter La Trappe.  It may seem kinda quiet upstairs, but that's because all the action is downstairs in the beer cave.

This is a serious Belgian beer bar.  A cozy cave of exposed brick and ostrich leather loungers, the perfect accompaniment for idle chit chat and Belgian (or Belgian style) brew.  They have at least a dozen beers on tap and almost any bottled beer you could ask for (including my personal faves Westmalle and Rochefert).  Served the proper way, each in it's own specially designed glasses, you would be forgiven for thinking you were in Trappist country (minus any monks or stylish Belgians with their eyeglasses).  

For beginners or those who just need more guidance in their ordering, there are descriptions of all the beers in the menu to help you choose.

And of course Belgian beer must come with proper pommes frites (which are known in all of Europe as Belgian fries and NOT French fries).  In this aspect La Trappe also does not disappoint.  Maybe not as good as Frjtz but still damn good.  They are thick cut and served in a cone (though with a holder) along with your choice of two dips.  Watch out for the spicy ketchup - it is seriously hot.

Bike Parking: street signs outside on Greenwich St.
author: Jean K.

description:
I'm not sure what to rate La Trappe.  I love the beer there.  But when I went there this last time, we felt very UNWELCOMED.  We ordered beer from the bar while waiting for seating to be available.  When our group was finally able to grab seats in the lounge, the waitress KICKED US OUT and told us the lounge is only for food service only.  What the... ?  She gave our seat to a more "suitable" group .. 

I was here previously and I remember speaking to a waiter about seating.  He told me that the table is for food service only, but we can sit in the lounge if we're just drinking.
author: Theary K.

description: I love Belgian beers so this place is great for me. The beer menu looks like encyclopedia, so you can entertain yourself if you come alone. The bartender was helpful recommending beers. I have not eaten here, but the food didn't look appetizing to me.
author: Patricia L.

description: Solid food, great beer. Don't like the wait.
author: Beer W.

description: Loved loved loved this spot.  Reminded me of Europe.  The beer menu was super extensive but I just cut to the chase and asked the waiter to pair a beer on tap with a burger,  The burger was excellent and my father's banger and au gratin dish was killer too.  I am definitely planning to go back and check out their small plates and another beer.
author: Kirsten M.

description: This place is deceiving.  The upstairs is a quaint and intimate restaurant.  Go straight downstairs and you'll find a bustling Belgian beer cellar.  The best selection of Belgian beer I've found (there are hundreds of bottled beers and about 10 or so on tap).  I can't attest to much of the food, as I've only had the Belgian Frittes (they come with your choice of two of their sauces such Belgian mayo, wasabi mayo, peppery ketchup, curry ketchup, red pepper alioli).  Those were good, but then again, I'd probably eat just about anyone's twice fried anything.  Anyway, this place could be pretentious, but the friendly and personable owners and bartenders make sure that it's not.  I'd recommend this ten times over to any beer lover.
author: Daniel F.

description:
Great belgian beer bar in North Beach.

I'm sure my being a fan is partly because its just a hop skip and a jump from my front door.... but the underground lair has its own appeal.

Great Belgian beer list, definitely tops any I've ever seen outside of bars in Belgium itself. 

Can't wait to go back soon.
author: Lynn C.

description:
Didn't eat there, just went for beer.  And oh man, what beer.

Barkeeps know what they're doing and the selection is ridiculous.   Great vibe too.    A unique and marvelous experience.
author: Jon B.

description:
I wouldn't have ever guessed there was a bar downstairs until more of my friends showed up in front and directed us downstairs.

From the entrance, it looks like a cozy little café with a few tables, and if you walk down the staircase you will see a dimly lit tavern with a lively crowd. This underground pub showcases its original red brick and cement walls still intact all over the room. There was a large mirror decorated on one end of the dining room. If you starred into the mirror and the brick wall at an angle at the same time, it looks like its closing in. But, then again, I was a bit tipsy at the time. On the opposite side, there was a seating area with a small entry way that looked like a spooky cave with deep purple and orange lighting hues along the back wall.

If you're into strong malts and ales, this is definitely the place for you! Beer glasses are shaped like wine goblets to enhance flavors and give full aromas. Glasses hung upside down above the bartenders readily available. I ordered the same beer as everyone else to get a good impression of strong Belgium beer. For the life of me, I can't remember the name of Belgium Beer I drank, but it was a dark espresso color that tasted bittersweet with strong notes of caramelized fruits topped off with a  inch head. It definitely wasn't a beer I was familiar with. In my opinion, I think this is the kind of beer that a person should enjoy sitting down over light conversation.

I just happened to come here to help celebrate an old friend's birthday and we took up a lot of space. There were probably 25 of us congregating all over the open area. They were still open to dinner the time we were inside. 

Last call for drinks was at 11:30pm and the bar was closed by midnight. A few of us headed back out to North Beach to get a snack at Golden Boy and satisfy our munchies cravings. I would make another trip out to La Trappe in the near future and get to know their varieties of fine Belgium beer and food. As unique as it is, La Trappe is a definite 'must try!'
author: Hogan W.

description: This is one expensive, pretentious pub. I am continually amazed at how bad the service is here and it's still in business. Must be the tourist connection because there's so many better options in this dept.!
author: john h.

description:
Can't comment on the restaurant BUT I love the downstairs beer cellar -- its dark and cozy and kinda tucked away, makes you feel like you're somewhere far away. 

I like the benches and the dark corners -- where you can have covert conversations (as if I have anything remotely covert to talk about!) 

If you're a beer fan (who isn't??) you'll be giddy over their whole binder full of choices -- they even list the alcohol content, which reminds me of my Irish relatives who factor alcohol content into all of their beverage decisions. 

I would love to spend a rainy day drinking in their cellar -- and maybe even eat something, what a concept!
author: Mary G.

description: Great selection of beer but food is way overpriced. I was charged for ketchup that i requested to eat with my fries.
author: Ella E.

description:
Two things I hate more than anything when I dine out: going with a large group where someone isn't on time, and a restaurant that makes you feel like the worst customer because you are with a large group where not everyone is on time. 

On one hand, I don't want to wait an hour and half for everyone to show up and THEN start to wait for the next table available (supposedly there is only one place in La Trappe that fits 10 people), on the other hand, I can see why the staff is irritated that our group got bigger and bigger over the night around our table that's supposed to fit 7. 

Actually, I don't really see why the staff got that irritated. We never burdened them with our problem. We just kept on getting cozier and cozier as more people came. And we asked people around us for empty chairs and everyone around us was totally cool about it (afterall, no tables crammed like we did; most tables that seat four comfortably were occupied by two people.) And it's not like the late-comers didn't order anything and just took up space. 

Maybe the staff is just over worked, so the mere thought of having to rearrange chairs after we leave got them all riled up. In the entire basement, there was one waitress and one guy who waited AND acted as the host. 

The food came out pretty slow after we ordered, but it was okay because everyone was enjoying their beers. Most of us got the moules et frites for $17. I got moules mariniere which was a bit overcooked. I chose spicy ketchup and curry ketchup as my condiments for the fries and spicy ketchup reminded me of sriracha sauce. Fries were fine, but I am not sure if you can really mess up fries. 

Despite the mediocre food and grumpy service, there were a couple of highlights of La Trappe. We came with a friend who is Belgian and he totally endorsed it. He had been here before and thought the food was authentic. And he licked his bowl of rabbit stew clean, so it must have been good. 

The restaurant itself is super cute. The basement is a bit stuffy, but still really spacious and comfortable for a basement. The lighting was great: not too bright, not too dim. 

The beer selection is outstanding. They have a whole binder of choices and have (if i remember correctly) 19 beers on tap. It reminds me of my favorite hang out when I lived in Lyon, this cozy bar called La palais de la biere where our manly friends can enjoy brews that are way too bitter for me, and I can enjoy a very girlie framboise bierre. And I don't think SF has places like this, so this really fills a void for all the beer lovers here. 

So, if you want to impress your beer connoisseur friends (don't bring more than 3) while munch on some Belgian food, this is a perfect and chill place. But don't try to come here with a large group. It'll drive you and the staff crazy.
author: Candice B.

description:
I should come clean and start by saying that I went into La Trappe with a giant bias. My mom is from Belgium, I went there every few years growing up, and I was literally there three weeks ago, so I may have a big Belgian chip on my shoulder. I went into La Trappe expecting reasonable greatness, and I ended up finding good-ish food but horrendously overpriced beers. This was, in short, disappointing.

As many of the other reviewers have said, the beer selection at La Trappe is huge. You pretty much need the drink menu to sort through all your options, and there are pages and pages of options. My issue was with the prices of the selections. Okay, I know we're in San Francisco and drinks aren't cheap here (and yes, I was spoiled by the cheap Belgian beer in, you know, Belgium), but this was too much. The basest Belgian beer will put you out $7, and if you want anything you've (or I've) heard of, you're looking at spending A LOT more. I gravitated immediately towards the Lindeman's Kriek and Gueuze, family favorites, and was shocked to see that they were on the menu for $29. "Maybe it's a giant bottle," I thought to myself. No siree, it's $29 for your run-of-the-mill 12 oz. bottle. And yes, I do realize that importing beer is expensive, but you can go down to Cost Plus World Market to buy Lindemans and you won't pay more than $9 for a big bottle. I resigned myself to a cheaper, less delicious beer and put our group's name on the list for a table.

Here's where I had another issue with La Trappe. We were a group of eight, and I know that that can be very hard to accommodate, especially on a Saturday night in the city. When I arrived there were only two of us, so I was more than happy to wait at the bar with my cheap beer for a while until more people in our group arrived. Not too much later, we had six of our eight people and asked if we could be seated. Unfortunately, we were told that we couldn't be seated until our full group had arrived, and any other full groups that came in the meantime could take the table we had our eyes on. In principle, this seems like a pretty good system so you don't have groups taking up a table long before they're ready, but I know that when we came in, we were asked if we were a part of a partial group that was... already sitting at a table. I don't mind being told to wait, but not if I know the rules aren't being applied across the board.

You'll be shocked to hear that by the time our last two people showed up, our table had been taken not five minutes before. We were told we could wait in the lounge area, but we could only have appetizers there and not the regular entrees. Since we had a show to get to, we decided that appetizers would be the best option; there were a lot of choices and many were just smaller plates of the entrees anyways. The group had several orders of twice-cooked fries and beef sliders, and a few people tried the mussels, mac n cheese, and "Chicken Videe," a kind of take on chicken pot pie. There's a great selection of dipping sauces for the fries, and aside from a lack of salt (I suppose if we weren't in the lounge we could have used the table salt), they were pretty good. Everyone seemed to enjoy the sliders, especially with the Chimay cheese, and the couple who got the mac n cheese raved about it. All-in-all, the food was enjoyable and reasonably priced for the amount we got.

Good food aside, I still couldn't get over the drink prices and the inconsistent service we received from the host (I should say that the bartenders were very nice). Maybe you'll think my two-star rating is a little harsh, but I won't be bringing my Belgian mom here any time soon.
author: Kristen L.

description: This was the second stop on my friend and I Pub Crawl in North Beach. This place is so deceiving it ain't funny. You walk in and it looks like a small hole in the wall . Then you walk down stairs and it looks like a Belgian Man Cave LOL. I had a Monk Ale which is like a 9% Beer which was tasty . We seated ourselves in the rear couch room which is a good chill spot. I had a Stille Naght which even had a higher Alchol content. The Man Cave was quite packed with patrons. The Bartenders seem to be overwhelmed with thirsty patrons. Ill definitely return.
author: Eugene L.

description:
A holiday trip to the East Coast rekindled my love for the Belgian beer and food and renewed my hunt for the best Belgian bar in SF.  Actually, the resumed search was for ANY Belgian bar in SF.  Note to the establishments who bill themselves as Belgian bars: I know that Chimay is a Trappiste Ale- just because you have on tap among Anchor Steam and Sierra doesn't qualify you as a Belgian bar.  I was in search for the real deal- a place with a big binder of Belgian brews I can't pronounce and a menu loaded with different flavors of moules, frites, and stews.

When I arrived at La Trappe, I was greeted with an empty, dead dining room.  But there were steps leading downstairs and smells of malt and mussels wafting from below.  Downstairs, I was greeted with a lively, packed lounge of patrons.  The first thing I noticed was Gulden Draak and Rodenbach Grand Cru, two of my favorite Belgian brews, on tap!  Next, I was handed a thick binder of an extensive Belgian beer selection.  So far, La Trappe is passing the authenticity test.

The menu was authentic, although somewhat limited (only 4 or 5 entrees offered).  It had the standard staples of moules and frites.  The frites were very authentic- double fried and served with different types of aioli.  For the entree, I want with the Chicken Gentse Waterzooi- a traditional hearty stew with chicken and vegetables in a lightly seasoned cream broth.  It was well-done with fresh ingredients, but could have used a bit more flavor.

Overall, La Trappe seems to be your best bet in SF for a true Belgian experience.  I'm looking forward to returning again.
author: Mike B.

description: I remember la trappe being great. But the last time i went there, my food was tepid and bland. The beers of course, continue to be great.
author: amit s.

description: We had excellent food, great service, wonderful beers (which doesn't cloud my judgement) and very well cooked meals.  It doesn't get much better!
author: Dave F.

description: The food was average, but not bad. The prices are a little steep for the quality. Beer selection was good, and the waiter knew a lot about them. When we went, the service was deplorable. The waiter was very apologetic, but it was hard to overlook. We were there at opening, and it took the two of us 2 hours. It was not the worst experience I've had in SF, but I would not go back.
author: Stephen B.

description:
Huge beer selection - there are a lot of really expensive imported beers in the beer book. Also a decent selection of beers on draft but when we went they didn't have Chimay on draft which was pretty much the reason we went there in the first place. It was pretty disappointing since their website said they did have Chimay on draft...

Anyway, cool space, lots of beers. A little confusing at first though since the huge bar is downstairs in the basement and it feels like you're walking into a tiny restaurant from the street.
author: Emily C.

description: Fantastic beer selection, knowledgeable staff and the mussels are the best if they don't run out!
author: RA R.

description:
Welcome to Belgium.

No, really.  

The lower level looks like any number of places you might patronize in Europe and the layout is pretty cool.  The staff are all great and bartenders don't just serve the stuff, they can definitely tell you about it.  There's usually about 12 Belgians on tap and a variety of other interesting styles or varieties, including domestic takes on Belgian beer.  This place has made me and number of friends a fan out of the Duchese, a Flemish sour ale red in color but delicious.

If you're not feeling too Belgian, the giant bible of bottled beers should keep you busy for awhile. They span the globe and any number of styles and unlike many places, they aren't trying to charge you way too much money for them.  If you're looking for something out of the ordinary talk to one of the bartenders, there's a few things they don't have on the bottle list.

Even if you're not quite a beer connoisseur or aren't really familiar with the drink, there is plenty here to try and you will definitely be able to find something you like.  Me and my roomie have definitely made a habit of coming here and spending the night drinking.  I feel like even if i came here for a few months I still wouldn't have tried everything.
author: Steven R.

description:
Would definitely come back here for the serious beer selection! Knowledgable and enthusiastic bartenders, great draught choices and a whole bible of specialty bottles. 
We also had the small cheese plate and ratatoille. Both were excellent and great pairing for our beers. I had the Chimera - an Italian strong dark ale. Didn't know Italians made good beer, but I enjoyed this one 100%. Followed it up with a bottle of Monk's cafe, cause i had the taste for something sour. 
Atmosphere was decent, i like the exposed brick and the underground feel. Could have done with a little less lighting though. Its def. got a restaurant vibe. 
I'll be back!!
author: Megan Y.

description: Mussels with frites and 4 beers = $60.  I was willing to sell them my belly fat so they can make bacon out of it to cut the costs down.  Pwned.  $15 beers is kinda cray
author: Fatty A.

description: La Trappe is now one of my favorite bars on the planet.  My husband and I were visiting SF recently and spotted La Trappe from the trolley.  When we hopped off, we made our way back as it looked like just our kind of joint.  I'm so glad we went in.  What an amazing little place!  I had some of my favorite beer of my life (Nautilus from Pacific Brewing Laboratory) at the bar downstairs.  I also had a really interesting coconut porter.  Their beer selection is inspired, with selections you won't find almost anywhere else.  The basement bar area is really adorable with interesting photos on the wall (one of Edith Piaf's dead stuffed cat) and a neat little cave area with seating.  The music playing was also perfectly suited to me - The Cure, Flock of Seagulls, etc.  LOVE this place!
author: Tara J.

description: Great Service (Mike). I recommend the mussel appetizer. Super nice selection of beers. Ask for recommendations!
author: Bjørn R.

description:
I think you can experience La Trappe two different ways, depending on when you want to go. Either way you're going to have excellent beers, hearty food, and great ambiance; it's simply a question of how long you want to wait for it.

You can eat upstairs, but I recommend the basement, with its rustic brick walls, dim lighting, and bar crowd that provides an ideal locale for good company and beer. On a weeknight the sound level is perfect for conversations while still feeling decently full. On weekends, I recently waited an hour for a table (no reservations accepted) and it was uncomfortably crowded and more suitable for drinking than dinner. 

Nonetheless, the meal was superbly satisfying once it arrived. In true Belgian form, they specialize in moules frites (mussels and french fries) which are served up in many different forms - classic mariniere (beer sauce), provencal, spicy tomato, and an alternative coconut curry sauce. They're all served with two dipping sauces you get to choose (wasabi mayo, roasted red pepper aioli, etc.) I've also had the boudin blanc sausage, which was served in a tasty mustard sauce over a potato leek gratin. The cheese plates are also a good starter.

Of course you're really coming for the beer list, which is extensive. A good number on tap, and many many more to choose from. I buy a number of Belgian beers from Whole Foods and I must say, however, that La Trappe does mark up their prices considerably. But if you're coming for these calibers of beer, you probably weren't expecting anything cheap anyhow.

My friend likened his last experience to coming into a small Belgian tavern for some hearty food and tasty beer to escape the winter cold. Hopefully you'll get that experience too.
author: Britt M.

description:
My group was hankering some Belgian food love and not necessarily the multitude of beers laid out at the bar.  We had to split up our party cause we were that big...my early group ordered 4 orders of twice cooked fries with the entire range of dipping sauces...awesome fries that we cried how crispy it was and the soft center is super hot, so watch out for the roof of your mouths. 

I ordered the mariniere style mussels and belgian fries. When they placed my seafood pot...I felt like I was brought to my feed bag..it was quite big and the mussels were super tasty. I love love the belgian fries.  My other friends ordered the rabbit stew (haha..she ate Thumper)....Dan M. ordered the Chicken Gentse Waterzooi and it was super delicious...it was also filling, he had to order a togo bag cause he was stuffed. All my other friends weren't as adventurous and chose the standard hamburgers and fries which they claimed was excellent.

If you make reservations here to eat, you need to have your entire party here or they won't seat you.  Also check on the board for their specials, they have the desserts listed there as well.
author: Pauline L.

description: Very cool spot for any beer fans. We've only been there once so far, but my wife and I both really enjoyed our experience. The food was really good (especially whatever mussels we tried that night). The beer selection is ridiculously large, and could be a little intimidating at first, but our waitress was really helpful in finding my wife something she would enjoy.
author: Patrick H.

description:
I'll admit, I haven't eaten the food. We just found ourselves in this basement bar and were instantly in love. Great atmosphere, awesome staff and probably the best beer list ever found. The patrons were also great, some guy Larry helped us out a lot on our travels, we really appreciated that.  I can't wait to go back next time I'm in the city and try the food (i'll update the review at that time).

Oh, and if you get the fries don't get the red pepper aioli or the chipotle bbq... they just don't hold a light to ketchup.
author: Lauren P.

description: food is great here.  got the rabbit and it was delicious.  great beer selection but they are expensive.
author: Wayne C.

description:
Wonderful Belgain Pub.  Really appreciate the knowledge that the staff has, and the extensive beer menu with full descriptions of every beer in the back.

BONUS - food is amazing!  Had the rabbit leg...I was so full that I couldn't finish it and felt like crying because I couldn't take the rest home (was heading other places afterwards.)

Will definitely visit again
author: Jason S.

description: If you want an exhaustive selection of Belgian beers, look no further. The food is good, but every time I've been there the service has been sloooow. It seems odd to me since there are hardly 8 tables in the whole place. As long as you're not in a hurry, you'll have a great meal and some great beer.  Nothing quite like a big 'ol pot of steamed mussels and some frites. Yum!
author: Tootie T.

description:
La Trappe did a great job of decorating their lower level to give you that European restaurant feel.  As soon as I take a seat, I forget that I'm in SF and immediately transformed to a restaurant in Europe on a cold winter day.  

The beer selection here is amazing; the best I have ever seen.  The food is hearty and filling; I ordered the rabbit stew and it was delicious.  If you're not familiar with Belgium beers, the beer menu will give you a crash course and the bartenders are very friendly and will help you with a selection if you tell them what you like and don't like in a beer.  This is a great place to enjoy a piece of Europe.
author: Shannon W.

description:
My favorite bar in the city, I've been coming here since it first opened and have yet to be disappointed.  Make sure to give yourself time to properly read through the massive textbook/menu of Belgian beers.  Be forewarned, the food is decent but this place is really all about the beer.

I highly recommend the Rochefort 10 and the Belgian waffle.
author: Jori P.

description:
I've always loved coming here for their great beers on tap. However, the last time we came the service was so awful it made for an uncomfortable time. First they told us we couldn't sit down unless we got full entrees, even though we said we wanted to order multiple appetizers. This happened when only 2 tables were occupied. Anyways, we ended up ordering the mussels,fries and a salad and some beers. Needless to say the beers were awesome and the mussels were pretty damn good. We know pretty good mussels too, having lived in France for 2 years. 
The service was so bad though, the waitress never came back to take a second drink order and we had to ask two separate workers. Then the bussers tried multiple times to take away our mussel pot when we were still working on it. We visibly had mussels still in the pot. I don't know if they were just trying to move our table along or what but it was very irritating. 
We've been here before and had great men waiters and got seated at a table without ordering any food at all. Maybe it was an off night or newly hired waitresses. Will probably wait awhile before going back though : /
author: Danette R.

description:
La beer is plentiful.
La ambiance is really cool. 
La food is so-so. 

I was really excited about the menu and ultimately disappointed by the execution. I had the mussels and the fries. The flavored mayos that come with the fries are amazing and I like that they're served in a cone just like in the old world. And it's french fries, c'mon!  The mussels were ok, but just ok. I'll go back because the space is so cool.
author: Eli B.

description:
Never left the continental United States?  Don't despair.  The beauty and allure of any large city in the US is that it is filled with culture.  The varied nationalities of the world bring a piece of their home and traditions to share with us Americans. 

After having visited Belgium on a Europe trip this spring, I had been sorely missing the taste of a good belgian trippel, and somehow longing for frites and mayo.  

I was met with a happy surprise upon walking into the basement of La Trappe.

A subterranean bar with low lights and rustic brick walls greeted us.  On its walls were black and white images of people and places in France and Belgium.  I felt like I was in Belgium again.

Moules frites, belgian beer, and rabbit stew graced the pages of its menu.  There was even an assortment of mayonnaises and aioli for fry dipping.

A separate menu was provided for those patrons eager to experience the wonderful world of beer.  Fifty pages of lambics, whites, trippels, Trappist beers, and abbey ales filled it's menu.

I began my journey with the Cherish Kriek.  Basically, it is a champagne-like beer, brewed with love and the taste of cherries.  This is a very popular drink in Belgium, second only to the infamous Lambic.

Many beers were being passed around the table, such as blondes and trippels, but the greatest beer adventure was the "La grande Blanche"  7.5% white beer. Hazy golden amber color.  A complex combination of tastes and aromas such as orange peel, mango pudding and lychee nut.  The finish was "sweet citrus spice, buttered bread and delicate herbal undertones".

Aside from the Belgians, there are Canadians and German, as well as Italian and Japanese beers.

It was a thoroughly enjoyable experience, feeling like I was no longer in the Americas, but back in a centuries old pub drinking beer brewed by trappist monks.

I highly recommend this as a place to meet with friends, sample beers, and eat mussels and fries.  The staff here is very knowledgeable, and it definitely helps if you know little about beer.
author: Jacqueline M.

description:
The first time I went via a recommendation from my friends who live nearby. Make sure you walk downstairs :) We were stuck at an upstairs table perplexed as to what all the noise was about. A waitress was kind enough to take us downstairs where we discovered one of my favorite spots in SF. You feel as if you're in a cellar with a lively but respectfully noisy crowd. The beer list in endless and the wine is pretty good as well. Food also receives a good grade.
Check it out
author: Patrick S.

description: What a surprise ! I have walked by this place many times and wondered how it stayed in business because there are never any diners inside. The secret is - a fabulous and lively dining room downstairs packed with diners. Great ambience, good food. My only negative - it is very loud so don't plan on having an in depth conversation here.
author: Kathleen D.

description: We were really disappointed with our visit here. The food was bland and unflavorful. They don't accept reservations, but we got a table fairly quickly. But once we were seated, it took an hour to get our food while we were trying to get to another reservation that night. My wife had a chicken stew and I had rabbit. Both were bland and didn't come with much meat. We were looking for one nice dinner in San Francisco and thought Belgian was worth a try. Definitely not worth the price or the time.
author: John A.

description:
Great place to grab a beer. Cramped, loud, hard to get a group together, but their tap and bottle list is stellar.

They have a menu, but why? Go somewhere else to eat, somewhere where you can get into a debate about which never-heard-of, monk-brewed, effervescent sour ale is the deliciousest, and then come here to find them all and pick a winner.

Good beer tends to buy my stars pretty easily. It's tempting to give this one 5 because it is so good at what it does, but I really do find the atmosphere oppressively crowded at times, particularly with groups more than 4 strong. It's a solid 4, and if you're out on a quiet night with a small group that has already eaten and just wants to wallow in the best that Saccharomyces cerevisiae has to offer, pretend I gave it 5.
author: Johnathan N.

description:
Oh yelpers, how I love your sensitive temperaments and freaky peccadilloes: they didn't have the obscure bottled beer I wanted, I don't know what rabbit is supposed to taste like, I couldn't match wits with the hostess, i raped - then ate - the busboy... haha.  L O V E  it.

This place is great. I HAVE eaten rabbit before, and the rabbit stew was fantastically rich and hearty. I've also eaten shellfish before, and the Seafood Waterzooi - in addition to being a fun made-up word  - was creamy and delicious. Just like the hostess. Whom I savagely outsmarted by choosing "dinner" when she asked whether we were there for dinner or drinks, and by failing to expound on precisely what the word meant to me at that particular moment. The beer was fine. I don't remember what I had, (always a good sign,) but I'm sure it was something relatively unpretentious without fucking fruit in it. And I learned something interesting: that all beer snobs go to hell and have to rectally pass a keg of Natural Ice for eternity. What I heard anyway.

Go here!
author: Cole M.

description:
This place reminds me of some of the spots I visited abroad...it definitely has the central/eastern european feel to it. We just stopped by briefly for a friend's birthday party, so I didn't really have a chance to take in the full array of beer offerings...just settled for a Duvel but I do love most yummy belgium beers!

When we walked up to it, we almost thought it was closed because there was no one inside...but everyone was just in the downstairs area, which was super cute and cozy and 'authentic' feeling. It also smelled great - would love to come back and try the food here! Only thing is, they close a little early for a bar - they booted us out by midnight!

Really awesome new discovery! I will definitely be adding it to my repertoire of acceptable North Beach destinations!
author: Shannon R.

description: Excellent belgian beer selection folks. Beer aficionados rejoice! They have 400ish bottles to choose from and 15 on the tap? Woot!! So you could practically go here every day of the year and still not repeat your drink :) just saying...Im not much of a beer drinker (personally) but their beers are super tasty...we also had the fries with the yummy aoli and the cheese platter which comes with an assortment of cheeses and fruits/olives/dill n honey comb. The food is rich n heavy...I have had an absolute blast every single time I've gone to the basement bar.
author: Natasha I.

description: Amazing beer list.  I just got back from a trip to Belgium and I can't wait to stop back at La Trappe and pretend I'm still in Europe!
author: Kelly L.

description: Dark, noisy, the waiter was rude, they were out of absolutely each soft drink, the food wasn't good (I'm from Belgium!) and they charged us more than what we should have paid! Disappointed. Wouldn't go back...
author: Chiara R.

description:
Belgian & local beer selection is awesome. Duchesse has been on tap lately--get it.

Mussels & frites, mini burgers and the boudin blanc are badass.
author: Alex F.

description:
It was my friend's birthday and after a boozy dinner at Rogue, we set out to find this "really awesome bar with two levels and good beer". Specific, no?

A few circles around the neighborhood later and we ended up at La Trappe. Around 11pm on a Saturday, it looked absolutely dead on the ground floor, but she was certain this was the place so we walked in and headed downstairs.

Cue angels singing, because it was like walking into a holy underground shrine dedicated to beer!

They have a great selection with a menu that explains a lot about the different kinds of beer. We didn't get food, but it smelled like some hearty European grubbing that I will definitely be down to try.

Less one star because they kicked us out around 12:15 - maybe it was just a slow night.

Drinks: 5 stars
Value: 3.5 stars
Service: ? stars - I didn't actually talk to any servers really
Ambience: 4 stars
author: Shannon B.

description:
I'm tired of drinking cheap beer. 
Seriously, when did this become a trend? and when is it going to end?
A recent Thursday night excursion led a friend and I to La Trappe, where within minutes we had seats at the bar and delicious drinks in hand. I went with the Duchesse de Bourgogn, highly recommended. The bartender answered our silly questions, poured us all the samples we could ask for and told me about a good place for focaccia bread.
Yeah its expensive if you compare it to $1 PBR, but La Trappe reminds us of the better things in life. Worth it!!!
author: Laura T.

description:
Cruising down North Beach, things get a little dark once you get closer to Greenwich.  If you look West you'll see a little shop on the corner, slightly dimly lit, with no big signs.

The place looks large from the outside, but that's because it's connected to the building.  When we walked in, everyone looked at us.  It was like they were surprised anyone else would come in other than them.  The bar upstairs was really brightly lit, and there weren't a lot of people.

We immediately headed down the stairs.  This place is really small inside!  Downstairs it felt like I was in a different country almost.  belgium?  I've never been, maybe it's also made of brick.

Lots of friendly waiters and waitresses who were always available when we needed them.  I had the La Divine beer, it was fantastic!  The fries were also quite amazing.  They're larger cuts, my favorite.

Go here for good beer, friendly service, and awesome fries.
author: Art C.

description:
LOVE LOVE LOVE this place. 

The gem and the tremens is downstairs. As you walk down the windy stairs you enter was looks like a secret room, a secret room of BEER! have I entered heaven on earth? What a great place to spend my birthday. I love beer, I love belgain beer and I love and midscale menu that's accessible (affordable) to hardworking Sf'ers. 

The beer-tenders are very informative and will talk your ear off about beer if you just say the word. The atmosphere is relaxing, communal and makes you want to read a book if that makes any sense. They also have a small offshoot room for lounging where you can order apps and beers as you chill on the sofas. 

I will go back for sure. Probably my favorite "well rounded" beer focused restaurant.
author: Sarah D.

description:
This was a completely different experience from the last time I was here. Do not come here on a Friday or a Saturday night.

This place should be ashamed to call itself authentic Belgian.

In Belgium, if someone walks up to the bar and loudly demands to be served the strongest beer available, they'd be laughed at and asked to leave. Here, they're served. Hey, money is money, right?

Not surprisingly, 30 minutes later, this same guy is in the bathroom, puking out his brains in a urinal. After his party breaks a pint glass.

On top of that, the food had noticeably gone downhill since the last time I was here. The butter was horribly stale. They forgot our dessert. The fries and cheese plate, were great however.

Regardless, you don't go to a belgian beer bar to get drunk. There are plenty of other places to do this.

This is why Europe has much less strict alcohol laws than we do, because they're not a bunch of drunken idiots.

Do you really need the money that bad that you'll just let anyone show up who wants to get drunk?
author: Mark A.

description:
I really wish I lived close to La Trappe.  Then again, if I did I would probably convert 1/2 of my income into beer and subsequently a lot of calories leading to a ginormous beer belly.  I guess that's not a bad thing since I like beer, but I like to keep "fit".

We almost always hit this place on a GNO (Guys Night Out) or a Bachelor Party pub crawl.  It's quite perfect for that type of event.

The selection of Belgian beers here is superb and is rivaled only by a few establishments in the bay area.  Definitely some exotics served here, including even the occasional Flemish Sour, which is my favorite varietal of beer - for those unaware, it's an acquired taste.

What really turns me on to La Trappe is the ambiance.  It's dark, mysterious and cave-like.  It reminds me of some of the deep basement brick-walled bars I've been to in Munich.  You walk down a dark staircase that leads you to a room with a bar and tables where jolly people laugh and chat with one another.  It makes you feel special.  Like you're in a secret place that nobody knows about.  That gives it an elevated status as far as I'm concerned.  It can make you feel cool when you definitely are not!  

There is a restaurant up top, but I've never sampled any of the food here.  I just head straight for the underground.  Hey, a man has to have his priorities, right?  The beer can be practically a meal in itself, so it may be a while before I even make an attempt at the Moules a la Biere and Frites.
author: Bryan T.

description: I only experienced the bar but the bartenders are rude and snarky. I won't be back
author: Olivia G.

description: Took my family here this weekend expecting some delicious Belgium food, and although our main courses were pretty good, they weren't very authentic. If you've had a real croquette, don't expect theirs to be anything like it we were really disappointed. They also didn't have 5 of the beers that we ordered, the waitress kept coming back to say they were out of stock. It took a long time too, for us that wasn't an issue because we had the time but it's not a quick place by any means. Our waitress also tried to charge us for a glass of wine that we sent back, and didn't drink because it wasn't the wine we ordered. She took it off the bill eventually, but it was strange she even tried to charge us for it. It's pricey for what it is, but the atmosphere is fun.
author: Caroline D.

description: I wish I could give La Trappe a higher rating, but after my last visit, I'm not coming back!  First of all, it was 7 pm on a Friday and they had ALREADY run out of mussels - their signature dish!  Also, we ordered 2 bottles of beer off their beer menu, and it took our waiter 15 minutes after ordering to tell us that they didn't have either beer.  Then we ordered another, and it took them another 15 minutes to tell us they didn't have that beer.  I appreciate the large beer menu, but don't pretend like you have 100 beers when you only have 10.
author: Leanne B.

description:
So much character! There are few bars in SF that create there own ambiance and this is one of them. 

When you first walk in, the bar looks deserted...but wind down the circular staircase and you will find a bar that is more like a cozy den. Red walls with dark wooden beams make a great set up. 

The Belgian beers are expensive, but delicious. The food was surprisingly good too! I recommend the split pea soup and grilled vegetable medley with polenta. 

Finally, for all the anti-glutens...your answer to beer has arrived--Greens blonde and amber beers!

Overall great spot to catch up with a friend and enjoy a great brew!
author: Jennifer W.

description:
My Haiku for La Trappe:

Belgian beer is grand
Moules Fritte is a must have dish
La Trappe makes me smile

I came here with my wife while on vacation.  I can't remember which mussels dish I had, but I really enjoyed it.  My wife also had mussels and enjoyed them as well.  Between the two of us we tried four of the sauces for the frites.  One of the spicier ones was our favorite (can't remember which one it was).

Now on to the good stuff.  If you like Belgian beer, I don't know why you would go anywhere else in SF.  This place has the largest selection I've ever seen outside of Belgium itself.  Yes, I'm dead serious.  My wife and I spent about two weeks in Belgium in 2008 and the beer list at La Trappe would rival many of the places we visited in Bruges, Brussels, Dinant, and other cities.  Not all beers on the menu at La Trappe are from Belgium, but I didn't see one that wasn't either from Belgium or a Belgian style (Triple, Quad, etc).

Perhaps my favorite thing about this place was the beer menu.  Not just the selection of beers, but the physical menu itself.  The organization was unlike anything I've ever seen.  The beers were listed by style, but each style had a definition of said style.  The section on Trappist beers was nice to see as well.  If I recall, the beers are also listed alphabetically.  I've never seen so much thought put into a beer menu like that.  If I was a clepto, I totally would have walked out with one (I didn't).

We dined downstairs in the corner and received good service.  Our waitress seemed fairly knowledgeable about some of the beers my wife asked about.  I ended up having Rochefort 6, St. Feuillien Triple, and Orval (one of my favorites of all time).

Like the Publick House in Boston, if I'm every back in SF, you'll most certainly find me here.  If you're ever in Atlanta, our best beer bars are The Porter and Brick Store Pub.  Both top notch.
author: Kevin F.

description:
Had dinner and drinks at La Trappe with one of my buds on a Saturday night.  The beer menu is voluminous.  And I never use the word voluminous.  Asked the bartender for a suggestion.  He gave me a "really??" look.  I'm telling you - voluminous.  The place was full.  The crowd was young.  Hit up the bar to wait for a table.    

Never had beer in a corked wine bottle.  Felt cultured.  Talking about hops and grains.  Wait - don't really know what that means.  High alcohol volume percentage?  I know what that means...yeaaaa...

The waitress is pleasant, service is pretty good.  Ordered the fries with spicy ketchup (great).  Very well cooked fries - almost McD quality.  Had the chicken gentse waterzooi for the entree.  Love the name.  Described as a cross between stew and soup.  Very on par description.  Getting a little bit tipsy at this point.  My waterzoooooiii tasted great with my corked beer (with delicious grains and hops) with high abv %.  Grabbed the voluminous beer menu.  Ordered another.
author: Mitchell L.

description:
There's no better place to have a beer in San Francisco. With over 300 beers to choose from, there's something for everyone here. The bartenders and waitstaff are very knowledgeable about beer and the owners are great guys. 

The food is unpretentious, good ol' bar food, belgian style. You can get mussels cooked several different ways, and the fries are heavenly. 

I highly recommend the Klokke Rolland or the Val-Dieu Grand Cru. Both are quite high in alcohol %, but both have such amazing flavor.
author: Aaron S.

description:
La Trappe...Good Beers. Good Food. Good People. Dark Corners.

One day, if zombies ever attack like in Shaun of the Dead, La Trappe is my safe zone.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
Really a 3.5 but I figured I will round down on this one.

If you aren't a beer person, I would not recommend this place. If you are a beer person, well then bottoms up!

The food was actually much better than I thought it would be.  The double fried french fries were good (though there are very few french fries that I will turn my nose up to) and the deep fried (are we seeing a trend) portabello burger was delicious! A couple hours later, I was not so happy that I made the decision to eat the whole thing, but all the same it was delicious!

The beer.  You are handed about a 50 page binder of beers (what beer-lover isn't in love at this point?!) However, it is a little bit overwhelming.  I got a blonde and a hefeweisen- both were delicious though quite small for $9 and $6 respectively.  Now lets be honest. No matter how delicious you might think beer is, are you really going to pay $40 for one? Probably not.  But the binder is FULL of WAAAAYYYY over priced beers.  Yes, yes import taxes, its cheaper than going to Belgium and getting one, but seriously? 

A great way to change it up from Italian food if you are in North Beach but I probably wouldn't make it a point to come here again.
author: Jean K.

description: I love, love, loveeee this place! The downstairs bar is SUPER cozy, food is great, beer selection is out of this world! Def one of my favorite places in NB!
author: Lacey L.

description:
4.75 stars of deeeeliciousness!

great beers on tap [i recommend tasting a few before ordering the right one]. great service. basement ambiance is loud and eventful.

but heres where it gets really good:

dozens of fresh oysters, moules fritte - duh that means buckets of hot, juicy, steaming mussels in your choice of savory broth with a giant cone of perfectly cooked french...err...freedom (?) fries with a variety of dipping sauces (the spicy ketchup is my fave), followed by a tower of german chocolate cake (yes theyre close enough to Germany to know how to make this divine dessert). the smoked trout on endives & roasted veggies over polenta are also great!

all in all if you follow the simple, yet satisfying steps:
beer
oysters
moules fritte
cake
you will walk out of here warm, full to the brim, and happy you didnt have to fly all the way to Belgium to get an authentic tasty meal!
me likey!
author: Kaylan S.

description:
If I could give this place half a star, it would be too much.  I have never met a manager so rude and unconcerned about the diners in his establishment.  How do you run out of the most ordered entree in your restaurant at 8:30 on a Saturday night?  But, don't tell the patrons until they've sat for 40 minutes.  Three steaks - medium rare - one raw and couldn't be eaten.  A burger ordered well done - waiter suggests medium well - comes out rare.  After 15 or so minutes, here comes the burger... It was really awesome eating by myself.  Approached manager with said issues...mussels issue.."yeah"...steak issue..."he ate his meal (had 3 bites)...burger issue..."was made good"...won't be back...."that's ok"...

Obviously, they must be doing well enough on the beer sales that the food doesn't matter.

Highly unrecommended
author: Weezab B.

description:
Perched on a three way cross way, this restaurant has more bang than it looks from the outside. On a Wednesday night, the ground level was crickets-cricking quiet, but the place was surprisingly busy downstairs. Watch your steps though, the basement is darker than most places, which made me feel drunk before I sat down.
