Service was very nice and helped us keep an eye out for a table for 10. They gave us a heads up about who they thought were going to leave soon and told us to hang tight. Also recommended a good beer that is on tap among their dictionary of a menu featuring a gazillion beers. I had the Affligem, a blonde beer, twice that night. We also had a "shot" of 13% beer--the name is eluding me right now, but it means devil in a language and dawns a little devil on the label. It was pretty good for a 13%, but also liked the Master Carlsburg that was about 12% in Denmark.

GET THEIR TWICE COOKED FRIES if you're not looking for a meal. They are delicious. It comes with two sauces that you can choose from 10 or so. The waitress recommended the Spicy Mustard and The Chipotle, of which I only liked the Chipotle. I loved the Honey something Aioli. Delicious.
I love my fries.

If you're looking for a filling meal, my friends gave great reviews for the San Francisco burger, which also comes with the fries.
The Mussels + Fries was also a great deal for $16--you get a medium sized pot of mussels and an order of fries.

Beers averaged from $6-$8 on tap.

I would definitely go back, but probably not often because of the 20 min bus ride from SOMA.
author: Rena Y.

description:
Here's what the Belgians do right - fries, mussels, chocolates and beer. Ok, there might be more but those are the only things I care about.


 Friday night I met up with some friends at La Trappe for a couple of beers and we were all impressed (so much so that one of my friends brought a group back on Saturday night) We tasted some fantastic beers and had a great conversation with one of the owners who filled us in on some of the history of the place. There are a few bistro tables and an open kitchen upstairs but the highlight of the space is the basement dining room/bar. We nibbled on some tasty fries and were all salivating at the dishes coming out of the kitchen - this is the type of place where I could roll in solo and grab a burger and a couple of beers at the bar without feeling like a total loser. Well, at least for dining alone.


 Five enthusiastic stars. Now this is a neighborhood spot where I can see myself becoming a regular.


 update
Since my initial visit I've become a bit of a regular at La Trappethe owner's are fantastic (they even reserved their lounge for my birthday happy hour) and I love all of the beer suggestions! Good stuff, definitely check it out next time you're in SF.
author: tvham

description:
Great Beer!  Lots of selection.  Cute place with a basement - can be with a group or a cute different date spot.  We had a group of 9 which they were very accommodating to on a Saturday night.

no reservations just give your name to the barman.  

The Fries are pretty awesome - there are 12-13 dippng sauces you can order 2 from.  We had a couple sets and all were awesome - best was the garlic mayo.  Oysters were great - fresh!  Again - GREAT beer selection. 

Wait staff was friendly and not impatient or pushing us out.   Came around often for beer orders. 

Would definitely go back.
author: Sarah G.

description:
I really love La Trappe's atmosphere. It's a place I want to hang out in. I'm impressed by the beer selection (even though I know nothing about Belgian beer) and we had great service. I also appreciate the cozy little lounge available for those waiting for a table.

But sadly....the food was a major bummer. I tried the chicken waterzooi, hoping to enjoy a traditional Belgian dish. I expected a creamy chicken stew; I got chunks of boiled chicken in a broth so bland, no amount of salt and pepper could save it. It was really nothing short of disgusting. I could have gone the safe route and ordered a hamburger (which looked really good on my friend's plate), but aren't you supposed to be "safe" ordering a traditional dish suggested by the server? Oh well. I'd love to go back, simply for hangout purposes, but my food next time will be limited to pub fare. Skip the pricier entrees and avoid disappointment.
author: Beth T.

description:
Yeah, the crowd can run the gamut from total tools to cool visitors. But whatever. The beer selection is incredible! Love the subterranean speakeasy feel. 

My suggestion. Order enough beers so that the alcohol volume adds up to 25 for the night. Best night ever. Get a cab.
author: Justin And Courtney L.

description:
We were on a Beer Crawl: Brainwash, Bloodhound, City Beer, Rogue, La Trappe. This was stop five on the list. I was doing Porters and Ambers, so they were all very strong beers. They didnt have a Porter, but they didn have a very nice Cask Amber. The Bar is downstairs in the basement... Private area in the back for the special peeps. Restaurant upstairs. Cant remember if there was any music as this was stop 5 on a long run...

Excellent beer selection. -1 for no Porter. 

+5 for the most attractive crowd i have seen in SF in a decade. Hot, Hot...
author: Adam X.

description:
Wavering around 3 stars, but these things push it to 4:

--Service: super pro, attentive, friendly, and knowledgeable!
--Atmosphere: it's cold and echo-ey, and totally unique.  Cool dining experience.
--Beer selection ?!  Overwhelming!!  Just ask your server for some rec's.  Or blindfold yourself and throw a dart at the menu.  You certainly won't miss the menu, and you'll probably try something you never knew existed.
--Location: north beach is so next year forever.

Things that weren't quite 4 stars:
--  The fries were so-so.  For a mussels & frits experience, I want superlative fries.  These were just semilative.
-- Price.  I can't help but compare it to Frjtz, where you get a bit better ding for your deutchmark.

Here's a story for ya if you're so inclined: http://stretchyhead.com/la-trappe-cafe/
author: S H.

description:
"I think that place should not serve food."
This coming from my husband... beer is good, but pours are small.  Fries were good, but the mussels were a mess: not cooked enough, and the Moules Mariniere  was quite spicy (it really should not be.)   They serve 20 mussels per pot, which is about half of what you'd get in Belgium/France/ or any decent restaurant. 
Our waitress was good, but when we explained the problems with the mussels, we were only offered a free beer, which we declined, and the check came full price.  We then asked to speak to the manager, who did not take the time to talk to us, but authorized the waitress to take the mussels off the bill.  Thanks for that, but don't you care about the quality of your food??
I guess not.  Most of the customers looked like beer dudes anyway.
 - "A good pub, definitely not a restaurant, and no customer service from the management."
author: danielle d.

description:
I finally figured this place out. This is not a beer parlor it's a restaurant with a big selection of beer. They make a big deal out of the beer but they have no respect for people that are just in there to drink beer. If they want to be a beer parlor they need a bigger bar, more people serving the beer, and more seating for the beer drinkers.

Also that dark little beer room is very creepy, I'm afraid I'm going to be molested in there. Turn the damn lights up a little!

I was finally in there with people eating the food and it was wretched. I thought the pork chop was under cooked until I saw the raw hamburger, by raw I don't mean rare, I mean raw.
author: Manny F.

description:
This is a tough call: on the one hand I'm a fool for delicious Belgian beer - and for their selection I can't fault them in the least (except maybe for not having Tripel Karmeliet on tap.) The service was above average, which is saying something considering that the place was at about 80% capacity.

So why the hemming and hawing? This may sound kind of irrelevant or vague, but... there wasn't a single person there that looked interesting enough to want to talk to. I don't mean like a pick-up scene, I just mean in general. Granted that it was Saturday night in North Beach and if all I wanted was good conversation there's always Trieste, Spec's, City Lights, blah blah blah... but still, I'm used to my Belgian beer bars being stocked with *characters.*

This won't stop me from going back of course; it'll only limit how long I stay. Oh, and I didn't get to try the café upstairs so will make a note to check that out too.
author: Ronzlo L.

description:
Oh hullo, I grew up on Greenwich and apparently so did the owners.   That property has been in their familia forever.   How cool is that?!  I am a LOVER of Belgian ales and Saisons.  Talk about choices!  Good food and snacks to go with.  It's rather unassuming from the exterior and upper level but then you descend into a cozy cave.  Had my birthday party there - excellent for gatherings and celebrations!

Really enjoy the Grand Cru Rodenbach and if you like cherries - the Kasteel Rouge.  Need to sample more unique Saisons...must go this week!

LOVE the owners and servers - they are real and down-to-earth peeps!
author: D L.

description:
This is hands down my favorite beer bar in the city.  It delivers on all fronts.  I was already hooked on Belgian beer joints after visiting my borther in DC and stopping at a few great places there.  Well this place is even better.  The food is awesome, with plenty of delicious mussles options (we tried several and they were all delicious).  The squash soup was also very good.

The beer selection is truly impressive and the menu is kind of daunting.  I am a true beer conessiuer and this place had lots of stuff I had never even heard of.  I really dig the atmosphere here too.  Downstairs the place is decked out in dark red with really dim lighting.  The tables are really comfortable and provide an easy way to escape the crowd if you get there early enough.  It's also pretty close to where I live, but I wish there were more bars like this on Polk st in Nob Hill.  I was really dissapointed with the selection a few blocks down and actually with SF in general.  However, La Trappe definitely did not dissappoint.
author: Paul W.

description:
Mussels four different ways? Heaven!! 

If you're headed to La Trappe for the mussels and are indecisive about the four different ways they are served, here are my favorites in order of preference: 

1) Provencal (White wine and garlic tomato sauce with parsley)
2) Spicy Tomato (tomatos, pureed with rosemary and dried chili)
3) Mariniere (white beer sauce with lemon, shallots, and fresh herbs)
4) Coconut Curry on Jasmine Rice (Jalapeños, lemon grass, cilantro and fresh lime juice)

The mussels come with twice cooked fries... can we say fried heaven? You have the choice of two of eight dipping sauces. Favorites were Roasted Red Pepper Aoli, Honey Graham Dijon Aoli and Spicy Ketchup. 

I would love to comment on the EXTENSIVE beer list; however, I just listened to the server's recommendations as I held the 2390438 page beer menu in my hand. Ok, I exaggerate but as an amateur beer drinker, I entrusted my beer choice to the waitress and was not disappointed.

My advice is to call for a reservation to ensure a seat downstairs in the more lively drinking and dining area. If there's a bit of a wait, at least you have 2390438 pages of beer selections to digest :)
author: Lan H.

description:
Cool spot that was just the place for my roommate's bday celebration.  She likes good food and lots of beer.

When I first walked in through the door, it was silent.  Not a customer in sight and just one or two workers roaming around.  I was told to just head straight down the stairs by my co-workers and I see what they mean.  Groups gathering around at the tables and bar.  It was lively and looked fun!  A bit dark down there, but I wasn't really complaining about that.

We had them set up a table for 10 of us and they were very accommodating.  I went w/ the san francisco burger which was great!  We also got to choose two dips for the fries and I went w/ the honey something sauce and the spicy ketchup.  Very different flavors but they both compliment the fries very well.  

This place reminds me of cafe biere, but bigger. cool spot for a chill night and a beer.
author: Tom Y.

description:
this place is probably great if you are just going to drink beer, but i doubt i will ever eat here again. we rolled in late on a tuesday and they were sold out of the mussels which apparently are good here--i'm not convinced tho based on the other options. i went with the spagetti with bolognese sauce. it was fine, if you're 10 years old. there is nothing special about it. the husband got the burger which he said was ridiculously dry and overcooked. we shared the fries with the table and those were not bad, just not particularly great or flavorful. i mean, even if everything else sucked, at least the fries should be delicious. the dipping sauces were ok, but didn't do much to make things more exciting. 

i would much rather go to monk's kettle where the food is as yummy as the beers.
author: rachel p.

description:
I went here last night for the first time and truly enjoyed it. I love places that have huge varieties and La Trappe is no exception. What a huge selection of beer! It is so fun to just sit at the bar and sample different Belgian beers, plus the staff is incredibly friendly and knowledgable. 

Five stars for the decor also...it's absolutely adorable- nice, cozy brick walls, and European style design.

I will definitely have to come back!
author: Angela G.

description: yay I'm a fan.  La Trappe has great beer, mussels & frits + ~12 different dipping sauces (and are the best foods on the menu). The upstairs and downstairs have totally different vibes, must go downstairs check it out...
author: Pamela A.

description: Can't really review as I looked at the prices and left.  $36 for a bottle of ABT 12?  Are you insane.  I can name 5 places I can go and get this on tap for normal prices.  I can understand charging high prices for rare or exotic beers, but they charge for everything Belgian.  Unless you have no other beer drinking options, avoid.
author: Jim G.

description:
I love how this place is so unassuming from the outside. A book full of Belgian beers to order from, buckets of mussels, and fries with a myriad of dipping sauces - it was awesome. The atmosphere is dark, and charming. There's a great spot in the back of the downstairs that's great for groups & low key evenings. 

A note on etiquette:
Unfortunately, the night we came some clumsy guy somehow catapulted the contents of his table in our direction - subsequently dumping ketchup, aioli, and other fries condiments on my fiance's leather coat. We were good sports about it - but I just wanted to make a note that while this has nothing to do with the restaurant or service there (they brought us towels, etc to help clean off) - if you SPILL on someone - the classy thing to do is a) offer to pay for a cleaning or b) - send a round of drinks over!
author: Jessica M.

description: Hands down one of my favorite places in San Francisco. Great beer, atmosphere and food. *highfive*
author: Matt M.

description:
My god, what a great beer selection. I went here at the tail end of a night of drinking with my brothers, and one of them got the recommendation from a bartender at another establishment. What a great call! 

The basement is intimate and a good place to hang out. The crowd seemed pretty cool, at least as much as I could remember through the haze of the evening. My only gripe? The douchey guy behind the counter who refused to give us a straight answer when we asked what his favorite beers were. I mean, come on dude. Obviously you're proud of your menu, but to say that you have NO favorites amongst the scores of bottles and drafts? At least play along and make conversation with your customers about why different beers are best with X, Y and Z.

Still, next time I'm in town, I'm definitely making a stop out here.
author: Anthony C.

description:
I got serious Belgian cred.  

Back when Belgium was a fly-over country and/or the butt of jokes (one snotty Brit once asked me, in all seriousness, "What exactly does one DO, in Belgium?"), I was visiting my family there, enjoying all things Belgian, e.g., Beer, Fries, Beer, Chocolate, Beer, Mussels...and so much more, and wondering why the hell all this great stuff never caught on in the U.S.  German beer?  Swiss Chocolate?  French Fries?  No, no no; Belgian, Belgian, Belgian.  Ahh, Belgie.  What do the smurfs and the saxophone have in common?  That's right, Belgian.   PS, no Belgian calls him or herself  "Belgian".  You are either Flemish or Walloon...but that's a whole 'nother topic...Ahem...

Fortunately, Belgium has slowly but surely been getting it's due here in the U.S. and I was stoked to check this place out.  (I had my 2-word review all set in case I didn't like it:   "La Crappe.")  What can I say, I did like it.  The basement is the place to be--felt like I was back in Antwerp.  Great, cosy decor, wood, stone and even some stained glass and a fountain.  Nice job.

The beer list is great.  They don't have my favorite, Westvleteren, but that is really tough to find, since the monks that make it are strictly old school (like, medieval old school) and only sell it right out of the Abbey.  Check it out.  http://www.sintsixtus.be/eng/brouwerij.htm  (Toronado is the only place I've ever found it stateside.)  But La Trappe had all of the other trappist beers, and a lot more.  

As for the food, they not only have the usual suspects, mussels and fries, they have stuff my grandmother used to make, like rabbit and even (gasp) the classic Belgian stew, waterzooi!  I actually wasn't crazy about the food (had the rabbit, mussels and fries, which were all on the bland side), and our server was a little absent-minded, but hats off to the owner for putting these Belgian classics on offer.  

Bottom line:  For a taste of Belgium, check this place out.
author: Peter V.

description:
I would place them at 4 and half stars.

I honestly wouldn't have known that a bar existed in the basement if it weren't for my friends leading me down there, but there it was - dim but vibrant and packed with people.

Their beer selection is book-sized, which is where the waitresses' and bartenders' expertise pay off, if you don't happen to have a well-versed companion.  You can spend many a night here trying out different varieties.

The selections I had were tasty and distinct - I liked learning that each beer is meant for a specific glass.

The food was the pleasant surprise - everything was great.  The twice-cooked fries were distinctive, and the cheese plate was a huge hit.

I had the sliders, which were tasty (if not a bit too salty), and mushroom polenta, that everyone kept coming back too.


Really, the only lost half star is the confusing way tables are handed out - we weren't really sure what was going on after an hour wait.  Smaller groups of people will definitely have an easier time weekend nights.
author: Don B.

description: I've been here about a half a dozen times. Page 12 of the menu is my favorite. The beer menu changes all the time and the food is great. I like this place because it feels secret. I will continue to go here.
author: Marty W.

description: Pretty cool spot to hit up if you're doing a progressive dinner/ cocktail night!
author: Shawday B.

description: Great selection of Belgian beers!  They are more expensive than your average beer.  For example, I had a Gulden Draak ($9) which I liked its stout texture with a hint of honey (10% alcohol).  Be aware of what your tastes are, these can be different.  For example, my friend had a beer that had almost a sour wine taste to it.  Because of the other reviewers comments, we didn't have food.  The atmosphere was brick walls and service was good.
author: Ethan K.

description: Mussels were bountiful.  Sauce was good (curry).  The french fries are double-fried, so it's got that nice Jack in the Box crust.  It comes w/ two dipping sauces and my fav was the wasabi mayo.  I also had the spaghetti.  Surprisingly good, better than most Italian pasta joints.  The noodles were thick (like udon) and were cooked perfectly to al dente.  The brussels sprouts were okay, plentiful, but boiled or steamed and covered in a ranch like sauce.  I was hoping that they would be roasted, but I needed fiber so they worked.  Overall, beer selection is crazy.  I'm not a fan of tripels, or doubels, but this place has a ton of foreign beers.  This place reminded me a lot of bars in Paris.  It has a really cool vibe and the servers are very nice.  I'm glad I came here.
author: Daniel H.

description: Very nice and clean restaurant on the top floor and on the bottom is a cool lounging environment; you can choose to dine on either floor. The staff is really pleasant and helpful. Had the mussels with Belgium fries ($18) which was really good. The rabbit cooked with beer was good too. Large portions makes it worth your money. Will definitely come back, lounge, and try their beer.
author: Sophia K.

description:
I wasn't overly impressed with La Trappe.   The Belgian Beer Selection is quite impressive, but the the "on tap" beer sizes vary and most selections are only offered in a single size.  I am used to being able to order any beer in 2 or 3 sizes when in Belgium.  For the most part I thought the Beer was overpriced (at least the beer that you can find at other establishments around town).  I tried a few different beers with my meal which I ate in the cellar. 

The food did not knock my socks off.  The "grass fed" burger was nothing to write home about... I didn't even finish it despite being hungry.  The fries were delicious, but not worth making a trip back for, I would probably head to Frjtz if that was what I was craving (they have more dipping sauces). My companion had mussels and fries which were served in a huge pot  filled above the brim, but they did not match the mussels I had a day earlier in Belden Alley, although there were more of them.

The round table for two was so tiny that our food and drinks were fighting for places to sit and helped to make the place feel even more cramped than it already was.  We asked if we could move to a slightly larger empty table when the food arrived, but were told someone was waiting for it.   It sat empty until just before we finished our meal. The noise level was incredible.  It was very hard to communicate and be heard despite there being a few empty tables while we were dining.  

I might come back here for beer and appetizers if I planned on sitting at the bar or if I had friends who wanted to drink Belgian beers in North Beach.  However, I don't think it is worth going out of your way to eat or drink here. It is very small, so not great for large groups.  The noise level due to the low ceiling prevents it from being cozy. It does feel like one of the cellar breweries in Europe built to a much smaller scale.
author: Cat C.

description: La Trappe has some Harry Potter magic going on, from its secluded downstairs pub atmosphere to its innovative take on the gastropub label.  Its got a certifiably Disneyland-sized selection of beers, an exciting/sweet take on Moules a la Biere, and their Boudin Blanc will make you wonder why you never ate more tubed meats in white sauce.  Do yourself a favor and stop by; you'll need to fuel up before taking on the Defense Against the Dark Arts teacher (Who eats at Sizzler, BTW).
author: Michael D.

description:
holy crap, what the hell happened to the tasty fries????  

also, i will translate La Trappe host-speak for you:

"we have a table for you...just a couple of minutes" means "you will get a table, unless 3 dudes come in AFTER you, and they will get that table and you will wait for another one, and don't complain or we will give you food that doesn't taste that great.  haha...just kidding, you will get food that doesn't taste that great either way".

okay, their sliders were actually pretty decent.  the bread they served was burnt.  the fries were not good at all...oh, did i say that already?  my friend got some portabello mushrooms over polenta....she had a small bite of the polenta and then pushed the plate away.  the mushrooms looked like kaka on a plate too...not that i've ever seen kaka on a plate, but that's what i would imagine it to look like.
author: Miss P.

description:
AWESOME.

There really isn't much to not like about La Trappe. From its subtle exterior to it's dungeon like bar downstairs, this place is nothing but good times for those who appreciate a fine selection of beers and a relaxed evening out. The bartenders/servers are all very friendly and are more then knowledgeable in the variety of beers available. And oh, the beers. While I refuse to even start to describe the beers I've tasted (for the simple fact that I'd do them an injustice describing them verbally), I was blown away by it all. 

What tops off having a great beer in your hand? How about some mussels with belgium fries and a selection of dipping sauces!?! Damn, I'm in heaven already. The Moules Frittes provencal style was by far my favorite. Factor in some chipotle mayo and spicy ketchup and the meal was money! Beyond this dish though, I wasn't too impressed with the remaining entrees... I really wanted to like everything but it wasn't in the cards. The grilled pork chop was hearty but came out too well done and dry. The Chicken Waterzooi - Ghent Style seemed more like an enormous bowl of chicken soup. Good but just got tiring to eat after awhile. While I'm still fan, I'm hoping there's a rotation or reworking of the menu. 

In the end, try the place out. You will not regret it.
author: Jonny Bobby G.

description:
This is an excellent Belgian beer bar and restaurant. I have been there twice now in 2 weeks and I live in Mountain View! 

Beer selection is very impressive. They have La Chuef on tap, which is rare. The environment is very European and fun. Exposed brick all over the basement. The top part looks very fancy, but the best part of this place is the basement.

I ate the grass fed beef burger and OMG, it is the MOST amazing burger!!!! Incredibly delicious. I've never had anything like it. I went home and tried to recreate it on my own, but unsuccessfully. Fries are only okay, and the sauces I tried were only okay too. Spicy ketchup is SPICY! Like jalepeno spicy. I love spicy food, but it was way too much for me.

Overall great place!!
author: Hannah K.

description:
I love going to La Trappe to hang out when we are in San Francisco.  The staff is always amazing, friendly and willing to teach me about the beers.  I have learned more about beer from the bartenders and the customers than I thought was even possible.  Making beer really is an art and with all the beers available here, it's fun to appreciate art!  

I have mixed opinions on the food there.  The burgers are great, the fries with the mix of dipping sauces are excellent but the duck soup and the sausage weren't that good.  We usually go out for dinner and then end up here for the rest of the night.

The prices are reasonable, the atmosphere is superb and the staff is top notch and most of the time the other patrons sitting at the bar are great company.
author: Misti P.

description: Holy moly this place was good! had the mac n cheese and the veggie raviolis which they had infused with CINNAMON!!! wozers 2 must haves... only docking one star bc it took the server super long to get to us but they seemed a bit short staffed and busy =)
author: Darlene T.

description: Amazing beer selection.  Awesome food. He's downstairs for the best ambiance. Don't be in a hurry as Each plate is made one at a time.
author: Eric S.

description:
Wandered in here one cold evening while waiting for friends to join up and it certainly lifted my spirits.

Apparently the upstairs is a restaurant, though it was closed at the time because all the chairs were up and the waitstaff were just standing around talking. They directed me down a set of stairs to the basement, which is the bar. 

The decor is great -- a bit dim and secluded, feels perfect for friends to gather and chat. The beer selection was beautiful; chock full of small Belgian breweries and obscure beers. They seemed to intentionally stay away from anything remotely "commercialized" which makes for great experimentation. The bartenders were impressively knowledgeable, and did a great job of recommending and helping.

It was a bit pricey due to the fact these are all tiny, rare brews, but for a beer or two with friends this place is perfect.
author: Kevin M.

description:
This place is so freaking awesome that it almost makes me want to cry.  That is perhaps because I am still a little hung over from the three-hour Belgian Beer tour that I participated in yesterday afternoon.  No matter - I may be emotional, but I do not exaggerate.

Let's start with atmosphere.  If you don't know the bar is here, you may walk by it on the street and never stop.  That's what we almost did the first time, but our trusty iphone convinced us to go in, although it was so dark and quiet that we thought it might be closed.  That is, however, because the party is happening downstairs.  And WHAT a downstairs!  Descend the spiral staircase and find yourself suddenly thrust into a European tavern.  It is a magical portal.  There are big wooden slab benches, glowing lanterns all around, and even Alphonse Mucha posters in the bathroom.  Magnifique!  How can you not feel European with a goblet of beer in one hand and a cauldron of mussels at your other? 

The beer selection... oh, the beer selection.  Should I mention that they have a book for a beer menu?  If you want to get to know Belgian beers intimately, you may not need to go to Belgium.  Just spend a few evenings here.  On top of that, the guys behind the bar know their stuff backwards and forwards, so you know that you are getting an incredible, well put together selection of beers.  If you have any interest in beer, or Belgium, at all, this is a place that you must experience.
author: Mariah M.

description:
I always forget the places I want to go when the moment comes for me to choose a destination but luckily some people have great memories (yay, Wakako) so I finally got to check out La Trappe.

Do they seat people upstairs?  All I know is that it was empty around 7pm but I was directed downstairs where my group already was.  The interior was warm, full of people and cavelike.  I also believe we were sitting by a waterfall.  We chatted with the owner and tasted several of the beers on tap before making our decisions.

The portobello mushroom burger, mussels provencal, fries and Belgium waffle were all very tasty.  The Belgium waffle, in particular, disappeared in seconds.   

At one point, someone asked what time I wanted to leave.  I asked if it was almost midnight since I had taken BART.  I was looked at like I was crazy and told it was 8:30.  Good thing since I wasn't done yet.
author: Seong P.

description:
Fantastic Spot! one of the first places I went to the first month I moved to The Bay. Now I bring all my visitors here. 

If you want a great vibe with amazing beer choices, this is the place. I would rather go to the bar than sit in the dining, I find the service bearable during sit down meals, but the bartenders are much more personable.
author: liana l.

description:
The beer list was longer than any book I have ever read.  And I read a lot - typically two books a year.

I was so overwhelmed with the beer selection I asked the bartender to pick something for me.  Typically with these types of Belgian beer joints I just look for the beer with the highest alcohol content and try that.  By the third beer I am cross-eyed and mission accomplished!  You could hit this spot everyday for a year and never drink the same beer - that's how vast this menu is!  So that is a HUGE plus.  I tried a couple new beers and really enjoyed them both.  

The food left a little to be desired, it wasn't terrible, but nothing really stood out.  The vegetable sides for each dish tasted bland and flavorless; I couldn't differentiate between baby corn and broccoli if I closed my eyes.  I had the pork chop which was good, but not great.  My gal pal had duck stew with a similar opinion.  Perhaps someone stole the spice rack that night?  Maybe the waiter licked all the flavor off our dish before he dropped it off?  Maybe I was just too damn drunk to tell the difference.  

My final verdict, definitely go for the beer.  If you're hungry, fill up on beer.
author: Sean O.

description:
Crazy good beer list - check

Mussels many different ways - check

Properly fried fries - check

Cool Euro feel - check

I'll be back!
author: Simon Y.

description:
La Trappe has apparently kidnapped a monastery or two of skilled monks, forced them give up their ascetic ways for a single-minded focus on beer-brewing, and brought their resulting atoned ales to SF for our heathen consumption and enjoyment.  

Ok, thats not exactly how it works, but the beers here are indeed blessed -- they carry a rotating list of belgians that may cause you to go all Bush-y (get born-again, invade another country, etc.).   

Descend down to the main dining room for an intimate dinner setting.  The food is passable--but clearly, its purpose is merely to supplement your drinking experience (the monks ain't cooking no burgers).

La Trappe is a good prelude to a night out in North Beach--although you're probably in for a bit of a wait on the weekend.  

And if you run into me, don't be surprised to hear me whispering to myself  "GIve us this day our daily brew, Amen."
author: LJ W.

description:
Novel-sized beer menu?  Check.
Awesome dungeon-esque bar?  Yep.
Great food with Belgian flare?  Done.
Super knowledgeable and nice wait staff?  Yes and more yes.

This place is amazing.  We went on a weeknight and as others have said, I would've walked right by if a friend hadn't known her way around; downstairs is where you need to be.  Once you've got that covered, you'll just need a tour guide to the beer menu.  Luckily, the waitress was well-versed in that department.

We ordered a round of mussels and frites (with requisite Belgian dipping sauces) and also had some chicken stew (which was named something far cooler than that, but I can no longer remember what that was...)

All the food was fantastic, service was quick and efficient and neither the restaurant or bar were too crowded or loud.  4.5 stars would be more accurate - the only gripe is looking like they're closed at street level, a bit off-putting.

I'll be back.  Hope to see you there.
author: Gretchen S.

description:
Mmmm, beer.   They have it and you should too, meaning get yourself a menu or ask the barkeep what you should have.  This place rawks.  I can do with a better location and maybe an expanded menu, but I really come for the selection of tasty brews from Belgian and of course our very own Californian beers.  

Mouth watering right now.
author: Toome B.

description:
Mmmmmm  Beeeeer! Yahoooo!

Don't let the upstairs fool ya. There's lots of room down under and so much beer to taste. Even though I have to cross the Broadway Tunnel this place is so worth it.

Plus - Lots of beers to explore, Blocks away from Broadway, The downstairs makes you feel like your in a different country (that is good in today's economy)

Minus - I gotta climb the stairs to get out of and you got to drink less beer to make room for dinner ( i heard the food is good so i guess i can make that sacrifice)
author: Alden M.

description:
St. Fueillon Saisson, I've never cared for beer until I met you. You are the most interesting, delightful, refreshing, beer imaginable. You are more than just my gateway beer... 

By choice, I drink maybe once or twice a month, and usually only red wine.  But i have fallen in love with La Trappe and can never say no to an invitation there. Amazing beer (i don't even want to categorize it as "beer" since i don't like "beer") and good food in a secret little cozy European den. It's one of those places I always end up going when I'm in the city.
author: Lily L.

description:
Love this joint... Best burger in town (grass fed, like me) and best fries in town... And then there's the brew - a catalogue of different beers and some strong-ass stuff, to boot.

I like that its kinda in a basement and the owners are tre' cool.
author: Tom M.

description:
i love love love love love la trappe.

people who love belgian style beer, this is a must. not to be mistaken for the similar phrase "people who love beer this is a must".

the underground brick lined, solid wood table environment with low lighting, is kitsch. i can't say enough good things about la trappe. the burgers are good, the chipotle mayo works well with the fries, and the steamed mussels help the beer go down.
author: Ameer N.

description:
Cool North Beach place. Dope dictionary sized Belgian beer list, surprisingly good homemade food, unpretentious crowd and service. 

The Belgian fries are epic.

Not so epic? The crazy mark-up on beer. Nevertheless, I keep coming back here like an abused wife because I just can't stay away! No but really, the Belgian beer is that good - expensive or not.
author: Britt M.

description: It is a very fun place with great beer selection! The food is pretty decent. We got here around 8pm on a Saturday night and waited for about an hour. Too bad we didn't get a chance to try the mussels because it was sold out but the small plates like Mac n' Cheese and Ratatouille are pretty good.
author: Yve H.

description: After a negative experience at the Toronado, I went here for the chance to expand my knowledge of Belgian beers. The staff were knowledgeable,courteous and professional. They even make food and beer pairing suggestions. Go here for a female friendly beer experience.
author: Chloe W.

description: Wanted to try it today 10/18/2012, but it was closed. Yelp says it is open till 12AM, their website (http://latrappecafe.com/directions/) says it is open till 11PM. It was CLOSED much earlier than 10PM today.
author: Mike R.

description: So many beers!  It was like a whole book of them.  A little overwhelming.  I loved my burger and I tasted my friends' mussels--perfect.  Fresh, salty, and flavorful.  The fries were crispy and new!
author: Julia D.

description:
I'M THE STUPIDEST PERSON IN THE WORLD

(and here's why...)

MENU
Some Belgian Beer -- 8
Some Belgian Beer -- 8
Chimay Blue -- 4
Chimay Blue Grand Reserve -- 4

Wow. Chimay for only $4? And Grand Reserve at the same price as regular Chimay?! And I thought this place was pricey... I head up to the bar and place an order for the Grand Reserve on my card. (No limit - "You can spend as much as you want," he jokes...) The bartender turns back around and places a huge bottle in front of me.

Him: How many glasses?
Me: *shocked* Uh... just one. (What a deal!)

He rings me up, and I'm starting to suspect I may have ordered incorrectly. I look at the bill: $18. Sigh. Clearly I did something wrong, but somehow I was okay with it (and since it's on credit, I'm not actually spending any money - that's how it works right?)...

La Trappe holds so much intimate beauty and class, I would gladly bring my mom here and, you know, get wasted with her. The underground bar exudes an incredibly romantic ambiance, enhanced by numerous lanterns casting intricate patterns of light upon rustic wooden tables. I hear the food is also fantastic, but it comes with a price. No regrets. Life is good.

Oh... and I looked at the menu when I sat back down, flipping to the section where I originally saw the price, and quickly realized my error...

TABLE OF CONTENTS
author: Keane L.

description:
WARNING: please make sure you have on appropriate footwear before reading this review as name-dropping will be involved. 

So Jen and I were sitting at bar talking to Mike who is one of the co-owners of La Trappe. (BOOM! POW!! Right off the bat I'm throwin' around names like Naomi Campbell throws phones. I probably should have used a Larry Bird or a sports simile but my first instinct was to go the supermodel route. What does that say about me Dr. Freud??) He was telling us the history of the building which has been in his family for years. During prohibition his family used the basement as their own hidden speakeasy/distillery, and it still has that feeling to it which is fantastic. In fact, from the outside La Trappe doesn't look like much. A small restaurant with a couple of tables... no biggie. It's not til you walk down the winding stairwell that you get to the heart of La Trappe.   It's intimate, welcoming, and tastefully decorated. 

Enough of that namby pamby interior decorator bullshit... Let's talk beer!! Are Belgium Beer Bars becoming the new Wine Bar?? There's the new Trappist in Oaktown and this spot. If so, I wouldn't mind that trend at all, because the beer we had here was crazy delicious. I wish I could remember the names because they had beer on tap that no one else on the West Coast has... and it was fantastic. Their been menu is slightly overwhelming but the staff behind the bar will guide you to the right choice.

Along with the great beer they have some seriously great food. We split the mini-burgers (the beef they used is from Marin Sun Farms) and the mussles and fries. The mussles came out in the pot they cooked them in and my wife is still talking about the cute presentation... and this was weeks ago. Everything we sampled (including some friend's food) I would have no hesitation in ordering again.

The only bad thing (at least for us) is that La Trappe is located in North Beach which we never visit for some unknown reason BUT the hassle of getting over here and putting up with finding a parking spot is totally worth another visit or three to La Trappe. Honestly, it's probably a good thing that it isn't located down the street from me. That's how much I loved and it...
author: Bucky K.

description:
TOTALLY MY TYPE OF PLACE.

thanks phil h.

beer menu that rivals most places wine list. check

quirky, fun dining area. check

food cooked a bit on teh salty side. check.

GOOD food cooked on the salty side. check.

MARIN SUN FARMS MEAT cooked on the salty side. check.

i LOVED the artisan cheese platter with dates accompanied with a balsmic reduction. yum. 

only issues? parkings a bitch and the service was at times spotty, but nothing to really complain about. i got a really relaxed, chill vibe from the whole place and i loved the food.
author: Euge L.

description:
I love the atmosphere here and the HUGE selection of specialty beers! The bartenders know their stuff, and can give great recommendations. I've only tried the food once, but was definitely happy with what I got!

My only gripe--and it wasn't enough to knock my review down to 4 stars, but still a gripe--WHY WHY WHY WHY does this place close at midnight?!! Really? On weekends? I think the reason this bothers me so much is because I had actual Belgian visitors in town and was excited to show them the place, only to find it closed down at 11:45 pm. 

But otherwise, this place is awesome!
author: Rose G.

description:
Saving the fifth star for a major re-visit!

My world stopped when I dove into their version of Filipino Arroz Caldo.  Instead of the chicken...they serve mussels giving this a kick ass dish a SUPREME menu winner!     Yes, this place is Filipino friendly so don't be intimidated by the white folks that partake here.   Just tell them Walter P sent you.   And you're good.

Beers:   I have to give credit to Ed H.   I don't remember the beers we had that evening.   After one...two...three... my mental notes went out the window.   Again.... a re-visit with pen and pad.

Dining:  Head down stairs where the action is.   The street level has limited seating and feels like your the center of attention with the kitchen staff.   Plus the pan handlers love staring while you eat.  Not fun.

Parking:  One thing I hate about SF is the parking.   On this cold ass summer night, we parked at the Safeway on Bay St.    This is a fairly decent parking structure.   There's a fee.

What is Arroz Caldo?
Rice porridge.  Perfect for the cold winter nights and months.  If you're feeling under the weather, this dish is a miracle worker for your immune system and eases your sleepless nights.   I grew eating it.  


ARROZ CALDO INGREDIENTS
1 1/2 cups rice
1 chicken, small, cut into serving pieces
2 tbsp oil
2 cloves garlic, bruised
1 small onion, chopped
a fraction of ginger, sliced thinly
6 cups water
3 tbsp soy sauce or patis
2 stalks spring onions, chopped
3 boiled eggs, halved (optional)
oil for sautèing

ARROZ CALDO
1. In a large saucepan, saute garlic onion and ginger. Add chicken. Season with soy sauce or patis. Cover for 2 minutes.
2. Add rice and water. Stir thoroughly, making sure that the ingredients do not stick to the sides of the pan.
3. Continue cooking over low heat for 20 minutes.
4. Sprinkle chopped spring onions on top before serving. Add boiled eggs, if desired.

-------------------------------------------------
Next Review:  One of the hottest new cover bands in the South Bay!
author: Walter P.

description:
Belgian Beer Heaven! Need I say more? Seriously, folks...if you're a beer fan, you NEED to check out La Trappe. Even if you're not the biggest Belgian beer fan...it's really quite an experience. As mentioned in the other reviews, the downstairs has a really nice setup and the bartenders know what they are talking about. Which means, they can make good recommendations for the Belgian beer novice. 

The first page of their menu has all the beers on tap. The rest of the pages list their numerous bottled beer selection. It's pretty damn awesome. Be sure to browse the pages for interesting tid-bits on some beers and explanations of different Belgian beer categories. It's makes for some interesting reading. 

Enjoy!
author: Samir P.

description:
When I asked for the Nostradamus, our server jumped up with glee, clapped her hands and scampered off to the bar.  I double-checked the menu, assuming by her reaction that I had just ordered an 80 dollar pint, but when she returned with my beer, she explained that she was just about to recommend the same libation and was just so thrilled that we synced so well. 

Mussels and fries for $16 is a steal, and I will admit that after a few strong trappist brews, I felt compelled to count my empty shells and though I can't trust my math from that particular evening, I counted 35 mollusks in my order and the cone of fries was comparably large.  The two dipping sauces were like metallic mayo and caustic catchup, which was the only thing I found unpleasant about La Trappe.  Our server was an absolute doll, checking on us regularly, patiently returning because we were never ready to order and dutifully recommending beers.
author: Quinn S.

description:
In case you wondering, I am a rad ex girlfriend. Yep. Date me, dump me, then let me take you out to a nice dinner for your birthday. I'm that nice. I could have chosen Taco Bell or some equivalent, but no, I chose an amazing restaurant with an incredible beer selection for my former lover's birthday. 

Everything* about this place I love. The ambiance is perfect. Love the cave for private parties (hi phil!), the checkerboard tables, the speakeasy feel. 

The food was top notch. We had the pancetta wrapped shrimp, pork in a beer reduction with amazing brussel sprouts, and the rabbit stew. For dessert we had some chocolate hazelnut pudding thing with raspberry sauce. Every bite was delicious. 

The beer was incredible. I always forget how fruity the blondes can be. (and no I'm not talking about me. or my faux date ex boyfriend). Having such a wide selection we took our time with the beer list. Everything we picked was great though. And our waitress had fun trying to teach us how to say them properly. I tried the whole point and say the one part of the beer you think you know, and she'd reply, "Oh? you mean the crazyforeignicantrememeberwhattocallit beer? You'll love it, it's got a great bite." Uh... yeah. What she said. 

The worst part of the meal, besides the whole staring into the eyes of the man who broke my heart thing, was this woman dining a few tables away. OMG. SHUT UP. I DON'T WANT TO HEAR YOUR IMPERSONATION OF MIKE MYERS IN SO I MARRIED AN AXE MURDERER. YOU HAVE THE LOUDEST SHRIEKIEST VOICE I HAVE EVER HEARD AND MY EAR DRUMS LITERALLY HURT FOR THREE DAYS. HOW DO YOU HAVE FRIENDS? Seriously. SHUT UP. Conversation was extremely difficult having to wait between shrieks and it's a bit hard to put the fork in your mouth when you have to plug your ears. Bonus points to the waitress for making fun of her and apologizing to us about her ambiance-ruining abilities. 

*The reason for 4 stars and not 5 is three things. And they are minor and easy to fix. 

First - when I ask for my food to be boxed up, I meant all of it. Not just part of it. I purposely saved half of my brussel sprouts so that when I heated up the pork I would have something to go with it. Also, please include the sauce. Every chef should know that when reheating moisture will be lost, so all that sauce sitting at the bottom of the plate, please pour it over the pork so I'm not chomping at a dry piece of rubber the next day. Having the meal taste good the next day just reminds your customers of how great it was the first time and brings them back. 

Second - Please print more menus. There aren't enough for every table so we couldn't keep the beer list with us the whole time even though it was one of the big things we were looking at and talking about during dinner. We are HUGE beer fans so we like to compare and contrast and find the ones we haven't had. It is likely to be a passion of a lot of patrons, so having lots of beer lists will only benefit you. 

Third- Make a real host stand at the entrance. Being greeted by the chef and a waiter picking up food is great but I think people immediately feel lost when walking in.

These minor complaints aside. I absolutely love this place and can't wait for another ex to have a birthday.
author: Ali R.

description: We were fortunate to grab one of the last tables before the crowd came in.  That said, I was in the mood for beer and fries, and I was definitely satisfied with both.  Hell, I probably forgot what kind of beer I got (it resembled something light and in a goblet).  The fries were fine as they were, as the beer helped.  I'd go back for sure.
author: Ren L.

description: Love, Love, Love this place.  The fries, the mussels, the huge beer and good wine list are awesome.  And, if you go downstairs you will be pleasantly surprised to see this secret gem has a warm cozy feeling and you feel as though you have been suddenly transported to a bar in Belguim, the staff is so friendly and helpful and I just love it here.
author: Jenn D.

description:
It was my friend's birthday and the 5 of us knew we were in for a long night of partying, so we wanted a good solid meal to start us off. The suggestion of La Trappe's "dungeon" dining room had us all excited. 

This is definately a place for people who are serious about beer. I like beer, don't get me wrong, but I don't want to read a fucking book in an attempt to find what I want... and I didn't. The server brought us some samples to try, but when I'm drinking beer.... just bring me a beer.

Two of us ordered a burger and two of us ordered the steak. I regret ordering the steak. I ordered it rare and got something close to medium. It was seriously under seasoned and filled with sinew. I had a small pile of inedible bits on my side plate. Good thing I wasn't dining with a girl huh?

All of the entrees were accompanied with french fries. We must have been served what was in the bottom of the bag of frozen fries, because it was a pile of over-cooked, tiny potato nibs. 

Give me a fucking break!!

Overpriced for what I got. This yelper will not be returning.
author: Dave U.

description:
You know it's an expansive beer selection when they have gluten free beer (they offer Greens beer in amber and blond).  

Also, surprisingly good food.  I've been to Belgium and I didn't once eat as well as I did at La Trappe.  Great split pea/sausage soup.  

Downstairs ambiance just tips this place off as a really awesome mid-week or weekend night destination.
author: Shireen T.

description:
Went here last Thursday night after a big group dinner and we continued the party at La Trappe.  This is how I picture a Belgian beer bar to be. Decor is nice with exposed brick walls and some cozy areas to sit in where you can sit and get to know that special someone.  Do NOT take someone looking for a strawberry daiquiri or carb fearing friend as I'm not even sure they have hard alcohol. They might just faint at the tasty dark brews put in front of them.

This is where I'm going to be on a cold winter's night when it's raining sipping on some brew with a book I read just to impress people.... not because I really enjoy it. 

Of course, being we were all already wasted, we just pulled some tables together sat down and were probably overly loud for the space. Belgian beer selections here are crazy. LOTS and lots of beer! Good Beer! (FYI- many of these beers are 8%+. Of course me being me, I had to select Gouden "Carolus Grand Cru of the Emperor" -- weighs in at a hefty 11%). I spent part of the night just trying to say my beer's full name 10 times in a row. I fail. I now am nicknamed "Mr. Mumbles".

I spent a big part of the night trying to keep a certain someone from telling too many embarrassing stories about me but to no avail. I had to go to the bathroom eventually after drinking so much liquid.  

No one tried the food; we were too stuffed from dinner to even consider it so I'll reserve judgment.   

Minus one star because they close fairly early. 

*BURP*
author: Morgan H.

description:
Yes, yes and yes! If ever an update was warranted, this is it. It was almost as if La Trappe actually went through my list of recommendations and addressed each and every one. Wonderful!

We were greeted by a hostess and immediately seated despite it being totally packed. Our server was gracious and with-it. No hovering water servers (carafe brought to the table), real Belgian fries served upright in a grease-absorbing paper cone (with choice of flavored and plain mayo), bread brought out in a timely fashion, well-prepared steak & frites - everything basically perfect with the one (ironic) exception that they had no "soup of the day " that day. And sadly, they had just completed a week's run of the beloved potato/leek.

C'est la vie. We will back frequently enough to catch it the next time. Kudos to La Trappe for extracting the diamond from the rough. Well done!
author: wendella a.

description:
I was SO excited when this place opened because the spot had sat empty for so long.  I came here last weekend for a couple beers to start off the evening.

Since the last time I was here, obviously the rest of the world has found out about it because it was slamm'in!  Packed to the gills - but we still got our drinks fairly quickly with a smile.

In the past I have eaten here and the food is sub par.  Their focus is definitely on the beer list and not the kitchen...so eat before you come!
author: Megan H.

description:
I was very excited when I found out that there would be a Belgian beer bar and restaurant opening in my neighborhood. If it's not obvious already, I'm a big fan of beer - even brewing my own - and Belgian ones are widely considered to be the paragon of said beverage. Dubbels, trippels, quadrupels, saisons, lambics, Flanders red ales - very, very, very tasty. So I was looking forward to visiting La Trappe. Unfortunately, they had issues in the first couple of months after opening - irregular hours and problems with equipment kept me away.

However, all that is past. I've only visited twice, but hopefully that plus $150 left behind (mostly spent on beer of course) qualifies me to say a few words. The place is split-level: a few tables upstairs and a big, Belgium-style "beer cave" downstairs. There is a bar and a few tables, which can accommodate parties from 2 to 10 people. The food menu is quite decent, if not extensive. I had a salad and some moules et frites here. The moules were good, but a bit on the small side, and the frites didn't quite compare to the ones served at Frjtz.

The beer menu on the other hand is extensive. There are about 30 beers on tap and 100+ in bottles. The vast majority are Belgians exhibiting the full range of the styles, with a few Belgian-style ones from other countries. Prices range from $6 to $30 per serving. You have to realize that some beers are served in big, champagne-size (750ml) bottles, so that $18 gets you a long way towards beer bliss. I've probably sampled 10 beers here and enjoyed all but one. Belgian beers are generally higher in alcohol content, reaching 10-11% sometimes, so don't expect to pound down a dozen in one sitting unless you want to be carried out rather than walk out. These beers with their complex aromas and flavors are made for tasting and you can spend a great evening doing just that with a couple of friends.

The service is a bit spotty. On the first visit, it took forever to order our beers on each round, but the second time around was better. The servers seem to know the menu fairly well, but are not experts in all the beers obviously. I'd try to research the beers on a site like BeerAdvocate.com before coming here and definitely take notes so that you know which ones you liked and didn't like.

I'll definitely be back to continue sampling the beers. If you happen to visit, try Zoetzuur Flemish Red and see why beers can be as complex as wines.
author: Andrei Z.

description:
I met a friend for dinner here last Thursday night. She had recently broken her foot, so I waited for her upstairs. Downstairs seems to be where the party's at though - it was so loud you could hear everything upstairs, and it seemed really crowded. Service wasn't exactly prompt or attentive, and confusingly, we had at least three different servers. It seemed like we waited quite a while for one of the three to notice that we were definitively ready to order.
The only reason to come to a Belgian place aside from the beer is to try the classic Moules Frites. So we went for the traditional Mariniere preparation with white wine and shallots. A steaming cauldron of mussels & broth showed up. I asked for an additional bowl and got a perplexed look. We were *sharing* - was I supposed to lean over my friend's shoulder and pick out my mussels from the pot on her side of the table? The mussels that we were able to eat were delicious. Unfortunately, at least 6 or 7 of the mussels at the bottom of the pot were still closed, ergo inedible. The broth was a little watery as well, but had good flavor. The cone of frites was on the average side. It was a good-sized portion to share, but the fries were quite unevenly fried - some nice and crispy, others limp. The roasted garlic mayo and the spicy ketchup were both very tasty though.
I'll reserve my highest praise for the beer selection. There is so much going on with this beer list! Their draft selection is extensive, and then there's an additional bottle list! It's organized by style and even includes a brief glossary of beer styles, which is very helpful. We had 4 beers in total, including the St. Feuillien Trippel, the Affligem Blond, the Ertvelds Wit, and the Ephemere Cassis. All except the Canadian Ephemere were Belgian, but they were all incredibly good and arrived in the appropriate glassware. The Ephemere was a great "dessert" beer - the cassis flavor wasn't overpowering at all, just subtly tart. I really want to come with a larger group so that we can explore the bottle list a bit more - they apparently have over 400 beers.
If this place stepped up the service, I'd definitely award another star. I'd also love to come back to try the Moules Pastis appetizer because it sounds delicious: baked mussels in a fennel & Pastis sauce, yum!
author: Stephanie S.

description:
I used to love La Trappe, but the staff has become too much to handle.  Strikes 1, 2 and 3 all happened this past Saturday night.

Let me preface this by saying that I love their beer list, I love their food, and I love their interior.  So I took some significant douchebaginess to earn my dislike.

We came on Saturday around 10PM,  knowing they close at midnight.  We had our first beer and just about 11:30, went up for a final round.  There were two bartenders, one who was helping the waiters and still providing beer, and another who seemed to be pissed at the world about his horribly difficult life working at La Trappe.  A waiter tells us last call was at 11:30.  I look at my watch and it's 11:32.  I also look at where we're sitting, about 12 feet from the bar, and wonder how 4 people could have missed any announcement about last call, until I realized there hadn't been one.

We continue to wait, hoping for service, when the nice bartender leaves to grab a last beer for one of the tables.  The other bartender, Captain McDouche, storms by us and says "We're not serving any more beer", before slamming some stuff around in the sink.  We keep waiting, hoping for either the other bartender, or the opportunity to close our our tab.  When Captain McDouche comes back and repeats his not-so-friendly admonition, we have to practically throw something at him to get his attention for our tab.  All in all, great service.

Strikes 1 and 2 for not calling last call and for such an awesome, passive aggressive, 14 year old pubescent bartender.  Strike 3 came in that my girlfriend left her cell phone there and it has, of course disappeared.  This obviously happens, but it's rare that you can prove it had to be a La Trappe staff member who took it.  She left her phone on the table while we were putting on our jackets to leave - I saw it, and she saw it and each thought the other would grab it.  We were literally the last people to walk out up the stairs Saturday at midnight and they are closed Sunday and Monday.  We called, stopped by, etc., and no one could get downstairs to check on it until Tuesday.  When we got back there, it was gone and the person we talked to swore that nobody there would have taken it.  Sorry buddy, but that ain't true.
author: Matt Z.

description: Great mussels and an eclectic draft beligian beer selection.  The smell of butter and mussels is overwhelming and amazing.
author: Patty C.

description: Not quite as cool as The Trappist in Oaktown but this place is cool in its own way and it's in San Francisco. Not many beers on tap but an extensive bottle catalog. The apps are pretty good, I recommend the sliders and the fries with the curry ketchup. I particularly enjoyed the cavernous, cozy, dimly lit downstairs area. There's room for large groups too so you're covered.
author: Boby M.

description:
Bountiful Belgium beer burps building in my belly... 

I like Belgium and Belgium-esque beers... Yes I do... 

*burpity burp*

I like cheese platters and bread for munching... 

*burpity burp*

The food was really good here, but I learned about Marin Sun Farms beef and I didn't like the taste. It was a little too gamey tasting for me, which is really weird because I love the taste of lamb. 

*burpity burp*

The Bavarian Cream pie was DELICIOUS! Goes really well with a Belgium blonde. 

*burpity burp*

If you try this place out, make sure to sit in the cellar, as it's more lively and fun than the upstairs dining area. And make sure to ask for the specials, as they have them nightly. 

*burpity burp*
author: Jen D.

description: Definitely a good place! Excellent beer list, good food.Not quite as impressive as Monks Kettle but in a better neighborhood.Here I wouldn't hesitate to go to dinner ,which I did.Ate upstairs , which i prefered to the downstairs.Recomend the rabbit and as with all good Belgian places, the fries.Liked the waiter who I believe knew something about beer which should be a requirement at a place like this.This was also true at Monks Kettle, where our waitress was charming, funny , hard working and good looking.Just go to both places.
author: John K.

description:
Let me tell ya....this is THE spot for drinking Belgian Beers on-tap. The downstairs atmosphere feels like you're in some 100-year-old monastery with the bricks and low lighting. The food doesn't get a high rating in Zagats (17), but stick to the muscles, fries and Belgian waffle and you'd never know. 

La Trappe is a great place to start or finish the night!
author: Scott C.

description:
Dear Reader,

I have yet to eat a *full* meal here, but I'm sure that once I do, this review will be bumped up to 5 big stars.

From the street, La Trappe appears unassuming.  However, beneath the street level dining space is a wonderfully cozy bar and eating area overflowing with an old world vibe.  There is a private enclave that you can reserve for parties (seats at least 12).  

This is the closest I've been to eating at a European bistro since I was in, well, Europe (go figure!)  La Trappe made me long for a computer so I could log onto Expedia and book my next trip to Euro-land (i.e. it gives you the warm fuzzy "I'm on vacation" feeling)

In addition, La Trappe satisfies one of my many food fantasies: beer and food pairing (because I am too gauche for wine and food pairing)

They have such a wide selection of interesting beers, and the owner/staff is eager to help you pair them to your appetizer/dinner/dessert.

Finally, I can feel a little more sophisticated without having to relinquish my beer!  Hallelujah :)
author: Kara D.

description:
AWESOME!  This place is simply one of the best bars that I've been to in the past few years for a couple of relaxing drinks with friends.  I've been very stingy with my 5-Star ratings, striving for a normal distribution in my reviews.  La Trappe gets 5 stars from me, for the stellar beer selection, cozy/sophisticated European decor, and the comprehensive Belgium Ale manual of a menu.  

My friends and I got there around 7pm on a Saturday night.  I initially thought that it was an empty bar, as that's how it looked from the outside.  To my surprise, we went downstairs into the basement area, and found the main event.  The basement bar was an intimate space, featuring soft, indirect lighting gently accented by masterfully coordinated red walls and yellow light fixtures.  The couches in the back area create the prime real estate that optimizes the combination of lighting, exposed brick pillars, and a one-way mirror looking into the outside of the restroom that definitely gives you something to talk about!

The process of selecting our drinks was more like choosing a sophisticated wine at a wine bar.  Except that for the old friends that I was there with, talking about each beer was more than just about the flavor.  Each beer they spoke of also triggered fond memories.  I get the sense that these Belgian brews also came with the magical properties of story making with every drink.  

It is a great place to get lost in the moment there, exploring and learning about Belgian Ales with close friends.  For us, that moment ended up running 3 hours.  I am definitely coming back to La Trappe!
author: Leo C.

description:
It's almost perfect.  They need a beaten down dude wearing a beaten down tux playing music on a piano while people in berets speak with French accents plot the resistance and there should be a cow wearing galoshes... no wait, that's Top Secret.

It's a fantastic list of Belgian beers, some Germans and I think I saw an Italian on there.  Each served in the appropriate glass, just one of those beautiful moments, probably tops out holding my baby niece for the first time, but don't tell my sister that.

The fries were rockstar as were the mussels mariniere.  Suited my beers quite nicely.  Cheese plate was gut, but honestly, the only purpose of the food here is to compliment the beer.

Two drawbacks.  First, they didn't have Corsendonk.  I may have been slurring a bit, but seriously... 

Second... actually, I know I had a second, but I forget... Stupid delicious beer.
author: Ed H.

description:
Four Stars - lets see, if you consider a joint with a good beer selection that does not require preparation of any sort, then I'll agree, however, when my buddies and I made a trip to La Trappe last night, it was far from 4 stars.  To start, we were seated fairly promptly and then placed our orders for Beer and apps.  The beer (Brasserie De Roc, Saison Dupont, and Affligem) delivered and were quite yummy.  The apps (smoked trout in endive cups and the salad were mediocre.  

Then we placed our orders for dinner (2 orders of the mussels and fries, 1 S.F. Burger, and 1 Portobello w/ Polenta) which didn't make it to our table for close to an hour.  Given the fact that there were only 7 other tables with people and 3 cooks upstairs, that was unacceptable.  

The Food: mussels were small and had little taste to it.  There was a lack of broth, which would have helped retain some of the flavor.  The fries that came with it was rather dry and didn't have much over say.. McDonald's fries.  The buddy that had the burger was extremely disappointed with what was brought onto the plate.  The burger was dry, tasteless, overcooked (he ordered medium and the meat looked a dark grey) and the Portabello and Polenta was undercooked.  

Overall this is how the scores stacked up:

Beer - 4 Stars  Weighting Factor  20%
Atmosphere - 4 Stars                     20%
Food - 1 Star                                    50%
Service - 1 Star                                10%
OVERALL - 1  1/2 STARS             100%

So, I would come back to grab a beer but not eat any of the food, if you can call it that!
author: Tom L.

description:
All I can say is that I am SOOO bummed that we moved out of northbeach before La Trappe opened. Although, maybe it's a good thing since I would've gone into debt trying every belgian beer on their menu. 

My first visit was wednesday night for Phil H.'s birthday (HAPPY BIRTHDAY PHIL!!) and we had a great time. We had the lounge reserved and michael did an amazing job tending to our large group. I also really appreciated his knowledge of all the beers and his excellent recommendations. 

I returned on saturday night with a friend who was visiting from out of town. Again, another great evening. I have nothing bad to say about the place. I loved it!
author: nicole c.

description:
Do you have any idea how long I've waited for a Belgian place in San Francisco???

Sure, Toronado was there for my Belgian beer needs, but they don't serve food. While the sausages from Rosamunde's next door are very tasty, they just can't substitute for a nice pot of steaming hot mussels & fries. 


La Trappe is definitely The Win. Not only do they have a very, very good selection of Belgians both in bottles and on tap, the food are also quite tasty.  Our little group was very satisfied by the end of the night. The North Beach location, with a view of the cable cars running up and down and a view of Coit Tower, is also a nice touch, like the best of SF and Belgium combined. Sure, Toronado's location might be more "authentic" (Seriously, if you've been to Brussels you know that 3/4 of that city looks like Lower Height anyway), but there is a reason I live in (or near) San Francisco, not Brussels.

The service was a bit slow (waiting for a table despite reservation, waiting for beer, waiting for server), but since they just opened I'll give them a little time.

Finally, a wonderful Belgian place in SF. My friend in Belgium is not gonna like this...she now has one less reason to use to convince me to go visit her!
author: Ben L.

description:
Finally a proper Belgian alehouse in San Francisco! (sorry Frijtz, but you just don't cut it). 

Great selection of ales on tap. They have lambics, wit, chimay, dubbels. tripels, and even a quadrupel. Ils ont moules et frites aussi. Had a four course meal here on Valentine's day with Jory R., and all the courses were delectable and served with a full beer. 

Best ... Valentine's ... dinner ... ever. I will undoubtedly be a semi-regular patron.
author: Joseph R.

description:
GREAT ATMOSPHERE! I can not wait to take my girlfriends here when they come to visit. 

Here should be your plan of action: Start out standing at the bar with all of the other singles and mingle, eye a guy, give him the buy me a drink "wink", then once you have landed your new man head over to one of the tables to talk about the important things that get discussed when you meet a guy in a bar (i.e. your place or mine), finally head over to the couches and plush chairs to play footsie and you touch me, I'll touch you to get you going before you head out and back to the discussed location. I should totally be a dating coach. Oh, wait, that would mean I would have to call the next day... scratch that. . Basically all the bases for various stages of the night and game are covered. 

I met some friends here, we hung out on the couches, drank mass quantities of good beer, ordered some tasty food (which took awhile to arrive but the waitress was apologetic), had a great time. The bar tenders are easy on the eyes, and flirt just the right amount ( I hate over the top bartenders, pet peeve of mine), there was a great mix of people in here for a Thursday night. 

I may not have executed the plan listed above, but I feel like someone should! La Trappe is perfect for it! 

1st time visitor make note: You have to go through the restaurant and down the stairs to get to the bar, if you get lost just look at the host with a confused face and he will point you in the right direction!
author: Jessica R.

description: Great Belgium beer selection and even have Russian River beers in bottles. Probably not the most adventurous meal, but I had the cheeseburger. The burger was good sized, approximately 1/2 lb but lacked flavor/seasoning. Fries were crispy and above average.
author: Aaron S.

description: i'm not a fan of beer (or any alcohol for that matter) but this is a great place for anybody who even slightly enjoys beer. they've got an extensive variety and the bartender certainly knows what he's talking about. he's sarcastic and everything you'd imagine you'd find at a place like la trappe. he scoffed at me upon the knowledge that i am an adult who has not grown to enjoy alcohol. while i didn't partake in beers, i did have the ribeye with fries (which comes with two dipping sauces as well) and very much enjoyed my meal. the ribeye was cooked perfectly and was an enormous portion. definitely a cool, chill spot to hang out with some friends.
author: Regina C.

description:
Came here for a quick pre-show bite. While sitting on street level and waiting for the food, I went downstairs to use the bathroom and found they have a great basement that was filled with mellow wooden furniture and a small waterfall, warm ambience with chessboard tables, which was a complete contrast to the upstairs bright white table-clothed dinning area. We immediately moved downstairs and enjoyed the two appetizers-- portobello mushroom on polenta that was simple but delicious, and the mussels in white beer sauce that was very mouth-watering flavourful!

They also have one section where only drinks are allowed (no food) with cozy sofa seats.

Definitely a hidden gem to come back and enjoy drinks (they have a great selection of Belgian beer), food and atmosphere!
author: T L.

description:
Not sure if they're related, but I'd have to pick The Trappist (in Oakland) slightly over this place - just throwin' that out there.
Great beers! But if you go on a busy night and it's pretty crowded, you'll probably have a hard time flipping through their beer-ordering bible. The appetizers are delicious - I remember their lil cup o' fries the most - very addictive. I had the rabbit stew - very good, and lots of other boujie stuff on the menu, too. 
I'll be back.
author: Quinn E.

description:
This place had me on a weeks long search for moules frites in Austin.  I didn't find an equivalent or a suitable substitute.  SAD.  Oh moules frites...I dream of you.  

I had no room for food but I still ordered the coconut curry on jasmine rice moules frites...and I ate every bit of it.  I got the curry ketchup to go with the frites & that was pretty good (I got a little curried away...hardy har har). 

My really awesome host got the Lindemans Lambic Peche beer.  If I had room for it, I would've gotten one too.  I tried a little of it & it was delicious.  

I liked the atmosphere of La Trappe.  Though it was too dark to take good pictures, it was really cozy & was good for groups.
author: Carol L.

description:
Solid belgian food and beer in North Beach.  Last time, we went to La Trappe, the belgian fries did not disappoint.  We loved the three dipping saunces - various takes on ketchup, mustard, and mayo.  The staff here is very knowledgeable and great with suggesting new beers to try.  I stick to the beers on tap as one could get absolutely lost in the bottled beer selection.  Their menu is a bible!  It is a a bit daunting but they do cover all their bases.  The basement bar is cozy and warm and great on a cold evening rather than a hot summer day.

Can't wait for my next visit.
author: Moe J.

description:
I love this place!  Have been a couple of times - but just a great spot.  They have an ENCYCLOPEDIA of beer - I really mean it, most of it imported.  So be wary of prices.  But simply amazing selection.  Sit downstairs, although its noisy because you are in an underground, brick cave/lair, the atmosphere is better.  French fries are pretty fan-freaking-tastic - I personally love the dijon mayo, spicy ketchup, bell pepper mayo, even though I don't even like mayo.  Mussels - fantastic, like you'll find in Belgium.  Beef stew and the sausage dish are also both cooked with tons of flavor and yummy sauces - I'm a sauce girl and the sausage one was fantastic!

Not super cheap, but I love it for its atmosphere - absolutely one of my favorite spots in NB.
author: Erika M.

description:
5 stars for the delicious beer!
4 stars for the cheese & fruit platter
4 stars for the frites! YUM (if you screw up frites you're dead to me!)
2 stars for the poor service!

We went to Trappe for an evening with friends - 2 birthdays to celebrate
Everyone convened it the downstairs room - which is good for groups. 

A. and I got there late and we were famished! We asked for a menu and the gal told us that we couldn't order entrees in the back room. We asked if it was a code issue or just restaurant policy. She said both.. Not sure how you can order Apps but no entree due to code.. OK we managed. 

Or other friend gets there late as well and attempts to order from the apps menu and they tell him they will not service apps in the back room. 

This place confuses me... One second they can; the next they can't.. The gal was pretty curt with us as well. Not going back. Too many other interesting places to try. Plus there's always Monk's Kettle in the Mission with a fantastic menu of beers to quench my thirst.
author: Monica S.

description:
We went here for dinner this past weekend and loved it.  We're vegetarians, so generally we have a hard time with any cuisine resembling German, but La Trappe even had a vegetarian menu.  We got the dumplings, which my fiance loved, and the portobello hamburger, which I could not get enough of (it was stuffed with goat cheese!).
