We also aren't usually big beer fans, but we thought we'd give it a try.  Our waiter was extremely helpful and knowledgeable and was able to suggest a few beers we might want to try.  My fiance got a fruit-infused Lambic beer that he loved, and I found a Belgian pale ale that suited me.

Also, they gave us the option of sitting downstairs or upstairs.  Downstairs was crowded and loud, and upstairs was empty.  We like quiet, so we sat upstairs and enjoyed our food together.

Good experience, good food, and good service.  The only downside is how expensive some of those bottled beers can get, but I guess that's just what happens when you have to import!
author: Shannon L.

description:
Want to feel like you're in a tiny old Belgian village on a cold blustery day? Grab the cable car down the hill to La Trappe. 

The first time my roommates asked me to grab a beer and some snacks with them at this place, I thought they were crazy. On the outside it looks like a tiny, mom and pop restaurant. Don't let your eyes deceive you, once you enter the restaurant there is a long spiral staircase down to the basement bar. Total speakeasy style!!

If you're into European beers, this is your spot. The menu goes on for DAYS and that's just the beer selections. I was clueless, so asked the bartender for a great girly option that I would enjoy. I forget what he gave me but it came in a pretty blue bottle and was delicious and light! Kudos to him for listening to the adjectives I provided!

After getting beers, we scored one of the picnic tables on the back wall and ordered up some fries. I don't think you can really mess up fries, but they were pretty scrumtious. We then decided to share the Belgian waffle as a dessert and it was culinary perfection.

The only downside on this spot is slow service (hey it's packed!) and the weird quiet vibe downstairs. Even though the place was full, my friends and I received many irritated glances for laughing and talking loudly. But that happens to us a lot.....
author: Lynsey C.

description:
We came here last night from Columbus and Broadway. We walked. Me in heels. In the rain. I harassed my friend, inquiring why we had to trek miles away, into the middle of residential area, past perfectly good bars. Especially since he didn't know the exact name of it, only that it was "some belgian beer place". Finally we're at the corner Greenwich and Columbus. Only there's no bar. Only a restaurant  with three tables in it.

We found an awning, my buddy called his source and low and behold, this itsy-bitsy place is it. We enter skeptically. But there's a stair case. A gorgeous , dark-stained wooden staircase with black metal railings. It's almost like that moment in "The Lion, the Witch, and the Wardrobe" where Lucy's expects the back of the closet to be there but there's actually no back and it leads into snowy woods. It was like entering another universe (ok maybe not that extreme but at least another country!). The downstairs is beautiful, there's a long bar on the right and to the left are tables, longer, Hofbrauhaus-style. The walls are brick, and slant at a slightly inward angle towards the bottom. The whole place is very soothingly lit with a variety of hanging ironwork lamps.

In the very back there's a lounge area, black leather couches, some small tables. Ideal for a group of people to hang out and drink Belgian ale that comes in goblets. We chatted with the owner for a while, he is a very cool gentleman and gave us some great suggestions for beverages we should try. 

Another thing I loved about this place was that the music was very low, so it was easy to carry on a conversation.

5 stars for atmosphere, and a variety of beer I haven't tried before. Minus one star because I haven't had their food (they have desserts too, I saw some, they looked heavenly). I can't wait to go back here and try the food and I suspect the review will be a full five stars once that happens.
author: Camille H.

description:
Fantastic ambiance! The basement makes it a little loud. 

Question: Is Belgium food supposed to be a little bland?
author: Morty P.

description:
4/17/08 - They're open and they're wonderful.  I love going in to sit at the bar when Jon is working.  What a great guy!

12/18/07 - Scratch that, now it's the 22nd.

12/13/07 FYI - I just stopped by their site to see if they mentioned anything about their hours and saw this, "Thank you all for coming out and making our opening night a success.  We will be open for normal business hours starting Saturday December, 15th at 6pm."  

Well, since I'm only the second person to review this place (at least the open to the public version), I'll give a quick run-down.  

The cheese and pate platter was fantastic.  We didn't get to order more food though because we gave up on the service at our table and moved to the bar.  There was just some confusion about where to find the beer we were ordering.  All the food looked fabulous though, and I look forward to trying more in the future.

After we moved to the bar the rest of the night was flawless.  Lenore was able to track down all of the bottles we ordered and we drank our way through about 10 kinds of beer.  The bartender was a great guy and the service was fantastic.  We did not see the bottom of a glass for  the rest of the night.  

I would recommend this place highly, especially once they work out the kinks.  I'm going to give it 4 stars because it was packed, and it was opening night, and nothing can go perfectly under those conditions.  But I'm already planning my next visit.
author: Jessica B.

description:
Great place for beer!  The bottom level bar is very laid back and comfy.  They have a binder that's about an inch thick with about 4 beers and their description. on each page. front and back.  That's a massive selection!!

Was served by 3 different bartenders, all of whom were very nice and  knowledgeable.  They did not have fries that night, which my friend tells me are amazing.  But we had a meat and cheese plate that was good.

So if you dig beer,  check this place out.  Not pretentious but not a total dive...just right.
author: sara r.

description:
When you walk in there are a few tables up top but down the staircase it opens up. They have a decent beer selection and my $11 burger was bleeding- exactly how I wanted it. The double cooked french fries (i didn't ask but am now curious what that means- fried two times? baked then fried?) were excellent. 

It's really really dark. I mean, so dark that our server had to hold the menu up to the light to read it. That seemed a bit much to me- even though we were in the basement.
author: B S.

description:
If you love Belgian beer, this is the place for you. But because we were pressed for time, I couldn't wrap my mind around the menu fast enough to make a decision.
Anyway, we split the moules frites (mariniere), carrot/ginger soup and the smoked trout and endive cups.
I have to say, La Trappe serves the most enormous portion of mussels I've ever seen and the fries were crisp and perfect.  I don't think it's been mentioned yet, but it's worth noting that the fries are served with a tasty wasabi aioli.
Wish we could have stayed longer and tried dessert!
author: Becca V.

description:
This place rocks! Take it from me: this is a Belgian restaurant/bar, and I am Belgian. The selection of beers is a - ma - zing. Let me tell you, some of the beers they serve are very rare, even in Belgium, and a lot of them come from really small independently-run businesses. San Francisco: you should feel really proud of having La Trappe in your backyard. No more hauling of beer bottles in my luggage; I can drink my homesickness away any time I want now, yay!

The mussels with garlic and beer were exquisite, comparable to how my mother makes them (but then without the motherly luuuv). The place seems to be very popular at times, and last time I went there, they seemed to have some growing pains (we had to wait quite long for our food). The owner personally came to apologize, which was really charming. He's a great guy who is determined to make this business work.

I'll be back.
author: Steven D.

description: The workers here were so rude. They pretty much just want you to know what you want to order in like 2 minutes and don't really wanna answer your questions. Well I'm sorry if it's hard for me to decide which beer I want out of your list of what seems like 200 beers. We had some light girly beer and some Belgian fries. At first, I thought the fries were nothing special but they were spectacular. I loved the taste of them especially with the realllllly strangely paired sauce. We got the curry wasabi (i think) sauce and the chipotle one. Yummm. I would go back but the workers need to work on their customer service.
author: Jenny T.

description: Wish I could give this place 10 stars - nothing but fabulous!! The most awesome beer, food and staff around. Super cozy basement/lounge downstairs that you would never know existed from street view.  Tried several different beers and will be back for more - the beer menu is the size of a dictionary and just purely fabulous. Includes the A to Zs on all that is served there.
author: T D.

description:
Amazing beer selection. Really, it's incredible.

Amazing belgian style fries, sooo good with a belgian style beer.

Great feeling downstairs (don't be fooled by the odd upstairs that really shouldn't even be a part of the bar, the real party is downstairs!).

Other than the fries, pass on the food, its flavorless (the mussels were the worst I ever had, but the beer made up for it).

The bar downstairs is the place to be.
author: Abby Z.

description:
We went to La Crappe on a Saturday night, sat downstairs or in the er dank basement. Waited about five minutes for a table.  

Waitstaff was understaffed and in the weeds. Waitress stopped by our table about .02 seconds after we got our menus then did not come back for over 20 minutes. 

Eventually a guy who appeared to be a bartender / line chef / manager came over and asked us if we "needed anything". Um, yeah, how about water, bread, drinks, and food? WTF do you think we are here? He seemed irritated and explained that they were busy and short staffed. Someone probably did not show up to work that night. Oh well dude - don't take that out on your customers!

He takes the order and brings our $9+ draft beers out. They are no more than 8oz. a piece. Teeny.

After a long period of waiting, the food eventually came out. Never got bread. Fries were missing from the order. My boyfriend got the Rabbit stew and I got the Chicken stew. Both were pretty good but the price was way too much for what you got. Trust me, I am all for smaller portions but paying $18-$23 for a bowl of stew - not so much. 

Fries final came. They had two hot sauces on the side. One is a wasabi mayo and the other was sort of a Tabasco mayo.  H-o-t.

We ordered a 750ml bottle of beer that was on the special list - $36. Ho-lee crap. Really? In the end, those few beers we had were half of our $100+ bill. 

Let's recap - that was two 8oz draft beers, one 750ml bottle of beer, one order of fries and two bowls of stew - and the bill was over $100. 

Busers were swimming around us like sharks. Snatching away anything that appeared to be a dirty dish. Even the dishes we were still eating from. Go away!!

In the meantime, the bar crowd was building and everyone's butts were pressed up against our chairs, heads and backs. There should *really* be a delineation between the bar and dining areas. 

For single girls, this may be the place for you. The crowd was 98% men. 

Sorry to say but I will not be back to this place. They would have got one star but I added one more because the stews were good.
author: Stephanie I.

description:
I can see why people like this place. Great beer, good food, charming cellar bar location. But it's not all good.

Unfortunately, the organization has it's issues. We were seated after a 15 minutes wait but then waited for more than 25 minutes before wrestling a passing waiter to the ground and demanding he serve us. (He said he would help us out as our waiter seemed to be "tied up" - but we didn't saw "our" waiter for at least another half hour.)

What happened next may show why there was such slow service.The waiter seemed to go to the bar, try to get one of the overwhelmed bartender's attention, and then wait while the the barman actually poured our beers. Surely the waiter had something better to do other than wait?

The best things about the service were the bus boys - there seemed to be two of them constantly filling glasses with water. Seemed like overkill to me - people are not here for the water - they are here for the beer! Someone should have given those guys a tray an had them delivering our drinks.

From this point of view, I should award La Trappe just one star. But the food was good and the beer was excellent and well priced, so guess two will do for now.

I hate to write a bad review. I will have to return when it is not quite so busy - maybe they can win another star or two.
author: Kingpin X.

description: First stop on trip to San Francisco. Everything was great, including great Belgian beers, and I highly recommend the portobello mushroom, twice cooked fries, and smoked salmon arugula salad. The one disappointment and reason I gave 4 stars instead of 5 was the smoked trout endive cups, which just really fell short. Highly recommended overall.
author: David P.

description:
Love love love this place. I will definitely be back. 

I joined co-workers here after work while I was visiting the city. We dined downstairs in the casual bar area. 

I loved the vibe: comfortable, big open booths. 

I am now a fan of Belgium beer!  They had an HUGE selection and our server was really helpful in figuring out what I might like or dislike. She even offered me samples. 

The food was nothing fancy. I ordered the sliders, but my favorite was the french fries that came with your choice of dipping sauce. I got the spicy ketchup.
author: Tracey R.

description:
Probably the best selection of Belgian beers you'll ever find outside of Belgium. They had every Trappist beer I could ever imagine. They have a nice menu that describes everything for you which was very informative especially if you've never had these types of beers before.

The soup we had wasn't too bad. This place is really 3.5 stars. It was actually the first time I've ever had rabbit (note to self never order rabbit again). I just couldn't give it 4 for some reason.
author: Len D.

description: Pretty interesting/huge selection of beers - seems like a nice place to grub too.
author: Leily P.

description:
Belgian monks sit around all day brewing
lucky
you can sit around all day drinking
(even luckier)
in the best brick basement barroom
author: nate l.

description:
The beer selection here is great and it's so easy to miss, if you're walking past on the street all you see is a handful of tables and the kitchen. This makes the place look quieter than it actually is.

Downstairs you have a large open area dimly lit with brick walls, you could be anywhere in Europe. It's a nice reminder of back home for me.

Food here has been great each time, though can be a little on the expensive side for an entree. The double cooked fries are delicious and there a large selection of dipping sauces to go along with them, wasabi mayo and spicy ketchup are personal favourites.

A pot of mussels with rice and curry is a hearty meal and has been great each time it's been ordered, if you're not quite as hungry then two slides from the appetiser menu is a reasonable snack, you can get a third added for $4.

Service can be a little hit and miss, getting the attention of your food server can be nigh impossible and it can feel like you're being ignored. This was on a Friday night so they may just have been busier than normal.
author: Scott M.

description:
What shall I say ---- a 1 page food menu, a 40-page beer menu.   Bliss.  They have a really amazing selection of Belgian beer.  The bartenders are extremely knowledgeable, and willing to give you a detailed description and recommendation.  

Didn't eat here - but had a lot of liquid calories!   I want a frequent-flyer card to this place!
author: S C.

description:
I must say the variety of belgian beers at this place was the best part of the night. As i perused the menu of beers the only thing catching my eyes was the column telling of alcohol content. I have never in my life seen so many beers with 11-12% alcohol content. I heart Belgian beer.

The food was excellent from what I recall(mind you, I was into my third or fourth glass of the 12% beer at this time). The mussels and frittes(fries) is a steaming pot of mussels placed in front of you and a cone of fries on the side. The steak was not bad but it wasn't memorable either. The rabbit stew was the highlight of the night. The meat just melted in your mouth and they plate it over polenta which I found excellent. I've never liked polenta by itself but with stew I found that it is one of those pairings that was meant to be like pb/jelly, spaghetti/meatballs, corned beef/cabbage, chitlings/ducks blood?!... I am so used to the american way of plating stew with mashed potatoes that the polenta at La Trappe was such a refreshing new take on stew. It feels lighter and carried more texture than your typical mashers that can feel like an anvil in your stomach.

And since this was a belgian restaurant, theres not a better way to end the night but with a plate of belgian waffles, strawberries and whip cream. A little too sweet for my taste but none the less fulfilling. 

Price and ambiance is a bargain for the area. The beer was the only thing out of whack at $8 a glass but then you come to realize that the 12% makes up for it. There were just as many people sitting and eating as there were drinking and hanging out at the bar which was all in one room in the basement. It was a nice mixture that didn't get too intrusive to either groups.
author: Ron T.

description:
Apparently the La Trappe secret is out - Friday nights are packed. I suggest traveling back in time to right after they opened (or current weeknights) for smaller crowds and quicker seating. But La Trappe is packed for a good reason, the beer selection is huge, superb, and a large number of beers on tap rotate. 

Did I die and go to Belgian beer heaven? Probably. I took my visiting family here and they are still looking for comparable Belgian restaurants/bars in their respective cities. Not only is the beer amazing, but the food (burger, fries, and mussels) is quite yummy. The intimate downstairs bar/eatery space just adds to the experience.
author: Abigail R.

description: It truly pains me to have to do this because in theory I love everything about this place; the ambiance, the beer selection, the food, the location. But I simply have to give it a 1 star rating because the service is the WORST I have ever had. And this is not just a one time thing, this is from 5 different trips. The service was so bad this last time I actually got up 6 times to check on the bill and the owner had the balls to yell at me about being a bad customer. I mean... that is just crazy. So go here if you have already had a few and don't mind bad service. But if you are sober, I would wait for a few hours to head down those steps.
author: Amy M.

description:
My husband and I found this place a couple of years ago and our go to place when we need a night away from the kids. The place is super cool with its underground bar... love the vibe and decor makes you feel like your in a secret hideout. We live in the East Bay and there is nothing even out our way compares to this place.

Food is not bad either...we usually order a burger a split it. The "pomme frites" are good too, we especially love the flavored mayo you dip them in, although too much mayo a beer have left our stomachs on tilt  few times.lol

The greatest thing we love about La Trappe is the BEER!!!! I'm a huge Belgian beer fan and my hubby is totally into all those fancy craft beers...we can get a good buzz on and not worry about getting into a fight when we leave 'cause there's no hard alcohol involved.lol
author: E B.

description:
First time to this place last night (buddy of mine suggested it) and I'm already looking for an excuse to go back there again.

Upstairs looks more like a mellow coffee shop but downstairs was like walking through wardrobe in Chronicles of Narnia.

It was this cool, hip bar with old fashion wooden tables, fancy beer mugs apparatus, etc. plus good looking scenery (lol).
author: Francis M.

description:
Pluses: Great casual atmosphere, extensive beer menu, and of course, mussels and frites!

Minuses: Pricey beers and closes way too early-- midnight.

Overall, a fun place to hang out with a group of friends.  Don't bother with the entrees, just go for the frites.
author: Lauren T.

description:
This is an excellent Belgian beer bar.  They have a respectable menu of beers on tap, but the impressive part is when you open the ~50 page menu of bottled beers that they have in the fridge.  

Ambiance was excellent.  Upstairs is nice, but the key is below ground.  They have turned downstairs into a dimly lit, well decorated, midscale bar with a limited amount of seating for dining.  They have a small lounge in the back, but probably only 10-15 people can sit back there, very small.  I was disappointed that our group was quoted 60-90 minute wait for a table downstairs, but perhaps that is my fault for not getting us there earlier than 7pm on Friday night.

Food is good, but not 5 star food.  Better than your average pub grub, but this is not your average pub.  They specialize in their mussels and frites, both of which were good, not great.  The prices for mussels are standard for North Beach restaurants and I expected a little more flavor in them.  Frites were good, but after my trip to NYC and craving Pommes Frites in East Village and dining on them at 3am....I haven't found anywhere that stood up to that 5 star mouthful.

Beers (Belgian ales), the beer list, the awesome basement ambiance, and decent mussels make this a place I will visit again with more buddies.
author: Chris C.

description:
We had to send a hamburger back because it was R-A-W on the inside. Like, mealy bug raw.

Also, they were not out of anything at 6:00 pm but by 9:00 pm (we had gotten cozy) they were out of three of the things we asked for. Great beer list, but upon exploration it's more like a shallow lake than a deep ocean.

But I do want to complement them on their seating. The large tables were great for a group that arrived in a staggered fashion.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
I went to La Trappe after a lovely dinner in north beach as part of my birthday celebration. Had I not had an intelligent friend who knew the place, I would never have imagined this placing have such a great bar down stairs....the top floor is so quiet, but as you descend the spiral staircase, you hear the noise and smell the glorious flavors of beers. It was lively and fun, with people sitting and eating, as well as just drinking at the bar. My friend happens to be a beer enthusiast, so he promptly ordered three glasses for all of us to share, and I have to admit, all were delicious. one had an interesting coriander taste, that was slightly spicy and bitter, but I couldn't put it down. 

The staff at this place is great....especially if you drop a glass and shatter it on the floor....luckily they said it happens all the time and I was able to laugh it off (sober is embarrassing). all in all, a great time!
author: britney p.

description:
I stopped by this past weekend, asked if they'd be open on Sunday night.  The guy in charge told me straight to my face they'd be open at 5 pm.  Showed up, nobody is there.

Several days before I read here on Yelp they were opening on 12/4, but when I showed up on 12/4, they were closed!!

I'm sorry, but if you can't keep consistent hours, and can't be honest about it, don't expect either patronage or support.

If you want good Belgian, take a BART ride to Oakland and visit Trappist.  La Trappe is a waste of time.
author: M.S. C.

description:
So I've been hearing about La Trappe for a while and finally got the chance to check it out this week.  We didn't eat really aside from some frites, so I will be reviewing mostly for the beer selections which are enormous!  The binder of options can be overwhelming, but luckily Melanie and I had Andrei to help out. 

Definitely some great finds and a wonderful place to try out new brews.  There isn't that much seating downstairs if you aren't eating so try to get there early or before it gets too crowded.  Otherwise, I'd definitely be inclined to eat the next time I'm there.  They also had some seasonal beers so I am guessing the rotation changes somewhat frequently.

Inside it's super cozy and it's laid out quite nicely.  Definitely a good date spot or just to kick it and try out some new beers.
author: Gene X.

description: If I could have a man-cave, it would look like the basement bar of this fine establishment. A nice Belgian on tap plus decent frites and garlic mayo is basically the perfect snack (or meal).
author: Maximillian M.

description:
Their selection of beers is astounding!  The mussels are cooked perfectly in flavorful broth (there's usually a selection of 4 or 5 preparations) and there are so many dipping sauces for your frites!  The spicy ketchup is my favorite.

I love this place.  The people are friendly, the ambiance is casual but cool, the beers are perfect and the food is delicious.  A must-try.
author: Alyssa W.

description:
Rating 5 to cancel out ratings of 1 from folks that didn't even get past the front door.  How can one rate something they didn't even try?

Otherwise..  Great new restaurant/pub in North Beach with a rare twist: its Belgian!  Lots of Belgian beers to choose from within a detailed, dozen page book.  The selection is comprised of mostly bottles, however there is also a handful of choices available from rotating taps.  Also had some other interesting looking beers/wines from around the world: Japan, Canada, etc..

Menu items range from small and inexpensive ($5) appetizers to large and expensive ($25) entrees.  I feel like the cheese plate could be spruced up a bit; it would be a nice touch if some of the articles making up the plate were Belgian or Trappist as well, for example.
author: alex w.

description:
It was mediocre at best...

When you go to a bar/restaurant that boasts 180 Belgium beers, you expect them to have the one beer you want...especially when we make it easy and order 4 of the same.

Ok, so mussels are the Belgium delicacy right? So we had mussels and Frites (fries) and honestly i can't remember the mussels, only the fries...thats how much i liked my dinner.

I would recommend this place to someone who just really wants to wrap their lips around a Chimay beer. The food seems like a good idea at the time, but really...who wants to eat rabbit?
author: nina B.

description:
Such tasty beer.  We LOVE it here.  The basement atmosphere is great for a day or night of drinking.  I would give it 5 stars except the food isn't that great.  The cheese platter we ordered wasn't very good.  The fries are tasty though.  I just wish the food was better/bigger selection, especially when the beer is so HEAVY!

Overall though, great spot!
author: Lauren K.

description:
Popped in here last friday night for a pal's birthday celebration.  

Honestly, who can ask for more than a HUGE belgian assortment enjoyed in the dim downstairs on wildly appropriate wooden benches?

I can't. 

I will definitely be making special trips to the city for La Trappe.  

Someday I may even eat there :)
author: Kellie T.

description: Love this place. I've been here many time and will continue to be one of my regular places. Only problem is all the calories that come along with the extensive Belgian beer collection. Do note, the extensive part is only on the Belgian beers. You still have ample options for non Belgian beer. But not as extensive. The food here...well you need to have the liking for Belgian food. I go there primarily for the beer. In fact the best time i like to go is in the afternoons around 3. It's a great place for an early evening beer hangout
author: Karthick S.

description:
This place is rock n roll on the down low.... 

The brick cave downstairs is like your in some Eastern Euro swank sheik nest, just liberated from the hard hitting Russia in the 80's ...

Plastic People of the Universe could use this joint as a back stage before and after jamming, not to mention between sets..

What else could you ask for in soft yet buzzing brews and not to forget they have a full menu of up scale bar food delights, the fries are of course a personal favorite especially if you are with a group.

I think I saw Lou Reed circa '79 lurking basement level in in the back corner last Saturday night?!
author: Scott P.

description: I didn't eat here so I can't fully review. I just truly appreciate a wide selection of Belgian beer.
author: Joe S.

description:
I've only been to the [downstairs] bar, but I'll certainly be back.

1st star -- amazing selection of belgian beers
2nd star -- great selection of seating. want to have a one-on-one with your bff? sit at a small table. want to kick it with six work friends? they have booths. want to mix and mingle with the eight or nine friends/acquaintances you brought, go sit in the loungey area. 
3rd star -- it wasn't so loud that i had to yell or strain to hear anyone and most of my friends have accents, so that's really saying something.
4th star -- friendly and helpful bar staff; even if david wouldn't give me my wittekerke until i learned to pronounce it semi-correctly
5th star -- i live about half a block away. assuming i could safely cross columbus, i could stumble home.
author: D L.

description:
I wasn't overly impressed with La Trappe.   The Belgian Beer Selection is quite impressive, but the the "on tap" beer sizes vary and most selections are only offered in a single size.  I am used to being able to order any beer in 2 or 3 sizes when in Belgium.  For the most part I thought the Beer was overpriced (at least the beer that you can find at other establishments around town).  I tried a few different beers with my meal which I ate in the cellar. 

The food did not knock my socks off.  The "grass fed" burger was nothing to write home about... I didn't even finish it despite being hungry.  The fries were delicious, but not worth making a trip back for, I would probably head to Frjtz if that was what I was craving (they have more dipping sauces). My companion had mussels and fries which were served in a huge pot  filled above the brim, but they did not match the mussels I had a day earlier in Belden Alley, although there were more of them.

The round table for two was so tiny that our food and drinks were fighting for places to sit and helped to make the place feel even more cramped than it already was.  We asked if we could move to a slightly larger empty table when the food arrived, but were told someone was waiting for it.   It sat empty until just before we finished our meal. The noise level was incredible.  It was very hard to communicate and be heard despite there being a few empty tables while we were dining.  

I might come back here for beer and appetizers if I planned on sitting at the bar or if I had friends who wanted to drink Belgian beers in North Beach.  However, I don't think it is worth going out of your way to eat or drink here. It is very small, so not great for large groups.  The noise level due to the low ceiling prevents it from being cozy. It does feel like one of the cellar breweries in Europe built to a much smaller scale.
author: Cat S.

description: One of the coziest places for a craft beer I've experienced (downstairs bar).  Tap selection rivals the other Belgian place in town, but this place is darker and actually located in San Francisco.  Server Michael was pleasant and helpful with draft selections.  We'll certainly return on future visits.
author: Albert H.

description: 5 stars! This is the BEST BELGIAN MUSSELS in town! When I crave mussels, I'd always think about La Trappe. Pick the beer marinate flavor+spicy ketchup and belgian mayo. NYUM!!!
author: Vinchia O.

description:
I celebrated my 20+7 birthday at La Trappe last night with some of my closest friends.  We didn't wait long for a table, but I also didn't mind waiting in the lounge part of the dungeon.  

Atmosphere is good, dimmed lighting, great for couples, small and big groups.  The Beer Menu is awesome... loved the "beers on tap today" list. Service is great!  The waitress was friendly, helpful and had great suggestions and recommendations.  Being downstairs is the way to go, but it does get pretty crowded so there's always an option of having dinner/drinks upstairs (less noisy, too!).  

The San Francisco Burger is delish!  Eight ounce burger (organic grass-fed beef) on brioche bun or Focaccia, served with twice cooked Belgian fries.  "Meat is murder... tasty, tasty murder!"  The dipping sauces for the fries are good, too.  Choose two (Belgian Mayo, Dijon Mayo, Chipotle Mayo, Wasabi Mayo, Spicy Ketchup, Curry Ketchup, Roasted Bell Peppers).

I really like La Trappe -- would probably be my new hang out in North Beach... :-)!
author: Celeste M.

description:
This place is pretty much the best place for Belgian beer and their adorable glasses.  I love the atmosphere and the little area downstairs in the back.  It's cozy, comfy and clean.  The beer book has a huge selection; it can take forever to decide...just close your eyes and drop your finger somewhere.  Or just stick to what you know and like.  I'm sure they have it.  
 
I've only had the fries, sliders and pancetta wrapped shrimp, and they all seemed a bit bland (loved the spicy ketchup though), but I didn't care much because I was hungry.  

If you like Belgian beers, I see no reason to go anywhere else.
author: Pamela S.

description:
Affligem Blonde on tap = money in the bank.

I love Belgian beer, and this place has the best selection, it reminds me of the bar in Amsterdam where I first fell in love with Affligem, and the bartender is just as hot.

Take me on a date HERE please.

Great vibe, plenty of tables, and a little lounge area in the back.  Walking down the stairs into the darkened room makes it feel a little like a cave or a den; it feels intimate yet worldly, and like all matter of good times and good conversations could happen over the tastiest of beers. All this two blocks from my house makes it my favorite nightcap ever.


HOWEVER:  it just might be too dank for your taste, so unless you really care, don't bother hitting it up, maybe stick to Amante and have a Sierra Nevada...
author: kerry a.

description:
I went here on a first date ... it went OK but we're not going out again.  I really want to go back but unfortunately, La Trappe is one of his "regular" spots! Great atmosphere downstairs in the vault, delicious Belgian beers on tap (of course each with it's own fun glass) complimented by yummy Belgian food.

But now do I really want to bring my friends here and risk running into him ...on another date? Don't you guys know that you shouldn't bring a first date to your favorite place?
author: A S.

description: Five stars for the incredible list of Belgian ales, three for the food, and four for the atmosphere.  Eat downstairs in the bar/dining room.  Mussels were tasty and the rabbitt was a nice surpise, if a bit overwhelmed with sauce.
author: Dan W.

description: Best mussels I've ever had!  Moules frites kokan...amazing.  Beyond that, the beer list is exceptional, the staff is very nice and knowledgeable, attentive but not hovering and the space has a very cool vibe to it.
author: Carmen R.

description: Authentic and cozy Belgian bar and restaurant. Very good place to take beer lovers!
author: Karen L.

description: Great beer selection and good food.  The bartenders are very knowledgeable.  Oddly, the tap beers are a much better deal than the bottled beers, which are over-priced compared to other similar places.  The one thing that keeps me from giving it 5 stars is that the seating policy is inane.  We had a party of 6 and there was a table for 6 available, but 2 people were running late so they wouldn't seat us.  Instead they seated a group of 3.  6 minus 2 is 4, which is greater than 3...
author: T.J. H.

description:
I love Belgian beer.  The beer menu here was half as big as the one I got when I was in Brussels, but that is good enough to impress me (considering the one in Brussels was larger than most textbooks).

The bartender I encountered was actually nice and gave you the time of day unlike most busy bars.  If they see that you know a little bit about beers, they will give you tons of recommendations.  I knew what kind of beer I liked, and even after I ordered, the bartender gave me a taste of a couple of other beers he thought I'd like based on what I was considering.  Pretty awesome.  

The only thing is that this place gets ridiculously crowded sometimes - To the point where you have to queue outside.
author: Jen Z.

description:
Very cool atmosphere downstairs in "the cellar".  Amazing selection of beers!  It took me a good 20 minutes to figure out which beer to pick.  

The Mussels are great, but the fries were a little too crunchy and had way too much salt on them.  Also had the La Trappe burger, which was very tasty!  The brioche bun and aged gouda were such a great combo with the 8oz burger.  Would definitely order it again.
author: km k.

description:
I'm torn, should I shout from the roof tops that this place is awesome or should I swear myself to secrecy so that it remains a hidden gem in North Beach? Screw it, I'll shout from the roof tops..."this place rocks!!!". They have an amazing selection of beers that would require even an Irish beer drinking champion to make a dozen trips to try them all.

The first time you walk into this place you'll think it's pretty borning, little do you realize that there's a basement bar that is probably packed with beer connosoirs. 

We started the night off by drinking a wide variety of Belgium beers and by munching on some fries (with dijon mayo....which was amazing).  We then heading upstairs for the main meal and everyone seemed to be raving about the rabbit stew, I personally had the steak and frites, which was also excellent.

I'll definitely be back...
author: Bryan B.

description:
Thanks to Yelp, I gave this place a try - I would've otherwise walked right by since there wasn't a patron in sight on the main street level.

Thanks to Yelp, I ventured down the curved staircase and voila!  There were quite a few souls enjoying their beers and chowing down.

19 beers on tap, and an abundance of bottled.  You can't go wrong.  

I had the Portobello Mushroom Burger with fries.  Dee-li-cious!  The bun was tender and the right proportion to the bello-shroom, cooked + seasoned just right.  The fries were crisp and a good warm - not too hot to burn.

Ambiance is calming, dim, and kinda medieval looking.  Good thing they don't serve giant turkey legs, which would've been over the top.
author: Cathy K.

description:
A great addition to North Beach, with Belgium beer and nice owners. 

They have a huge Belgium beer selection, as you might expect.

Unfortunately, the service is not very good. On our first visit, our food was cold and the second time, we had to go up to the bar for beers rather than wait another half-hour for the waiter.

I'd like to give these guys more stars. The beers are so good but I sure hope they hire another waiter, soon.

Update: I went back with my guy friends and service was phenomenally poor. Good grief, get it together!
author: Eric ..

description:
A pleasantly blurry Friday night spent drinking fine Belgian beers surrounded by exposed brick walls, dark wood, and recessed lighting? I'll take it! 

A couple of weeks ago some friends and I began a Belgian brew tour of the greater Bay Area, and we may have found our Shangri-La at La Trappe in North Beach. It looks small and unassuming from the outside- a corner restaurant with a few tables and chairs- but enter and descend the staircase and you'll find yourself in a spacious yet cozy underground bar, with tables for food service and a lounge in back tricked out with cushy booths. You'll also find lots of premium Trappist brews both on tap and by the bottle. 

It is wise to exercise caution (or at least awareness) when you're doing it Belgian style. La Trappe lists the alcohol content of each beer on their menu to help keep you informed of how much of a punch you're getting in those innocuous looking chalices. Leaving this bar sober is unlikely at best. Luckily, you're a hop skip and a jump from Cinecitta so you can suck down some awesome pizza to help soak up the alcohol.
author: Angie R.

description:
This place has great atmosphere and great beer. But as you can see from the rest of the reviews on this page, don't  bother with the food. Seriously. Okay, the fries are good enough. But, man, those were the worst mussels I have ever had. Shameful.  Mussels are easy.

I only give them three stars for their beer selection. Frankly, I'd much rather go to Monk's Kettle which is a little pricey,  or the Toronado where they do what they do well.
author: Fareed R.

description:
One of my favorite places in SF!

I love trying all types of beer, and this is a great place for that. Additionally, there are 10 different sauces to choose from to dip your fries in. I'm sold.

My friends and I have only had the burger and mussels. All are quite decent. I can understand that others will think they are overpriced, as they are a bit.

That being said, for my tastes, the good outweighs the bad. If you like gastropubs, check it out. Makes for a very nice evening.
author: Andrea S.

description:
They have trappiste beers here!  As in the failry rare ones brewed in the monasteries of Europe...

This hidden downstairs is probably one of my favorite locations in town.  Whether at the bar discussing the menu with the bartender or hidden in the dark moroccan-inspired corner, I find this the perfect location for date night, guys night out, girls night out, everyone night out, or solo drinking  night out.

never tried the food, but like i said, it's all about the BIER!
author: Gabrielle J.

description:
My review is based on the treatment I received at La Trappe.  

I was not drinking that day so all I had was a diet coke.  A small group of us (4) arrived for a friend's birthday - a group that would grow to about 8-9 people eventually.  First we were disappointed to see no food served until 6 pm (it was 3:30 on a Saturday).  Someone asked if they could get food and bring it so that we could stay together.  They were told no.  (Our group was split on whether this should have been allowed.)  

Upon arrival, I stood away from the 3 others and ordered my first round - a diet coke and a beer for the birthday boy.  I started to pay with cash and the bartender asked me if I wanted to start a tab.  Wanting to save my cash for parking I said sure.  45 min later I went up and ordered another diet coke and a second beer for my friend.  Another in my group was at the bar and the bartender asked him his first name to make sure and charge the right card.  I then gave my name so my order would be charged to the right card.  30 min later I went to cash out and received a bill for $43!!  The bartender had put 5 beers on my card that I had not ordered.  I asked him how that had happened and he said that HE had asked people I was sitting with if he should put their drinks on "THE tab."  Problem was those people had left to get their food so I couldn't even collect money from them.  I asked that he change the charge and he refused.  

I have NEVER been to a bar where the bartender would allow someone to charge to a tab without making sure it was authorized by the cardholder.  NEVER.  In fact, in this case, he had volunteered my card to others, which I find even more despicable.  He should have reversed my charges and approached the table to either get cash or another card.  

I have written the owner requesting a refund - we'll see what he does.
author: Kimberly S.

description: Dined here tonight,  party of 5.  The ordeal took 3 hours which was beyond ridiculous and can be boiled down to bad timing and a poor server.   The downstairs was moderately busy,  but everyone seemingly arrived at once.  Our server,  1 of 2, was quirky and just out of it.   We arrived at 7:30, did not receive drinks until 8:30.  Nor did our server return  to retrieve our dinner orders during this time.   Ordered dinner at 8:30, just after 9, he returned to ask if it was a half dozen or two dozen oysters.   Five minutes after,  he returned to advise the kitchen had notified him they were out of scallops.   It was at this point we determined that he had just put the order in,  and it was also at this point the other server,  possibly the owner? Noticed our situation and took over our table along with the bartender.   They tried their best to make up for the issues.  We did not ask for compensation, but they took it upon  themselves to take 1 dozen oysters off the bill,  and all of our drinks which included 3 beers,  1 glass of wine and 1 bottle of wine.  The food itself,  OK.   Lastly,  we never received one of the appetizers we ordered,  nor was it on the bill.   Must have forgotten about it in the 45 minutes he took to put our order in the system.   Sadly,  I would try this place once more as the tables around us seemed to have reasonable service time,  the downstairs ambiance is cool (although music would be nice),  and they have an extensive beer selection.  One last note,  upon leaving we noticed an application for new ownership transfer in the window dated 9/30/13.  Maybe this contributed to the poor service and so so food as ownership is transitioning?   Who knows.
author: Justin M.

description: Have I been transported back to Belgium?  Where is the pee'ing boy statue?  This is the closest you can get to Belgium without a passport.  Go, go, go!
author: D B.

description:
Tops Brouwer's in Seattle due to more interesting menu and beer selection, plus excellent atmosphere in the basement (although there's nothing wrong with the upstairs dining area either).  Food is good but not great.  Agreed the mussels were small, but still can't complain when they're in a pot that big.  I opted for the burger and it was fine, although the bun nearly slipped out of my hands due to the high butter content.  But hey, it's Belgian food - that's to be expected.

Dip tip - Everyone seems to love the wasabi, but I fell in love with the honey dijon.
author: John H.

description:
As others have noted, if you are a beer lover, this is the place to go. I have now been twice and feel know closer to having a grasp on their massive beer selection then the moment I walked in. Of course they specialize in belgium ales and have a wide selection of both draft and bottles. The downstairs lounge/dining area has a great ambiance with comfortable clean coches, oak barrel tables and a lot of open space.

 I also have eaten here once and had the burger. It was very good and came with a massive side of fries for about 11 dollars. They also have a choice of about 8 dipping sauces for the fries, this just adds the excitement. I would recommend coming here during the week, because it was a little more crowded and less enjoyable when I stopped in on friday night. Come to think of it maybe I shouldn't have written this review cause I dont want this place becoming too popular!
author: Clayton V.

description:
A solid Belgian restaurant was a long time coming in San Francisco. And it has finally arrived! Yes, they had some missteps in their opening (I asked and apparently the Fire Department was giving them Code Crap over their really beautiful spiral staircase). 

But, that aside, it is now open and in full swing. The street level is actually the upper level and has been seemingly empty no matter when I show up and no matter how crowded it is in the basement. So...skip right past this and go down the aforementioned spiral staircase to the basement!

Once there, you'll notice you are in a very cozy, taverny, cave-like setting. They have booths for larger groups with actual church pews serving as yours seats. Very Trappiste. Bonus. The menu is standard belgian fare - moules frites, monkfish, et al. Of course, the only you need to know is that the National Dish of Belgium - moules frites - are pretty fantastic.

Of course, the single most important thing here the beer. La Trappe has delivered with the most comprehensive beer list in the entire Bay Area (although I hear The Trappist in Oakland is stepping up to compete). In any case, there is a 10-page beer menu which didn't knock my socks off...it blew my pants off. Wow! The bartenders were fairly knowledgeable, but they weren't exactly experts in the way those at the City Beer Store are. Huge credit to their menu and even more impressively, their 14 or so beers on tap. A great selection from all over. If you need quality beer in SF - you have no choice but the simple love this place.
author: Tolga E.

description:
Walking down the spiral stair case and seeing Manneken Pis I knew I was a fan. I loved their beer selection, not quite as many as Monk's Kettle but their prices were a few dollars cheaper on most bottles.

Great mussels in many different variations. I had the spicy tomato, but I also smelled the coconut curry and they must be amazing. Loved all the dipping sauces I recommend the curry ketchup, chipotle mayo, and Dijon mayo. I liked the fried but they were pretty standard nothing that amazing.

The Barbar Honey beer was some of the tastiest beer I have ever had, with an awesome but not overwhelming honey after taste. 

Would def recommend for a party or large group fun atmosphere downstairs, but if you want a quieter date spot stay upstairs.
author: Katie M.

description:
LOVE LOVE LA TRAPPE. After my Paris trip last year, I was determined to find a place in SF with good Moules and FRittes and beer.  We came across La Trappe, and we were so thankful.  I love their mussels with tomato sauce and coconut sauce, so good.  Their burger was so tender and juicy. Their fries come with so many fun sauce to dip in.  And the BEER, there are so many choices to chose from and they all taste so good.  
The only bad thing about this place is parking, pretty tough to find on a Friday or Sat nights but it's worth it.
author: NT C.

description: Hidden gem in SF ... well not so hidden after all, but easy to miss.  I'll be short:  best ambiance in the city, best mussels and best pomme frites aka french fries.  You really feel like you are in europe here.  They serve the largest pot of mussels I have ever seen.  Also there is a huge selection of dips for pomme frites.
author: Ruslan K.

description:
I drive by this place every day and I finally went in for a friend's birthday gathering on Friday night.  What a pleasant surprise!

From the outside it looks like an empty cafe, which is why I never went in.  There is a downstairs that I had no idea even existed with 180 beers on tap and a really cool atmosphere.  I'll definitely be back soon to try to food.  Great spot!
author: stacy b.

description: Great beer selection and the down stairs bar is a great place to duck out to.
author: Jesse M.

description:
A medieval dungeon with a beer menu that looks like a Tolstoy novel.  Couldn't be more up my alley.

La Trappe focuses more specifically on Belgians than the other top beer bars in the city.  While you might not find the crazy new seasonal brew from X local brewery, you will see Belgians that you've never heard of.  In fact, you'll probably lose a good 20-30 minutes fretting over the menu before your first drink...

Small points down for some very picky things... our waitress wasn't quite as knowledgeable about her beer as servers I've talked with at Monk's Kettle or City Beer.  But she didn't glare a hole through my retinas either, so, points over Toronado there.  Also, we observed that one beer was listed on the menu twice, under different names and different prices.  Kinda lame, but easily corrected.

The food was nice as well, whether you're ordering a full dinner, or just some frites to snack on at the bar. 

Overall, definitely in my top 5 must-go beer stops in SF, along with City Beer, Monk's Kettle, Toronado, and Church Key.  I'd probably rank it about #4 for selection/quality, but #1 in terms of atmosphere.
author: Joe K.

description: Someone brought me here a few years ago. There's cool hidden bar downstairs with a book filled with tons of Belgium beer. I don't know my beer, but I can definitely drink them. The fries here are pretty good too.
author: V N.

description:
Having never been here, we were pleasantly surprised when we got to the bottom of stairs - great ambiance!!

The lounge is a nice idea, but the configuration of benches and tables makes for really awkward seating/eating arrangements so next time I'll just sit at the bar.

Beer was great, veg food selection was fairly good. The fries were good, not great, and the portion was generous. They have a few flavored ketchups that don't come with the fries, so be sure to ask for those if you enjoy dipping. The polenta was fine and cheese plate was fine but pricey for what you get (I didn't like the bread that it came with).

Neat place, I'll be back.
author: Shal J.

description:
Walking past this place you'd think nothing more of it than "Oh, another cafe." But then venture inside and walk downstairs, and leave that empty storefront behind! Downstairs is a bustling atmosphere with an amazing beer selection.

The menu is literally a tome of delicious Belgian beers. I'm not your typical beer fan and I'm kinda uppity when it comes to beers. But oh man, La Trappe has been one of the most satisfying beer experiences in my entire life. A Belgian beer hall in the middle of SF like this, is one not to miss.
author: Jeremy W.

description: This is where to go to get yer Belgian beer on. Beer beer beer! As everyone else has said, they have a large selection. In fact, it's a rather overwhelming selection.
author: Ken L.

description: Absolutely fantastic place.  Go downstairs for the lively bar.  With so many delicious Belgian beers, you need to get opinions and suggestions from the bartenders.  The food is great too, but this place gets five stars for the beer selection and atmosphere alone.
author: Jeff P.

description:
The atomosphere of this place is great! It's pretty funny because there is never anyone upstairs and it looks empty but the second you go downstairs you're greeted by a nice decor and relaxed vibe.

The beer selection is probably the best I have ever seen in the states, they probably have 30 beers on tap and another hundred or so in a bottle.  The "Beer Menu" is probably 50 pages thick with great descriptions.  Every beer I have had here has been amazing.  

Now the bad, the food isn't very appealing.  The fries are good, but I honestly can't recommend much else.  A few friends got several dishes that literally looked terrible, there was a boiled sausage dish that looked like it was sitting in a vat of oatmeal.  Apparently it tasted about as good as it looked.  

While the waitstaff was friendly, the service was pretty subpar.  I don't know if they don't have adequate staff or what, but it seemed like it was tough to get her to come over.  The food took a long time to come and it's not like we had a small check.  You would think if people are spending $200+ you would get a little more attention right?

All in all, I think this a great place to get a beer either prior or following dinner.  Nice atmosphere, great beer selection and since it is somewhat hidden, you don't get a lot of tourists or randoms coming in.
author: Eli Z.

description:
Alright, so I live on the same block as this establishment, and yes that excites me quite a bit.
Lemme tell you why.
First.  Any new restaurant in North Beach that serves food other than Italian deserves a major high five.  Not that I don't like Italian food, it's just raining from the sky around here.
2nd.  The owners rule in a big fat way.  Great people. 
3rd. A boggling amount of beer choices - they hand you an actual book for crying out loud !!
4. The fries are to die for.  I'm a picky fry guy - gotta be crispy and never soggy - I got two orders last time I was in and they rocked the funky house.
5. The downstairs is cool as all get out. Church pews and bricks walls - The atmosphere is made for drinking.
6. The soups were outstanding too.

Yeah I'm biased.  I live two doors down - so I'm excited to have a great neighborhood place.
One word of caution.... stand up once in a while whilst you're drinking for a drunk check...
That Belgian stuff comes on strong and fast.

Alright, Right on.
author: David L.

description:
What to do for Easter? ... Better eat some rabbit.

In typical lightweight Hayley fashion, I was bombed after a single Belgium beer.  The higher alcohol content and larger quantity had me worked over in no time...  I am such a wuss.  So of course, I had a blast at my first time at La Trappe!  The whole time I reminisced about an old hangout/cellar/bar in Vienna called the Hexenkeller.  It felt legit. 
 
The beer was certainly legit...

The food was the kind of food you want when you forgot your winter coat on a cold night and you are hoping that eating enough will somehow make up for that fact.  Stew, creamy polenta, sweet potatoes and green veggies dripping in butter were in abundance.  Thankfully, I had a substantial appetite so i was able to hork down the whole plate, but i can imagine many have visited La Trappe wishing for slightly smaller portions at a lower cost.  

Have the rabbit stew and a kwak.  You won't regret it.
author: Hayley W.

description:
The one thing I learned at this place is that apparently all Belgian beers get their own special glass.  "Oh, you want the Chimay?  That comes in this glass.  And you want the Hoegaarden?  Well, we can't pour that in a Chimay glass, now can we?!?"  

Being a connoisseur of the High Life and PBR, the switch to Belgian beer was quite pleasant and made me feel like a beer snob (at least for the 73 minutes that I was there).  Haven't tried the food yet, but I'll be sure to be back to try their grub and see how many different Belgian beer glasses I can drink out of.
author: Norm U.

description: If you are a member of the cult of Chimay or spell beer with an I, then La Trappe should be given a couple of hours of your time.  We headed here after a wedding in North Beach and it made for a good cap to the night.  The stonework and decor actually look like a European basement bar.  (If you have seen Inglorious Basterds then you have a vague idea of what it looks like and you know that this is not the kind of place to tangle with a bunch of Nazis.  This being San Francisco, I do not think that that will be a potential problem, but just saying)  Service takes their time, but this is the kind of place where you do not need to worry about the passage of time and need to try a couple of beers and relax.
author: James P.

description:
La Trappe's atmosphere is super live and intimate. The food is great and... 

their - 3
beer - 4
menu - 4
has 5
a - 5
table - 5
of - 6
contents. - 6

Don't you go there, though. I don't want my neighborhood Belgian joint getting too crowded.
author: Dustin K.

description: Belgian Beer Pub and Belgian pub fare (sorta). I'm actually not the biggest fan of Belgian Beer since I'm more of a light beer drinker (it's ok to groan).  I'm one of the ones that just don't like too much hops. However, I did find some selections at La Trappe I was content to drink. The atmosphere was boisterous and fun (it reminded me of the basement bar room scene in Inglourious Basterds). The food was on the better side of average. Would I come here again? Maybe if there was a special reason, like an out of town visitor.  As a regular go to place, it's a bit too packed. I'm not a fan of fighting for the bartender's attention at a crowded bar, and it takes a bit of a wait to get a table (i think we we had reservations too). Oh yeah, last call is at midnight or so which is too early.
author: Bern H.

description: I had a very similar experience to Roth E. There were plenty of empty tables but the hostess wouldn't seat us because we were "only" ordering appetizers. It was 10pm! We came for fancy beers! From Chicago! Come on!
author: Jennifer S.

description: Belgian nirvana.  Enormous beer selection.  Pretty decent Belgian fries. Yummy food.
author: Mauricio S.

description: One of my favorite spots in North Beach... Love the fries and mussels, and their burger is pretty impressive, have to take a star away for not having avocados or bacon for the burger.
author: Sarkis S.

description:
Conclusive proof that Belgium is far from boring, La Trappe is a quite outstanding hole in the wall with the cosiest of downstairs bars, a jaw-dropping beer menu and several appealing dipping sauce options to go with those heavenly twice-cooked fries. I went cajun mayo and spicy ketchup and was mightily pleased. And of course, no plate of frites is complete without a helping of moules, steamed in beer (yum!) or otherwise. 

The place was pretty bustling for a midweek night so sadly, I am not exactly blazing the trail here. Nonetheless, you should give it a try.
author: Leela S.

description:
If its great beer you want, then this is the place! The list is so extensive, its hard to know where to begin, but fortunately the bartenders are really nice to let you sample as many as you want (it seems) before deciding on a refreshing glass. Mmmm.... Belgian beer.

If its good food and attentive service you're after, venture elsewhere. The experience of La Trappe was killed the moment we were seated for dinner. Though we didn't have to wait for a table, we sure as hell waited a long time our waiter to take notice of us. After we got our menus, we decided on three appetizers. We told our waiter we'd like to order them, then take a little more time to decide on entres. Instead of checking back after 5, 10, hell even 15 minutes, we notified a bus boy after sitting idly for 20 minutes that we were ready to put in our mains. All he could respond with was "ask waiter." I asked if he could please get our waiter, as he was nowhere in sight, but all he could respond with again was "ask waiter." Finally, our waiter made it back to our table. He asked if we could use more drinks in the meantime and we asked for recommendations. After my friend decided on an ale, I decided to try a sample of the same beer. 10 minutes later the beer came, but the waiter forgot my sample and had to go back for it...another 5 minute wait.

After waiting nearly 40 minutes, our appetizers came. I can't imagine it takes that long to throw some frites in a basket, but perhaps it was the mussels and the mushroom polenta dishes that did it. For 40 minutes, I was hoping these would be outstanding dishes. Well, what do the 2 stars tell you? 

*The Frites: how can one be expected to dip fries into a sauce if they are the length of your pinky fingernail? Its impossible! The curry ketchup sauce was pretty good, though the curry sauce at Frjtz in the mission is better and comes with fries that can actually be dipped without a fork!

*The mussels: are apparently steamed in a beer sauce, but you wouldn't know it because they completely lack in any flavor. And the onions they're served with are thin and few.

*Portabella mushroom on polenta: this was the best appetizer, with polenta not too fried or soggy.

We were 5 people, and considering we were clearly sharing the the starters, it would have been nice if they'd considered giving us plates that were a little bigger than a teacup saucer so we didn't have to keep passing the food around in circles, trying to cut and serve it up without knocking each others elbows and drink glasses. 

About a half hour after getting our appetizers we got our mains. I got the cod gratin with salad, two people got the rabbit stew, and two others got the moules frittes to share.

*Cod gratin: getting to sample the others' dishes, I concluded this was the best dish. It was cooked in a decent beschamel sauce and not overly cheesy. The side salad, however, was just a few pieces of lettuce with some red vinaigrette. If you get yourself this dish, ask to substitute the salad with veggies. The veggies that came with the rabbit were far better than the salad, though a little bit overcooked.

Our waiter did not once come to check on us while we were eating, and only offered to bring us the check after we asked our waiter to please get him (again, "ask waiter"). 

I was totally unimpressed by the food and would never want to deal with the wait staff again. But, if I feel like a good beer, I might belly up to the bar and hope the female bartender with the short black hair and tattoos is there, because she and the beer she served me were the only good things about this place.
author: Raquel C.

description:
Beers...5 Stars!!

Service...1 Star!

Food - I dunno, 3 stars?

I am so understanding about service.  I have been in the biz for years.  Everyone has a bad night, etc, etc.  This was beyond bad service.  Like, at a level that I don't think I have seen since I left the mid west.  I'll spare the details, but let's just say I would be more forgiving if the mains weren't going for $21 each - I know that isn't Gary Danko prices, but I would expect that at those prices, I had a right to some sort of service.

The food ranged from pretty good rabbit stew to inedible gnocchi.  My husband ordered it and ate it, but it was scary - little balls of flour in a cheese soup.  I swore he would be moaning with stomach pain by the end of the night.  The sliders were overcooked - kind of like little burned meat pucks.  But you put enough ketchup on anything and yay, tasty delight!

But...the beer!  It rocks!  I lived in Brussels for a while, and this really reminds me of my favorite place there.  A review with a happy ending!  Great selection and they are pouring them in their proper glasses - how  cool!  Really great atmosphere too.  I am looking forward to going back and ordering beers at the bar.  Hopefully they will hire some more help.
author: Melissa G.

description:
Ah, I simply love this place.

I finally had something close to my legendary Delirium Cafe experience.  The menu, the bartender, and that strong moules smell in the air, all very, very lovely.

The atmosphere was cute too.  Hidden from the main dining room in the basement, I was safely tugged away under with fellow beer affectionados.

Beware of severe hangovers, though.
author: Jiajia C.

description: Been here twice, and both times have been excellent experiences. I had mussels both times (two different preparations); they were delicious, and incredibly filling. HUGE pot of the yummy things. As I know next-to-nothing about Belgian beer, all I can say for their selection is it has a great variety and everything I've tried has been quite good. The owner and staff have been nothing but friendly and helpful, chatting with us the entire time as we ate at the bar. The only drawback is that it's in North Beach, which I tend to avoid like the plague. This place is worth the trip, though, and thankfully tucked away from the chaos of drunk fratboys and confused tourists...
author: A M F.

description: My group, like Roth E.'s, ran into the waiter he referred to as BGH (beard glasses hat) guy, with a tilt to his SF giants cap. We ordered food and waited....and waited...and the were told by surly BGH that our food was "next up". 30 minutes later (1 1/2 hours after ordering!!!) We got our food. At least the beer was good enough to distract us from screaming at the wait staff. Great food. Great beer. WORST SERVICE EVER. Be a professional, man! TAKE OFF THE FUCKING BASEBALL HAT WHILE YOU'RE WAITING TABLES. If the place has white tablecloths and cloth napkins, and you're waiting tables in a baseball hat, something's wrong with that picture...
author: Peter F.

description: Great food, romantic ambience, very nice and friendly personnel.
author: Haleh H.

description:
When you are a party of 5 you order then the waitress come back to tell you they run out of mussels fine then suggest to take the seafood stew instead ok then come back again sorry no seafood stew so let go for the calamari salad then sorry again out of calamari. 
So let me give you one advice " Communication " 

By the way we finally got the 2 entrees 15 minutes after the rest for something to be so so.
author: Laurent G.

description: Food was good beer list was crazy, over 400 bottled beers and a good amount on draft as well.  All beers had detailed explanations in the beer list which was nice.  We had a big group (nine people) with no reservation on a Tuesday night at there was no seating downstairs, which is a cool pub atmosphere.  Sat upstairs, waiter was great.  Everyone had a great time.
author: BJ G.

description:
My roommates and I decided to go out for a quick drink one evening and decided to hit up La Trappe since it's across the street from our apartment.  The place looked quite dead until we headed downstairs.

We were greeted at the end of the stairway by a rock waterfall, which then lead into a cave-like area.  The whole place looked pretty cozy.

The beer and wine selection fills a whole book!  Very impressive!

We sat down and was quickly approached by our server.  You can definitely tell that they've done their homework on their beers.  If you're not sure what to pick, the servers will definitely be able to help you here.  Just tell them what type of beer you like, and they'll fire back with a few suggestions.  My company and I have always been satisfied with their picks.

Great place for groups.  Try it out!
author: Maggie L.

description:
Go for: 
enjoying a beer
catching up with old friends (they keep the music low so you can actually hear yourself think!)
enjoying a laid back evening

Don't go if you're looking for: 
getting sloppy drunk
taking people you're uncomfortable with
rave/dance/party scene

Any beer lover in your group will thank you for taking them here!  Helpful bartenders who will ask you what you like and give you great recommendations.  I like the cozy feeling given from the underground, exposed-brick environment.  

Busy after work (6pm-8pm) but if you go around 9 or 10 you won't have to wait long for a frosty brew.  Pleasant crowd at any time of day, though.  Haven't tried the food but it all looks good.

Just go!
author: Carrie B.

description:
I believe La Trappe is Flemish for "Cool little bar with a wide range of good beers to choose from." That may seem a little long, but the Belgians are renown for saying a lot with very few words.

My girlfriend and I went this weekend with four friends to celebrate my birthday after dinner and a few beers at Rogue. The beer selection was spendy in comparison to popping out for a PBR, but reasonable if you've priced bottles Belgian beer at  BevMo, the City Beer Store or wherever it is you buy your beer.

We ordered dessert and I had a Belgian Waffle that was really well done. My girlfriend had the four layer chocolate mousse which satsiated her chocolate cravings for at least the day. Lesser desserts have failed at doing so in the past.

The best part about it though was the environment. The area we were in had nice padded chairs that could be moved about to suit the mood of your party. We set back and had something you really can't have in most bars-- a nice conversation. 

The downside is that you're not in for a cheap evening if you hang out here. My one beer ran 8 bones, after all. But it is a very enjoyable place for those moments you decide to splurge.
author: Joey J.

description: scotch de silly , A winner , one of the best beer ever made .
author: NAEL K.

description:
Astounding beer selection.  So if you are a beer aficionado you will definitely want to check this place out.

I like the downstairs area, very quaint and Euro feeling.  But deafening acoustics make it difficult to talk and hear.

This place failed one of my litmus tests - french fries.  Mediocre.  Kinda flavorless.  Unless they are cold or soggy, it's pretty hard to screw up a french fry.  These were hot and crisp yet devoid of yumminess.
author: darla s.

description:
Totally unassuming Belgian joint in the middle of the hustle and bustle of North Beach. A huge selection of Belgian beers for a pretty penny--but the Chimay was only $4?! Is Chimay to Belgium as Bud Light is to the US? 

Anyway, I've only been to the cavernous basement area and totally enjoyed it. The lighting is dim and it's pretty chill for its location, at least when I was there. Great place to go if you just want to relax, have a beer and chat it up.
author: Natalie T.

description:
I had high hopes for this place. A place like The Trappist with heartier food? And mussels?

An out-of-town friend and I dropped in around 7:40pm on a Wednesday night.

We finally got a table at 8:20pm

Orders taken 10 minutes later, and our server disappeared into the ether.

At 9:20pm, with the place now virtually empty (and a table seated 10 minutes after us already halfway through their mains), the server came by and told us our meals wouldn't be much longer. We finally got ours 10 minutes later. Burn-the-roof-of-your-mouth hot.

I've never before known a place to rear a cow from embryo for their burgers. Must've been fresh.

The server apologized profusely and told us because it took so long, our meals were on the house. OK, not so bad. He then came by and told us his mistake, only one burger would be comped. Still, better than nothing, and a decent gesture.

We finally finished up, split the bill and left. All good, right? The beer was fantastic, the food (for what it was) was good.

But no. 2 days later, the charges went through. They'd mixed up the charges between my friend's bill and mine. So I called to rectify this.

Now, 5 days and a dozen calls later, I still can't get past their voicemail (which now has a full mailbox).

It might be a Belgian style pub, but the attitude definitely isn't.
author: Darren Q.

description: What a let down! As a La Trappe neighbor, I've always been a fan of their amazing beer selection. If you're only going for beers, then this is absolutely your spot. Unfortunately, my friends and I went for dinner last Friday and were served cold fries, and dry, flavorless, over-cooked burgers. If I'm going to pay $14 for a burger, please know that I mean "medium rare" when I order it that way. I am sad to cross this off my (short) list of places in North Beach that are ok for locals and tourists.
author: Michelle P.

description: Back in San Francisco after 4 years, living in North Beach, looking for beer. And I found La Trappe. Became friends with the bartender, and asked him to recommend a beer from the 400 bottle deep list. Beers I've never heard of such as Bos Keun and Brasserie de Rocs. From the taps I've tried the Quad Hendrick, and the Cantillon an amazing sour beer, and the Russian river supplication. They have old standards like the Allagash, or Chimay. The staff are incredibly busy, slammed by tourists and locals alike. The food is OK, this is not a gastropub, just a place for amazing beer in my opinion. The bartender told me about 2 guys from Belgium who landed, and went straight to La Trappe, why in Gods name would you do that when you're from the motherland of beer? Now that's respect.
author: G K.

description:
Who knew this place existed? At a dark end of Columbus, between the bustle of North Beach and the cotton candy kingdom of the Wharf, La Trappe will stun you with an array of Belgian beers you've never heard of. I decided to start things off right with a glass of their Koningshoven, which is brewed by Trappist monks and smacks you in the face with 11% alcohol content. 

I particularly enjoyed this bar's rathskellar design. Very classic, makes you want to throw your arm around somebody and belt out drinking songs about sailors. Also, I can't get over that every Belgian brew has its own type of glass with name painted on it. Belgium must be the greatest country in the world that no one cares about. Delightful!
author: Andrew K.

description: We did not try the food at all - just came in for drinks after having dinner someplace else.  Their beer selection is nothing short of amazing.  You get a "bible" that turns out to actually be their beer menu, complete with a table of contents.  All the beers we had were amazing, and the bartender was very friendly, talkative, and quite knowledgeable.  We got to try many beers that we have never had before, which is rare for us!
author: Shannon A.

description: Haven't tried the food but as far as ambiance and beer selection goes, La Trappe is something special.  The room downstairs did it for me as well as the cozy fireplace in the back room. Probably a nice place to take a date for some good make out sessions. What? =)
author: Susan A.

description: My bf took me here for my bday, it was great. Service was great, they have so many beers...we told the waiter what we liked and he totally understood and delivered!  When there are 400 beers that's pretty amazing. The food was delicious, we had the cheese plate and a chicken dumplings...both great!  We will for sure be back. The building has a lot of character. It added to the experience!  I highly recommend, especially if u r a beer lover!
author: Dawn E.

description:
This restaurant is new and it shows.  I'm sure the service will improve over the course of the next month but the waiter I had seemed to lack any knowledge of the menu and beer selection.

The overpriced beer selection is quite good but the waiter fails to explain the multitude of choices.  The beers on tap seem to range from $7-9.  I set might sights low for service based on the reviews and asked for a dark beer.  The waiter did not know of any dark beers. Wrong answer in the place that is hoping to overcharge you on their beers.

The food was good.  The mussels and rabbit are the highlights and are worth the $15 and $20 price points .  The risotto was good at $10 as was the gnocchi.  

The heat did not work and we were told that in advance.  I'm sure it will be up and running by tomorrow.  If the owner is reading this review... Comp something if your patrons are freezing in the hopes you get positive word of mouth.

Decor is cool and the music is a little off.  Overall I would go back if the beer prices reduced and the waiter decided to provide service.  The owner seems to really care and in time I'm sure they we will work out the grand opening bugs.  This restaurant has potential.

Work on the desserts and add some traditional Belgian treats.
author: Mo P.

description:
Absolute train wreck.  

On the positive side, back corner of downstairs felt cozy and loungy . . . Overall the place feels welcoming.  Clientele was mostly 20-something and a few older folks (50+); we were the only 30-somethings I noticed.  Amazing selection of beers (average $9-11).  Bartender was helpful and friendly.
