The 8 if us decided to have dinner and I connected with the SOLITARY server in the downstairs dining area to let him know we'd like a table.  He was nice, and we had a table within 15 minutes.  

After we were seated almost 25 minutes went by and we still hadn't had the opportunity to order anything (we wanted food and BEERS!).  Our server was taking/delivering orders elsewhere and never looked our way.  Finally, we told a busboy we'd like to order.  Then we saw our server run upstairs, and we waited some more.  Then we told another busboy we'd like to order.  And we waited some more.  That's right, folks, until someone with a brain and some authority sent down reinforcement around 9:15 on a Saturday night, one server was all alone with approx. 10 full tables of 35 customers!!  Finally a girl came down from upstairs and took our drink/food order (no less than 40 min. after were were seated).  While she was at our table the other male server gave me an apologetic look from across the room and mouthed "sorry."  Sure, it's okay dude . . . don't mind us.  I know you're busy.  

Beers took at least 15 minutes more of waiting.  We were very happy to finally have something to drink (having been seated for almost an hour)!  Then we waited for our food, which took another 20 minutes. 

Food -  Panchetta on the prawn appitizer was burnt - so black it looked and tasted like charcoal (ick!), calamari salads were very bland and lacked any distinct flavor, burger was average, fries were fine, portobello burgers were so salty that's all you could taste. 

After our table was cleared by the hardworking busboys we waited about 20 minutes for the check until one of us waved his hand and our server came over and we asked for our check.  She nodded and went away.  We waited about 10 minutes.  Check didn't come.  We saw the male server and asked him.  He went away.  We waited another 5 minutes or so before we signaled to him across the room.  Finally he came over with the check and my friend's boyfriend said (very loudly) "Alright! The check!"  Sure, it was pretty obnoxious, but heck . . . we were genuinely thrilled to finally have the check . . . could we be blamed!?  So, here's the icing on the cake - the male server (remember the nice guy who was all alone down there and got us the table right away?), looks down and away from my friend's boyfriend with a face twisted with anger and mouths "Fuck you."  WTF????  

You know, I truly felt his pain and don't blame him for being at the end of his rope, but he needs to tell the managers/owners of this train wreck of a restaurant "fuck you," not us!!!  For the amount of money they charge for beer, I can't believe they can't afford more than one server for 10 tables, 8-9PM on a Saturday night!  

On our way out a group of young guys were apprehensively heading in.  We jokingly warned them to get ready to lay down some cash and advised them NOT to order any food.  During this exchange a guy came out of the restaurant, sarcastically yelled at us "yeah, thanks for your honesty," and appeared to go around the corner and into a side door.   Ummm. . . . so we're not supposed to tell other people about our negative experience!?  Sorry La Trappe, that comes with the territory.

In summary, without a doubt I would absolutely never go back to this place.  I don't know the real story, but La Trappe feels like it's run by a bunch of trust fund frat guys who came up with a great idea during a late night of beer pong and who know nothing about running a restaurant.  If you like (Belgian) beer, play it safe and go to the Toronado or Amnesia.
author: eileen d.

description: It's a shame its come to this, but I can never recommend anyone coming here, especially on the weekend. Instead of focusing on the beer its clear that they are trying too hard with the food. This could have been a great pub, but instead its a mediocre restaurant/cafe/bar. The Belgian beer selection is unbeatable but the service is unbearable and the clientele even worse...
author: Nicolas H.

description:
First of all, let me preface this by saying that this place is less than 2 blocks from my apartment, so proximity may add to a bit of bias.

One of my favorite parts about this place is the reaction I get whenever I bring a new person here. You walk into the restaurant and it looks like a boring, ugly coffee shop. There is usually no one at any of the tables and a few waiters running around in the kitchen. THEN...I point us towards the stairs and we walk down into the awesome Belgium Beer Cave!

The atmosphere is great downstairs, especially if it's a typical SF evening. There are no windows, and a low ceiling and a water feature by the stairs. I prefer to sit at the bar, as do most people so I would recommend getting there early if you want to get a seat. 

They have a bar menu with snacks for about $10. The mussels in beer sauce is fantastic and it comes with some yummy toasted bread on the side. 

Not only do they offer hundreds of beers, but they also have the matching glasses to go with every beer you order.

The food prices for dinner are a little high and although I've eaten here twice and enjoyed my food I prefer the bar. 

As a pre or post-dinner spot it is perfect. Romantic if you want it to be or just a great place to drink some good beer and catch up with an old friend.
author: Jackie G.

description:
From outside it looks dead, but that's because the restaurant portion has only about 5 tables.  Head inside and down the spiral staircase, and you'll be in a friendly, low-key pub.  

We had beer and dessert, both of which were excellent.  The beer menu is several pages long and contains Belgian and Belgian-style beers from around the world.  All beer was served in their respective glasses.  

All in all, a great experience.
author: K. B.

description:
Finally got to check this place out. As stated elsewhere, very confusing when you first come upon it. I was meeting a friend there around 5 but when he got there, sign said kitchen not open till 6. We went to the Rogue tasting room instead - cool place, marginal beer. Went back La Trappe, greeted upstairs by a room full of empty tables and a pleasant waitress who said "Sit anywhere" "Um, is there a bar?" "Sure downstairs!" Not only a bar but an awesome one at that complete with little chill lounge area.

We had frys to start and several rounds of beers then moved on to dinner. Burger, mini burgers and salads - very tasty, reasonably priced.  Everything was excellent, including the awesome belgium waffle for desert.

Overall, a fantastic experience and will return but we were perplexed by a couple of things. First, the layout. This place is kinda upside down with a small dinning room and kitchen when you walk in and a very cool restaurant, bar and lounge downstairs. I can't imagine anyone wanting to sit upstairs unless downstairs was packed. Just a dull, empty room with no atmosphere. Why were asked if we wanted to sit there? Why not make this room more inviting with a bar and set up more like a lounge area so you'd want to hangout there. Second, we saw a sign in the bar downstairs that said happy hour 3-6. That's strange, we thought they didn't open till 6! Turns out, that's just for dinner. Seems like a few small adjustments would yield more business. Of course then it would be even more crowded so maybe I shouldn't complain!
author: John B.

description: This past Saturday my hockey team celebrated a teammates 40th birthday.  The initial reason why we decided upon La Trappe was the beer selection.  But surprisingly the food was absolutely top notch.  Upon entering the restaurant we made our way down a spiral stair case to the basement bar and dining area.  The brick arches and water fountains gave this lower level an intimate speak easy type atmosphere.  It was both warm and inviting.  Once seated our servers were attentive, knowledgeable and prompt.  We each were recommended some draft beers that were to our individual liking and were given plenty of time to look over the menu.  I asked the server what he liked best.  I was told "Mussels, steak and burgers".  At first, that is pretty much all that I saw on the menu and that had me worried that the food was going to be poor quality red meat prepared by nuking with little attention to detail.  Was I wrong in a good way! The steaks were cooked perfectly and served rare/medium rare per order.  The burgers were perfectly seasoned and never robbed of moisture during the grilling process.  The fries that came with the burger and steaks were blanched and had the perfect color and crunch.  A friend I was with got an order of the mash potatoes with bacon and the consistency was perfect.  They were whipped but still held together well from the bacon fat.  In all, I strongly recommend La Trappe as a dinner and drinking spot.  My group did seem to miss the rush so I would recommend leaving time to wait for a table if you arrive during peak times.
author: Darin E.

description: Great atmosphere. Service is a bit slow (was on a Wednesday night), waitress could have used some assistance. Very large selection of Belgian beers, prices are higher than normal, but seemed to be in line with Belgian beer prices.
author: Zachary B.

description: This place is super sexy. Gotta try the beer and the muscles! I had the burger and it was not as great as i thought it was gunna be. But overall the service, seating, and surrounding was awesome! Btw, the water jug thing is soo cuuute!
author: Kim T.

description: I have lived in North Beach for four years now and when I tell people where I live they usually say one of two things, "do you always go to Mama's" or "you're so lucky that you live near La Trappe." And I was always embarrassed to say that I had never been to La Trappe, well as of last month, I can now proudly respond, "yeah, I love that place." I've now been three times and can't stop telling people about it. You feel like you are in Europe. One of my friends compares it to the underground bar in Inglorious Basterds, it's like that but better, you know without the Nazis and lots more seats. GREAT beers, I never realized how much I loved Belgium beers AND the moules frites are awesome.
author: Rose K.

description: Lots of fun!  Beers were great.  Mussels were superb. And big portion.  Also had the hotdog and a chicken dish in puff pastry, both were very good.  Ambiance was energetic, staff knowledgeable.
author: Steve C.

description:
I came here for dinner on a Saturday night for a girls' night out and loved it!
 
The restaurants has two stories where the upstairs' ambiance looks like your average restaurant with just a few tables but the downstairs has a totally different feel.  It's surrounded by break walls with dim lighting made up of a lounge and English pub type of ambiance.  Super cute!

We didn't have to wait long for a table but they did want our entire party to be present in order to seat us. Waiters were pretty nice and helpful w/the beer selection. When you sit down, they're pretty quick on starting you out with bread and water and bringing you the dinner, beer and wine menu.

The beer menu is awesome. It's a binder made up of a great selection of Trappist, Belgium, Italian and other types of beer.  I had one of the Trappist blondes since I've never had one before and found them rare here in the Bay Area and totally loved it. I wish I could buy a case of them.  My friend had one of their peach flavor ciders which I took a sip of and also totally loved.  Both of our drinks were served in their own special glass. 

Now to the food.  After reading other yelp reviews, I ordered the mussels and fries dinner which costs $16.50.  I was so amazed by the portion of this dinner.  The mussels came in a pot and there were so many of them.  The fries were also very tasty.  There were a selection of sauces also for this and my favorite was the wasabi mayo.  Yummmmm!

The only con side to this place is the noise level is a bit high.  Other than that, the bathroom was clean and food, ambiance + service were great.  I totally want to go back to explore the rest of their beer menu.
author: K L.

description:
Meeehhhhh

Beer selection good

No belgian fries

Food ranged from 1-3 stars depending on your entree and took a long time

place was packed

go for the beer, don't order food.  you will be very sorry.  especially don't order steak frite
author: Anthony L.

description: The place has a really cool vibe, plenty of praise and pretty reasonably priced. I got an endive salad and my friend got some fries and a bowl of soup. I didn't have enough to eat to judge, but I can definitely say it is a solid place to hang and have a beer (they have over 200 beers to choose from) with friends.
author: Blissful G.

description:
I like beer. It's easy to drink, it pairs well with lots of foods (that I eat at least) and it's fairly accessible wherever it's origin...aka Bev Mo, Trader Joe's, etc. With wine, I'll occasionally find myself shelling out a few bucks for a "decent" wine only to take a sip and wonder whether I'm actually tasting the "earth, currant, berry, with traces of oak". Having said that, La Trappe is perfect for guys like me...simply because all of the beer they serve is fantastic and I don't regret the $7 I paid for it. 

In line with many of the places I like, La Trappe comes off looking like a very ordinary restaurant but then there's more than meets the eye. Downstairs is where all the magic happens. You'll find a cozy dining area that plays audience to a centrally located bar. They can handle reasonably sized parties (around 6-7 to a table) but any larger than that and you'll be split up. 

Of all the food we ordered, the fries and mussels stood out. These days, fries are often an afterthought, filler if you will...not at La Trappe. They're served with a dipping sauce that simply rocks...each plate didn't last but for a few minutes at our table...and by the night's end, we'd had ordered 4 or 5. Thinly sliced, with potato flavor that stands up to the light frying, it sounds trivial, but they're damn good fries! Their mussels come in a big bucket you could wear as a helmet...'nuff said! 

Last but not least is the beer...they have a HUGE selection of Belgian beer and if you don't know where to begin, just ask your server. Our server for the evening was very friendly and gave some excellent recommendations. While friendly and helpful, he was only 1 of 2 servers for the night, which meant we were waiting awhile between orders. Overall, the food was good, the beers awesome, and the vibe awesome. Try to make reservations ahead of time because the place gets packed on Fridays and Saturdays.
author: Eric N.

description:
We went to La Trappe on a Thursday night after wanting to go here for many weeks.  We were meeting friends and upon arriving and entering the restaurant we were a little leery...there was NO ONE in the place (or so we thought).  One of the wait staff told us to head downstairs; and what a surprise!  A nice, cozy, dark, intimate, stone walled oasis filled with other diners.  Totally different from the empty, stark interior upstairs.  (I can see foot traffic being turned off by what seems like an empty restaurant so I hope it gets the business it needs to stick around.)  We sat at a nice big wooden booth that would be great for a party as large as 6 and had a great time.  Here's a quick run down:

Pros-
-Cozy atmosphere makes you want to stay and drink a LOT!
-Nice large booths, good for a group up to 6
-Yummy Beers hard to find elsewhere
-Bucket of muscles that could feed a small army, wish I would have shared!  And they were great too with the fries!

Cons-
-Wait staff a little slow
-Cheese plate appetizer a bad choice
-Empty upstairs, weird entry
-A bit pricey

This would be a fun place to share some food and sample a lot of good beers with a group of friends.
author: Karie V.

description: I love this place!! Everything from their selection of beer to the entire atmosphere is amazing. I would go there everyday if I could afford it :)
author: Camille R.

description: Don't be afraid to walk through the restaurant upstairs towards the back corner to the staircase that leads you downstairs.  It's like a whole different world!  Great selection of beer and it doesn't feel snooty!
author: fancy-schmancy S.

description: Love this place.  Always solid food and a good place to go with friends.  I love the mussels in particular.  The beer selection is alot of fun and they always have something good on draft.  The bartenders are also very knowledgeable without making you feel stupid for not knowing much about Belgian beers.  Only downfall is they don't take reservations, so the wait could be a long time on a popular night.
author: Lauren S.

description:
Best Belgium beer place that I've been to in the city! They have so many choices it's a little overwhelming when you first come here, but the bartenders are super helpful and know their beer. They can help suggest a beer for you and chances are its delicious and strong!

I've also eaten here three times and always get the Belgium chicken stew which is very good. Its perfect for a cold San Francisco night.
author: Laura W.

description: Best beer selection in town and great options for pub food.
author: Michael M.

description: Unfortunately a bad combination of poor service (we had to wait 90 min), mediocre food and expensive drinks. Disappointingly yours, T
author: Tanguy P.

description:
We stopped by La Trappe for a beer tonight when we saw a sign that it was finally open. My husband was hoping to find Leffe on tap and low and behold... there it was. They had Chimay, Leffe, Alfigen, Hoegaarden and about 15 other beers on tap. Plus, they had pages and pages of beers on a menu that you could order. It was very, very impressive. The bartender, John explained to us that yesterday 12/21 was their first day opening to the public. The ambience was great, the bartender offered us several different beers to taste and we had a really enjoyable time. This bar is only a few blocks away, so, we are really excited. I've been searching for a place to have good Belgian beer. I don't think any place in San Francisco compares to the selection at La Trappe.

We had 2 glasses of Leffe, and Affligen and an order of Frites ($5) for a total of $22. I think that is a pretty good deal seeing as most places will sell you a glass of Chimay for about $7.  We did not have dinner here yet, but, we will be returning in the next week or so.

If you love Belgian beer, this is worth the trip. They are open to the public now... really!
author: Joan L.

description:
Update:

Came here last weekend.  

Beer - still good

Service - not so good.  Sat there with menu's and some empty glasses for about 15 minutes.  Finally, we flagged a waitress and said we were ready.  She was like, oh, no one has waited on you.  Takes forever to get a beer. 
 
Food - Burger was good.  Fries were good.  Moules a la Biere was good.  Steak, eh.  Gnocchi, YUCK!  Undercooked pieces of raw dough.  We first thought, maybe there was some type of cheesy filling.  But not really.  

Overall, it seems like many of the employees are in constant motion, but not getting too much accomplished.  The bussers are very efficient, though.

************************

My husband made reservations for us on Valentine's Day.  I greatly dislike going out on Valentine's Day, as you're usually surrounded by starry-eyed couples who make me want to throw-up.  We're not old, but the last time we dined out on Valentine's Day was in 2000, when we just started started dating.  So, I was very apprehensive about going out.  

My husband chose this place, as I LOVE french fries and Belgian beer.  Unfortunately, even through he called in the reservation on Monday, no one mentioned to him that the regular menu would not be available.  Luckily, we found this out on Wednesday when I went to peruse the menu and saw only the set-price four course dinner was the only option available for $60/person.  So, we were not taken-aback when we were seated on Thursday (as some other couples obviously were).

When the hostess gave us the menus, she said for $20 more, one could get the suggested beer pairings with each course.   My husband said, so like, 4-6 ounce tastings, and she confirmed yes.  

For the appetizer, we ordered the moules a la biere and the artisanal cheese plate.  Both were huge servings and extremely tasty.  When we received our beer, we were surprised that the specialty glasses were full.  Having not quite finished the complementary glass of prosecco and realizing that we'd be getting four beers each, I said this is going to be a long night.  

Long story short, the experience at La Trappe was wonderful.  Great beer: an extensive list of Belgian and Belgian style beers from around the world (though they are missing the Corsendonk Brown); and great food: huge servings, excellent flavors (we had, in addition to the above-mentioned appetizers, Cream of Ginger Carrot Soup, Harvest Salad with Roquefort toast, the filet with potatoes au gratin and green beans, Ricotta and Spinach Ravioloni, and for dessert, the Chocolate Ganache and Creme Brulee).  

The service in my opinion was good.   Perhaps it was because we were experiencing a differently paced meal.  But our server was friendly and the busser always kept our water glasses full and cleared our plates.  

The atmosphere was nice.  It seemed a little off the beaten path of North Beach establishments, so it looked pretty free of touristy type people.  All the tap handles for the different Belgians certainly doesn't detract :-)

We will definitely be returning.  Hopefully so I can sample some of the frites.  But the extensive list of Belgian beers is enough to draw us back.
author: Jory R.

description:
Great beer selection in a cool downstairs bar.

We got there for happy hour on Friday after work, there were a few empty tables, so we just ducked into them. Apparently they are for people eating, which kinda sucks. But we went to the bar, and ordered a few more beers.

The half litre Hacker for $6 is pretty damn good. The other selections are amazing, well worth a trip. Saw this reviewed in 7x7 and it really lived up to expectations. If they can open up the tables for drinkers and stop being such snobs, this could be a favorite.
author: Joseph T.

description:
I had heard great things about this place, but the first time I went there to meet up with people it looked like a dud, so I left... It wasn't until my next trip that I realized that there was a downstairs portion, which is where all the action was... 
Great place to go for drinks... very extensive beer selection... the food is okay... but not great... 
however, where the food lacks, the beer selection makes  up the difference... worth the trip
author: Andrew K.

description: Very large and amazing beer selection, both on tap and bottle.  (So many amazing Belgian beers.)  The beer menu is large, detailed, descriptive, and very useful. Food menu is small, but everything is delicious. Downstairs ambiance is very cool.
author: Joe R.

description:
This place is amazing. (It's in the basement!) With the beers being nothing less then amazing, and the food is great. It's great to find a place in the US where the Belgium beers are on draft. Fantastic. 

I will definitely come back, next time I'm in the city.
author: John J.

description:
Bear is really excellent, lot's of choice.
Food is ok.
casual
author: armelle p.

description: I went here for happy hour last Friday.  The bartenders know their stuff!  I told the guy that I was a fan of Russian River Brewing's Temptation (which they have in bottle), and he suggested a Gueuze Grand Cru Cuvée René which was excellent.  They were then able to recommend 3 or 4 different Belgian beers which were also outstanding.  Wasn't too crowded or expensive.  The moule were very good.  Cute downstairs room!
author: brandon c.

description:
5 stars all the way for my new favorite place ever aka La Trappe, 

seriously.

the food is great, the beers are to die for and every single person who works here is rad.

if i didnt have to worry about paying my rent i would be here every waking hour.

Thanks mike, mike, mike and michael!!!
author: Britney K.

description: If I lived through prohibition, I think this would definitely fit the bill.  Its dark basement tavern-esq seating is super chic and cool.  It's such a neat place to get a drink and even in the break of day, time doesn't seem to exist. The crowds don't seem to hijack the place until after 7pm and by then we were already heading to our next spot.  Although we only went for drinks, our server was super awesome and attentive.  This really is any beer lovers dream.
author: Tamz O.

description: Went here tonight. Got there at 6 and it was empty. It took 30 minutes for the waiter to take our order and it was 90minutes before the food came out. Beer was mediocre, food was okay. One person in our group thought the mussels were amazing, but burgers were dry/tasteless and stew was okay. After several complaints about wait/etc they did remove the mandatory 18% tip, but we ended up tipping about that anyways. Basically, I would not return here or recommend.
author: Rachel B.

description:
One of Northbeach's best spots!  I reluctantly walked in this place to get a beer on some random night.  I was suprices by the atmosphere and the beer.  They have an extensive beer list with some very rare beers.  I have developed a taste for belgium beers and they have a ton.  If you get a chance to talk to the owner do it, He is a chill dude and knows everything about belgian beers and exactly what flovors are in them.  
The service here was great and the food was simple but perfect.  I love that kind.  I had the steak and frittes and it was one of the best steaks I have had in a long time.  I have gone back there to start a weekend off and this is perfect for that.  Try beers that you never knew existed.  A small place perfect for a date (make sure she drinks beer).
author: Pete L.

description: A fan of frites and Belgian beers alike, I was totes pleased by La Trappe. We sat downstairs: the atmosphere was cozy, though it was a bit loud (at one point, I thought the waitress mistakenly thought that I wanted yet another order of fries). The fries were excellent - medium-width and golden - though the sauces we ordered were only OK. (The spicy ketchup was awesome, but the red pepper aioli was bland.) I had the vegetarian platter, which included grilled veggies with a side of polenta and blood orange reduction. The reduction was easily the best part of this dish - I scooped all of it up! My boyfriend's mussels were also evidently tasty, though I'm not one for seafood. I'll be back soon to sample more from the ueberextensive beer list!
author: Kate G.

description:
I had high hopes for La Trappe, and to be honest, it just didn't measure up to my expectations.

La Trappe has what looks like a nice, street-level restaurant, but when we went in, the cooks directed us to the bar in the basement.  This seemed strange, since the bar was very loud and rather casual, and it seems it would make sense to offer diners the option of eating in the more romantic and peaceful restaurant if that is their preference.

Once seated, we ordered beers.  I like beer more than most people like anything, and La Trappe definitely deserves recognition for their extensive, varied, and detailed menu of Belgian and Belgian-style beers on tap.  I tried three, and while I didn't find any of them to be phenomenal, sometimes that's just the way it goes when you're trying new beers.

La Trappe has a mouth-watering menu of European-inspired cuisine.  I'm always looking for bars with a great list of draft beer, and decent food, so any beer bar that goes beyond wings, sliders, and nachos earns points with me.  We awaited our mussels, steak, and chicken stew with great anticipation, and unfortunately were generally disappointed in all of it.  The mussels did not taste very fresh, and the beer and cheese preparation was not very good.  Both the steak and the chicken stew were bland, and while the steak was enjoyable once I tossed some salt on it, the chicken stew really had no redeeming qualities.  The fries, which so many people had raved about, tasted rather ordinary, but the Belgian and chipotle mayonnaises were quite tasty.

Overall, I appreciate La Trappe's effort to be a beer bar with real food, but I do not think i would choose to eat here again.
author: Megan S.

description: it's cute and good beer selection but service and food terrible.  Took over 2 hours to get our food and it wasn't good!  Ridiculous.
author: Briana B.

description: If you're in the mood for some good beer, this is the place to go.  They have a huge selection and the downstairs bar is superb.  You feel like you're transported to Europe by going down a set of stairs.  No hard liquor in this place though.
author: Lidiya B.

description: I love this place. There is lots of history here as the basement it's located in used to be a speakeasy back in the 20's.  The servers are really cool and they have an awesome Trappist beer selection. Just tell them what flavor/type your looking for and enjoy!
author: Markl F.

description: Loved this place!!!  Super friendly staff and great bar/seating area downstairs.  Nice list of beers and the mussels and fries are fantastic!  Choosing from all the dipping sauces was great.  This was a great break from walking the city all day and one of the highlights of they many bars we visited along the way.
author: Catie B.

description:
Update:  
Finally ate here, had the burger and the mussels.  Burger was thick but no flavor.  Mussels and fries were OK but I've had better.  Lesson learned:  I'd only go to La Trappe for the beers for now.  Still 5 stars though.

----
If you like Belgian beer, this is your place.  The selection is unbelievable.  They have about 10-12 beers on tap and a huge menu of bottles.  The bartender (John) was extremely nice and very knowledgeable about the beers.  We didn't try the food.  The bar is located downstairs and the atmosphere was fun and lively even on a Sunday night.  It has a slight speakeasy feel to it which was cool.
author: Ben K.

description:
I might only like this place because its a block from my apartment, not super touristy and I'm a sucker for cool glasses and beer... 

But i like this place. A lot.

I like the spiral staircase down to the cellar bar.  The seating is plentiful and comfortable. The bartenders are quick -- and not scared to tell you want you want.

Which is nice since they have WAY to many beers... and making decisions isn't my forte.
author: Becca S.

description:
Een bier, alstublieft!  (Or maybe more than one, actually.  Many more.)

To my tastes, the pinnacle of affordable SF dining.

An excellent cross section of mostly Belgian beers, many of which are on draft.  All served in the right glassware and at the correct respective temperature. I know beer, and I can tell you that these guys do, too.  

The food, however, is not to be outdone.  Fresh ingredients, both bright and subtle flavors in near-perfect balance, and exquisitely prepared.  They have something on the menu that pairs well with just about every type of brew on the list.  I only wish they would specifically call out beer pairings on the menu; I'd like to compare my own opinions with theirs.

If you're willing to sit upstairs, there's almost always an immediately available table.  A trip to the basement requires a lot more planning, and the waits can be substantial.  However, their service is not lacking in the slightest.

I'm not one for lavishing superlatives in general, but La Trappe deserves them.
author: Susuk L.

description: This is a fabulous place to dine and or go out for drinks! The main dining area is where you walk in. If you head down the spiral staircase you will enter the bar area that is like a beer cellar. You can sit at the bar or tables and order food or there is also a lounge area in the back with leather couches. This place is very relaxing and fun to have a low key night. They have a variety of Belgium beer on tap! The only down fall of this wonderful place is the close at midnight.
author: Connie P.

description: Absolutely horrible.  This is the third time I've been to Le Trappe and each successive trip is worse than the last.  Tonight we sat and waited for a table for 40 minutes, only to be told once we finally sat down that the restaurant had enough mussels left for one order.  The mussels are one of four or five entrees on the menu and quite honestly the only reason to dine here in the first place.  Well, we've already waited 40 minutes, it's too late to leave and go wait to sit somewhere else, so we decide to stay.  We order a few beers, which arrive a good 10 minutes after our mussels get there and it turns out that the last order of mussels is actually only a half order.  Oops.  We order our dinners.  Three steaks, all medium rare and one hamburger, well done.  The waiter informs the hamburger orderer that the well done burgers tend to have the consistency of a hockey puck and strongly suggests going medium well, to which the orderer agrees.  The food comes and of course the hamburger is medium rare, nowhere even close to medium well.  It gets sent back and doesn't return for a good 15 minutes.  The steaks are absolutely without flavor and mine appears to maybe have taken a brief look at the grill, but moos at me when I cut into it for the first bite.  Medium rare steak is not purple in the middle and does not require you to chew it for 5 minutes in order to swallow a bite.  All these screwups and they still have the nerve to charge an extra $1.50 for the cheese on the undercooked burger.  All the aforementioned issues are mentioned to the manager and his only response is to say that they fixed the burger and to question why I "finished my meal" if the steak was underdone.  I took three bites of it.  The manager refuses to do anything with our bill and says that it's ok when we inform him that we will not be back.  To have the manager activities  extremely rude after everything that already happened was just adding insult to injury.  Dine at your own risk.  They're completely understaffed and obviously ill equipped to deal with guests when an issue (or several) arise.  Maybe you'll have a better experience, but you couldn't pay me enough to go back.
author: Nate J.

description: From the looks of it, it seems as if this place is just a small cafe with a few tables... but then you start to head down a staircase and it starts getting louder - and there is a crackin bar downstairs. I had the Affligem Blond- enjoyed so much had I had it twice. Get there early if you are trying to sit in the small bar area for a few beers. I didn't get a chance to try the Belgian fare, next time fo show.
author: Tara M.

description:
5 stars for beer.
3 stars for food.

if it's crowded it may take a while for a seat and service. But a grab an awesome beer and hang out. Nice people. Beer menu trumps the food menu.
author: B B.

description: La Trappe, as advertised, indeed offers a large selection of Belgian beer, well known for being the world's tastiest, if categorized by country.  Of course, they also serve these beers in their appropriate, unique glasses (Belgian beer is as snobby as it is delicious).  But, La Trappe is pricey, and frankly, a bad bar to chill at.  I haven't eaten there (and gotten an exclusive space at a table), so perhaps that's my mistake, but the architecture at the tiny bar in the basement really makes it difficult to stand and hang out, especially with a handful-sized goonsquad.  Go here for a cozy date, maybe, but if you're just fixin' to get drunk, come to La Trappe first, ingest one or two tasty, high ABV-% Belgian beers, and then move elsewhere.
author: Alan R.

description: Great food and beer! It's a long wait but it's worth it. Love the atmosphere and how laid back the place is.
author: Do L.

description:
as good as it gets...  what's not to like honestly.  40 pages of beer goodness and some beers that make non-beer drinks cheer in glee (peach lambic, i'm looking at you).

the bartenders (and some patrons) are very knowledgeable and pick the right beer for you just by hearing what you typically like and i haven't been let down anytime yet.

the ambiance is pretty cool and the lounge area near the back is a good spot to chill w/ friends.  i look forward to many years of traversing the beer menu.
author: Swarup B.

description: one of my favorite little spots to come get a drink with friends...yes even a non beer drinker has a chance to pick from a very nice selection of wine! Nothing like a good glass and sitting in the corner of the lounge..or what i refer to as the cave (in the back). its dark and cool, great couches, fun lamps and decor. def a fave spot.
author: Farrah S.

description:
We went for drinks on a Friday afternoon and although it wasn't still happy hour really, it wasn't quite the dinner hour either.  There were about 8 of us and the basement is a little tight when it comes to common areas for drinking/socializing.  We had wanted to have some drinks and appetizers, but there was no place really to sit in the "lounge".  We had asked if we could grab a table, but were told no because they were reserved for the dinner guest. 

There were two sets of dinner guests in the place with 10 tables.  Because it was an uncomfortable arrangement for us, we decided to take our business elsewhere.

From my standpoint, it wasn't the dinner hour and we had 8 people who would have had a minimum of two drinks and appetizers.  That is probably more than a 2-4 person group would have spent on a one entree dinner. So they turned away 8 guests and didn't make any money off of us, because they wouldn't accommodate us for seating.

I guess these days, you shouldn't probably turn away 8 people, just because you don't want them to take one of your dinner tables for people that aren't even IN the restaurant.
author: Audrey W.

description:
Finally had my first visit.  Great selection with very reasonable prices on the beer.  Staff had good knowledge.  Will make me venture to north beach more often!

Revision: After visditing a handful of times over the last year or so, Ive decided this:  Great Beer, Great Food, Great service, and the owner is a total jerk to everybody.  Guess thats why its only been a handful...
author: scott t.

description:
A true Trappe that is a insult to Belgian food, but, I have to admit, has a great beer selection.  Go for the beers and NOT NOT NOT NOT NOT for the food.

We got there last night, a group of 5, including 3 Belgians.  Nice place looking a little like home, beside the paintings hanging on the wall that were out of place.  then we saw the beer menu and the menu.  It started well.  Got a great beer.

But then the food came in and that's when all fell apart. The soup and salad were just served than the second dish was thrown on the table at the same time!  It this an error?  Actually, that was the start. The mossels were the worst thing I ever tasted, and I am Belgian and have eaten it hundred of times.  The fries were just OK, but definitely not belgian cooked.  The rabbit was horrible. The Portobello mushroom were OK.  The steak was OK, beside one guest had asked for medium-well cooked and he got a medium-rare.  Oh, did I say that the mossels were absolutely horrible...yes, HORRIBLE.

Then the bill came in.  They remove the cost of the steak that was not cooked properly.  Gor the bill for $85.  Then the waitress came back with another bill of $130, overcharging one of the beers by $2.  We did not complain and just wanted to get out that trappe, disgusted.

Bad service; very bad food; great beers.  So good as a bar, and a horrible mistake to try to cook anything.

My recommendation: if you want good mossels, go to Frjtz on Valencia St.  Don't waste any penny in this Trappe.
author: Pierre S.

description:
I had been hearing about La Trappe for several months now, especially from Phil H. who was a huge fan.  I myself have never been much of a beer connoisseur, but I liked Stella and that was Belgian, right?! ;-)

We walked in and the upstairs was practically empty...I wondered where everyone was...it was a Friday night after all.  Had this place lost it's shininess after only a few months?  Non, non, non!  The people were below!  We were directed to go downstairs where I was told that this was a traditional Belgian Beer "Cave"...who knew that they had beer caves?  I was under the impression that the only things made or grown in caves were wine, mushrooms or bats!  But apparently the Belgians have their own way of doing things.  

We walk up to the crowded bar to grab a menu and the waitress hands us this five pound tome of beers.  How do you choose a beer when you have 35 pages of choices?!  Luckily Andrei Z. was there to help Gene X. and I out as it was our maiden voyage at La Trappe.  He made great suggestions based on what we liked.  We sat down in their lounge area since we weren't there to eat.  It's a comfortable open space of cushioned benches....it's quite dark down there and even I was struggling to read the menu in the light....however I didn't do what the 50ish year old gentleman across from me did...he used the candle to read the menu.  Youthful eyesight prevails!  Speaking of youthful, I got carded both times I went up to the bar.  Yes, they were different bartenders but still....I was flattered the first time, annoyed the second time.  Do they really get that many under age drinkers in that place?!  Somehow I doubt it.

Overall I think this is a great location, great idea and they've managed to do it quite well.  The beers are on the pricier side though, so don't expect to go in for some sort of happy hour.  I think the majority of beers are in the $8-12 range and if you're buying a large bottle they can be in the $22-34 range.  That being said, if you're a fan of good Belgian beer, you're probably okay with spending that kind of money.
author: Melanie N.

description: I love this place. They have a great selection of beers from all over the world, and awesome employee's. This is a place I always recommend people to swing by and drink a 750ml bottle of Gueuze.
author: Andrew H.

description: They are never effing open!  I have wasted too much of my life trekking to North Beach to find out they are closed for some secret reason.  Never again.
author: Susan A.

description: Mike the bartender is great. He will guide you to the perfect beer and will provide a sample before you commit. I love dark cave-like atmosphere. It sets the tone for a laid back place to enjoy some Belgium beers. There are lots of options. In fact, for you non-beer drinkers I am telling you there is now hope. The Raspberry Lambic is the drink of choice for my friend who can't stand beer. We also ordered the fritz with all sorts of dipping sauces... delicious! This is a must go to bar in North Beach.
author: Jen B.

description: Oh, how I love you Quadruple.  You're not so bad either, Triple.  So much flavor I can't even describe!  I was not much of a beer drinker before I moved to the city, but after being introduced to the Trappist wonders at this place, I not only drink beer, I LOVE it.  Monks, if this is what life is like for you every day, sign me up.
author: angela t.

description: No this is not the location of Rommy's vagina.  It's a small restaurant/lounge/bar that has an amazing list of Belgian brew.  Don't make the mistake of thinking that Chimay Blue is only $4 for a 24 ounce bottle like one person in our group though.  You are looking at the table of contents and Chimay Blue is listed on page 4 at $18.  Still a good deal for a bottle of beer that will have you swerved with a quickness.
author: Luis M.

description: Seriously?  Mussels, Belgian fries, and Belgian beer all in one place?  Add in the great ambiance downstairs and this place is a winner.  The beer selection was unbelievable and the food was delicious.
author: Josh G.

description: I went to this establishment for a friend's birthday party a few weeks ago and I am happy to report that this is my new favorite SF restaurant. This place has it all - an underground bar & lounge, reasonable prices, and the book of beers that they carry is thicker than a Harry Potter Book. Everything here was amazing, from the service to the signature mussels. I would highly recommend this location for anyone that is interested in trying some great beer, and dining in a location that is uniquely San Francisco.
author: Michael H.

description:
*                                       (===)
                                           !     !
                                           !     !
                                     (                )
                                      !               !
                                      !               !
                                      !  BEER  !
                                      !               !
                                      !               !
                                     !_______ !

                    132 Varieties of Belgian Beers
                       (Soon to be 200 varieties)

70 North Beach Neighbors decided to welcome the new owners of La Trappe by throwing their year end Holiday Party at La Trappe.  My guests and I sat with a board member, Jeri B.  Our dinner was set for 7:00 pm.  The appetizers  were ceviche (calamari, veggies resting on an endive leaf) and Fresh shucked oysters.  It was a long stretch between the salad or soup (minestrone) to the main entree.  As noted in previous reviews, probably due to new opening jitters.  The salad was excellent (spinach, radicchio, walnuts, and apples (thinly sliced).  They were great at making sure we were well stocked with water, drinks of our choice, and bread (baskets and more baskets).  My guests and I had their very tender pork chops (steak size) cooked in Belgian Beer!  Jeri B. had the Monk Fish.  The people on the next table had the impressive Belgian mussels and frittes.  They gave me a sample of their mussels.  Huge pots - about 3 dozens!  I spied the one half of roasted chicken, risotto, and gnocchi.  We came away happy and content.  We were given the choice of cheese cake or chocolate tart ( we had the latter).  I am not much of a dessert freak so from the looks of one of my guests, he inhaled the chocolate tart.  

I was amazed that they had only two wait staff and 3 bus boys for 70 people.  The music they "channeled" was inconsistent  and hopefully they will have better selections.  

My family used to dine quite frequently when it was Bucco Giovanni, so I was impressed with the newly renovated interior on the top floors (kitchen, seating for 8) and the stairways down to the main dining area which still had the original brick facade (similar to Cafe du Nord), and the rest rooms are totally well designed.

My guest and I decided to give La Trappe some time before returning soon, but we will definitely put our chops on the mussels and Belgian Fries.  

The Signature Entrees are excellent.  Give this establishment a few months to work out the kinks and they are off and running.
author: Marian G.

description:
I expect these four stars to grow to five upon future visits to this lovely, lovely place. I would give them five stars out of the gate, but even opening-night jitters cannot explain the disappearance of our waitress for nearly an hour, while we sat with an empty, yet formerly delicious, cheese plate and utterly beerless. When we did see her, it was to hear that yet another beer we ordered could not be located or had not arrived in their stock yet. All of this would have been entirely forgivable had she not abandoned us without so much as a panicked smile and a "I haven't forgotten you, it's just my hair's on fire" look. But as sweet and lovely as she was when she did materialize, her frequent and prolonged absences were frustrating. 

That's the bad news. Everything else was fabulous. The basement dining room and bar area was beautiful and transportive--you felt like you really were quaffing fine ales in the basement of a monastery in a tiny town in Belgium. The beer list is truly phenomenal. Even my brewmaster, beer geek boyfriend was struck speechless by its breadth and length--and the shear number of beers never before (or rarely) seen on these shores. The food menu was an exercise in enticing simplicity. We only sampled the amazing cheese and pate platter, but I will eagerly return for a more complete meal. 

And once we moved our tab to the bar, everything was wonderful. The bartender, clearly overwrought, but thrilled with the beer and the business, was attentive and friendly and funny. The crowd was very local, which was refreshing for a Saturday night in North Beach. 

I anticipate many lovely hours spent in this very welcome and welcoming place.
author: Sage R.

description: First time here last night.  Friends and I were having dinner before the show at Bimbos.  Service was really good and I loved that they give you a menu "book" for their beers along with their food menu.  We ordered the toast, twice fried fries, beet salad, stewed rabbit, asparagus and had the small cheese plate and belgian waffle for dessert.  Everything was great except for the toast.  I found it flavorless...but everything else was really scrumptious.  I would eat here again and try the other things on their menu.
author: Elena F.

description: La trappe has curry ketsup.  Thank youuuuuu.  I don't have to carry around hela curry ketsup.
author: Wakako U.

description:
I am definitely a fan of La Trappe, and would come back for another round. This was my choice when The Boy came up to SF for a dinner date. He just wanted something laid-back with tasty food. I knew that he liked beer, and wanted some place quiet-ish for us to relax and chat while we ate dinner as well. La Trappe has over 200 different types of bottled beer, and about 30 on tap. They do serve wine as well, but that seems rather, well...stupid. 

We walked in, and noticed about six tables upstairs, and asked if we could go and seat ourselves downstairs. You walk down, and are in this cozy warm lit space that has a bar, several tables set up, and a back space that was being used for what looked like a little party going on. We decided to sit at the bar, as there were 2 seats next to each other on the end, and it was obvious that no tables were going to free up anytime soon in the larger space. We were almost snuggled up right under the stairs, and we were quickly handed the beer book and their 1 page menu after being greeted by one of the beermen. I was totally overwhelmed by the list, and The Boy seemed pretty impressed as well. 
I actually managed to wade through a bit of the beer book and select something, and we ordered the sliders as a starter. My suggestion? Get the sliders. You can thank me later.

The beer man that helped us was so wonderful at giving us some of his time (as it quickly became PACKED within 15 minutes of us sitting down) in explaining the different kinds of beer, why they cleaned certain glasses and not others, and the types of glassware that they used at the bar. He did check in with us from time to time, but not so often that we felt smothered. I ordered the mussels and frites, and The Boy ordered the black cod. My food came pretty quickly, and as we sat and waited for his food (and nibbled at my fries), they realized that the fish order hadn't gone in, and quickly put it in with their apologies. No worries, we said, and they got that order down to us in lightening time. We ordered 2 more beers at this point, and the one The Boy picked the beerman said had a very distinct, almost sour taste, and let him taste it (since it was on tap), and let him choose something else to finish off his meal with. 

While obviously, this place is about the Beer, the food is certainly not to be missed. My mussels (which I ordered in the Mariniere style), were of a generous portion, and the fries were hot and crisp and consistant in size and style. They were also well seasoned - where they were not too salty, nor did they need any additional work should you so desire to eat them plain. They also come with 2 of their dips. The Black Cod (which is now off the menu, sucks to be you) was served with some potatoes and veggies, and was cooked pretty much to perfection; I remember it being moist and fresh seafood flavorful. It really was high end pub style food. 

While it did get busy, it never seemed like I was shouting at The Boy  in order to have a conversation with him, though we did have to cozy up to each other at the bar to let other people get in and order. When we asked for the bill, our beerman has comped one of our rounds of beer since we had to wait for the fish (which was almost the price of the dish anyways). They quickly processed our order, and we got out the door for a very reasonable dinner about for the amount of food and drink we consumed. 

Keep in mind that the beer here is not cheap - you won't be getting any $5 PBR. Be nice, be patient, and enjoy. I am excited to bring people back.
author: Jessica S.

description:
Came here based on the recommendation of a tenant who lives above me. After reading some of the reviews about shoddy, unwelcoming service, I was reluctant to give LA Trappe a shot. However, my partner and I were desperate for a good burger and beer and inevitably said 'what the hell.'  
I couldn't be happier that we decided to stop in for a few. The basement is insane, and that's a good thing. The feel of the downstairs dining room is somewhere in between a wine cellar and an old European gastropub. The real highlight, though, is the Beer Bible. The list of beers, both bottle and draught, is so lengthy the Bible requires a table of contents. And if you're feeling overwhelmed, no need to fear, the attentive servers are extremely knowledgeable and will undoubtedly steer you in the right direction. I started with a Gentse Triple and then moved on to Malheur Stout (recommended by our excellent server). If you're looking for a wonderful, affordable place to kick back, enjoy the ambience, and drink some of the finest beer in SF, you need to come here.
author: Bruce S.

description: Amazing beer list specializing in Belgium and Belgium Style beer
author: Albert C.

description: Beans.  Adam Carrolla.  La Trappe.  What do these things have in common?  I hated them all without giving them a fair chance.  Now, I like them.  La Trappe was closed the first TWO times I tried to go there despite advertising that they would be open.  That's why I hated them.  Finally, I have been able to go twice in the past month.  Food is a step up from bar fare - mussels and frites are the way to go!  The beer selection is unbelievable and they did a good job of making the basement feel like a tavern.  Table service could be improved and I am still stinging from getting shut out so that's why I can't go for five stars.
author: T-Bone L.

description:
don't let the first impression fool you.
what looked like a quiet casual space upstairs was just a cover for a hopping time downstairs.

a pretty iron spiral staircase leads you to an underground bar.
exposed brick walls with arched entries house the main bar and eating area.
a separate vip area is complete with a two way mirror.  so people beware of checking your teeth while waiting in the hall outside the bathroom.

the wine selection was average at best but i got to sample some very interesting italian and belgian beers.

the two partners "mike and mike" took a once run down restaurant and made something really unique.
one mike is quiet and sweet while the other mike is always chatting and laughing as they serve you.

i had the moules frites - aka mussels and fries.  you get two dipping sauces to choose from.
the original belgian mayo was solid but the wasabi mayo had a really nice kick.

overall, a good experience.  the two m&m's make you feel at home even to a first timer.
author: Anh V.

description:
This place is NOT good for large groups.

First of all, no reservations.  I showed up an hour before our group of 15 was set to arrive to see if anything can be arranged.  They could care less, told me they'll deal with it when everyone has arrived.  When everyone showed up the place was packed.  Took 90 minutes to seat 10, the remaining five just stayed in the lounge the rest of the night.

Oh, and the service.  No menus were ever presented to a single person.  Guests had to walk around and try to find menus.  No service in the lounge, 10-15 minute wait to get a beer at the bar.  When we finally sat down, took another 45 minutes for the food to arrive.  The attitude of the staff made it very clear they felt they would have been better off if we did not come.

Of course the beer is great.  And I do like the space.  Food is OK, nothing special.  But I would not recommend this place at all.  There are tons of other places in SF where the staff enjoy their work and don't treat customers like numbers.
author: Gregory K.

description: La Trappe is definitely worth 5 stars and the honor of being my 100th review. The underground Trappist Lounge is superbly cozy, very peaceful thanks to the fountain, and has incredibly nice staff. I have no idea how many Belgian beers they have, both on tap and bottled, but the beer menu is pretty thick! There's everything from light witbiers to dark brews weighing in at over 12% alcohol. Can't say I've tried their food yet, but as a place to unwind with a good Belgian beer, La Trappe can't be beat.
author: Will A.

description:
Dear Owner of La Trappe- Please, please, please start being open on Sunday and Monday nights!  I love your underground cozy bar area and amazing beers.  It feels like every Monday and Sunday we are in the mood for La Trappe-but you're closed!  I love burger on the sweet brioche bun.  The fries are super crispy and delicious.  

It can get busy and service can be mixed.

PLEASE STAY OPEN ON MONDAYS AND SUNDAYS.
author: Stacy P.

description: Cool as $h!t...looks like nothing special from the street.  Go inside and downstairs and be prepared to be wowed.  It is a bit noisy down there...just saying.
author: Shawn H.

description:
12/01/2007: For the sake of a completely upfront review: My fiance's family is friends with the family of one of the owners (Mike) of this new restaurant/bar.  That said, I do not believe that their friendship prevents me from being able to review this place  honestly.  I have only met Mike a few times, all as he was working on turning this space from the old shell of Buca Giovanni into what is now La Trappe.  As you can see from my numbers, I have been doing some serious Yelping and this is not one of those reviews from someone's Mom/aunt/best friend who just created an account to review their new place. Now on to my review. . .

After many months of waiting, we were very excited to finally check out La Trappe on their opening night.  Having seen the space when it was completely gutted and totally under construction, I can say that it has come a long way!  It is absolutely beautiful inside.  The upstairs is a warm, inviting dining area with terracotta colored walls.  On such a cold night, it was a very comforting color choice!  A very sturdy wrought iron staircase leads downstairs to the bar area, where there is also additional seating for drinking/dining.  WOW.  The downstairs area is cool.  We actually sat upstairs on this visit and then cruised downstairs to check it out. OH MY GOD.  The back corner is like a fabulous little drinking cave.  Now I know when you hear cave, you think BATS or OSAMA BIN LADEN, but I am telling you - this is so freaking cool.  Next time we are totally cozying up in the cave.  Trust me, check out both the upstairs and the downstairs before deciding where you want to settle down.  The downstairs was definitely louder, but you have got to see it!  While you are down there, make sure to pay attention to the beautiful wood that is the bar itself.  It is one piece of wood and just gorgeous.  I was seeing the edge of it from upstairs and drawn downstairs to take it all in.

Now, for the beer.  They have a bottled beer list that is 4 pages long.  I believe that almost all of those beers are Belgian, with only a few exceptions.  They also have 9 Belgian beers on tap.  My fiance had the Delirium Tremens on tap and the bottled Cherish Raspberry.  (I had my neurologist in my head telling me to stay off the beer and on my epilepsy medicine.)  It would take you a long time to get through all of the beers on the beer list.  You could go many weeks, even as a heavy drinker, without having the same one twice.

Foodwise, I decided to make a meal of sides.  So I had mixed vegetables, polenta, mashed potatoes, & frittes.  My fiance had the potato leek soup, the chicken dish, & frittes.  Everything was very tasty and the portions were definitely ample.  The portions were so ample in fact that we never even made it to the dessert menu.  :(  Next time!  I can't really comment on whether or not the Belgian-style dishes are authentic or not.  I have never been to Belgium in my life, so I will readily admit to having no idea.

Service - There were definitely some opening night snags that were to be expected.  I was shocked to see how many people were there.  Not only was the place packed, but there was a wait (for upstairs dining) the entire time we were there.  The staff definitely had the opening night jitters, but I don't think that there are any problems that won't work themselves out over time.

Overall - La Trappe is a great addition to the neighborhood.  It is so nice not to have another Italian restaurant.  We look forward to coming back again and spending some quality time in the cave.
author: Squirrel L.

description: I'll keep this short and sweet. I come here for the beer and the burger. The Beer selection is pretty extensive (180+) but I generally get the same thing because it's tasty and that keeps things simple. The service is sometimes a little on the slow side but the servers are extremely knowledgeable about the food and extensive beer selections so that, coupled with the fact that I generally come here to spend time with friends and always enjoy myself, makes up for the wait time.
author: Thel D.

description: Arrived 5:30 pm on Saturday, greeted by friendly staff that directed us to the bar downstairs. The beer selection is overwhelming. Tried several from the tap. Stayed on for dinner. My rabbit was the best I've had. My son raved about his boudin blanc. My wife had the portobello burger and said it was okay, clearly she regretted not ordering the rabbit. Our waiter was great and good with our dumb questions. The place packed out by just after 6:00, and that made the downstairs very noisy.
author: Jeff A.

description: Amazing beer selection.  Gone here a couple times and I'll definitely be going back.
author: Andrew K.

description:
I think maybe we just went here on a bad night.  We got there at around 8pm on a Friday night and we were a party of 6.  The lady told us it'll be about ten minutes before a table is ready...So we decided to grab a drink in the bar/waiting area.  Twenty minutes later there's no sign of a table, so we go ahead and order some apps.  30 minutes later there's no sign of a table or our apps :( we manage to flag down the waitress that took our order and ask her how long our table be - her response is "they ordered dessert" she shrugs and walks off.....OhKay, maybe ten minutes later we manage to flag her down again and ask after our apps...and are told "the kitchen is working on them"  We just ordered fries and salads for apps.  Finally one person goes to cancel the food order only to be told its on the way out....And they do come straight away with our fries.  Twenty minutes later our salad followed.  After being there for an hour and 45 minutes we get our table.  We go ahead and order 4 entrees.  Our food only takes 40 minutes to come out - and the food is good.  We had the mussels, and the burgers.  And it really was good food.  I also like the sauces they serve with the fries - a much better selection than anywhere else I've seen.

When we get our bill there has automatically been an 18% gratuity added, when our waitress comes to collect the bill I tell her thats not fair and she says she'll send the manager over.  all in all we managed to get him to only charge us gratuity for the food we ordered at the table.

This place is a 4 hour ordeal type place - which is their perogative, but don't tell me my table is ten minutes away.
author: Kym P.

description: I love this spot!  I can't stop thinking about the Bieken Honey Ale.  The food is pretty good.  I didn't have the mussels and fries, but they looked really good.   People mainly come here for the beer, so if you're not a beer drinker, then I would pass. 5 Stars. =)
author: H. A.

description: Great selection of beer. Excellent mussels and fries. Can't wait to return to this place.
author: Joshua S.

description:
So loved this place! But who even knew it was here?! Which is a BAD thing. If Gordan Ramsey had his two cents worth, he would be making sure that there were diners sitting upstairs by the windows to advertise the fact that this is a restaurant.  When you walk past you can't even tell if it is a restaurant or if is open as all of the diners are hidden away downstairs. So they have all of this redundant space upstairs-  come on, this is SF, space= money!
Anyway the food was amazing. i decided to try the rabbit stew, as I have despite being a country girl have never tried it. Loved it so much and the polenta and veggies that it came with were also perfection. If you like beer then it has a huge selection.
Decor also amazing, kind of like a converted London underground tunnel. They should take down the art work on the wall though as it really cheapened the look of the place and didn't fit in at all. 
This place is also let down by the service, as people have already said in their reviews. Very very slow. But overall it is a great addition to Northbeach.
author: Carrie A.

description:
this place veddy veddy dangerous for me.

omg.  the beer selection.  duh.

the portobello mushroom burger w/pesto and goat cheese.  yummo.

the FRIES!!

just be mindful that belgian brews are pricy.  i'm sure you know that already.  i had a peach lindemann's lambic and the burger for $25 plus tip (18% gratuity included for party of 6+).

oh, and eat in the basement.  it's so bohemian (like, actual bohemian, not mary-kate olsen bohemian), it reminded me a lot of dingy dives in prague (but more so budapest).  mucha posters in the bathroom, can i get a what what.
author: Michelle W.

description: I fell in love with this place the first time I went there.  The place is cozy with an amazing beer selection.  Talk about literature.  You could sit there for an hour just reading the beer menu.  After a few times, the food gets a little old, not much selection, and the menu hasn't changed since I went there the first time. The heavy alcohol totally makes up for it.  Parking is a problem though.
author: Lyn D.

description: We just got back from La Trappe, it was so good. The beer menu was really impressive, they even have a $350 6L bottle of beer. The 4 of us had mussels, oysters, pork chop, risottos, and more mussels, everything was amazing. The pork chop was probably the best of all. Dessert was alright, not the best or anything but decent. Their downstairs is really chilled, they have a bar there that looks like the kindda place i would hang out with good friends to talk about fashion and what not... I live a few blocks away from it, so will def go back often...
author: Andrew N.

description:
when a bar cares enough about the authenticity of their beers to have in their possession a special glass for each and every beer, you know you're in a good place. this exceptional quality is in addition to their selection of beers being mostly rare belgians not found in most restaurants in the states. la trappe is a welcome vacation from the multitude of italian restaurants in the region; granted, it's on the outskirts of north beach and located at a convenient tourist trap (a.k.a trolley stop).  their unique selling point is the building is a renovated trolley workshop, or at least that's the version i heard. the cables once ran through the building, which in my opinion, would be an awesome thing to still have flying around above you while eating. maybe covered by soundproof glass or something, but still an impressive attraction.

as far as the food is concerned, i had a pretty tasty cheeseburger on my visit. they offer you a few choices of sauces - really just variations on mayonnaises and ketchups - to either use on your burger or fries, like wasabi mayonnaise or spicy ketchup. and, instead of a normal bun, they go a step further and put the burger on a soft, delicious kaiser roll. like i said, the burger was tasty, but i'm unsure if the cost was defined by their assumed quality of product, or the fact they're in a tourist-heavy area of the city. either way, the beer list is a definite reason to revisit this place. in fact, i'd go as far to say as it's one of the better beer joints around.
author: Jeremiah W.

description: Hands down the best french fries in San Francisco. I've been to this place a few times, I can't complain about anything. Get a chees plate, split it with your friends, you won't be sorry. The sauces here for the fries, and anything else you can get sauce with are amazing! Highly recommended.
author: Elizabeth D.

description:
WOW this place was so cute and unique!
The beer selection here is awesome.  The place is super cute and quaint.  It is not the place to go with a huge party or on a night where you are looking for the hardcore bar scene.  It is a place that would be amazing for a small group of friends to get together at and have a couple of drinks in an intimate setting.
The bartender was REALLY helpful when it came to picking a beer, I was overwhelmed by the choices but he even gave me samples so I could pick the right one.  I ended up with a really good wheat beer and a thirst for all the rest of them he let me try (this place could be very dangerous for my credit card!).
My friends got a bottle of wine which they were impressed with, and from the few sips I stole so was I.  The wine they said was even pretty reasonably priced, unlike a lot of the beers.
I have not tried the food here so cant say anything about that.  All I can say is the beer is amazing and the atmosphere was really cool, I will surely be going back when I get the chance.
author: Marie W.

description:
I had a 5 star experience here last night...this place did it for me! I don't like beer (I know, weird)...and it's not that I haven't tried enough. I have worked in 5 restaurants and bars over the years, as a server, cocktail waitress, beverage cart driver, and bartender. So I've had plenty of opportunities to try my share of beer over the years...never liked any. Anyway, that was my disclaimer...now back to the review. 

So this place doesn't seem like it would be as amazing as it actually is from the outside, or even walking in the front door. The good times to be had are downstairs. Yes, there is a downstairs that a lot of people might not know about. It used to be a speakeasy, so it has a cave feel to it, with a waterfall and plenty of tables and booths, great for just hanging out with friends or a date. Mike, the bartender/owner was beyond helpful and attentive to us and here's the highlight...HE FOUND 2 BEERS THAT I LOVED. Mike hit the spot (sicko, not like that)! The first was the kasteel rouge, and it tasted like cherry soda. The second, and my favorite was the framboise raspberry lambic, and it tasted like a raspberry cider. It was delicious. Each beer comes with it's own glass, unique to that beer. Neat, huh? 
If you're looking to check out new craft beers or just love a good Belgian beer, this is the place.
author: Julie F.

description: Yah, this place is amazing!!!  It feels like you are in Belgium, drinking monk brewed beer!  You will love it!  Oh, and try the mead!
author: Mason G.

description:
Friends from out of town always make plans to meet up here.  No argument from me.
The owners and bartenders know their beers and all are super cool to talk about their new tapped favorites.  
This place can turn super crowded on weekend nights feeling a little too full and the service can turn into beer bar mode.  You know, you forget the idea that there's a waitress and stand behind two people at the bar trying to do that head nod to the bartender to get their attention and then shout 'Westmalle Double'.
You'll be happy when that one arrives.
Weeknights are mellower.
Also, they close around midnight.
If you're with your guy friends and you're cool with standing around cheers'ing and retelling stories about that trip to Antwerp, then you'll dig it.  Seats are for the eaters.  Bar holds only about 10 or so.  Prices?  Just order from the list and enjoy.  Are you really planning to skimp on your own happiness?
author: Kev M.

description: A hidden treasure with a hidden beer bar downstairs, one would have never guessed  the bar exist since the upstairs dinning area is deceiving, with what seems like a mellow kind of restaurant for a quiet dinner date. The restaurant didn't look busy at all as we walked by, but once we went inside and walked downstairs, it was a whole different story. The space has enough seating to accommodate groups on the bigger size and it seems like a definite fun and lively atmosphere for a laid back night.  I liked how it didn't get excessively busy where you have to reach over someone's shoulder to get the bartender's attention.  From the extensive beer list I enjoyed both the Wittekerke and peach beer over some great conversation.  Definitely worth coming back!
author: Lisa C.

description: Haven't eaten here, but 4 strong stars for an excellent belgian beer on tap selection, friendly service, and a very cool, dark, intimate downstairs room (go down the stairs and to your right). It's a great place to be trapped (get it?) with belgian beer and friends for a couple of hours!
author: beth l.

description: This place had a pretty great atmosphere and a speakeasy feel, very cool.  Good food and good company.
author: Adolfo W.

description: I had rabbit stew here. Where else you gonna get that?!  The server, though slammed (read: bad management!) was a nice person concerned with our welfare. The beer we had came in a wine bottle-sized bottle and did the trick. I agree with Meredith R. - spectacular ambience. There were some tools there for sure, but hey, I have to be honest here, everyone in the world is somewhat of a tool compared to me :p
author: Jason M.

description: This place is pretty cool. The downstairs was such an unexpected, late night find.  We had drinks only, but our friend had a burger and it looked fantastic.  For cocktails, at least, the space was so unique that it warrants a trip....especially if you're a beer-snob.
author: Emily M.

description:
Great atmosphere and they were most accomodating when we went in at 9:30 for beers and dessert. Their subterranean restaurant/lounge area is really nice. On St Patrick's it was crammed but civilized --- still off the beaten track. 

They do have an awesome selection of beers, all served in their proper glasses (many different shapes and brewers' stamps... I can see it being fun to order everything over the course of time just to check out the glasses). 

We were inspired to discuss international beer experiences. Terry's was the best; at about 20, she spent 3 days in Brussels sitting in the youth hostel drinking dollar beers w/o ever going outside. 

Someone mentioned how Tommy's Joynt doesn't really have all the beers they profess to have, and within minutes the waiter returned to our table to say they did not have the beer I ordered, a Val-Dieu Grand Cru, "Dark Ale with chocolate and port wine overtones, Deep dark color is oily and spicy with aroma of roasted malt and chocolate finishes slightly dry. " So then I chose the Duchesse De Bourgogne "Matured in oak casks blended 8 and 18 months-refreshing and smooth iwth interplay of fruit and chocolate - long dry and acidic finish. After 2 years in the barrrel, Iris goes through another hopping process for two weeks making it smell and taste more bitter." But he steered me away from that for a reason I can't recall, and in the end suggested the Gulden Draak, "Thick beer malt toffee like sweetness with a mellow happiness and some hoppy accents, like a barley wine. It's to sip and enjoy." I did like this last one a lot - it was just what I was wanting and the waiter seemed to understand that.

It was someone's birthday so we ordered the belgian waffles with beer sauce and a chocolate trifle, all of which were really good. Pleasant and mellow, I only reserve one star because I couldn't get what I ordered initially. Not a huge complaint since they have so many wonderful and beautifully presented beers.

This is their food and beer list:
http://sfbeer.blogspot.com/
author: Roxmarie M.

description: If you know anything about quality beer, than you know about this little hidden gem in the heart of North Beach. Hidden down in a tiny sweat box basement you will find one of San Francisco's gems of beer selection. Actually, let me rephrase that. You will find San Francisco's most important beer gem that provides us humans with the highest and most premier quality beer from around the world. La Trappe carries hundreds of beers traveling many oceans and continents from all over the world. Specializing in Belgian style beers, La Trappe also offers almost every trappist style beer one could have. There are a couple trappist breweries that do not allow their product to leave their country. If I recall, Kwak being one of them. The two boys running the ship, Mike Moore and Mike Azzalinni, provide their friends and customers with the most reasonable prices in the bay area and support many local beer events, such as strong beer month. They also have teamed up with a local butcher creating awesome culinary events, one of which was a breakdown of a pig and serving it many different ways. Not to forget of course to have a beer pairing with every course. These boys know their stuff, and I encourage you to stop by and have a beer with them. Dollar off all drafts on happy hour!
author: monika l.

description: great beer, very cool decor.  The only flaw was the music (reggae).  threw me.  Needed some monk-type music.
author: Gina C.

description: Beer here is awesome and the ambiance is well worth going there for.  Do not go here to have a full dinner though.  The apps are good.  The fries are a must get but beyond that the service for the regular meal is slow and the food is just so, so.  It is too expensive to justify eating there.  You can go to any restaurant in nearby North Beach and pay less for a much better meal.  So go here for your apps and your beer then go have dinner in North Beach.  Then come back for more beer.
author: Ronald G.

description:
this place has the largest selection of beers!!!
this place is so hidden and the atmosphere is great. the bartenders recommendations were awesome and their steamed mussels reminded me of Paris. Being able to pick 2 sauces for your french fries should be implemented everywhere! spicy ketchup and a type of aioli...mMmmmmm
