author: Angela J.

description: Great beer list, good fries.  Food is average
author: Irene C.

description: Great selection of beers and solid food. The carbonades flamandes are excellent and so are the mussels and fries. The staff is always friendly and helpful.
author: Cris P.

description: Not being a beer lover and entirely unaware of the variety of beers available, I was surprised to find myself enjoying this new haunt.  First the decor was spectacular.  The dining area at street level was quaint, cozy and very inviting.  Downstairs was more seating, a bar and lounge area.  The tables were very private and it was easy to converse with your party.  The service was very accommodating - we were on our way to Bimbo's for a show, so they took our order and brought out our food and drinks in a timely manner.  On a Friday night they were able to seat us right away too - without a reservation.  Very impressive.  The food was delicious - a variety of entrees, appetizers and salads to choose from.  The beer list - well there isn't time to go through it all - there's an entire book.  Shared a bottle of cassis something or other with a friend.  It was delicious.
author: Rebecca Z.

description: What a cute place.  I am glad a beer-oriented hall can come off so brew-chic!  Tried a white beer and some cheese plate and burger sliders.  All delisch.  Check it.
author: e w.

description: We walked in and the street-level room was totally empty. The boyfriend and I looked at each other, wondering where the people were, but when the kitchen staff saw our puzzled expressions, they suggested we go downstairs. We descended the winding staircase and was so pleasantly surprised by a lovely little subterranean dining room, complete with water fountain and a crowd of people. I felt like I was in a speakeasy. The food was good, the fries especially are amazing, complete with multiple dipping sauces. And the beer. Fantastic.
author: Noelle Q.

description: This place is awesome and I can't wait to go back ASAP.  It was my b-day and some friends suggested it....I was so pleasantly surprised when I got to the basement!  The ambiance is awesome!  I love the dimness and the cave-like candlelit  room with comfy seats and brick walls.  Be careful though when going to the restroom - those mirrors are not one-way! ; )  I will definitely be back.  The beer selection is fantastic and the staff was very friendly and more than helpful.
author: Rise G.

description: fun place!  they have like thousand kinds of beer and bartenders will know exactly what you'd like if you tell them your style.
author: Jee C.

description: This place fulfills a dream of mine, where I live in a magical underground cave full of amazing beer and frites with heavenly sauces. Not many have seen their dream become reality, so I know how lucky I am. The staff/owners are also very nice, attentive, and wouldn't you know it, have great taste, so I ask for recommendations. But shhhh, if you suck, don't go there, don't shatter my dream.
author: Isabel L.

description: Pretty great, I'd say. The beer list is nothing short of impressive. You are literally presented with a book of choices, and they are not just limited to Belgian. Beware, though, some of those choices are not cheap. Someday I maybe be tempted to drop $40 on a bottle of beer, but not today. The food was pretty good as well. Not astounding, but very hearty and good. And the staff was very pleasant. A good place for a jovial saturday night dinner.
author: Tom H.

description: Checked out La Trappe last night and really liked it. Crazy great beer selection, cool interior, and our burgers and fries were extremely tasty! Definitely recommended! We'll be back!
author: Sarah R.

description:
from the street, it looks empty, but go down the stairs and you'll quickly find yourself immersed in a cozy, comfortable, and fun bar!  awesome selection of beers and we ordered fries.  they have an array of dipping sauces -- your order comes with 2 sauces, but there were so many we wanted to try that we requested all of them at an extra $1 charge (i think there were 8-10 of them!!).  

we had a group of 6 on a friday night, and even though it was crowded, we asked the bartender for a table and he hooked us up with one right away -- stroke of luck i suppose.  but the waitress was very knowledgeable in the beers and made great recommendations to us. 

definitely an awesome find!
author: Maxine C.

description: You'll find so so food here, great Belgian beers, but very little hospitality.  Whenever it gets crowded - usually Fridays/Saturdays - the barkeeps can't keep up with the flow and start treating their clientele  with outright contempt, get irritated by customers who ask for tasting notes to the many beers (not all of us are beer nerds) and yell at those who dare ask for their bill after an half hour wait. Stress is part of any fast paced restaurant, but if you can't take the heat, stay out of the kitchen, especially the Belgian kitchen where they treat people like people - not customers. if you want to give your friends a taste of Belgium, don't go to la Trappe.
author: Hans D.

description: good beer selection but something feels wrong about spending 3x as much on a beer I can get at Bevmo... But the atmosphere and the food is pretty authentic but the fries weren't belgian though (they are wider) but you cant really mess up fries.  Try the moules frittes  you'll have so many mussels you'll sick of them half way through.  Also they serve the beer too cold, some were meant for room temperature to enhance the flavor.
author: S. K.

description: Didn't try any of the food, but they have a great selection of delicious belgian beers. The downstairs portion where the bar is located has a really great ambience. Lot's of natural wood, dim lighting, and outward angled walls. It's also not absurdly loud, so it's a great place to drink and actually have some good conversation. Great bar!
author: Zach C.

description:
great food, impressive beer list and awesome service. they don't take reservations but we went here with 20 people - luckily before the dinner rush. the people were very accommodating, going beyond to make sure they can set up a table to fit our large group. love a service with a smile :) 

the beer list is insane, it's booklet of all different types of beer! it's a bit overwhelming if you first look at it but the people are helpful and when in doubt, just start with the beers on tap specials. didn't know beer can mess me up until i had the 9% ones. 

food is also very very yummy! i had the sausage (nothing can go wrong with beer + sausage), but the winning dish of the night was the rabbit stew (my friend ordered and it was awesome). the mussels in dark beer was the perfect app, and i LOVE that they bring you a plate full of diff sauces for the twice cooked fries - nom nom nom.
author: Lucy C.

description:
chicken stew and belgian beer on a cold winter night?  in a dark little downstairs bar/cafe? with wooden tables?

YES PLEASE.

what a wonderful surprise and welcome addition la trappe is to north beach.  my only regret is not ordering dessert.  the burger, fries, beer and stew were all ordered and are highly recommended.  food is GOOD - definitely worth it for more than just beer.    

my only suggestion going forward is reservations - it's a small place.  really small.  since everyone seems to like it was much as i did, it won't be long before reservations are a must.
author: Kristin K.

description:
I SO wanted to like this place.  And I still kind of do despite a seemingly endless series of fuck ups.
The ambiance is great--we ate in the downstairs and it was far cozier than you might expect for a cave.  
I also appreciate walking in at 10:30pm on a Friday and being able to get a meal without any problem--not always the case in SF.
However, something was seriously amiss with the service.
Not only did the waitress have a wholly surly and unapologetic demeanor, the execution was poor.
The four of us sat down and ordered beers from the (impressive/overwhelming list).  Three beers arrived.  Five minutes later we flag waitress down who says they are out of the 4th beer.  Friend picks a (safe) beer on TAP.  Five minutes go by--no beer.  Friend is growing pissy and unpleasant to be around.
Five minutes later we again flag down waitress who clearly goes and enters beer order for the first time.
That basically set the tone for the rest of the night (e.g., only 3 entrees came out; getting refills on beer was far more of a production than it should have been, etc).
I'm tempted to give them a pass, call it an aberrant night of shitty service, and return again, but I'm certainly not rushing back.
author: Auburn D.

description: Ugh.  I was so excited about going to this place.  Anyone who knows me knows how much I love Belgian Beer.  I have a Flanders red, 2 different Lambics and a Dubbel in production at home right now.  Yes, I brew.  In fact, my husband and I brew a lot and we brew a lot of Belgian beers.  We planned on going here on Sunday night with 4 other friends.  One of our friends called ahead on Thursday to make sure they would be open on Sunday at 6PM.  They said yes.  Two of our other friends went in on Saturday and double checked that they would be open the following evening.  They said yes.  We all show up at 6PM and they were not open.  I understand having issues when you are first opening up, but if none of the employees are capable of figuring out your schedule, there is a serious problem.  You wasted a bunch of our time traveling across town for this as a destination and we are not impressed.
author: Kate B.

description:
5 stars = has my favorite beer in the world: kasteel dubbel.

also has kasteel rouge and kasteel trippel. all tasty. kasteel isn't so easy to find, and i have sentimental preference for it as i was introduced to the brewery by a good friend one night in belgium.

occasionally they have leffe brun, another elusive favorite from that same trip.

massive selection of beers, and the belgian-style food is good. good burger, good mussels, good waterzooi, good fries. 

good.
author: grace l.

description:
5 stars for the beer choices.
4 stars for the food choices.
3 stars for the service and access to the bar rail to order direct.

I will come here when I go to Bimbo's or Cobb's, but I wouldn't make a special trip just to come to La Trappe like I would The Trappist in Old Oakland.
author: Chris P.

description: More than 100 Belgium beers on their list, including several kind of hard to find Gueze? That's a 5 star in my book.
author: Neena W.

description:
the belgian beer selection here is great, if not a bit overwhelming!!  they have a revolving list of beers on tap, and the others are just bottled.  i tried  a couple witbiers last night, along w/ other darker belgian ales.  

for food, i had the mussels (so-so), fries (yum!), a salad w/ roquefort, and my friends had the gnocchi and sliders.  they said the sliders were delish, and they came on a brioche bun, yum!
author: Helen T.

description:
I loved this place, and I really want it to do well, but I was really really disappointed with our service.

We walked in and waited at least fifteen minutes before a single person greeted us. We ordered, and I asked to keep the wine list so that i could order more, and they didn't have enough for us to do so. Someone else brought us our drinks and then we waited with empty waters and empty drinks while our apps came. The food was very good. Not excellent, but very good. Our server walked past us several times. Finally I stopped her and asked to see a wine/beer list. She brought it ten minutes later, but didn't bother to stop back and take our orders. We ordered more to drink, and continued to wait for our entree. It never came. 45 minutes later I stopped our server again. She thought our meal had come. She went to check on it and nobody had even put the order in. She asked if we still wanted it. We had to get to a show, so we said no, could we just have our check. 15 minutes later we got our check. Another 15 minutes later she came and picked it up, and didn't bring it back for us to sign for awhile. Seriously. OVER two hours at the place and we had each had two drinks, an app, and not received our entree. Boo.

We REALLY liked the place, though. The food was great, the beer was great, the atmosphere was great. But the server should have PROFUSELY apologized and comped us either drinks or our apps or something. This was a HUGE mess up and she didn't really care. That was very lame. We'd like to give it another shot because it's such a great place, but it's gonna have to d a whole heck of a lot better than that.
author: Monika M.

description:
what a strange place! we saw it from the outside, and there were only a few diners, and it kind of looked sad. nevertheless, the menu sounds intriguing so we go in and the hostess says:

"so, i can seat you up here right away, but it'll be 30 minutes if you want to sit downstairs."

waaa

downstairs??!?

"can we see this downstairs you speak of?"

"sure, check it out."

we wander downstairs, and it's like following the white rabbit. a friend with me, who lived in belgium for a while, says it's like wandering into a bar in brussels -- very cozy, dark, rocky, old old old feeling

and it was packed!

we got the mussels and fries and beer. the beer was by far the best part, i don't think the mussels or fries were much to write home about. so go for the beer, and be pleasantly surprised by the wondrous basement bar.
author: omar k.

description:
They have my favorite belgian beer...they have EVERY ONE's favorite Belgian beer.  They serve each beer in the right glass and all the beers we tasted were fantastic. 
You must go downstairs, you feel like you are leaving San Francisco with every step down the beautiful spiral staircase. The exposed brick walls, the stone ceiling, the warm dim lighting and the comfortable booths...its all so perfect for a cozy huddle with some close friends.  The food is also wonderful, we all had burgers but the rest of the menu looked great.  Now for the service...our server was amazing.  Yes I said amazing, one of the most overused words in Yelp reviews.  But its the right word to describe her.  She was friendly, efficient and attentive when we were the only table seated (we were early) and she was friendly, efficient and absolutely attentive when the place was packed with people 3 hours later...I just wish I had gotten her name so I could give her some credit. But I did track her down as we were leaving and personally thank her and I hardly ever do that. I wasn't even that drunk.
We will be back as there is an almost novel-sized book of beers we still have to try.
author: Nilu r.

description: The attitude of the owner is flat out arrogant. We had a group of 20 people on a slow night. Been in their before as a local and was glad to bring some folks. The owner/barkeeper had such an angry way taking our orders we all looked at each other. After third round my buddy said "...and we are giving this A-wipe our money because....?". I said,let's go. Never to return. We all live with in NB,RH a few blocks away.
author: s s.

description: Went here a couple weeks back because I was in the neighborhood killing some time before a show at the Purple Onion.  Despite it's proximity to the hinterlands of the Marina, I was pleasantly surprised.  There is an upstairs and downstairs which is cool, I love separate spaces like that.  The downstairs has a dungeon feel, which I totally love.  I felt like a Trappist in my beer brewing caves.  Or something like that.  Anyways, the food was great and prices were reasonable.  But the beer selection was slamming.  I love beer and I love trying new ones.  The staff had great recommendations as well.
author: Katie M.

description: I love La Trappe. The decor is wonderful, and they have some fantastic beer there. The downstairs is the place to go. Mike and Boots are great guys, and fun to chat with at the bar. I still have not tried the food, but it looks damn good. This is a must when I am in The City.
author: Brian C.

description: Excellent beers, decent food, but service was abominable, even if you count in spillover from the North Beach Douche Fest - waited over an hour to receive our complete order. Two-and-a-half stars.
author: Kai H.

description: Fabulous beers, friendly ambience, clean and non-sterile decor: feels like your chill yet not slummy neighborhood pub. Which happens to have a beer list the size of a novel.
author: Cyn K.

description: The place is absolutely beautiful! Great for a hot date, or just chillen with your homies. The bar is underground it's all brick, the lighting is dim very intimate. The beer menu is the best, great selection of every type of belgian beer ever made, it's up to date and has descriptions and even the alcohol % (very important to light-weights like myself). The staff was friendly, knowledgeable and helpful! Great spot.
author: Jessica C.

description: Cool basement of a cafe+bistro+bar with an echo, so it makes you feel like you're in a beer cellar or tavern. Great selection of Belgians. Too bad it closes at 12 every night. Didn't get to try anything past our first round. So we'll see what we come across to next time.
author: Inbae L.

description: I can't say no to a 200+ beer selection.  I didn't have the food.  Came in about 7pm on a Saturday night and it was a great time to go have a nice tasty Belgian beer.  The bartender was really cool too.  I have a feeling I'll be dropping by this place on all my SF visits.
author: Andy P.

description: Amazing Belgian beer list. Reminds me of The Back Abbey down in Southern California. The beer menu is more like the Belgian Bible and they update their draught list on their website. Definitely get an order of fries or two to try the delicious dipping sauces. The mussels are pretty good but I prefer to get the burger. Overall pretty good food. Not as good as Monk's but definitely good. Try to sit downstairs as the basement has a great feel. Gets pretty crowded on the weekend and they often run out of their famous rabbit (which is probably why I have not tried it)
author: Mike W.

description: Oh North Beach, you proved me wrong.  This place was not fratty, smelly, pretentious, or Italian.  I found great beer, better fries, and decent mussels.  I also got my learn on - the beer menu teaches about all the different varieties of beer!
author: Kim S.

description:
This is for the food only. The place had a cool atmostphere and great beer selection, but the food is horrible! (I'm sure it'd be a good place for drinks only).

Went here last night after reading the chronicle review. ordered the calamari salad, mussles provencale and rabbit stew. calamari salad was the best thing we ate, and not even that good. the mussels were bland, tasted off, the fries went cold right away, the dipping sauces tasted too much like mayonase, the rabbit stew was heavly and bland. the veggies on the side were drowing in butter. yuck. DO NOT EAT HERE.
author: Kay T.

description: The atmosphere was great, especially the downstairs 'cavern'. The beer selection was almost a novel. The food was good. Will take more friends next time!
author: Barbara W.

description: A neighborhood GEM! Great beer selection and a cool setting. I've been here twice and had some great beers and finally got a chance to try their food. The mussels were good but not very flavorful but I have heard the rabbit stew is great and will definitely be back soon to try it, along with some more of their delicious beer!!
author: Kelly C.

description: Great place with great beer.  Weekend nights it's a little overrun with youngsters getting their drink on but the guy behind the bar is tall and saw that I required beer nonetheless.
author: shannone e.

description: I have so much love for La Trappe! I just had the rehearsal dinner (with approx 20 guests) for my wedding in the bar/lounge area downstairs. They did a kick ass job at everything - the service, food, drinks - we were so impressed. They designed menus for the event, happily explained their huge beer selection a ton of times for all of our guests, and promptly brought out additional appetizers when we ran out. Try the grilled shrimp by the way - everyone's favorite. Once the dinner was over about 30 more guests showed up to meet us for drinks. It really was the perfect place for the event.
author: Abby P.

description:
I had heard great things about La Trappe, so when my husband and I found ourselves house sitting in NB, we decided to pop in for dinner on a Tuesday evening.  The trip started off well enough as we made our way downstairs to the cellar-type dining room and settled into a small table for two.  After that, things were just so-so.  The service was pretty slow, but friendly enough when they were around.  We ordered our apps and entrees and some beers.  The potato leek soup was ok flavor wise, but it was only lukewarm, which didn't help matters.  We had some oysters on the half shell which were actually quite good.  My husband had the burger, which he said was pretty good. I had the Moules Frites in the white beer broth, the entree portion.  It was enormous - so I'll give them credit for that, but I wish they had paid more attention to the quality than the quantity.  The broth was virtually flavorless and the mussels were unevenly cooked (some overdone, some fine).  But, really the biggest disappointment were the frites - I mean, this is your mainstay - they should be perfect!  Sadly, they were barely more than mediocre.  Each one should be perfectly crisp on the outside, unfortunately, only a few actually were.  Most were soggy and I ate only about 1/3 of the portion, very unusual for me as I'm a bit nuts for frites, normally.  

Maybe it was an off night, maybe it's like that all the time.  Either way, though it wasn't the best food experience, I'll definitely go back to enjoy drinks and the atmosphere which would get 4 stars on their own.  And who knows, maybe I'll give the food another try and update the review if they improve!
author: AC S.

description: I'm glad I discovered this place. Warm, cozy atmosphere. Nice place to go with friends on a low-key night and sip some rich Belgian beers. It's spacious, with two levels, which is something I really appreciate in a city where space in bars is scarce. I wouldn't recommend the desserts--the raspberry mousse tasted like it'd been sitting out for a while, but maybe I picked the wrong thing. Overall, sweet bar!
author: Jenni L.

description: I really wanted to like this place since it's two buildings away from me but I just can't love it.  The atmosphere is great, our server was decently attentive but the food was horrible and way overpriced.  We went before a show at Cobb's for some food and beers.  The beer selection is amazing and the beers that we chose were very good and worth the hefty price.  We ordered the cheese plate with the extra prosciutto, the fries, pancetta wrapped prawns and something else I can't remember.  All of the cheeses were sub-par, the fries were bland and cold and the prawns were hard as rocks and dry as the desert.
author: Jennifer A.

description:
Great place for grabbing a Belgian beer or 2...The food is fairly good too...BUT the food service is horrible.  I want this place to survive, but they need to get their act together in terms of food service.  
I suggest sitting at the bar, to avoid the frustration of being lost at a table.
author: m g.

description: loved the food and the waffles! great atmosfere, a little loud but nice, huge beer selection, my boyfriend loves, good service, good prices
author: A Z.

description: this would be 5 stars if it were a little cheaper, but i guess when you have to import all of your delicious Flemish sour ale from Belgium it could  get pricey, you enjoy your beer and hopefully fries in a vaulted cave like basement, the bartenders are nice and knowledgeable, and happy to let you try any of the things on tap that night. a great spot.
author: Jared Z.

description:
As Belgians, living in San Francisco, we had to check out this place. You can see it's co-owned by a Belgian. There are some typical Belgian entrees on the menu (Gentse waterzooi, mosselen met frieten, etc.). The three of us tried the marinated mussels with "twice cooked fries" (yes, that's how you have to make them!). Overall, I wasn't too impressed. The fries were almost cold, the mussels a bit overcooked and dry. And we really missed the typical mussels sauce. On the other hand,  they had a great selection of beer, but then again, failed to present them in the appropriate glass (this is oh so important to a Belgian!). The Trappist in Oakland does a much better job here. Finally, they overcharged us on all beers (1, 2 or even 4 (!) dollars on the Grimbergen). So double check your bill. The server corrected his mistakes though and gave us a 10$ discount.

This place has all the potentials to be a true 5-star must-check-it-out place, so I am willing to give them some time...
author: bart a.

description:
I visited La Trappe, with my husband and two other Belgians, last night. I had been told it was not a big place so I went ahead and made reservations.

The service was ok. Despite the reservations, our table was not ready and we had to wait 5 minutes for them to pull out an extra chair for us.

The food was definitely nothing special. There were only a few Belgian food  items on the menu and everything was overpriced. 24 dollars for a steak and fries??? You pay that much and you expect your fries to be warm and at least to be served with mayonaise! 

The beer list was great but the beer wasn't always served in the correct glass, which was disappointing. On top of that, we were overcharged for almost 10 bucks so keep your eyes on the bill and double check with the prices on the menu! The waiter did apologize and added that he was not yet familiar with the beer price list.

La Trappe did do a good job of remodelling the basement. It has a crypt-like feel to it, featuring brick alcoves, and the bar set-up is perfect.

All in all, I'd go back to La Trappe for the beers if I happen to be in the city. We have The Trappist here in Oakland so I don't even have to cross the bay to get Belgian beer! Food-wise, I prefer Frjtz on Hayes. Their fries are much better and served in a traditional Belgian cone.
author: katrien z.

description: Excellent food. Amazing beer selection. Belgian heaven. Downstairs is more the drinkers' lair, upstairs for dining. Service is friendly, but not speedy. Coming here is a night out that need not be rushed. Cheers.
author: n b.

description: I love this place!  It came recommended by a friend of mine and since then I have been to La Trappe 3 times.  Love the food and the atmosphere, and the selection of Belgium beer is amazing!
author: Ally M.

description: When the bf suggested a pub for date night, I was cynical.  However, I am now a convert.  I want to steal their beer menu and study it like a Princeton Review workbook!  An amazing selection of beers, and good food to go with!  The fries are good and I like the dipping sauces you can choose from.  We also had the seafood stew, which was very good, properly cooked and seasoned.  Need to go back and try more beers and the mussels!
author: win c.

description: The rudeness of the staff on my first (and last visit) was about as bad as I have experienced in my 20 years in San Francisco.  I can't speak to the food or the beer selection - after one glass of wine I was pretty ready to leave.  When my date and I arrived, the bar was not overly crowded so the waitstaff apparently had nothing to do but mill about behind the bar ignoring us.  It took quite some time to be given all the various menus (beer, food, wine), and then even longer to get a drink.  I made eye contact repeatedly with a waitress who could not be bothered to ask if I needed help.  Finally, I asked the bartender who I should speak with to order.  He rudely told me he would get to me when he wasn't busy.  I guess they didn't teach multitasking at his bartending school. Our experience was better than our friends' who were almost asked to leave when they took up too many tables and the waiter assumed they wouldn't be ordering food (it is a bar, isn't it??). Maybe I am just too old to put up with bad attitude on a Friday night.
author: Leslie G.

description: Good food (get the mussels!), excellent beer selection, and the basement vibe is totally cool. I really like this place and go there whenever I get a chance.
author: J R.

description: TERRIBLE.   I, too, really wanted to like this place.  It's a belgian beer and food hall, with a cellar area and a bar that has a huge selection of beers.  That said, the service is terrible, the place is totally disorganized, and worst of all, the owner / bartender is absolutely awful.  I was with a group trying to get food and some beers before a show at Bimbo's.  I called that afternoon to make a reservation, but was told "we don't make reservations after  7 pm."  Ok, fine.  So, we show up at 7:30 pm, and the place has two huge empty tables with "reserved" signs on them.  I ask the owner what the deal is (hello, I thought "no reservations after 7 pm?!") and he arrogantly and coldly tells me "well, some times people can make reservations for later" and then folds his arms and stands back behind the bar glaring at me.  What the heck!??  The owner (who also doubles as the bartender) was completely rude and arrogant, and made no attempt to accommodate at us at either of the huge empty tables, or at the rather large lounge area that was also totally empty ("no, we won't serve food over there."), or anywhere else.  He said, "You can wait an hour."  (For what!? There appeared to be no other customers ahead of us).   Um, ok (!?!?).   As we walked out the owner again glared at me the whole way up the stairs.  I'm sorry, but the guy was a jerk, and being the owner of a new place I don't think being rude and completely cold and unaccomodating to your patrons is any way to generate return traffic.  AWFUL.
author: Johnny K.

description:
Managed to complete my initial survey of the new Belgian triumvirate we're blessed with in the Bay Area by visiting La Trappe tonight. I didn't dine, having just gorged myself on dan-dan and chicken soup at Z & Y, but I'll have to return for the moules frites - they're the most interesting item on the menu (offered three ways) and nothing goes better with a Belgian ale.

No, I was here for the beer - and headed straight downstairs. Contrary to earlier reports the music was tasteful (Sonny Rollins) and played at a very reasonable level, so that I was able to carry on normal conversation with one of the owners, and a nice young French couple next to me. The cellar "Trappist Lounge" is suitably dark, decorated in stone and soft woods, and does a good job capturing the mood of a European beer cellar. As for the main event, I would rank this place on a par with The Trappist (and well ahead of Monk's Kettle) for the true Belgian beer geek. Outstanding selection - about a dozen on tap, and around a hundred more in bottle, including a number of seasonal Belgians and non-Belgian Euro offerings. All were priced more fairly than at MK, with very reasonable markups given the setting. While the tap list included what have become the usual suspects (Chimay White, Maredsous, etc.) there were a couple nice rarer options - Grimbergen, and a lovely white beer called Wittekerke that I hadn't had on tap and really loved (and according to the owner, Duvel may be available on tap in the States soon - we can only hope).  

I asked the owners at all three places if any of them had a theory on why - after an eternity of virtually no Belgian-themed bars, the Bay Area got three new ones within a month. None of them, as it happens, had any notion of the others' existence basically until they were open. In short, a coincidence - except, of course, that SF has been woefully underserved in the premium beer arena and three groups had a good idea at about the same time. All nice people, but the (British) owner/bartender at La Trappe was exceptionally convivial and gregarious. I'll be back to try the food, but I was more than pleased by the selection and pricing of the beers, and the passion and knowledge of the staff about same.
author: Dan G.

description: I went to this place for a bday party on a Thursday night. It was actually really crowded. They had a huge selection of beer. The food was pretty good too. I wasn't drinking that night, but I did try a someone's 11% beer that was pretty amazing. My only complaint was the waiter, he was too busy texting or talking to his coworkers to wait on our table. When 2 ppl in my group went to the bar to order he all the sudden appeared and asked that we order from him if we were going to sit at the table. Ok grumpy ginger with a beer belly, maybe if you were actually waiting tables we wouldn't have to get up.....
author: Jennie B.

description: Very disapointed, the food was mediocre at best. The beer was good. This place is overated. The staff was friendly but that's about it.
author: Ruth R.

description: Good selection of beer on tap.. The menu for beer alone is about 10 pages..Price is good for North Beach as well. Go here if you want to try a bunch of different beers!
author: Matt S.

description: This place was good, the atmosphere was good.  But, I gave this place 3 stars only for the super long wait for the food and the terrible fries.  Fries were not seasoned well and just not what you would thought for Belgian foods.
author: K. R.

description:
400 different beers and a pot of mussels with belgian fries!!!

and my very first Yelp review!

This place is right next to where I live and I never actually thought to walk in.  From the outside, it has just a few tables and a kitchen just as big as the seating area.  You'd never know that there's a magical little pub beneath this humble setting, filled with over 400 beers from all over the world.  The food menu is only a few pages but the beer menu here is an encyclopedia!

I've only tried about 10 different beers here so can't say much as to what my favorite is just yet.  But one thing for sure.  CONSECRATION!
Local sour beer unlike anything you've had!  It's like Rodenbach but with rich oakwood you can taste.  Perhaps the reason I haven't tried other varieties here is because I go back to this place just for this beer.

The atmosphere is awesome and I've had a chance to meet Mike, one of the co-owners, who's just as awesome as the selection and the quality of the beers.

Whether with a buddy or a whole gang, GO, SIT DOWN, order a pot of MUSSELS, FRIES, and of course BEER.
author: Ethan K.

description: what a great experience we had. went for the beer but had sunday brunch first. excellent menu and the stuffed french toast was great, went downstairs to the bar,it's the closest thing to belgium ambiance i've experienced in the city. mike the owner and bartender is very knowledgeable and let us taste several beers before we ordered. very extensive beer menu and a great all around experience.
author: David S.

description: Oh man, the boudin blanc sausage was to die for, or atleast die from ( the sauce was sooo rich!) the beer selection was good with a serious concentration in Belgium and Belgian styles (don't remember any IPAs on the menu). Be warned though the beer book has an index in the front for better organization; which I mistook the page number for prices at first ( pg31 not $31 phew! )
author: Steve L.

description: The fries and dips here are truly great, and what better to wash them down with than one of there hundred or so Belgian beers? The downstairs atmosphere is pretty sweet as well, dark, mysterious, I could sit down there all day eating fries and drinking Belgian ales (heaven?).  And in half of the downstairs you can do just that (you can probably do it upstairs too, but it's considerably less cool up there), but the other half is only for people eating dinner. Having been a person on both halves I thoroughly recommend staying on the bar side and enjoying some fries, drinking some beers, and just sitting back and relaxing on their plushy couches. While the mussels look like they are going to be great, they are sadly mediocre. The mussels made with beer rather than white wine are especially tasteless. So save your cash and spend it on a fine rare Belgian ale or some extra dipping sauce, because while La Trappe is great for drinks and snacks you're much better off elsewhere for dinner.
author: Alex D.

description: food was great and it was really cool inside.  also- all the one star people are petty and stupid and i doubt anyone would want you there anyway.
author: Kaitlin V.

description: great place to try some unique beers.  super cool owners and friendly staff.  marina douche fest on the weekends, but any other night of the week (tues-thurs) a great addition to the neighborhood.  We didn't have a chance to try the food but the items on the menu looked really tasty.
author: franklin p.

description: new rarely seen beers w/ helpful descriptions, proper stemware & awesome music selection...   I'd sit downstairs with the $16 Mussels & Belgian Fries drinking a Hoppy Blonde or an Amber!  great addition to The Beach!
author: Louisa P.

description:
Having lived in Belgium for a year I was stoked when i heard about La Trappe.  It was high time this city had a refuge for Belgian beer and cuisine fans.  After one visit, some good and some bad:

GOOD:  Two words: atmosphere and beer.  The downstairs "cave" reminded me of a true Belgian cafe.  Very convivial, non-stuffy, I could come here once a week and hang out.  The beer list is beyond outstanding.  They have Rodenbach on tap which blew me away and would keep me coming back for this alone and to delve deeper into the list.

BAD:  the food was dissapointingly mediocre.  While I was excited to see some Belgian classics on the menu such as Waterzooi and an interesting rabbit dish, I opted for a first visit to go with the classic "Moules Frites" on which any Belgian establishment should be judged.  It was easily the worst mussels I have ever had anywhere on both continents.   They were small, shriveled and dried out and basically not even an edible dish.  In Belgium, there is definitely a "mussel season" and if you order them out of season  the waitstaff will kindly steer you away when they are not plump and juicy as they should be. I don't get the impression that level of care is taken here judging on what i was served.  Frites were decent but nothing to rave about.  They served a few mayo-based sauces as is tradition but the server was at a loss when i asked what they were.  The serviceable provencal sauce with pastis was mediocre and didn't incite you to lap it up with a spoon.  The shrimp croquettes, another classic, was well done and about double the portion size of what you would expect.  My guests both had Steakes-Frites and the steak looked like NY Strip from Safeway with an odd chunky vegetable saute that wasn't touched. 

BOTTOM LINE: I would come back here for some after-work beers but skip the food and go eat somewhere else until they get a handle on something as classic as  Moules Frites.
author: Peter L.

description: My boyfriend and I stumbled on this place in North Beach. When we first walked past, we weren't sure it was even open because there was nobody in front. We were taken downstairs, and the place was buzzing with people. The food was super yummy and the beer menu was impressive. The atmosphere and decor was comfortable. The staff was attentive even though the restaurant was busy.
author: Monica T.

description: Great basement with tons of energy, cold beers served in their branded glasses, a good flow & crowd, and tasty appetizers to go with it.  Adding it to my go-to spots!
author: Josh J.

description: Belgian food in North Beach. For all of you who want a very large selection of Belgian and Belgian style (Japanese Belgian beers), this is your place. The downstairs cave, with the bar and the primary dining area, feels very warm and reminds me of Brugges. My husband looked longingly at the bar. No, they aren't open for lunch yet, much to my husband's regret. They were out of 3 of the 5 beers he ordered (hey, he only drank 2), but the selection is large enough to keep him very, very happy. Not as impressed with the wine selection, but it is a BEER house, so I'm not complaining, just informing you. My rabbit entree was delicious and my husband said that it went well with the beer, better than his fish entree. His beer had a pear note to it, so he drank that with the cheese plate and was very pleased. The chocolate mousse with raspberry reduction was excellent and belongs on the San Francisco Chocolate Trail (it's like Boston's Freedom Trail, but for chocolate), although the chocolate mousse at Le Petit Bistro in Mountain View is even better (world class).
author: Vena V.

description: Went here one day after work for some food after some coworkers wanted to go here. Walking along Columbus we almost passed it because we didn't see it because it's kinda a small place...initially. After getting in and going into the downstairs we soon found out it was a lot bigger than the eye sees. The ambiance and the environment was a lot of fun, though, they could use more light to read their menus. We had a lot of trouble with the book o beers(yes, they have a lot of beer there). So the main word of warning is that if the number to the right seems too high....that's the page number. The food was good and interesting and complemented the beer very well.
author: Mark M.

description: We went to La Trappe last night for the first time after waiting impatiently for it to open.  It was definitely worth the wait.  The downstairs area is very cozy on a rainy night.  The number of Belgian beers is mind boggling, and it was very hard to choose which to order from all the great options.  For food, we shared a large cheese and pate plate that had an amazing duck sausage on it. We also had a huge pail of mussels and the harvest salad.  Our waiter was a bit overwhelmed with a very big group next to us, but he was still pretty attentive and friendly.  All in all, we're looking forward to going back, and we're so glad to have this new edition in the neighborhood.
author: Jen Y.

description: Four stars for the 180 beers available. Although the bartender admitted one beer of the 180 was not available that night. Very delicious beer. Downstairs bar area is fun. Little waterfall, euro bartenders, and wood beams. I felt transported somewhere in Burge. I learned the lie of the french fries. Apparently french fries came from Belgium. So of course we had Belgium fries and the dipping sauces we're delicious. So much to like in this neighborhood place. However, my fiance's brother's wife is Belgium. She ordered the white asparagus and a traditional Belgium dish. She said it was good and then said just okay. She wanted to love it.  We still love the place for the beer and the Belgium fries but not for the Belgium food.
author: Seymour S.

description: Gets five stars for serving strictly Belgian beers, correctly too. The food is pretty good as well (though the portions could be a bit bigger). The best Belgian Waffle I've had outside of Brussels (and possibly the only authentic one I've had in North America). Overall a faithful representation of the sultry food and beer of Belgium, with an excellent location across from Washington Square Park. Guys, if you take a date here, I'll predict you go to bed with dessert.
author: Jeremy J.

description: went there on friday night.  the service was bad. they were understaffed or under experienced.  or both. but they were nice. the food mediocre. but inexpensive. packed. great vibe. and great belgian beer. cute downstairs area.  so 3.5 stars for this place. i would go back for beer and a snack.   we were there late so when it cleared out, they cleared out their trash. we were still eating downstairs. the whole place stank and we had to leave. id strongly suggest not doing that until all the patrons have cleared the house.
author: Yelper S.
